title_en: Introduction to the PLA Institute of International Relations
Cultural studies of the BRICS countries
abstract_en: ＜(For the editor) In recent years, one of the most important features of the development of international relations has been the rise of emerging powers as a group and the continued increase in the weight of Asia in today's international relations. This is a new situation that has emerged for the first time since the formation of the modern system of international relations in 1648, and it is also the general trend of the current era. In line with the trend of history, China and Russia have shouldered the mission of the times and the mission of development, and have constructed an all-round new type of great-power relations characterised by multi-level and wide-ranging features on the basis of equality and mutual trust, with practical cooperation as the content, and with the goal of realising the "Chinese dream" and the "Russian dream", which is a new type of great-power relations in the present day.

title_en: Historical evolution of the international community and its impact on the formation of the strategic basis of culture and education in the BRICS countries - the regional system of international relations
abstract_en: The main structural parameters of modern international system were formed on the eve of the 20th Century. After World War II the decolonializing and modernizing Asia chose between two versions of European model of modernization and development. Each of them went through turbulent transformation at the second part of 20th Century and the mainstream model of development within the old technological stage was exhausted. Successful Non-Western countries based their way of development on the Western model of market economy but with national characteristics and put forward their own models of modernization managing to economically"catch up"leaders. Some even challenged the Western mode of post-industrial development. Thus the modern global model of high competition in modernization and development was created. This model requires education and training a new generation of professionals through"responsible internationalization"of future political elite. The creation of BRICS bloc is a new stage of the implementation of this cultural-educational strategy.

title_en: Likhachev's Legacy and the Study of International Relations in Russian Literature
abstract_en: In the 20 th century Dmitry Likhachev proved the only person capable of studying Russian literature, Russian folklore and Russian culture, including art and architecture,throughout its development and in the broad international context. Likhachev, among other things, managed to create a school of comparative literary studies researching the old Russian literature in the global context.

title_en: Briefing on the Working Meeting of the Centre for Comparative Humanities Studies at Beijing Normal University (BNU)
abstract_en: ＜On 30th December 2011, the first working meeting of the Centre for Comparative Research in Chinese and Russian Humanities of Beijing Normal University was held. Professor Xia Zhongxian, editor-in-chief of Russian Literature and Art, Professor Zhang Bing from the College of Foreign Languages and Literature, Professor Zhang Baichun from the College of Philosophy and Sociology, Professor Zhang Jianhua from the College of History, Professor Li Zhengrong from the College of Letters and Arts, and Professor Li Xing from the College of Political Science and International Relations of Beijing Normal University were present at the meeting. The meeting centred on how to break down the barriers between literature, history and philosophy, and how to better carry out cross-field and interdisciplinary academic research.

title_en: "Background, potential challenges and future trends in the concept of the Silk Road Economic Belt
abstract_en: During his visit to Kazakhstan in September 2013, Chinese President Xi Jinping put forward the strategic concept of the Silk Road Economic Belt. The idea breaks with the traditional model of regional economic cooperation and advocates the construction of an open and inclusive system that is open to the active participation of all parties. Reactivating this ancient trade route is of great strategic significance to the economic construction of the countries along the route, the prosperity of the region and the balance of the world economy. Once the idea was put forward, it immediately aroused great concern among the countries concerned. What is the background of the Silk Road Economic Belt? Can this ancient road of civilisation once again carry the historical responsibility of promoting regional economic prosperity and fostering the fusion of Eastern and Western civilisations?" What are the distinctive features of the "Silk Road Economic Belt" as compared to the "New Silk Road Initiative" of the United States? How can political coordination between the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO) and the soon-to-be-established Eurasian Economic Union (EAEU) be achieved, taking into account the factors of Russia, the United States, Japan, Europe and other major powers with influence in the region?" The Silk Road Economic Belt will cross multiple borders, and cross-border logistics will need to take into account the negative impact of institutional, bureaucratic and corruption factors. In order to clarify these issues, the editorial board of the journal has invited experts and scholars from home and abroad to participate in the discussion, so as to sort out the concept of "Silk Road Economic Belt" from the dimensions of historical inheritance and international co-operation, to further understand its connotations in vertical and horizontal comparisons, to assess the potential challenges it may face in its development, and to judge its future trends and prospects.

title_en: Another visit to Moscow
Academic Seminar on "Contemporary International Relations Theory and Chinese Diplomacy" Held at the University of Shanghai
abstract_en: ＜In order to promote the development of China's contemporary international relations theory and discuss the direction of China's diplomacy in the period of strategic opportunities, a seminar on "Contemporary International Relations Theory and China's Diplomacy" was held on December 5-6, 2012 at East China Normal University (ECNU), co-hosted by the Centre for Oriental Studies of Shanghai Century Publishing Group, the Centre for Asia-European Studies of East China Normal University (ECTU), and the Centre for Russian Studies (CRS). The seminar on "Contemporary International Relations Theory and Chinese Diplomacy" was held on 5-6 December at East China Normal University. More than 70 experts and scholars from universities and research institutes in Beijing and Shanghai, as well as a number of well-known domestic media, discussed "New Progress in the Study of Contemporary International Relations Theory", "International Relations Theory in the Perspective of Multidisciplinary Studies", "International Relations Theory and the Current International Situation", "International Relations Theory and Chinese Diplomacy", and "Theory of International Relations in the Perspective of Multidisciplinary Studies". International Relations Theory and Current International Situation" and "Theoretical Reflections on Chinese Diplomacy".

title_en: Contemporary Research Trends in the Psychology of International Relations in the USSR
abstract_en: ＜The need for a psychological approach to the study of international relations was raised in Soviet academia as early as the mid-1960's. After the 1980's, research in this field made significant progress in the following three areas: first, the establishment of a system of conceptual categories for the psychological study of the theory of international relations; and second, the creation of a system of conceptual categories for the psychological study of the theory of international relations, which Soviet scholars considered to be the result of the development of the scientific and technological revolution, which has led to the emergence of an endless number of new weapons.

title_en: Analysing the significance of trade and economic relations in the structure of trilateral relations between Russia, Europe and the United States
abstract_en: The dimension of trade and economic relations is becoming increasingly important in the structure of international relations. On the basis of the assumption that the state's foreign strategy has the triple goal of security-benefit-power, the paper first analyses the mechanism of influence of economic and trade relations on interstate relations, explains the method of measuring the influence of economic and trade ties in the relations between Russia and Europe, and then discusses the influence of economic and trade relations on the structure of the Russian-European-American tripartite relations. Then we discuss the influence of trade and economic relations on the structure of the Russian-European triangular relations. It is concluded that trade and economic relations are becoming increasingly important in the interaction of international relations in the era of globalisation.

title_en: Shaping a New Type of State Relations: The World Significance of the Development of Sino-Russian Relations
abstract_en: In the post-cold-war period, structural changes have taken place in international relations, mainly in the form of the trend towards multi-polarity in the international landscape, the wave of globalisation in international relations, and the demand for democratisation in international relations. "The development of Russian-Chinese relations has been a major factor in the development of international relations. The development of Russian-Chinese relations is to a large extent a product of such structural changes in international relations. At the same time, the Treaty on Good-Neighbourliness, Friendship and Cooperation between China and the Russian Federation and the Russian-Chinese partnership of strategic cooperation which it defines, as a programme document guiding the stable and healthy development of Russian-Chinese relations in the new century, go far beyond the significance of bilateral relations and will have far-reaching consequences for the entire structure of international politics and international relations.

title_en: Preventing confrontation and promoting a positive agenda for international relations
abstract_en: ＜The discussion of the urgent issue of the transformation of the system of global relations is of profound significance. This vast topic, old but new, embodies the organic unity of ancient civilisations and realities, of which the process of globalisation is one element. History will certainly provide a revised balance of globalisation.

abstract_en: ＜I would like to mention here what I see as the new era. In addition to the information revolution and the process of economic globalisation, the political awakening and increased political participation of billions of people brought about by the information revolution, the decline in the manipulability of the sphere of international security, the old fissures between Islam and Christendom, and the long-standing North-South contradictions between rich and poor countries.

title_en: Truths and falsehoods about the new world order
abstract_en: ＜The question of the establishment of a new world order has become a topical and important issue for two reasons: a global one, because it encompasses the state of international relations and the trends in their development, and a national one, because the state of international relations and the trends in their development are to a large extent reflected in the methods of solving the Yugoslav crisis. First of all, with regard to the global aspect of the establishment of a new world order, there are those who believe that it is purely political propaganda and has no basis in the political, legal, economic and other structures of international relations. Others believe that we are witnesses to the formation of the foundations and contours of a new world order which should

title_en: Subjectivity Matters - Rethinking Russia's Relations with the West
abstract_en: In the post-Soviet period,the characteristic pattern of Russian foreign policy is the reemergence of situational inconsistencies,namely disproportionate changes and shifts of positions and behavior substantially contrary to engagement.Such illogical foreign policy behavior is typically embodied in Russia’s reactions in the Russian-Georgian war in 2008,NATO enlargement and US plan to install missile defense system on the European continent.The author thinks that traditional rational,actor-centered IR theories,which assume that an actor’s policy preference does not easily change,lack explanatory force for the puzzling Russian foreign policy behavior.He believes that foreign policy is affected by actors’ subjective interpretation of the world and their emotions.Russia’s feeling of disrespect breeds tensions and conflict and its "anger" expresses an emotional judgment resulting from the feeling that Russia is not respected by the West,which aims to reveal Russia’s importance rather than to serve as a destructive role.Analysis of the subjectivity in Russian foreign policy helps to provide a new theoretical and analytical perspective to better understand the relationship between Russia and the West.

title_en: Methodological and Paradigmatic Innovations in Regional Country Studies in the New Development Landscape
abstract_en: In May 2021, under the guidance of the Shanghai Association of International Relations, the editorial office of the Journal of Russian Studies, together with others including the Global Review, the International Review, the Journal of International Relations and the Deutschland-Studien held an academic seminar entitled "Methodology and Paradigm Innovation for Regional and Country-specific Studies under the New Development Pattern". We select manuscripts of some experts to form this proceeding（arranged according to the content of speeches from general theories to country-specific research cases）. Currently country-specific and regional studies is of great significance as things in China have always been closely related to how to rationally grasp the relationship with the outside world. Contemporary China is transitioning from "China of China" and "China of Asia", described by Liang Qichao, to "China of the world". Now it might be the first time in history that Chinese political and intellectual elites are trying to develop a truly global vision（even including the North and South Pole, the outer space）. In this process, "China of the world" urgently needs to establish a knowledge production and dissemination system which can cover all geographic spaces of the world. Meanwhile, there is also an increasingly urgent need to "tell the world story well" according to China’s realities based on "telling China’s story well". The further a rising China is participating in world affairs, the greater the needs for understanding of various regions of the world will be. As an important part of China’s "national knowledge system", country-specific and regional studies is duty-bound to provide related knowledge reserves.

title_en: From X to Z: The Rise and Decline of Soviet Studies in the West
abstract_en: Sovietology was a huge enterprise in the West.This study tries to identify places where Western/American Sovietology,international relations（IR） theories and policies toward the Soviet Union intersected and interacted.This paves the way for further inquiry into the West’s study of Russia and Eurasia in the post-Cold War period.For this purpose,two articles—one by Mr.X in1947 and the other by Mr.Z in 1990—are chosen because they represented the beginning and end of Western Sovietology.They are also intersecting and interactive points between academia,policy-making,area（Soviet） studies and IR theories in the West.This research finds that Western academic studies and actual Western policies toward the former Soviet Union were not necessarily symmetrical;they may even diverge to opposite directions.In those 43 years between X and Z,U.S.policies toward the Soviet Union were consistently driven by a strong dose of ideology,while those realists such as George Kennan were increasingly marginalized.Meanwhile,U.S.intelligence failures regarding the Soviet Union were also common.In contrast,main-stream Sovietology became more "academic" with an tendency to perceive the Soviet Union as a "normal" state,which was considered by Mr.Z（Martin Malia） as "pro-Soviet." Z’s 1990 critique of the Western Sovietology,though not necessarily fair,happened to be an almost perfect prediction of the Soviet demise.

title_en: "Post-Soviet Space and the Silk Road Economic Belt: An Analytical Framework
abstract_en: Many countries included in China’s "Silk Road Economic Belt" Initiative belong to "the Post-Soviet Space". In the meantime, "the Post-Soviet space", influenced by the power and ever-changing strategic intents of Russia, in addition to external powers, has become increasingly characterized by apparent elastic features. When "the Post-Soviet Space" is squeezed or expands outward, it often encounters corresponding reactions. Therefore, the basic features of this strategic region include geopolitical instability, changing internal structures, and particular vulnerability to international relations and regional situation. The outbreak and continuation of the Ukraine crisis is obvious evidence. Currently, major external factors related with "the Post-Soviet Space"mainly include opportunities and challenges of China’s opening up to the West, involvement of external powers and their co-optition with regional powers, as well as the coordination between the "Silk Road Economic Belt" and the Eurasian economic Union. By means of a theoretical perspective based on such disciplines as international relations, international political economies and new economic geography, through empirical studies on major issues, this paper aims to set a reasonable analysis framework. This can deepen the understanding of the status quo and prospects of "the Post-Soviet Space", which will be conducive to the cooperation and construction of the "Silk Road Economic Belt".

title_en: Historical survey of "peaceful coexistence"
abstract_en: ＜The idea of peaceful coexistence was first put forward by Lenin after the victory of the October Revolution. Over the decades, the idea of peaceful coexistence has been continuously supplemented, improved and developed into five principles for handling all international relations. At present, the five principles of peaceful coexistence have become the universally acknowledged basic norms of international relations, the standards by which the international community judges right and wrong, and have played an inestimable role in maintaining world peace and stability and in the prosperity of the world economy. After the victory of the October Revolution, Lenin put forward the idea of peaceful coexistence in order to deal with the relationship between socialist and capitalist countries. The victory of the October Revolution and the birth of the socialist USSR.

title_en: International relations in Eastern Europe in transition
abstract_en: ＜After the war, Europe was divided into two and a political structure of "Eastern Europe-Western Europe" was established. With the end of the Cold War, this structure has been broken. Various international forces are regrouping, and the European continent presents an intricate and complex picture of networking. European countries are fundamentally adjusting their relations with each other in their own interests. Here, the primary factor determining the closeness of national relations is no longer the affiliation of the group, but their national security interests and national interests. I. Integration Processes in Eastern and Western Europe After escaping from Soviet control and breaking away from the framework of the Warsaw Pact and the Mutual Economic and Social Co-operation Conference, the countries of Eastern Europe have become free from any alliance structure and have become self-sustaining.

title_en: Russia and Sino-Russian relations after the 2024 presidential election
abstract_en: The year 2024 marks the 75th anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relations between China and Russia. After Vladimir Putin was re-elected as the President of Russia in March 2024, Chinese President Xi Jinping called to congratulate him. Russia will continue Putin’s governance philosophy and practice to address global and regional challenges within the context of the once-in-a-century changes. Domestically, Russia has shown certain resilience in social and economic aspects and will face long-term severe international situations due to the ongoing Russia-Ukraine conflict, centrifugal tendencies in post-Soviet states, and difficulties in diplomatic breakthroughs. Against this backdrop, Russia has hosted multiple events with conceptual designs and platform-building significance and will host the first summit of the BRICS countries after its formal expansion. As an important part of the Russian foreign policy system, China-Russia relations, amid a tense international context, have shown strong internal dynamics and independent value, with bilateral trade continuing to grow and civil exchanges expanding. In the new circumstances, China and Russia still face challenges institutionally and structurally, and challenges brought by the spread of globalization and of building new international relations, in addition to cultural and civilizational challenges. This requires China and Russia to continue optimizing their foreign policy coordination strategies; to address multipolar challenges and promote integration based on pragmatic cooperation; to align the “Belt and Road” Initiative with the “Greater Eurasian Partnership”; to understand civilizational uniqueness based on recognizing national developmental specaility and the diversity of modernization paths while promoting the concept of a community with a shared future for mankind to drive social progress and actively respond to cultural and civilizational challenges; to enhance the roles of multilateral platforms such as the SCO and the CSTO to address regional issues like terrorism, and to maintain regional security and stability, including domestic security and overseas interests; and to explore new models of international cooperation in specific actions addressing regional and global crises.

title_en: Building a Multipolar World: Russian Foreign Policy Adjustment and the New Development of Sino-Russian Relations
abstract_en: Since the end of the Cold War, the outbreak of global systemic crises and changes in the world order have always been the focus of world’s attention. The world order since the 1990s to the present is still a unipolar structure dominated by the United States, while existing international organizations and institutions are unable to prevent and resolve crises or conflicts. The NATO’s eastward expansion eventually led to Russia’s special military action against Ukraine. The United States and other Western countries have imposed unprecedented sanctions on Russia, which further promoted Russia’s “pivot to the East” in its foreign policy. Against the backdrop of accelerated evolution of great changes unseen in a century, the relative weakening of Western countries has made themselves unable to do what they want in the unipolar structure dominated by the United States. The rise of Global South has accelerated, and international structures of power have become more balanced. The outbreak and lasting of Russia-Ukraine conflict is leading the world move faster towards multipolarity, and the multipolar world is gradually returning. Facing such complex and severe challenges, appropriate national policy responses should be made. The two sides, based on principles of non-alliance, non-confrontation, and non-targeting of any third party, have found a path of major-country relations featuring strategic trust, good neighborliness and cooperation, setting a new model for international relations between major countries of different histories, cultures, political and economic systems. Both countries have become important forces for maintaining world peace, security, development and prosperity. In this regard, China and Russia need to first further deepen their mutual trust and understanding, consolidate political foundation and friendship through people-to-people and cultural exchanges. Secondly, both sides need to promote bilateral practical cooperation in various fields, and strive to achieve their respective development and revitalization goals. Besides, they also need to promote democratization of international relations and commit to promoting multipolarization of the world on the basis of principles of non-alliance, non-confrontation, and non-targeting of any third party.

title_en: Domestic politics and foreign relations - a study based on Russian-American relations
abstract_en: The Cold War, which began as an ideological dispute, is over, but the debate over the dynamics of the dramatic changes in Russian (Soviet) foreign policy is far from over. An important aspect of the study of foreign policy or diplomatic history is the relationship between internal and external affairs, since a country's diplomacy is an extension of its internal politics. However, this theoretical logic has been repeatedly ignored and forgotten by scholars. The study of Russian-American relations as a base can be approached precisely from this "back-to-the-future" perspective.

title_en: Determinants of the formation of Russian foreign policy
abstract_en: ＜For the first time, the early Russian foreign policy was forced to adapt, in form and content, to the changes that were taking place and to the changing realities. Inevitably, Russian foreign policy reflected internal struggles and factional and personal struggles at the top over which path to take in Russia's socio-economic development. The struggle for the future of foreign policy often became the means of these struggles. Thus foreign policy became a combination of the tendencies of various factors, which were evaluated differently. The effect of mutation passed and was replaced by the understanding of new realities and tendencies and the reaction to them.

title_en: Concept of training mode of regional and national talents in China in the context of the first-level disciplines - based on the experience of the construction of the programme "Extraterritorial Regionalism" in Russian universities
abstract_en: Since the 1960s,China has started to build institutes in international and area studies,accumulating rich experience and cultivating a large number of researchers.However,due to lack of support from the first-tier discipline,the talent training in international and area studies is deficient in terms of systematization,planning,coherence and professionalism,which,to a certain extent,directly affects the depth and breadth of studies in this field.It was in the 1990s that Russian universities and colleges began to develop area studies.This direction is featured with rich curriculum,diverse types of schools,and obvious regional characteristics.Besides,the talent training mode and curriculum construction methods could also provide references.Based on the curriculum construction of area studies in Russian universities and colleges,this article attempts to explore the construction methods and implementation ways of China’s talent training mode in international and area studies as a first-tier discipline,and puts forward the concept of “double track system” talent training mode.While building the talent training mode of “integration of bachelor’s,master’s and doctoral degrees” in majors in area studies,according to characteristics of teachers,students’ professional foundation and knowledge structure of different universities and colleges,the talent training mode of “integration and coordination” with other majors will be built so that problems,which restrict our talent training and academic development,such as weak professional foundation,unsound teaching staff,and lack of systematic training at this stage,will be solved.

title_en: The Asian Moment of Great Power Game and Two-Tier Parity - Russian Think Tanks' Perceptions and Policy Positions on the US-China Economic and Trade Friction
abstract_en: Russian think tanks have a unique understanding and expectation of Sino-U.S. economic and trade frictions, and they are complementary to official stances of the Kremlin. Behind economic and trade frictions is the competition between these two countries for military, political, scientific and technological, regional and global leadership. As a result, the domestic agenda and foreign policies of these two countries will be profoundly affected and spillover effects will emerge: forming a bipolar structure in the Asian region. Even if these two countries will reach a compromise on economic and trade issues due to domestic and international political factors, China will not give up its ambitions to gain world science and technology leadership, nor will the United States abandon its strategic intention to curb China’s momentum for development. Russia should continue to maintain economic and military cooperation with China, avoiding the deterioration of relations with the United States and the West, promoting the "Greater Eurasian Partnership" initiative in the Asia-Pacific region. Based on the deduction of their own interests, Russian policy analysts define Sino-U.S. economic and trade frictions as a game of great powers. The corresponding policy recommendations reflect Russia’s double-level balancing strategy aiming at balancing both the United States and China globally and regionally. Russia will play the role of a strategic balancer with the participation of other Asian countries, taking advantage of the overall confrontation between China and the United States, and reversing its adverse external development environment. Russia’s invigorating role in the Asia-Pacific region will lead to the establishment of a new model of bilateral and trilateral competition and cooperation.

title_en: The influence of ideology on the external goals of the Russian state
abstract_en: According to its influences on a country’s foreign policies,ideology can be divided into two types: conservative and revolutionary. There exist endogenous confrontation and conflicts between revolutionary ideology and existing international order. As the guiding ideology of a country’s foreign policy,the revolutionary one has its inherent revisionist motives. The former is satisfied with the status quo, recognizing existing international distribution of power,complying with existing international law; while the latter is dissatisfied with the state quo, hoping to subvert and revise the existing power structure, criticizing current international law according to legal principles and is signed with the external expansion of imperialism. Traditionally, Russia’s ideology belongs to the former type, aiming at maintaining legitimacy and imperial tradition of absolute monarchy, turning against liberalism and nationalism. In the late 19 th century and early 20 th century, Pan-Slavism and international communism became dominant with distinct revolutionary features. Influenced by revolutionary ideology, the goal of Russia’s foreign policy was characterized by more revisionism, holding negative and hostile attitudes toward the traditional international system. Moreover, it underwent a series of confrontation and conflicts with then international system as well. However, compared with major powers, Russia did not have obvious advantages or disadvantages. As a result,out of the urgent need for national security, Russia needed to maintain the balance of power at that time in order to protect itself from being threatened and invaded by potential hegemons, especially those primary powers with invading intentions and obvious superiority in strength. In the last resort, in accordance with then prevailing international balance structure, Russia adjusted timely its foreign policies characterized by revolutionary ideology, making a certain degree of compromise in its revisionism goal. When its national security is not so threatened, Russian revolutionary ideology is more offensive, otherwise its offensiveness is weakened.

title_en: The Disciplinary Positioning and Development Space of Regional Country Studies--Interview with Prof Zhao Kejin
abstract_en: Area studies is a first-tier discipline established under the interdisciplinary category,which is the sum of a country’s academic knowledge system about the outside world.In fact,area studies has a long history in China.Nevertheless,under the existing disciplinary system,it is scattered in many disciplines such as political science,economics,sociology,anthropology,world history,and foreign languages and literature.As China is getting closer to the center of the world stage,both knowledge and practice require that area studies should be a separate first-tier discipline to undertake functions of knowledge construction,cultural interpretation,political advice and social service for China’s relationship with the outside world.From the perspective of disciplinary connotation,area studies should integrate multi-disciplinary resources,committed to independently constructing an extraterritorial knowledge system.As a country with a long history in civilization,China’s area studies should have its own characteristics.To build area studies as a first-tier discipline,we need to learn from the existing paradigms of civilizationalism,nationalism,globalism and integrate multi-disciplinary methods of humanities and social sciences.Besides,we should strive to build disciplinary,academic,discourse,and teaching material systems in area studies.Based on its own advantageous disciplines,each university should creatively put forward programs for the construction of area studies with its characteristics,creating area studies with Chinese characteristics,Chinese styles and Chinese features.

title_en: Analysis of trends in the international landscape and changes in the world order in the context of the epidemic
abstract_en: The Covid-19 Pandemic is vehemently shocking the global affairs and international relations, speeding the already-accumulated qualitative changes, and catalyzing the birth of new international configuration of powers and world order. However, under the basic peaceful conditions, the configuration of international powers and world order have to go through many rounds of tests to realize their fundamental changes. China, Russia, the United States, European Union and other major international forces are exploring and preparing the relevant areas of guiding principles, main agendas, norms and institutions. The majority of the international community are strengthening multilateralism through cooperative combating against the pandemic. But the Trump administration is posing the most serious challenge to the multi-polarization and a more justified and rational world order by advocating America First and unilateralism. Therefore, analyzing and studying the changes in international configuration of powers and world order under the pandemic will help raise the consciousness of practices and theories so as to promote the building of a new type of international relations and community of shared future for mankind.

title_en: China-Russia-US Trilateral Relations: Structure, Perception and Politics
abstract_en: From 26 to 28 September 2008, an international seminar on "China-Russia-US Trilateral Relations: Concepts, Structures and Politics", jointly organised by the Centre for Russian Studies of the East China Normal University and the Shanghai Institute for International Studies, was held at the East China Normal University, with the participation of nearly 40 experts and scholars on international issues from the United States, Russia, the United Kingdom, China and the United States of America. Focusing on the current state of trilateral relations between China, Russia and the United States, the mechanism of interaction, functional characteristics, the similarities and differences between pre-cold-war and post-cold-war trilateral relations, and future prospects, the seminar set up three topics for discussion: "Transformation of the Contemporary International System and Trilateral Relations between China, Russia and the United States", "Geopolitical Transformation of Eurasia and Trilateral Relations between China, Russia and the United States", and "Interaction between Domestic Politics and Economy and Trilateral Relations between China, Russia and the United States". We hereby select some of the best speeches for the benefit of our readers.

title_en: Characteristics and development trends of strategic interaction between China, Russia, the United States and Europe
abstract_en: The interaction among China, Russia, the United States and Europe is an important part of the once-in-a-century changes. China’s strategic thinking and holism could help make up for existing researches on the four-party relationship. Since the end of the Cold War, China-Russia-U.S.-Europe strategic relations have been generally stable, but they have also undergone dynamic adjustments due to changes both internally and externally. After Biden came into power, the four-party relationship is encountering new and important changes. The strategic interaction among these four parties is at a crossroads of history. The interaction of these four parties on development and setting agendas, maintaining international peace and security, in addition to seeking ideology of the times is of great and profound strategic significance. Neither China, Russia, the United States nor Europe alone could dominate current and future international relations and world affairs, but it is possible to achieve greater development and gain a more active position through their interaction. The international community should not only avoid the "new cold war" reactively, but also create actively a new environment for international cooperation and construct new types of international relations.

title_en: Soviet and East European Studies: a guide to Western research institutions (continued)
abstract_en: ＜Association of Greek Slavic Studies, Greece. Institute of Political and Economic Studies, Gokhaley, India: Director, Niraganta Rath. founded 1930. Affiliated with the University of Pune, India. Staff consists of 33 full-time researchers, 12 full-time support staff, 28 research members and 76 others. Responsible for research and training missions. Conducts research programmes on various economic and political issues in India. Main areas of research include: agrarian economics, industrial studies, population, education, economic policy and planning, financial economics and finance, foreign trade, economic history and the economic and political situation of India.

title_en: A Brief Analysis of Russia's Foreign Language Strategy
abstract_en: From the perspective of a major country’s growth experience, a major country has always valuing constructing foreign language strategies with its own characteristics to achieve its national strategic goals. So far, Russia has already built a complete set of foreign language strategy system. The evolution of Russian foreign language strategy could be divided into four periods: extensive development period, initial formation period, basic formation period and modernization period. Its accumulated experience has great implications for China to plan our foreign language strategy with Chinese characteristics at the strategic level and to improve our foreign language capabilities.

title_en: One Hundred Years after the October Revolution - The Dissolution and Reconstruction of World Order and Western Identity
abstract_en: A century after the Bolshevik Revolution, the West-dominated colonial system has long collapsed. Their materialistic and technological advantages over non-western world become unsustainable. It is just the time that we look back into the Bolshevik Revolution and have a much clearer perception of its historical significance. According to arguments of Lenin and Bolshevism on national self-determination and imperialism, the world war was directly related with the West-dominated imperialism and colonial system. At the turn of the 20<sup>th</sup> century, when colonialism reached its peak, it challenged the West-dominated international order and ideology in all directions, pushing forward changes in international system. When constructing Western ideas, racism constitutes an important core of its ideology. As a matter of fact, those who advocate pluralism in Western countries do not want to see a truly pluralistic world. The West actually observes the world from a self-centered perspective and is unwilling to accept the rise of non-Christian and non-white nations. How to maintain the coexistence of civilizations will be a major challenge for the international system in the new era.

title_en: The struggle for recognition and the changing political landscape of the world
abstract_en: The struggle for recognition is not only related to the ontological security of individuals and countries,the conditions for survival and development,but also a basic demand from human nature,hoping to obtain freedom and equality.Therefore,the struggle for recognition constitutes a fundamental driving force to promote changes in world politics.The struggle for recognition will lead to a more decentralized social system and international order,as well as the rise of liberalism,nationalism and identity politics.As for power structure in world politics,the recognition struggle leads to changes in national and international systems,and the struggle for great power status,which eventually leads to changes in the structure of power distribution.As to ideational structure in world politics,the recognition struggle has led to the rise of liberalism that emphasizes individual freedom and rights.However,nationalism and identity politics are challenging the status of liberalism as a universal political identity,resulting in the increasingly serious phenomenon of “polarization” in world politics.

title_en: The Russian Orthodox Church and Soviet Public Diplomacy (1943-1953)
abstract_en: Scholars have different cognition of public diplomacy and its functions. From 1943 till 1953, the Russian Orthodox Church （ROC）, with the support of Soviet government, carried on a series of foreign exchanges activities, which actually were public diplomacy. The historical experience of the Soviet Union shows that making use of religions to launch public diplomacy can offer a source of legitimacy for sponsors; it is not necessarily confrontational relationship between transnational religions and secular states, and transnational religions can cooperate closely with secular states; Religions can adapt to socialist society, religions and religious figures can play an active role during foreign exchanges.

title_en: Russia's Strategic Options in East Asia after the Cold War
abstract_en: ＜Looking back at history, it is easy to see how different the pattern of international relations between Russia and East Asia was at the end of the nineteenth century and the end of the twentieth century. At the end of the nineteenth century, Russia was internally sick and in crisis, but it was an ambitious country that looked outward; a hundred years later, Russia is still sick and weak, but it is struggling for an unknowable democracy. The situation in East Asia has also changed; it is no longer an external stage in the Eurocentric international landscape, and relations between East Asian countries and European countries, as well as between East Asian countries, have changed dramatically. China is no longer an object of aggression by Japan and the European powers.

title_en: Soviet and East European Studies: A Guide for Western Research Institutions
abstract_en: ＜This booklet is a reference work. It provides information on a number of research institutions in Western countries devoted to the study of international problems, particularly in the Soviet Union and Eastern European countries. We hope that this booklet will be useful to specialists and other interested persons in this field of study. International relations, as a distinctive discipline, is still fairly new. In the West, the study of the Soviet Union and the countries of Eastern Europe is not as well known as the study of the Soviet Union and the countries of Eastern Europe.

title_en: Prospects for the development of Russian-Chinese relations - the Treaty on Good-Neighbourliness, Friendship and Cooperation between China and Russia in 20 years' time
abstract_en: The Treaty of Good-Neighborliness and Friendly Cooperation between the People’s Republic of China and the Russian Federation, as unambiguous and powerful legal support and guarantee for bilateral relations,establishes the concept of friendship for generations and principles for a new type of international relations. Meanwhile, it safeguards and guarantees to the greatest extent the due mutual respect and equal treatment between sovereign states, which is a major innovation for the history of international relations. On the occasion of its 20 th anniversary, this article looks back into the treaty, observing its strong vitality and demonstration effect against the backdrop of current international configuration, especially on border issues, safeguarding national unity, sovereignty and territorial integrity, and launching bilateral mutually beneficial cooperation, in addition to promoting the establishment of a fair and reasonable new international order. Obviously, it has greatly promoted the development of Sino-Russian relationship and made it a model for new types of international relations. In the contemporary world where Sino-Russian relationship has reached its best in history, the comprehensive strategic partnership of coordination in the new era has further developed. Having surpassed the definition of so-called alliance, Sino-Russian relationship continues to develop legally, rationally and reasonably, which has a positive role in breaking Western discourse monopoly, maintaining the objective and fair international order, and safeguarding the world peace.

title_en: Soviet and East European Studies: A Guide to Western Research Institutions (continued from V)
abstract_en: ＜Cornell University Peace Studies Programme: Director George Quist. established 1970. Issues research and teaching activities at the Centre for International Studies, Cornell University. Funded in large part by the Ford Foundation. Research to postpone or avoid war. Political, economic, technological, and social preconditions for peace, arms control in the international order, and other related topics. Publication of thematic collection series (one or two issues per year). Weekly seminars on issues related to peace, military and foreign policy. Has a library. Council on Foreign Relations: Chairman Winston Lord. founded 1921. Independent, non-profit research, organisation.

title_en: Methodological Ruminations on Contemporary Russian Diplomatic Studies - An Examination Based on Subjects, Concepts, Structures and Cycles
abstract_en: This article observes contemporary Russian diplomacy from perspectives of subject, concept, structure and cycle. Through the discussion of subject and concept of diplomacy, this article analyzes in-depth the complex meaning of Russia’s diplomatic role, aiming to explore limitations of the Western narrative pattern, the concept of single-line time, and the simplification of dividing the world into two just according to the "democracy-autocracy" standard. As a result, we could observe the unique identity of Russia’s diplomacy. In terms of the structure, this article tries to explain the growth and development of Russia amid the world civilization and within the international system, including both internal and external characteristics of its civilization structure, in addition to its position and dynamic structural functions amid the multilateral relations among major countries. From the cyclical perspective, the article traces the recurring logic of Russia’s foreign relationship through the "short-mediumlong durée" analysis. In the context of global transformation and Russia’s interaction with other countries in particular, Russia’s diplomacy is explored. This article strives to provide a number of constructive references and groundwork for the construction and application of academic categories and theoretical tools in this field through reflections based on analyses of facts and theories.

title_en: Standing at the Crossroads of History - National Security, Global Development and Building a Community of Human Destiny
abstract_en: In October 2022, the 20th National Congress of the Communist Party of China was successfully held. General Secretary Xi Jinping delivered a report, entitled “Holding High the Great Banner of Socialism with Chinese Characteristics and Working Together to Build a Modern Socialist Country in an All-round Way”, to the conference. In this report, centering on the theme of “promoting world peace, development and making endeavors to build a community with a shared future for mankind”, a series of new theories, new expressions, and new initiatives were put forward, which enriched and developed Xi Jinping’s diplomatic thoughts. The current international situation is undergoing profound changes, and the development and security of the international community are facing serious imbalance risks. The report put forward new judgments of “three changes” and “four major deficits”, and profoundly analyzed the new situation of the development of the world today and new challenges when building a community with a shared future for mankind.Regarding the resolution of the “four major deficits”, peace is the premise,development is the key, security is the guarantee, and governance is the path.China is committed to promoting coordination and positive interaction among major countries, promoting the resolution of hotspot issues, and consolidating the value foundation of international security. China respects the independent choice of development paths and models by all countries, promoting exchanges and mutual learning among civilizations, and realizing the coexistence of civilizations. In addition, pushing forward “developmental peace”, China takes measures to solve the problems of global development and global security. China establishes and enhances the awareness of independent innovation, and actively respond to the threat of technological blockade. Looking seriously into the report and understanding in-depth the essence of Xi Jinping’s diplomatic thoughts will help us grasp the general trend in the complicated international situation, see the way ahead, and always take the initiative in handling foreign affairs.

title_en: The Historical Logic, Way of Getting Along, Endogenous Dynamics and World Significance of Sino-Russian Relations
abstract_en: On March 21, 2023, presidents of China and Russia signed the “Joint Statement of the People’s Republic of China and the Russian Federation on Deepening the Comprehensive Strategic Partnership of Coordination for the New Era”, which systematically elaborates key areas and common tasks in comprehensively deepening strategic cooperation at bilateral and multilateral,global and regional levels. Based on historical logic, real challenges and future development of Sino-Russian relations, this statement clarifies goals and directions for sustained and rapid development for Sino-Russian relations in leading the trend. The editorial board of Journal for Russian Studies specially organized these articles to discuss in-depth historical logic, ways of getting along,endogenous motivation and world significance of Sino-Russian relations. Thanks to the summarization of historical experience and lessons by heads of both countries, Sino-Russian relationship has entered a stage of comprehensive strategic partnership of coordination for the new era. Based on principles of “good neighborliness and friendship”, “equality and mutual benefit”, and “strategic coordination”, both countries have found ways such as “equality and mutual trust”,“non-alignment, non-confrontation, and no targeting of third parties”, “seeking common ground while shelving differences, and win-win cooperation” among major countries. It provides a demonstration of a new type of major-country relationship. The Sino-Russian relationship is a major-country relationship with endogenous motivation, guided by high-level exchanges. It ensures stability and long-term progress through political mutual trust, boosts cooperation and development through economic complementarity, and deepens social foundation of traditional friendship through cultural exchanges. Currently global major changes unseen in a century are accelerating, and the world has entered a new period of turmoil and changes. The impact of Sino-Russia relations goes beyond bilateral scope and is crucial to the world structure and future of mankind as well.China and Russia are global powers and neighbors. These two countries’ goodneighborliness and friendship, steady progress, and continuous deepening of strategic cooperation are in themselves conducive to the stability of international situation, to the multi-polarization of the world and democratization of international relations. Sino-Russian relations have global significance in terms of safeguarding international fairness and justice in politics, breaking shackles of the Cold War mentality in terms of security, building a new pattern of regional development economically, providing momentum for multilateralism in governance, and enriching the connotation of the new type of major country relationship theoretically.

title_en: Russian-Chinese military-technical cooperation: review and prospects
abstract_en: ＜Military-technical cooperation between China and Russia is one of the main pillars of the Sino-Russian strategic partnership. Close exchanges between the two sides have not only injected substantive content into the development of the strategic partnership, but also helped China to accelerate the process of military modernisation, and at the same time provided a rare opportunity for the large Russian military-industrial enterprises facing a period of transition to get out of a difficult situation, and created conditions for the revival of Russia's national power. The strengthening of military-technical co-operation between Russia and China is reflected in the exchange of equipment, the transfer and joint development of advanced weapons technology, the training of military personnel, the sharing of information, and the holding of joint military exercises. What factors have contributed to the military exchanges and cooperation between Russia and China, what are the prospects for military cooperation between Russia and China, and what are the geo-strategic backgrounds for cooperation between the two sides?

title_en: Summary of the International Seminar on "Great Power Relations after 9/11"
abstract_en: ＜The reason why the "9-11" incident is regarded as a major historical event in the field of international politics is that it led to a fundamental change in the entire pattern of international relations. In order to promote the study of this issue and to enhance the consensus of the international political theory community on this issue, a seminar was held on 5-6 April 2002 at the Centre for Asia-Europe Studies of the East China Normal University.

title_en: Russian Eastern Diplomacy in a Nutshell
abstract_en: ＜All political and economic signs point to the fact that the twenty-first century will be the "Asia-Pacific century". The system of international relations that has traditionally existed in the Far East is the "Big Three" and the "Small Two". The three big ones are Russia, China and Japan; the two small ones are Mongolia and Korea. The Russian voice is the youngest of the quintet, having been part of the group for only 400 years.

title_en: Guide to Western Research Institutions (continued from VI)
abstract_en: ＜Council on International and Area Studies, Princeton University, USA: Professor Robert Tucker, Chairman. 1961. A constituent unit of Princeton University. Funded by the University, the United States Government and the Ford Foundation. Staff rotates on an annual selection basis. Studies topics in East Asia, the Near East, Russia, Latin America, Africa, and modern Europe. Also coordinates the University's research activities in the social sciences and humanities; interdepartmental projects in African, East Asian, Latin American, Near Eastern, modern European, and Russian area studies; and the activities of various other research institutions within the University, including the Centre for International Studies, the Office of Population Studies, the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Relations, and the School of Architecture and Urban Planning. Publishes World Politics.

title_en: Sino-Russian military-technical cooperation: current situation, problems and countermeasures
abstract_en: This article first introduces the process,content and development dynamics of Chinese-Russian military technical cooperation.Then,it focuses on analyzing the attitudes of the U.S.A.,China and Russia towards Chinese-Russian military technical cooperation,especially different viewpoints within the official and academic circles both in the U.S.A.and Russia.Based on this,the author describes the problems and reasons regarding Sino-Russian military-technical cooperation,which include declining trading volume,differences in prices,technology transfer,intellectual property rights and etc.However,according to the author,the potential and prospects of Sino-Russian military technical cooperation remain favorable,and is of great significance for China’s national interests.Finally,the author puts forward possible countermeasures for deepening Sino-Russian military technical cooperation.

title_en: Shanghai Cooperation Organisation: Seizing New Opportunities, Meeting New Challenges
abstract_en: On 17 October 2008, China Development Bank (CDB) and East China Normal University (ECNU) signed the "Agreement on Cooperation and Co-construction of CDB-EECNU Institute of International Relations and Regional Development", and on 1 June 2009, the inauguration ceremony of the CDB-EECNU Institute of International Relations and Regional Development and CDB-EECNU Institute of Shanghai Cooperation Organisation was held at the Yifu Building. On 1 June 2009, the inauguration ceremony of the "China Development Bank-East China Normal University Institute of International Relations and Regional Development" and "China Development Bank-Shanghai Cooperation Organisation Research Institute" was held in the Yifu Building of East China Normal University. Chen Yuan, Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Institute and Chairman of China Development Bank, led a group of more than 20 people from various departments of China Development Bank, as well as members of the Board of Directors of the Institute, Zhang Deguang, the first Secretary-General of the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO), former Chinese Ambassador to Russia and Chairman of the China Foundation for International Studies (CFIS), Nurgaliev, Secretary General of the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO), Pan Shivei, Deputy Director General of Shanghai Municipal Party Committee Propaganda Department and Secretary of Shanghai Municipal Federation of Social Unions (SMFSS), Zuyev, Vice-Consul-General of the Consulate General of Russia in Shanghai, and Zuyev, Deputy Consul General of the Russian Consulate General. Zuyev, Consul General of the Russian Consulate General in Shanghai, leaders of the East China Normal University (ECNU) and heads of functional departments, as well as more than 40 experts and scholars from all over the country attended the inauguration ceremony and witnessed the milestones of the historic cooperation between an important financial institution of our country and a 985 key university. Mr Chen Yuan, Chairman of the Board of Directors, and Professor Zhang Jishun, Secretary of the Party Committee of East China Normal University (ECTU), inaugurated the "China Development Bank-East China Normal University Institute of International Relations and Regional Development", while Professor Yu Lizhong, President of ECTU, and Secretary General of ECTU, Mr Nurgaliev, inaugurated the "China Development Bank-ECTU Institute of Shanghai Cooperation Organisation". Ambassador Zhang Deguang was appointed as the Honorary President of the SCO Research Institute, and Ambassadors Pan Shiwei, Nurgaliyev and Yang Chengxu were appointed as the first advisors of the Institute. After the inauguration ceremony, the East China Normal University held a grand ceremony of honorary professorship for Ambassador Zhang Deguang. Afterwards, Ambassador Zhang Deguang delivered an excellent academic lecture. The establishment of these two institutes is another strategic initiative of China Development Bank following the co-operation with Peking University and Tsinghua University, and is a new attempt for China's economic circles and universities to join hands to promote China's higher education, aiming at building the institute into a research institute with the research on Russia's relations with the big powers as its core, and with distinctive features and high standards matching the country's development goals and the international academic frontiers in the field of international relations and regional development research. The aim is to build the institute into a research institution with a core of research on Russia and great power relations, distinctive features in the field of international relations and regional development that match the national development goals and international academic frontiers, strong research and consulting service capabilities, and a multidisciplinary research team with wide influence both at home and abroad. This issue hereby publishes the academic speeches of Ambassador Zhang Deguang and Secretary-General Nurgaliyev for the benefit of readers.

title_en: Analysis of the shifting dynamics of Russian-American relations and their regulatory mechanisms
abstract_en: ＜The confrontation between the Soviet Union and the United States was the main axis of international relations for nearly half a century, and the dissolution of the Soviet Union in 1991 led to a turnaround in relations between Russia and the United States, the main inheritor of the Soviet legacy. However, contrary to the global trend that the economic mechanism is becoming the basic mechanism of international relations, the Russian-American relations are still complicated by a number of institutional factors such as power, security and culture, which not only determines a number of shifts in the dynamics of the Russian-American relations in the last four years, but also makes the future prospects of the relations unpredictable. This article attempts to make a preliminary analysis of the three shifts in the Russian-American relations in recent years and the internal mechanisms leading to these shifts, in order to see the possible future direction of the relations.

title_en: Tito and Yugoslavia's Foreign Policy
abstract_en: ＜This year marks the fiftieth anniversary of Tito's becoming the leader of the Communist Party of Yugoslavia (CPJ). On the eve of the Second World War, a new epoch began in Yugoslavia's domestic life and development, a decisive event in the country's recent history. There is every reason to talk about the multifaceted and creative character that Tito possessed. In the struggle for a free, independent and non-aligned Yugoslavia; in the struggle for world peace and progress, against any form of oppression, hegemony, threats and use of force in international relations, Tito's character convincingly demonstrated his revolutionary stoicism and statesmanlike revolutionary vision. In his handling of foreign policy, Tito also made historic decisions of far-reaching significance. These decisions have given him and Yugoslavia, and the JNA, a high degree of prestige throughout the world. This prestige and influence was the result of a series of struggles in the country under Tito's leadership.

title_en: Two Worldviews and the Return of World Disorder - The Neo-Hobbesian Imagination and the Functional Dissonance of Russian Diplomacy
abstract_en: Moscow’s worldview, first of all, holds the world is mutually exclusive and often hostile, where the strong becomes stronger and the lagged is beaten. Secondly, perpetual belief in hard power. Thirdly, the international system is dominated by great powers. Russia’s expected world is a multi-polar one, where Russia is a center. Russia believes that the multi-polar world is promising, especially with the decline of the West and the rise of non-Western world since the financial crisis. However, the actual world is full of various challenges, different from Russia’s perceptual world. The current international environment is full of chaos and disorders. In such a world, compared with the U.S. and European powers, Russia is more vulnerable. Nevertheless, Russia is still outlining the picture of contemporary politics under its conceived multi-polar（polycentric） world structure.

title_en: A new interpretation of the trilateral relationship
Some scholars in Shanghai discussed the recent political and economic situation in Russia.
abstract_en: ＜On 12 November 1998, the Shanghai Society of East Europe and Central Asia, the Society of World Economics and the Society of International Relations jointly convened a symposium on the recent political and economic situation in Russia, at which some scholars in Shanghai who study international issues talked about their own opinions, which are summarised as follows.

title_en: Russia's "New World Order" Theory and Diplomatic Options
abstract_en: Russia's conception of the new world order is linked to its position in the current international system and its historic mission of rejuvenating the great Powers. Within Russia, there are four views on the world today and the new world order, of which the "multipolar world" theory and the "American unipolar world" theory have had the greatest impact on Russian diplomacy. Since independence, Russia's foreign policy choices in terms of how to integrate into the Western-dominated international system have been contested in three orientations, which in fact constitute three stages in the evolution of Russia's foreign policy. The pragmatism of Putin's diplomacy, i.e., "using the opponent's power for my own use", is associated with Putin's view of national interests and is also an inevitable product of the process of Russia's transformation from a modern state to a post-modern state, which determines its duality and contradictory nature. The expectations of the concept of a "multipolar world" are manifold, but the multipolar diplomacy of the Yeltsin period was more confrontational and counterbalancing in terms of subjective motives as well as objective reactions, and after Putin's coming to power he began to turn it towards rationality and pragmatism, with greater emphasis on coordination among the major Powers and multilateral cooperation.

title_en: East European Central Asian Studies Sourcebook
Formation and Reflection on the Theory of Soviet Foreign Policy in the Khrushchev Period
abstract_en: The development of the post-war situation in the Soviet Union at home and abroad required an adjustment of the rigid foreign policy of the past and a new understanding of the modern world. After Khrushchev came to power, he re-examined a series of theoretical and practical problems in the post-war international political and economic landscape, put forward a number of principled theoretical questions on the development of the modern international situation, and formed a whole set of theories on foreign policy, marking a significant change in the Soviet Union's thinking on foreign policy strategy.

title_en: Russia's Energy Diplomacy through the Lens of International Political Economy
abstract_en: This paper mainly applies the relevant theories of international political economy to Russia's energy diplomacy as the object of study, revealing the mechanism of political and economic interaction in the field of energy. The Russian government's "Basic Points of Russia's Energy Strategy until 2020" has made oil and gas energy an important means to achieve the country's strategic diplomatic goals. Analysed according to the relevant theories of international political economy, this paper argues that the Russian government tries to obtain and has obtained the "structural power" in the field of energy production and has made use of this power to promote its diplomatic strategy, but it is also constrained by many factors in the process of implementing its energy strategy and diplomacy. However, the Russian government's implementation of its energy strategy and diplomacy has been hampered by a number of factors.

abstract_en: ＜With the approval of the Ministry of Education and Shanghai Municipal Bureau of Press and Publication (Shanghai Xinshuibao [2007] No. 33), the periodical of Russian Studies has been changed from a quarterly to a bimonthly since 2007, with issues appearing on the 23rd of every second month.
