title_en: Where will the "two-headed eagle" fly? --Review of "The Age of Transition: A Study of Russia's Relations with the United States and Europe".
abstract_en: ＜Recently, a new book reflecting Russia's diplomacy in the era of transition, "The Era of Transition: A Study of Russia's Relations with the United States and Europe," has been published by the Beijing Normal University Press. Though there are many books on Russian-American relations and Russian diplomacy in China, there is no systematic study of Russia's relations with the West in general, and Russian diplomacy and international relations in the era of transition in particular, but there is a lot of research on Russian-American relations.

title_en: Developing Russian-Chinese relations
abstract_en: ＜Sino-Russian relations are the primary object of Russia's oriental policy and a major aspect of Russia's foreign strategy to regain its influence as a great power. In recent years, thanks to the efforts of both sides, relations between the two countries have developed considerably. In the four and a half years of the post-Soviet evolution of relations between the two countries, there have been several high points in the exchange of visits between the top leaders: the first high point came around the end of 1992. After the end of the Cold War, the international environment in which Russian-Chinese bilateral relations were based changed considerably, economic development became the main theme of international relations, and ideology dominated the development of international relations.

title_en: The Russian-Georgian conflict: an analysis in the geopolitical framework
abstract_en: The Russian-Georgian conflict, which broke out in August 2008, is a product of the geopolitical game between the parties concerned and reflects the reality of geopolitical conflict at three levels: between Russia and Georgia, between Russia and the United States of America, and in the Eurasian region. Accordingly, the conflict has produced realistic results reflecting the geopolitical conflict's power pattern and balance at the three levels. The Russian-Georgian conflict also has important implications for the future international situation at the geopolitical level, including an impact on the current United States-led international order, on the future development of NATO and on the international energy situation.

title_en: East European Central Asian Studies Sourcebook
Some Thoughts on Sino-Russian Relations
abstract_en: The current period is one of real equality and health in the history of Russian-Chinese relations, and the improvement of relations with Russia has a special strategic value for China. Russia needs a stable and reliable Russian-Chinese relationship for a long time to come and will attach great importance to its relations with China. The development of Sino-Russian relations in the next decade will have an impact on the construction of a new type of international relations system in the future, and on the vital interests of the two countries and peoples, which will require the Russian and Chinese sides to continue to attach great importance to them and to plan them carefully.

title_en: Rebuilding, Not Just Rebooting: Russian Interests in Relations with the United States
abstract_en: This paper analyzes the basic reasons of the rapid deterioration and the crisis of U.S.-Russian relations as follows: the United States ignored Russia’s important geo-strategic interests; Russia wishes the West to recognize Russia and its established security system; Russia and the United States holds quite different views on their respective roles in the world system. This article emphasizes that President Obama’s "restart" strategy involves almost no important strategic interests which are of great significance to Russia. The main interests of Russia and the United States are not in the bilateral relations, but in the relations with the third countries. This paper argues that Russia and the United States can’t implement their own interests without constructive cooperation. Therefore, Russia recommends that the U.S. should not "reset", but re-adjust the US-Russia relations and do a "big deal" with Russia on the basis of their fundamental interests and priorities.

title_en: Sino-Russian Relations in the Convergence of Traditional and Contemporary Changes
abstract_en: ＜The historic development of Sino-Russian relations and the richness of their achievements are the result of the longstanding commitment and painstaking efforts of the political elites and the general public of the two countries; at the same time, they are a contribution to mankind under contemporary conditions by the two great countries, with their ancient civilisational traditions. No country's diplomacy can be divorced from the overall trend of the contemporary evolution of international affairs, and there is hardly any set of bilateral relations that can be cut off from tradition, divorced from the traditions of one's own civilisation.

title_en: Five major achievements and five prospects for Sino-Russian relations
abstract_en: Over the past two decades, within a new framework of partnership, China-Russia relations have rapidly developed and have become one of the best examples of new-type bilateral cooperation in the contemporary world. The strategic cooperative partnership between China and Russia is built on five pillars: close personal contacts between leaders of the two countries, a shared vision for the future of humanity, the perfect neighboring relationship established by thoroughly resolving border issues, continuously enhanced bilateral economic cooperation, cultural affinity and historical memory. To further promote the development of China-Russia relations, governments and all sectors of society in both countries still need to continue their efforts, striving to achieve five forward-looking tasks. These five tasks include promoting the alignment of the “Belt and Road” Initiative with the Eurasian Economic Union, creating comprehensive logistics and transportation routes between Asia and Europe, advancing the construction of financial infrastructure, expanding the Shanghai Cooperation Organization and the BRICS mechanisms, and strengthening cultural exchanges to better understand each other.

title_en: Diplomatic Mechanism of Reticular Partnership: A New Path of Sino-Russian Cooperation
abstract_en: Sino-Russian cooperation would be one of the decisive powers of reform and development of the international system in a period of time in the future. Besides the original bilateral mechanism, China and Russia could also cooperate via network partnership diplomatic mechanism, which means these two countries conduct cooperation within several relevant multilateral mechanisms in order to deal with their relationship more effectively. It is logical as well as multilateral, coordinative, cooperative, flexible and strategic. To strengthen and deepen Sino-Russian cooperation does not mean that these two countries would form an alliance. And the network partnership diplomatic mechanism, which would alleviate competition and game plights between China and Russia, and promote the development of relevant international mechanisms, would put forward to provide the new path for Sino-Russian cooperation.

title_en: Russian Universities in the Wave of Market Economy
abstract_en: ＜Since its independence, Russia has attached great importance to the maintenance and development of education, which can be said to be a good tradition inherited from the former Soviet Union. Over the past few years, a series of special conferences on education have been held, leaders have made many speeches, and a number of documents have been drawn up, such as the Russian Federation Education Act, which clearly stipulates that "the sphere of education shall be a priority area of development"; the Draft State Programme for the Development of Education in the Russian Federation, which has been the subject of a nationwide discussion among all sectors of society; the National Policy on Higher Education; and the National Programme for the Development of Education in the Russian Federation, which has been adopted by the Russian Federation. State policy in the field of higher education

title_en: Sino-Russian Relations: Retrospect and Prospect
abstract_en: Review and studies on the history of Sino-Russian relations is conducive to building our confidence in Sino-Russian relationship. Since the collapse of the Soviet Union, such issues as ideology and social system have not affected the direction of Sino-Russian relations. Led by leaders of these two countries, Sino-Russian relationship has entered a new era. Both countries abandoned the Cold War mentality of non-alignment, embodying a new type of major country relationship based on mutual trust for security and mutual benefits for cooperation, which not only serves the interests of people of these two countries, but also has irreplaceable positive impacts on the establishment and development of a new world order and for new international relationships as well. On the occasion of the 70<sup>th</sup>anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relationship between China and Russia, we remain more optimistic about the development of Sino-Russian relationship and will unswervingly deepen this high-level strategic cooperative relationship.

title_en: Academic Evolution and Intellectual Renewal of Chinese Studies on International Issues of Russia and the Soviet Union (1978-2018)
abstract_en: In parallel with the innovating reform and opening up,China’s research on Russia-Soviet international issues has adapted to the rise of China’s demand for discipline specialization,modernization and internationalization and has made tremendous progress based on the reconstruction of the academic tradition. From the orientation of ideology and demands of socialist country construction to the trend of learning from the developed countries’ international relations theory,from imitating and drawing on Western theories to Eurasia regional studies with Chinese characteristics, from national diplomatic policy-oriented studies to relatively independent studies on the "local knowledge"in the Eurasian region and linking their domestic politics with diplomacy,from focusing on the theme of war to enriching the problem areas and standardizing the methodology,China’s Russia-Soviet international studies show a strong vitality. Although there are still some problems in China’s Russia-Soviet international studies and further efforts are needed to compete for the rights of international discourse,however,as China rises,the Eurasian studies will inevitably make more progress along with the ’intelligence innovation’.

title_en: A Useful Attempt at Academic Exchange between Russia and China in the Field of Humanities and Social Sciences - A Review of the World Politics and International Relations Series
Institute of World Economy and International Relations, Russian Academy of Sciences
On the October Revolution and the Problem of the World System
abstract_en: The article expounds the impact of the October Revolution on international relations vertically and horizontally.Vertically,the October Revolution was a very radical and brand-new form of rise,or in other words,the socialist way,adopted by the Bolshevik Party led by Lenin,who grasped and utilized the opportunity of war and revolution.It avoided Russian territorial,economic,political and even cultural splits,and preserved an integrated and potential major behavior community in international relations,thus,laying foundation and creating conditions for the subsequent rise of the Soviet Union.Horizontally,the October Revolution played a very unique role in the international pattern and world system.The role seemed to be very small,but actually it was enormous.By detaching itself from the capitalist clique,Russia erected a bridge between the Western proletariats and the oriental national liberation movements.But in order to facilitate its own survival and growth,Russia could not but cope with the major capitalist world.The Soviet Russia seemed to be very isolated and ridden with difficulties,and seemed to be marginalized and edged out of the international arena core,but actually the survival and growth of Soviet Russia was a challenge and negation of the predominant international relations.Without a Soviet Russia,the Versailles system was ill rooted,the international order was protractedly unstable,and the European pattern was pregnant with major changes.There were signs of international political focus deviating from the traditional Western Europe and tipping in favor of the newly rising Soviet Russia and North America.Lenin was one of the founders of the idealist school of thought in international relations.Peaceful co-existence and internationalism were landmark creations by Lenin in the theory of international relations.

title_en: Centre for International Strategic and International Relations Studies, United States of America
Theoretical innovations in the study of the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation: assessment of the current situation and directions of efforts
abstract_en: Since the establishment of SCO（ Shanghai Cooperation Organization）, it has achieved major innovations in the theory and practice of international relations. However,the academic research on the organization at home and abroad has not made significant progress in theoretical innovation. Most of the research are descriptive rather than theoretical and the level of innovation needs to be upgraded. In general,we can start with conceptual innovation and theoretical innovation to achieve major innovations in the study of the SCO. Relatively,conceptual innovation is less difficult and more practical but it should be noted that the refined concept should actually depict the innovation of the SCO at the practical level. Save for avoiding simple imitation. It is necessary to show the ingenuity and generalizability. After the concept is recognized by the academic community the political world needs to provide necessary support. In addition, this paper tries to propose the "recognition-based regional cooperation mode"in terms of the development experience of the SCO. This concept can not only summarize the SCO’s innovation in practice but also can be applied to the analysis of other regional cooperation organizations. As for how to achieve theoretical innovation through this concept the academic community can conduct further discussions or research.

title_en: Analysis of the Motivations and Prospects of Sino-Russian Cooperative Relations under the Threshold of Mainstream International Relations Theory
abstract_en: Western mainstream international relations theories consider that security and power,economic development and people’s welfare and collective identification are the three dynamic reasons for international cooperation.The development of China-Russia cooperation is mainly based on security and power,and economic development and people’s welfare.The factor of collective identification is non-existent.Such cooperation is unstable to some extent,for it is vulnerable to the impact of three factors,the USA,China itself and Russia itself.

title_en: Bearing in mind history and peaceful development - Summary of the seminar on the impact of the Second World War on modern international relations
abstract_en: ＜The victory of the Second World War is a great event in the 20th century and even in the history of mankind, 2015 is the 70th anniversary of the end of the Second World War, China and Russia are both important participants in the Second World War as well as the ultimate victors, and in 2015, the two governments will organise a series of activities to commemorate the 70th anniversary of the victory of the Second World War. On 1 April 2015, a seminar on "The Impact of the Second World War on Modern International Relations", co-hosted by the Institute of Russian, East European and Central Asian Studies of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences and the Embassy of the Russian Federation in China, was held in Beijing. Chinese and Russian scholars and diplomats discussed the changes in the world landscape brought about by the Second World War and its impact on international relations, the planning of the post-war order and territorial development.

title_en: The Russian school and its traditions in the study of integrated world regionalism
abstract_en: The study of world regional complex is a combination of many theories. This paper examines the geographical and sociological methods in the study of national conditions,and their contributions to the establishment of modern world complex and its research methods. On this basis,the study of Russia’s world regional complex can be divided into four stages: the emergence of comprehensive Orientalism and National Conditions Science from the 18 th century to the 19 th century;,the economic,social and political issues enriched the study of traditional national conditions from the 1920 s to the 1940 s,the attempt to analyze the regional phenomenon and process by using professional and interdisciplinary knowledge from the 1950 s to the 1970 s,a holistic research method of regionalism has been formed,the world regional complex science has been established,and theoretical tools have been created since 1990 s. After the Cold War,the influence of Regionalism on international academic has increased significantly. In order to understand the characteristics of the relationship between global problems and local problems,it is necessary to study the interaction process based on the specific regional conditions and national conditions. Only in this way can we judge the scale and consequences of global trend progress.

title_en: On Russia's Nuclear Policy and Strategy - with Analyses Using Western Theories of International Relations
abstract_en: An analysis and study of Russian change in nuclear policy and nuclear strategy with the Western theory of international relations will find a very proper framework for realistic analysis of former Soviet nuclear policy and nuclear strategy,quite a proper framework for liberal analysis of former Soviet ones at the end of cold war and the Russian ones in the early period after the end of the cold war while it is basically fit to apply a framework of constructive analysis for the current Russian nuclear policy and nuclear strategy.In terms of nuclear force development goals,Russia seeks to maintain a low level nuclear balance with the US at the present time.As to the policy of using nuclear weapons,Russia switches from refraining to be the first user to being ready to be so,and then to make preemptive use of them.It also uses nuclear threat as a tool of pressurizing and maintaining international strategic balance.Though still oversized,Russian nuclear arsenal is conducive to maintaining global strategic balance under the present circumstances.Overly dependent on nuclear weaponry for maintaining its great power status and self-dignity,Russia may fall into security predicament with the US.Its effort against nuclear proliferation is conducive to preventing nuclear weapons from falling into the hands of terrorist organizations,but Russia sometimes outweighs commercial interests over prevention of nuclear proliferation.

title_en: A Brief Discussion of Khrushchev's Theory of Policy Towards the United States
abstract_en: Stalin, based on the historical fact that the Soviet Union had been surrounded by capitalism for a long time, took the international communist movement as the coordinates and integrated international relations and class relations in handling Soviet-US relations, which was an important reason for the Soviet Union's "mismatch" in its role in international relations over a long period of time. Based on the changed pattern of international relations after the war, Khrushchev put forward his own theories of policy towards the United States. Although these theories had strong Stalinist colours and implied the ambition of world domination, they were in line with the norms of regulating Soviet-US relations with the sovereign state as the basic actor, indicating that Khrushchev began to get rid of the tradition of using the international movement as the coordinates and blending international relations with class relations in dealing with Soviet-US relations. Khrushchev was a pioneer who stepped into the new era with one foot and was stuck in the mire of the old era with the other, and began to deal with Soviet-American cooperation and conflict according to the rules of the bipolar pattern.

title_en: New Forms of Human Civilisation and Great Power Diplomacy with Chinese Characteristics: Ideological Sources and Practical Paths
abstract_en: The New Model for Human Progress（NMHP） is the Chinese answer proposed byChinese leaders to answer the question of where mankind is going. Its main ideological sources include the Marxist international outlook and world view, Chinese Marxism international outlook and world view, and the excellent traditional Chinese culture such as Taoism, Confucianism, and Legalism. Under the concept of NMHP, in the processof promoting major-country diplomacy with Chinese characteristics, a community with a shared future for mankind is the goal, a new type of international relations is the practical path, and the “Belt and Road” is a cooperation platform. The various concepts,strategies and policies of a community with a shared future for mankind are alsomanifestations of building a NMHP. They are reflected at different levels such as macro,meso and micro, including politics, security, economy, culture, ecology and other different fields, and four layers: bilateral, regional, global, and functional issues.

title_en: A Test of Regional Integration of Economic and Security Relationships since the Dissolution of the Bipolar Landscape
abstract_en: This paper is the author's first attempt to explore the basic directions of the development of international relations after the disintegration of the Cold War. The paper discusses the impact of the disintegration of the Cold War pattern on the operation of the current international relations; analyses in depth and in detail the deep-rooted reasons for the regionalisation and blocisation of the current world economy and the emergence of the role of regional security institutions, as well as their manifestations; and puts forward and initially demonstrates that the regional integration of the economic and security relations is not only a basic phenomenon and a driving force of the development of the current international relations but also a basic way to form a multi-polar pattern of the international relations after the end of the Cold War. The thesis proposes and initially argues that regional integration of economic and security relations is not only a fundamental phenomenon and developmental force in the operation of current international relations, but also a basic way to form a multipolar pattern of international relations after the end of the Cold War.

title_en: The China-Russia-India "Strategic Triangle" in International Relations in the 21st Century
abstract_en: US unilateralism can no longer override the world into the 21st century. Pluralization becomes an inevitable trend of development in international relations. The China-Russia-India strategic triangle is a historical opportunity and a product of the times shouldering a major historical mission. It is not directed against any third party, but a constructive and open dialogue. The real siginificance of the strategic triangle is to set up a really just and rational international new order to settle the problems facing mankind in the 21st century. On the other hand, in the development of US-Indian relations, the US effort to make a cat’s paw of India to contain China and to interfere in the China-India-Russia strategic triangle is also futile. The United States and India differ not only in state interests, but also in cultural foundations, in the outlook of values and game rules. They have different ultimate goals with each taking its own needs and each having its axe to grind, while the China-Russia-India, with the expansion of their economic interests, will not only be interdependent, but also complementarian to each other, with more co-operation than competition. This will not only help promote their economic development and comprehensive national strength, but will also stand out as a highlight of the strategic triangle. Meanwhile they have greater co-operation potentials in the non-traditional security field. It is true that they are still confronted with new challenges and are required to properly deal with the existing contradictions and problems. For example, they have to settle their triangular contradictions and problems with the win-win idea, further strengthen triangular mechanism of mutual trust, security and co-operation and keep expanding the convergence of their interests. Only in this way can they expect to place their strategic partnership on the healthy track of benevolent interactions.

title_en: Foreign relations of the countries of Central and Eastern Europe in the post-cold war period
abstract_en: Since the 1990s, the world situation has changed dramatically with the end of the cold war and the demise of bipolar confrontation. In the new post-cold-war situation, the geopolitical situation of the countries of Central and Eastern Europe has changed, and, in connection with this, their foreign policy and external relations have also undergone significant changes accordingly. In the area of external relations, along with the changes in the ideology and values of the countries of Eastern Europe, there have been significant changes in the nature, content and focus of their external relations. They are no longer divided into close and distant relations on the basis of ideology, as evidenced by the dilution of their political, military and economic relations with the Soviet Union. Efforts have been made to expand political, economic and military contacts with Western countries with a view to an eventual return to Europe. In the context of global economic integration, while strengthening regional cooperation, the countries of Central and Eastern Europe hope to achieve their medium-term diplomatic goal of "returning to Europe" by joining the process of European economic integration. Although the accession of the countries of Central and Eastern Europe to the European Union is expected to become a reality by the turn of the century, the countries of Central and Eastern Europe have been slow to come under the NATO security umbrella because of Russia's hard-line stance.

title_en: the news in brief
Geopolitics and beyond borders: an analysis based on Russian think tanks' perceptions of the Ukrainian crisis
abstract_en: The perception of the Russia-Ukraine crisis by Russian think tanks has a distinct geopolitical image. In order to explain the geopolitical code to the public and the international community,the Russian academy has proposed the concept of a borderless space to reconstruct Russia-Ukraine relations from geopolitical perspectives. Given traditional power contrasts, the absence of natural borders and centuries of shared historical experience, Russia and its post-Soviet neighbors together have formed a borderless space. This is an important insurance for Russian national interests that the territories of neighboring countries which should not be used by powers unfriendly to Russia. The Ukrainian crisis will have a significant impact on Russia’s diplomacy,geo-environment and economic politics. Russia should rethink and reposition its foreign policy and international relations theory. Russian scholars believe that the development of Russian-Chinese relations will help Russia get out of the crisis,but Russia should rely more on its own strength. The main concern of Russian scholars is how Russia will stand in the world.

title_en: Regional Polarity, Status Quo Preferences, and China's Diplomatic Philosophy Towards Central Asia
abstract_en: In recent years,the area studies increasingly become analytical hierarchy process of international politics.It’s new phenomenon that with deepening area studies,the area was developed for the analysis of national foreign behavior.To deepen research on China’policy towards Central Asia and build up more academic consensus,this article tries to explain China’foreign philosophy orientation as the core issue,introducing two independent variables:area polarity and status quo preference,and analyzing the logical relationship between diplomatic philosophy of China’s policy towards Central Asia and the above-mentioned two independent variables.The research shows that when there is a certain pressure in the international system and there is uncertainty in unit decision-making risk,China’diplomatic philosophy orientation for Central Asia is positively associated with area polarity and status quo preference.According to the changes of area polarity and status quo preference,China’diplomatic philosophy for Central Asia tends to choose between offensive-defensive and offensive-defense.From the disintegration of the Soviet Union to 2016,China’diplomatic philosophy for Central Asia tends to choose the medium risk,namely between attack-defense or defense-attack.

title_en: A brief analysis of the asymmetric structure of Russian-European relations and its development trends
abstract_en: The development and evolution of Russia-Europe relationship as a very important one between big powers is restrained by the internal structure thereof.Based on an institutional framework,it is characterized by asymmetrical features,asymmetrical not only in role character and cooperation mechanism,and the means of gaming and impact,but also in key interest and core concern,as well as in the transatlantic tripartite relations impacting Russia-Europe relations.

title_en: Normalisation of Sino-Soviet relations and Gorbachev's idea of peaceful coexistence
abstract_en: ＜After a long period of antagonism and anomie, China and the Soviet Union are finally on the verge of normalising their relations. It should be said that this is the result of the long struggle and unremitting efforts of the Chinese side to remove the obstacles to the normalisation of relations between the two countries on the basis of the five principles of peaceful coexistence. At the same time, it is also directly related to the major adjustments in the internal and external policy of the Soviet Union after the coming to power of Mikhail Gorbachev and his new thinking and practice of the principle of peaceful coexistence, which is a universally acknowledged norm of international relations.

title_en: Reflections on the development path of Central and Eastern European countries
abstract_en: Located between big powers,the Central and East European countries often look up to the big powers or the big power groups for protection in choosing their road of development.Thus they are especially prone to the impact of the changing international relations,and are mostly modes transplanted from outside.Their Europeanization is also the transplantation of Western modes,but compared with the attempt to imitate the Western democracy as after the end of WWI and the mechanical copy of the Soviet mode following the outbreak of the cold war,the difference now is that the current transplant benefits from their own subjective will,the aptitude of their national conditions as well as their favorable internal and external conditions.They have got rid of the fate of defeat and the process of Europeanization has made remarkable progress.

title_en: Hard and soft power in Russian-American relations - a semiotic examination
abstract_en: The major reason for increased frictions in Russian-US relations since 2003 has been severe interest divergence in geopolitics.Furthermore the two powers have great differences in their semiological elucidation of international relations.The article makes a centralized discussion on Russian-US relations in a semiological sense.The US effort to change Russian semiological system and inflict soft influence on it in the first decade or more after the end of the Cold War did not yield the premeditated results and Russia continued to use the anti-hegemony semiological system to decode the information released by the USA and formed nationwide uniformity in foreign policy from top down.

title_en: Rethinking and Adjusting Soviet Policy Towards the Third World
abstract_en: ＜In recent years, the Soviet Union has been pursuing a comprehensive contractionist policy towards the third world, in contrast to the expansionist interventionist policy it pursued in the 1970s. In the world-renowned Gulf Crisis and Gulf War, the USSR, in a departure from the usual practice, coordinated its actions with the United States. Obviously, the present Soviet leadership has repudiated the Third World policy of its predecessor and given up the idea of competing with the United States for the Third World.

title_en: The Russian Factor in U.S.-China Relations
abstract_en: Home politics and foreign policy are closely interrelated. Likewise, China’s foreign strategy is deeply affected by home political factors. It can be divided into four stages under the framework of China-US-Russia triangular relations since the establishment of China-US diplomatic relations in 1979: （1） the first stage （1979—1989）: the China-US Para-security alliance without economic ties against a common rival the Soviet Union; （2） the second stage （1989—1991） the ineffective China-US Para-alliance without a common rival; （3） the third stage （Dec. 1991—Sept. 2001） China-Russia Para-para alliance based on weak economies; and （4） the fourth stage （since the Sept 11 Incident of 2001）: China’s parallel development of relations with Russia and US in its two-way cooperation strategy. China-Russia Para-para alliance is mainly manifested in regional and international cooperation, military ties and partial political ties, but this by no means implies an alliance against the US. China and US are closely related in trade, culture and knowledge, but lack political and military trust and cannot form G2. Due to the complicity of home politics, the pluralization and diversity of home interests, China is seeking the maximization of state interests by parallel development of ties with Russia and US, two-way cooperation and beneficial interactions.

title_en: Photo News
Russia's Multi-Polar World Vision and Diplomacy
abstract_en: In 1996 former Russian foreign minister Primakov raised the concept of a multi-p olar world, triggering concern from all parties. Putin came to power and inherit ed his concept, yet displaying many different features from it in concrete diplo matic moves. As an important ideological concept, the idea of multi-polar world  sparked extensive controversies in Russia, which climaxed in 1998～2000. After t he outbreak of the Iraqi war, the future world order became the focus of discuss ions and Russia began to re-examine the concept and its diplomacy. This article  systematically expounds the formation of the concept, its connotation and specia l features. It makes a comparative analysis of the difference between Putin and  Primakov in the concept and points to the theoretical discrepancy of the concept , revealing its essence as well as its impact on Russian diplomacy.  The author  holds that the Russian multi-polar world concept is purported to build a balance  structure or strategic balance that tips in favor of itself, seeking for the id entity to participate in the game rules on a equal footing in a bid to achieve t he goal of restoring its great power status. Therefore the concept is a tactic o f Russia to realize its state interests.

title_en: On the concept of comprehensive security in the Shanghai Cooperation Process
abstract_en: With the end of          the cold war the threat of traditional military security factors marked by confrontation of the two major military blocs is declining. In its place are the rising dangers of regional unrest and conflicts caused by non - traditional security factors such as terrorism, national conflicts, religious contradictions, drug trafficking and illegal immigration. Meanwhile, the comprehensive security theory encouraging multi-security areas and multi-security bodies is winning ever-greater approval. The article makes a review of the regional security cooperation process started in Shanghai, China in 1996. It shows that it was actually a positive practice and beneficial probe of the comprehensive security concept to carry out the struggle against the evil forces of terrorism, extremism and separatism immediately after the successful settlement of military security issues. And from this, to further extend and deepen the cooperation process into the economic, cultural and social security fields in combination with the European Asian geopolitical features.

title_en: The combination of history and theory is rich - "From Confrontation to Dialogue - Soviet-American Relations during Khrushchev's Administration" after reading
abstract_en: Dr. Zheng Yu has newly published a new book: From Confrontation to Dialogue - Soviet-American Relations under Khrushchev's Administration1. This 200,000-word monograph was written on the basis of the author's doctoral dissertation, after some material additions and framework structure adjustments. Many of the ideas contained in it are based on the diligent search in the past when he was studying hard in a cold window, as well as the unique perspective of today's high level. International Relations ...

title_en: Status signalling and international conflict: a study based on the Russian-Ukrainian conflict
abstract_en: There is no consensus in the academic community on why Russia has taken specialmilitary operation against Ukraine. Based on the status signal theory, this article explores the reasons for Russia’ s “ struggle” strategy towards Ukraine, and tries toreveal the mechanism and deep reasons of Russia’ s demand for international and regional status. Russia’s special military operation against Ukraine faces multiple audiences, and international and domestic audiences have prompted it to shift towards a“struggle” strategy in pursuit of great power status. At the international level, the Hobbesian relationship model between hegemonic and rising powers is a structural prerequisite for the outbreak of conflicts. When a dependent country moves towards its own hostile camp, leading to a challenge to its international status, it adopts a“struggle” strategy, releasing a high-profile status signal. At the domestic level,facing the domestic audience group that has suffered losses due to war, they will use the image of “victims” to carry out “biased narratives”, releasing low-profile status signals to the audience group, stimulating domestic hawks, and ultimately promoting the adoption of“struggle” strategies externally. This research framework and related conclusions have certain implications for understanding the conflicts in the Post-Soviet region.

title_en: The Institute of Russia, East Europe and Central Asia of Renmin University of China held a seminar on "Security in Russia and Eurasia in the new situation".
abstract_en: ＜On 25 November 2015, the Institute of Russian, East European and Central Asian Studies of Renmin University of China (RUC) held a seminar on "Security of Russia and Eurasia in the New Situation". More than 30 experts and scholars attended the meeting, including Professor Chen Yue, dean of the School of International Relations of Renmin University of China, Major General Wang Haiyun, senior advisor of the China Society of International Strategy, and Researcher Xing Guangcheng, director of the Institute of Frontier Studies of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences. The participants held in-depth discussions on regional economic security, political security, the implementation of the Belt and Road Initiative and China's countermeasures to the regional situation.

title_en: Welcome to subscribe
"Partnership but Not Alignment": A Realistic Choice for China-Russia Relations
abstract_en: ＜The core concept of China's new-type international relations in the new era is "partnership but non-alignment".1 The joint statement of the heads of state of China and Russia in June 2016 clearly set "non-alignment" as an important principle defining the nature of relations between the two countries.2 It emphasised the promotion of a new phase of the China-Russia Comprehensive Strategic Collaborative Partnership, which is "based on equality, trust, mutual support, common prosperity, and friendship for generations", under the guidance of the policy of "partnership but non-alignment".3 The author believes that this strategic positioning of relations between the two countries is in line with the reality of international relations and the strategic interests of both countries, and that it is the most effective way to promote their relations at the present stage. The author believes that this strategic orientation of relations between the two countries is in line with the realities of international relations and the strategic interests of the two countries, and that it is an important element in the current development of relations between the two countries.

title_en: China and Russia: Theoretical Value and Relevance of Political Development
abstract_en: China has made great progress in political development in the past three decades; so has Russia in the past eight years. This is not only a great fortune for the two undaunted suffering nations,but also a great contribution to human social progress. In contrast to the stubborn efforts of certain countries in the international community to export or duplicate Western democracy,China and Russia have been probing into a political line that complies with the interests of the overwhelming majority based on their respective national conditions.They have correctly handled the interrelationships among social democracy,personal freedom,national stability and political efficiency,eliminated all sorts of social obstacles,and provided good political guarantees for quick economic growth. Given the complicated contradictions in the international context,the political development of the Chinese and Russian communities demonstrates unique theoretical values and international significance. Compared with certain remote and inaccessible political patterns in the West,there is no denying that the development roads of China and Russia are closer and more realistic to their vicinity and to certain developing countries. Along with the further extension of democratic international relations,the human world will present itself in a more mature and diversified democratic manner and the flowers of democracy will blossom in greater splendor in various countries.

title_en: On Contemporary Geopolitical Scope
Overview of Chinese Research on Central Asia: Review, Problems and Prospects
abstract_en: Central Asian Studies in China are relatively young discipline both in cultural studies and the current affairs. From the beginning of 90 s of last century,the basic research of and dynamic focus on the Central Asia has been gradually developed thanks to the urgent need of the China ’s foreign policy. Since then the researchers and the publications of Central Asia have doubled and redoubled. In recent years some realistic factors in the development of relations between China and Central Asia have determined the development trend of China’s Central Asian Studies,but also highlight the problems in China’s Central Asian research.

title_en: Sixth Russian East European Central Asian Youth Forum held in Guangzhou
abstract_en: ＜On 16 April 2016, the Sixth Russia-East Europe-Central Asia Youth Forum and the Fourth Lingnan International Relations Forum - Seminar on "'One Belt, One Road' and the Eurasian Continent: History and Reality" was successfully held at Guangdong University of Foreign Studies (GDUFS). The forum was co-organised by the Institute of Russian, East European and Central Asian Studies of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, the Guangdong Institute of International Strategic Studies and the Institute of International Studies of Guangdong University of Foreign Studies. More than 50 scholars from Beijing and Guangdong attended the forum. Li Jinfeng, Secretary of the Party Committee of the Institute of Russian East European and Central Asian Studies of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, introduced the history of the Eurasian Institute.

title_en: Economic analysis of the outbreak of the "colour revolution" - a comparison of the transition economies of Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan
abstract_en: The outbreak of the "colour revolution" has attracted great attention from scholars at home and abroad. Academics at home and abroad have explored the reasons for its outbreak from the perspectives of history, ethnicity, culture and international relations. The outbreak of the "colour revolution" has profound economic reasons. Through a comparative study of the transition economies of Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan, this paper explores the economic reasons for the outbreak of the "colour revolution", points out the diversified characteristics of the transition economies, and puts forward five points of enlightenment for the countries with economies in transition. It also points out the diverse characteristics of the economies in transition and offers five lessons for countries with economies in transition.

title_en: On Chemical Disarmament in Russia
abstract_en: The Convention on the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons was the first multilateral international disarmament treaty signed by Russia. Russia began preparations early and ratified the Convention in 1997. The article analyses the reasons for Russia's chemical weapons reductions and the many constraints it faces. Russia's disarmament process has been delayed by a lack of financial resources. However, Russia's attitude has been very strong, and work has not stopped.

title_en: Globalisation in Russian Perspective: For or Against
abstract_en: Russia cannot bypass globalization which is a trend and current of world development. The problem lies in how Russia looks at it. In the light of relevant articles published in the main Russian academic magazines, this article systematically sums up the generation of the issue in Russia, hammers out a combing of how Russia identifies or rejects globalization and further analyses the effects caused by identifications or rejections, showing that nationalism is the main basis for Russian judgment of globalization. This depiction is conducive to our identification of the complexity of the globalization issue.

title_en: Current trends in transregional cooperation in Asia and Europe and their implications
abstract_en: that at the present time, the trend of Asian-European co-operation is developing. After the end of the Cold War, three main strategic links are taking shape, firstly, the China-Russia strategic co-operation partnership and the Shanghai Co-operation Organization; secondly, the China-Europe comprehensive partnership relations and thirdly the Russia- Europe strategic partnership relations. Since the outbreak of the Iraqi War, many main force centers on the Asian-European continent have made strategic coordination. In recent years with the Asia and Europe dialogue deepening, mutual understanding is increased. The main causes for the trans-regional Asian European co-operation include the following: （1） Pushed by the trend of economic globalization, Asian-European economic and political exchanges and co-operation are rapidly developing and promoting the formation of Asian-European new partnership ties, and promoting the regional peace and development; （2） The center of world affairs is moving from the Atlantic region to the Pacific region; （3） Asian countries share many similar or close concepts with Russia in international affairs. The trend of Asian-European co-operative development has become one of the important manifestations of the world trend of polarization, helping accelerate the world’s polarization trend, but the process will still remain a protracted and complicated one. This trend will promote a new round of land and sea power interaction and begin a process of Asia-Europe identity in international relations.

title_en: Exploring the origins of the Russian Federation's national security ideology
abstract_en: Russian Federation’s security thoughts is the ideas and theory about how to making use of current resources and potentials, resist outside threats in political economic, social, military, scientific, technological, ecological and information area. Russian Federation’s Security Thoughts is both continuation and perfection of the traditional security thoughts. By means of the historical overviews on Russian security policy as a medium of security thoughts, this paper analyzes three important theories of the traditional Russian security thoughts, i.e. geopolitics, military might and collective security, and their impact on current Russian foreign policy, makes an objective evaluation about the three factors’ role in the forming of Russian statehood.

title_en: New results of intensive research - a review of the book "Research on Population Problems in Central Asia
Russia and NATO: From the "Partnership for Peace" to the Madrid Summit
abstract_en: This paper briefly discusses the diplomatic struggles between Russia and NATO during the period from January 1994, when the United States put forward the "Partnership for Peace" after NATO's eastward expansion was put on the agenda of European international relations, to the NATO Madrid Summit in July 1997, when one side opposed the eastward expansion and the other insisted on the eastward expansion, and describes the evolution of the policy and various counter-options of Russia's opposition to the eastward expansion. The article describes the evolution of Russia's policy against eastward expansion and the various countermeasures, and discusses the ups and downs of Russia-NATO relations around this issue. The article argues that after the first phase of NATO's eastward expansion is basically finalised, the struggle over this issue has not come to an end, and it will continue to be a cross-century diplomatic problem for Russia.

title_en: Experience of building a high-end think tank at the Institute of World Economy and International Relations of the Russian Academy of Sciences
abstract_en: ＜The Institute of World Economy and International Relations of the Russian Academy of Sciences (Институтмировойэкономикиимеждународныхотношений Российской академиинаук (IMEM), abbreviated as ИМЭМОРАН) is one of the most influential and top-ranking think tanks in Russia. In 2013, the Institute was ranked 32nd on the list of global think tanks by the University of Pennsylvania, ranking first among Russian think tanks. The Institute's experience in building high-end think tanks is important for the implementation of the Programme of Action of the Russian Federation.

title_en: Russian Westernism and the Evolution of International Relations
abstract_en: The dominance of the West has shaped modern international relations, and Western modernity has set a strong normative framework for latecomers. Historically, in order to integrate into the West, Russia not only paid a high price but also suffered from cyclical national development. Westernists in Russia hoped to promote their country’s transition and integration with the West in the cultural-religious, economic, political and social fields, but have all ended in failure. This is not only because they underestimated the national principle as well as the inconsistency between Russia and the West’s strategic interests, but also because the West tried to maintain its interests and dominant position and refused to accept Russia. With the advent of the era of late modernity, Russia should use its historical experience of interacting with the East and the West to strengthen crosscivilizational dialogue, promote economic openness and world multipolarization, and strive to build a new international relations system based on equality, interdependence and cooperation. This article was first published in the Issue 2 of the Journal of Russia in Global Politics in 2024 and is authorized by the author to be published in Chinese in the Academic Journal of Russian Studies.

title_en: Research on Building New International Relations - A Geopolitical Economy Analysis of China-Kyrgyzstan Relations as a Perspective
abstract_en: There are three levels of building a new type of international relations:firstly,relations between great powers;secondly,relations between neighboring countries;thirdly,relations between developing countries.These three layers can be independent respectively or cross each other.No matter which level,the new type relations between China and one of them should include economic,political and security relations,the only difference is that it has different focus when China deals with different countries.The basic information of one country,including size,geographical location,the development stage,is the premise by whichwe judge its position in international relations and the basic demands,it is also the coordinate system that we deal with the bilateral economic relations.Compared with the world economy with its own rules,international politics is more unpredictable,this requires we closely follow the real-time change of host countries,take political reality as an important basis for determining the bilateral political relations.Since security interests are the primary interests of China and Central Asian countries,security relations among the geopolitical,economic and security relations between China and Kyrgyzstan should be taken as the top priority.

title_en: Research on Building New International Relations - A Geopolitical Economy Analysis of China-Kyrgyzstan Relations as a Perspective
abstract_en: There are three levels of building a new type of international relations:firstly,relations between great powers;secondly,relations between neighboring countries;thirdly,relations between developing countries.These three layers can be independent respectively or cross each other.No matter which level,the new type relations between China and one of them should include economic,political and security relations,the only difference is that it has different focus when China deals with different countries.The basic information of one country,including size,geographical location,the development stage,is the premise by whichwe judge its position in international relations and the basic demands,it is also the coordinate system that we deal with the bilateral economic relations.Compared with the world economy with its own rules,international politics is more unpredictable,this requires we closely follow the real-time change of host countries,take political reality as an important basis for determining the bilateral political relations.Since security interests are the primary interests of China and Central Asian countries,security relations among the geopolitical,economic and security relations between China and Kyrgyzstan should be taken as the top priority.

title_en: Eurasian Regionalism in the Perspective of Western International Relations Theory - A Review of Research Perspectives and Arguments
abstract_en: ＜With the end of the Cold War and the new changes in the international system, the trend of decentralisation of the international system has become obvious, and the regional<sup>1</sup> study of international relations has also emerged. Along with the increasing trend of globalisation and regional integration, regional organisations formed by different countries have sprung up, and the traditional political and economic competition has transcended the level of sovereign states, and the world politics based on regions has shown the development of regional integration and cooperation and competition among regional groups of countries. Regions as

title_en: International relations in Central Asia in 2011
abstract_en: The international relations of Central Asia mainly have three characteristics:first,some great powers’ contest in Central Asia goes intense,international relations become even more complicated;Russia pushes forward and the United States is subject to change,China’s influence increases in Central Asia;the struggle between Russia and the US is still a main trend;all the forces wane and wax in turn and present a dynamic parity.Second,the Central Asian countries’ principle of diplomatic choices is to maximize short-term interests,this determines the uncertainty and diversification of the Central Asian countries’ diplomacy.Third,the contradiction between the Central Asian countries is constantly upgrading and the regional fragmented trend becomes obvious.

title_en: Disciplinary Development of Russian-Central Asian Studies in China in the 40 Years of Reform and Opening Up
abstract_en: After the collapse of the Soviet Union, Russian and Central Asian studies began to separate from the Soviet and Eastern European studies and have new directions in research contents and focal points, and the collaboration within and outside the discipline has been strengthened. Since the reform and opening up, China made many achievements in the Russian and Central Asian studies. Since then the publications are numerous and research contents are diversified, at the same time, a disciplinary study is increasing. This will be very beneficial to the long-term development of Russia’s Central Asian studies. With the support of theory, the development of disciplinization resulted in the collaboration among different subjects in regional study. The recognition of the differences and consistency of different countries has made the cooperation among scholars is possible. The specialization has enhanced the ability of Chinese researchers in international academic dialogue. In order to achieve the objective in teaching and research, two basic methodological tendencies of Russian and Central Asian studies, namely disciplinary and cross-disciplinary, will develop in parallel for a long time. The BRI will promotes China’s Russian and Central Asian studies in two ways: putting more academic research tasks and speeding its rapid development.

title_en: Russian foreign policy think tanks: trends and obstacles
abstract_en: According to the findings of Professor Ivan Turin, a leading Russian expert on international relations, over the past 20 years Russia has formed an independent, politically neutral community of foreign policy researchers and analytical centres. However, a large number of important works show that the study of foreign policy in Russia remains essentially at the theoretical level. These experts have so little interest in policy formulation that politicians and civil servants continue to work without the support of independent analytical centres. Russia lacks independent think tanks in the process of foreign policy development, while "think tanks" have already become a mainstream instrument of Western political life. At the same time, Russia's attempts to establish think tanks and research centres have mostly failed, or their activities and influence have been very limited. The study found that the main obstacles to the development of independent foreign policy think tanks in Russia are the absence of a competitive environment for ideas, the lack of clear forms of cooperation between the government and think tanks, and the failure to diversify the planning and funding of think tanks. This article was translated from Russian Analytical Digest, 28 March 2019 (General No. 234) and published in Chinese in the Russian Journal with the author's permission.

title_en: Analysing the restructuring of Russian foreign policy in the light of the new Concept of the Foreign Policy of the Russian Federation
abstract_en: The "Concept of the Foreign Policy of the Russian Federation" released in March 2023 is a strategic planning document to guide the medium and long-term diplomatic practice of Russia. In the new concept, becoming an important pole in the future multi-polar world and building a strong and unique Eurasian country have been established as the key directions of Russia’s diplomacy. The new concept has distinctive anti-hegemony and active defensive characteristics. It divides the world into "constructive countries ", "neutral countries" and "unfriendly countries". For the first time, the concept of "AngloSaxon countries" is used in the official diplomatic documents, which along with Europe are placed last in Russia’s diplomatic ranking. The new concept attempts to create a land power plate that "relies on the land and faces the sea". It focuses on developing countries, especially the "neighboring countries" and the BRICS countries, and makes use of the structural contradiction of France, Germany and the "Anglo-Saxon countries" to win over Europe and suppress the US. The new concept has significantly increased its reliance and trust on China. It regards China-Russia strategic cooperation as the cooperation between the two world civilizations in building a new world order, and is eager to establish a "strategic alliance" with China and deepen their economic integration.

title_en: The Treaty on Good-Neighbourliness, Friendship and Cooperation between China and Russia and the development of Russian-Chinese relations
abstract_en: The "China-Russia Treaty of Good-Neighborliness and Friendly Cooperation"（hereinafter referred to as the "treaty"） expires in 2021, and the two countries decide to extend the treaty for 5 years. This is an important strategic decision, and also an important announcement by China and Russia to continue to strengthen strategic cooperation in areas involving global, regional and bilateral isssues, maintain world peace, keep regional stability and defend the two countries’ core interests facing the great changes unseen in a century.As a programmatic document for the two countries, it guides the development of their bilateral relations for the long-term future.The treaty stipulates that China and Russia respect each other’s political, economic, social and cultural development path and ensure the long-term and stable development of bilateral relations.The treaty provides legal protection for China and Russia to "be friendly for generations and never be enemies" and to be good neighbors,good partners, and good friends. The norms of international relations and inter-state relations set forth in the treaty conform to the essence of the new type of international relations. Over the past 20 years, the treaty has promoted the healthy development of China-Russia relations and has made important contributions to the security and stability of Eurasia and to world peace. Facts have proved that as long as the China-Russia relations develop healthily, the people of two countries can live in peace, and Eurasia and the entire world will have more peace.

title_en: The Evolution of Russian Policy towards China and the Construction of the Middle East Railway
abstract_en: Russia was fully prepared in politics, economy and diplomacy for the rights and interests of the Chinese Eastern Railway. After the Sino-Japanese War of 1894 and 1895, Russia took the lead in successful interference in returning the Liao in 1895. This showed that Russia had completed political preparations for seizing the rights of the Chinese Eastern Railway. Russia also used this favorable opportunity to make economic preparations for seizing the rights of the railway, i.e. giving credit to the government of the Qing Dynasty and establishing a Sino-Russian Daosheng Bank, attempting to control China’s economic lifeline. Russia signed the Sino-Russian Secret Agreement with the Qing government next year, obtaining a privilege of the Chinese Eastern Railway. The construction of the Chinese Eastern Railway was an inevitable outcome of Russia’s Far East policy and it indicated that Russia’s policy on China had a great change and brought about a remarkable influence upon the international relations of the Far East.

title_en: Summary of the International Symposium "China and Eurasia: New Opportunities and Challenges"
abstract_en: ＜On 28-29 March 2016, an international seminar on "China and Eurasia: New Opportunities and Challenges" was held at the Shanghai Academy of Social Sciences. The seminar was attended by more than 40 invited Chinese and foreign delegates from the Diplomatic Academy and the Moscow Institute of International Relations (MIIR), which are think tanks directly under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Russian Federation, the Institute of Strategic Studies of the President of Kazakhstan, the Institute of Strategic Studies of the President of Kyrgyzstan, the Institute of Strategic Studies of the President of Uzbekistan, the Institute of Strategic Studies of the President of Tajikistan, the Department of Eurasian Affairs of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the People's Republic of China, the Institute of Russian, East European and Central Asian Studies of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences (CASS), China Institute of Modern International Relations, as well as professional institutions and academic research units of universities and colleges engaged in the study of Russia and Central Asia in Shanghai.

title_en: Regionalism in Russian Higher Education: Theoretical Construction, Historical Evolution and Mutual Learning between China and Russia
abstract_en: The discipline construction of reginal studies in Russia’s higher education began in 1994. After nearly 30 years of development, a relatively complete and unique discipline system has been formed in terms of professional setting, personnel training, and theoretical construction. The development path of the discipline construction is a typical transition from institutional design to connotative development. After several adjustments, Russia’s regional studies finally made sure the subject orientation alongside political science, forming a regional theory represented by Balykin’s "regional studies foundation" and Voskresensky’s "world comprehensive regional studies". In September 2022, China will officially include regional and national studies in the catalog of graduate education disciplines, marking that China’s national and regional studies have entered a new stage of standardized development of disciplines. In this context, by comparing the similarities and differences between our regional studies and Russia’s regional studies in terms of discipline construction background, subject positioning, and discipline training models, and absorbing the experience of Russian regional studies in discipline construction, it can promote the development of regional studies in the new era in China.

title_en: An Analysis of the Construction of a New Type of Great Power Relationship between China and Russia
abstract_en: The new pattern of relationship between China and Russia is the all-around cooperation relationship established on the basis of comprehensive strategic partnership. Its establishment conforms to the requirements of the times for peace, development, cooperation and win-win, accords with the strategic interests of both China and Russia, and is also affected by factors of large powers such as America. During the diplomatic practice to construct new pattern of relationship between China and Russia as great powers, the two countries make cooperation in politics, economy, humanities, military and other fields under the structure of comprehensive strategic partnership, conduct benign interaction through web partnership diplomatic platforms such as SCO, BRICCS and G20, and make effective strategic alignment in hot and sensitive issues including Syria Crisis and Crimea Problem, etc. To achieve continuous development in the new pattern of relationship between China and Russia, the humanistic communication between the two countries should be strengthened and their traditional friendship should be developed; the dissonance in their relationship should be removed and conflicts and contradictions should be controlled; pragmatic cooperation should be enhanced, and the butt joint between "One Belt One Road" strategy and the Eurasian Strategy of Russia should be strengthened. To form the mutually compatible, mature and stable strategic structure is the direction for the new pattern of relationship between China and Russia.

title_en: Overview of Russian policy and research on the BRICS establishment
abstract_en: ＜In recent years, research on the cooperation mechanism of the BRICS countries has flourished in Russia on the initiative of the government, and a series of scientific research results have been achieved, providing the Russian government with suggestions and ideas for the formulation of foreign policy. Russian scholars have put forward different views on the future development process of the BRICS countries and the establishment of the mechanism, which reflect their different positions on national interests and international cooperation. In this paper, we compare and analyse these different views and positions through the theories of neo-liberal institutionalism, neo-realism and constructivism in international relations on national interests, international system and international cooperation, and analyse the different positions on international cooperation embodied in the different views.

title_en: Russia's Far East Policy and the Construction of the Great Siberian Railway
abstract_en: After the mid of the 80s of the 19th century, Russian capitalism came into a monopoly stage. Economic penetration was the principle character of Russia’s Far East policy at that stage. The construction of the Trans- Siberian Railway became the crux of Russia’s Far East policy and Russia changed its strategic defensive since then. Russia’s Far East policy made a real success. The construction of the railway was also an important sign of Russia’s strategy of expansion in the Far East and had a signif icant effect on the Far East’s international history.

title_en: Transregionalism in the foreign policy of world and regional powers: the Russian perspective
abstract_en: At the beginning of the 21 st century, all the major powers in the world, even including the regional powers have participated in the rapid development of transregional processes. No matter new or old, the BRICS, IBSA, MIKTA, TPP, TTIP, BRI and EEU have all obtained great development space. But considering constant competition between these programs, it is necessary to comprehensively study the transregionalism. The phenomenon of transgregionalism is not only a stage of globalization, but also anew trend affecting world politics and the diplomacy of world powers. From the perspective of real effects of diplomatic policies, transregionalismis a useful tool to realize national and group interests at the regional and global levels, eliminate the limits on globalization, minimize the destructive effects of globalization, while ensuring geopolitics and economic benefits, promoting institutionalization of cooperation, reforming global and regional management systems, establish regional cooperation and identity, and enhancing interdependence. Therefore, there is a fierce competition between different plans of transregionalism.

title_en: International turmoil and Russia
abstract_en: The speed and depth of the world-order transformation is unprecedented over the past 200 years. Concerning international turbulence, one of the most important indicators is the deglobalization of the world economy. The study on technological, social, economic, and political variables of social changes has revealed that the traditional social contract between government, business, and civil society within developed countries has come to a crisis. This social contract has been in effect for more than half a century, since the times of an industrial and bipolar world before globalization. Its inconsistency with modern realities, coupled with the inability of the old political center to offer convincing approaches to its modernization, has polarized societies and weakened social cohesion in the developed part of the world. As a result, populism and isolationism have come to power, which have started the dismantling of the existing system of global governance and its norms. For the current world order, the main challenge is an attempt to change the polycentric world to a uni-polar system with the dominance of the US. The most likely scenario for resolving this contradiction is to create a new bipolarity. Russia’s foreign strategy in the future might be adapting to the bipolarity in the 21 st century and to a new role as a balance-keeper, and proposing a new global architecture based on multilateral responsible leadership.

title_en: Diplomatic Decision-Making in Russia: Personality Traits and Strategic Culture
abstract_en: Foreign policy making has always been the focus of international political research, in which Allison’s decision theory, from the perspective of personal temperament theory and historical scenario theory, established a decision-making model with rationality as the core, emphasizing the importance of personality traits. Russia’s foreign policy decisions are also deeply influenced by the Russian President’s personality. This is especially true during Putin’s presidency. The dominant theme of the Putin’s era has been Russia’s great power strategy. In the context of the great power strategy, the Russian elites,including Putin, share the same principles and objectives in their foreign policy:to maintain Russia’s position as a country that cannot be ignored in the world.Putin’s personal experience has given him a strong sense of sovereignty and a strong will to safeguard national interests. Moreover, in the historical scenario emphasizing timeliness, the strategic culture of diplomacy endows Russia with the transcendental combination of geographical space and elite consensus, and Russian uniqueness always appears in different forms and conceptual systems at the appropriate time, which is the reflection of Russian national temperament in presidential personality. It can be seen, from the perspective of personality traits and strategic culture, that the Russian concept is the crystallization of Russia’s response and independent exploration under the chock of the long history of world politics.

title_en: Reflections on the construction of a knowledge system for regional country studies
abstract_en: China has a long history of regional and country studies, but in the early days, the discipline was generally classified in the category of international politics.2022 after the State Council Academic Degrees Committee formally set up regional and country studies as a first-level discipline, academics began to explore the concept of the knowledge system that should be possessed by the discipline as a first-level discipline. The Russian Journal, as an academic journal on Eurasian issues, also hopes to contribute to the construction of the discipline of regional country studies. In this issue, we have published a set of interviews with six experts to discuss the following issues. Chinese Regional Country Studies: National Needs, Spatial and Temporal Architecture, and the Construction of Cross-disciplines; Basic Issues to be Warned about in the Construction of the Discipline of Chinese Regional Country Studies: The Tension and Pitfalls of Concepts and Cultures in Chinese Regional Country Studies; The Symbiosis between the Construction of the Discipline of Regional Country Studies and the Construction of China's Autonomous Knowledge System; The New Dynamics of Developing the Regional Country Studies Think Tanks in Colleges and Universities and their Re-upgrading; The Intellectual, Functional and Competence Structure of the Talents of Regional Country Studies; The Impact of Chinese Regional Country Studies on the Development of Chinese Regional Country Studies and the Development of Chinese Regional Country Studies The new impetus and upgrading of the development of regional country think tanks in universities; the knowledge structure, function structure and ability structure of regional country talents; the issue of "Western-centrism" and "China-centrism" in China's regional country studies; the issue of human orientation; the issue of the construction of the discipline system of regional country studies in the perspective of economics; and the Eurasian studies and South-East Asian studies, which are the important contents of the regional country studies. In particular, some experts proposed that the study of Southeast Asia should be carried out from a spatial perspective. In particular, some experts suggest that from a spatial point of view, regional country studies have a fatal flaw that needs to be noted, that is, it can not cover the study of global issues, and can not cover the study of region-to-region and country-to-country relations. Of course, regional country studies should meet the needs of countries, and it is the consensus of scholars that the paradigms and methods of regional country studies should be innovative, integrated, grafted and crossed.

title_en: "State-civilisation" and political theory
abstract_en: The new version of the Concept of Foreign Policy of the Russian Federation of March 2023 introduces for the first time the concept of "State-civilisation", which deals with the basic issues of national identity, which is the basis of foreign policy thinking. The website of the "Valdai" International Debate Club (https://ru. valdaiclub. com/a/highlights/gosudarstvo-tsivilizatsiya-i-politicheskaya-teoriya/) was launched on 18 May 2023, with the aim of promoting the concept of "state-civilisation". ) Article published on 18 May 2023 - ""State-civilisation" and political theory". According to the author, the use of new concepts may mean a change in the theoretical framework of Russian foreign policy. The author's main points are that the theory of civilisation has historical depth, helps to understand the cultural factors behind foreign policy, and is a way of thinking beyond the nation-state paradigm, but the theory of civilisation also has shortcomings. Firstly, realpolitik still needs to be understood in the context of reality; secondly, civilizational theory is not universally interpretative of the issues of peace and war; and thirdly, it is difficult to integrate the concepts of sovereignty and civilisation when the nation-state model is still the dominant model for actors in international relations. Russia may be trying to break away from its almost century-and-a-half-long track of national identity under the influence of Western thought and seek a new identity through the concept of "nation-civilisation", but this path is bound to be a difficult one, and the applicability of the "nation-civilisation" model to other countries is uncertain. However, this path is bound to be difficult, and it is uncertain whether the "state-civilisation" model is applicable to other countries. This article is published in Chinese in the Russian Journal with the author's permission.

title_en: Turkey's Central and Eastern European Strategy
