abstract_en: Over the past century and more, Turkey’s relations with Central and Eastern European countries have undergone many changes.The reasons for the change lie in two dimensions. One is the difference between the political development trajectory and modernization process of the two sides, and the other is the constant changes in the world system and regional pattern.Taking these two dimensions as the entry point, a comprehensive analysis of Turkey’s strategy for Central and Eastern Europe reveals that Turkey’s the strategy reflects Turkish consistent diplomatic thinking: changes in national identity and positioning determine the evolution of the strategy in Central and Eastern Europe, but on the issue of conflict and regional security, Turkey’s diplomatic actions have a more realistic considerations.In the future, Turkey’s strategy for Central and Eastern Europe depends on three factors: the polilical game between Turkey and the EU; Turkey’s national identity and dominant ideology; and the change of its relations with Russia.

title_en: Newsletter of the symposium "Comparative study of soft power of Russia and China".
abstract_en: ＜In recent years, "soft power" has become an important field of study for Chinese and Russian academics, as well as an important policy pursued by the governments of both countries. Enhancement of soft power is a strategic task faced by both China and Russia, and the promotion of soft power research is in line with the requirements of the development of the international situation and can provide intellectual support for the development strategies of the two countries. In order to promote exchanges and activate ideas, the group of "Comparative Research on Soft Power of China and Russia" held a symposium in Beijing from 15 to 17 October 2013, inviting experts and famous scholars in the field of international relations and communication science to participate in the symposium, focusing on the concept of soft power, and comparing the soft power of China and Russia in the dimensions of culture, political resources and foreign strategy.

title_en: Transformation of the world order under the conditions of the post-Western international reality
abstract_en: The international political and economic process of the post-Western era has a decisive influence on the transformation of the world order, and the academic community has made different interpretations of this process.In view of the international relations system, the author proves that the spatial and temporal changes of the complex system of international relations system need to use both stereotypes and new methods based on the basic principles of complex system theory.At present, the core problem of international political economy and international comprehensive regional science is to formulate the most competitive and stable social political system and political and economic structure model.The new multi-center world order calls for the formulation of mutually beneficial cross-regional space docking policies through consultation instead of strengthening geopolitical confrontation and intensifying the competition for geopolitical control of buffer space.This approach opens up the possibility of constructive competition for regional projects, and at the same time helps prevent competition from developing into direct geopolitical confrontation or military conflict, and promotes the overall transition of the international system to a more stable state by reducing regional and national uncertainties.

title_en: Evolution of Russia's Policy Towards Africa and Sino-Russian Cooperation in the Field of Relations with Africa
abstract_en: During the period of polarization, for expansion of its influence sphere and challenge to the American hegemony, the Soviet Union attached importance to relations with the third world countries, paid more attention to Africa in particular. At the beginning of the post-cold war, Africa was once a neglected area by Russian diplomacy. Since the new century, due to Africa’s rising international political and economic influence and its need of integration into the global economic system, Russia has adjusted its policy toward Africa. Russia uses the advantage of energy and military equipment to promote and deepen the practical cooperation the fields of political, economic and defense. The policies towards Africa of China and Russia have similarities in principle. There is no fundamental difference in political interests and there is also no structural conflict existing in the economic and trade cooperation. Therefore two countries can cooperae in their relations with Africa.

title_en: Post-Cold War Relations between China and Central and Eastern European Countries
abstract_en: After a drastic change of the political situation of the countries in Eastern Europe in 1989, the relations between China and the countries of the Central and East Europe （CEE） changed from the bilateral ties based on the same social systems and values into a new type of bilateral relations with different social systems and values. Under the guidance of the Budapest principles and Bucharest principles, the development of the relations between China and the countries of the CEE has risen while maintaining stability. However, political and economic non-symmetric relations and different values in the development of the bilateral relations have hampered a stable development of the bilateral political relations.

title_en: English Teaching and Research Department, School of International Relations
abstract_en: ＜The English Department of the School of International Relations (i.e., the Foreign Service Institute) uncovered many problems during the double-anti-campaign. There were serious shortcomings and mistakes in our teaching materials, teaching attitudes and methods. The quality of teaching is not high and the effect is not good. (1) Teaching materials For several years we have not had a set of scientific and systematic teaching materials. The primary textbooks are compiled by the Institute of Foreign Languages, and the subsequent levels are basically self-compiled. The primary students (the first year of the speciality course are all cadres) spend a long time learning pronunciation, which is a problem for them, and they also have strong opinions about the subject matter. In the first year, the texts were more related to college life, and the vocabulary was not always suitable; some texts were "Two Young Patriots", originally taken from the Soviet junior high school textbook, which was about the patriotic story of the Soviet Red Scarf. For comrades who were politically mature and already had some experience of revolutionary struggle, such texts would not be popular. The subsequent self-edited volumes were written in a messy manner, with incomplete explanations. Students asked: Is this a textbook? Or is it a compilation of information? This is a good question. Some

title_en: Review Meeting of New English Listening Textbook Held in Shanghai
abstract_en: ＜The review meeting of the textbook for English listening class at the basic stage of English, "Introduction to English Listening" (Step by Step), prepared by the Foreign Language Department of East China Normal University, was held from 13 to 20 March 1983 in Shanghai. The meeting was attended by representatives of the Institute of International Relations, Shanghai Institute of Education, Beijing Institute of Foreign Languages, Liaoning University, Shanghai Maritime Academy, Sun Yat-sen University, Shandong University, Shanghai Institute of Foreign Languages, Shanghai Teachers' Training College, Luoyang People's Liberation Army Foreign Languages College, Fudan University and East China Normal University.

title_en: 1992 Annual Meeting of the Society for the Study of Foreign Language Journals in Colleges and Universities
abstract_en: ＜The annual meeting was held from 27 to 30 May at the PLA Institute of International Relations outside Nanjing. Thirty-six representatives of member institutions attended the meeting, and five publishers, including Shanghai Foreign Language Education Press, sent their members to participate in the meeting. Under the careful arrangement of the Council and the host, the four-day meeting was compact and successful. Five representatives made speeches at the conference.

title_en: The Evolution of Portuguese Language Education in Mainland China and Macao Universities from the Perspective of Intercountry Interactions: An Exploration of Diversified Pathways
abstract_en: This article combines studies of international relations and foreign language education and tries to establish a causal relationship between the "foreign language departments growth" and "relationship between China and target countries". It concludes that international relations have played roles of positioning, orientation, quantitative and qualitative configuration in building foreign language departments. This article focuses on the impacts of the interaction between China and Portuguese-speaking countries on the construction and development of Portuguese departments in the Chinese mainland and Macao. Based on recent development trends between these countries, the paper proposes a possible diversified education of Portuguese majors. It suggests that Portuguese-speaking majors should be cultivated with economic and trade expertise as well as cultural knowledge of the regions concerned, which can be better achieved by exploring the potentials for cooperation between mainland universities and Macao universities.

title_en: Seminar on Curriculum Setting for English Majors in Colleges and Universities at the Foundation Stage Held in Shanghai
abstract_en: ＜On 18-20 December last year, a seminar on curriculum setting for English majors at the basic stage was held in Shanghai, attended by representatives of Peking University, Beijing Institute of Foreign Languages, Institute of International Relations, Shanghai Institute of Foreign Languages, Shanghai Teachers' Training College, Fudan University, Guangzhou Institute of Foreign Languages, Sun Yat-sen University, Liaoning University, East China Normal University, Nankai University, and Nanjing University, among others. The representatives of twelve colleges and universities. At the meeting, the delegates exchanged views on the current situation of the English curriculum at the basic stage of each school, discussed the division of the basic stage, the purpose and requirements of each course and the relationship between them, and put forward some ideas for the future curriculum.

title_en: Teaching English Grammar Past and Present
abstract_en: ＜This time, under the leadership of the Party, the English Department of the Beijing Institute of Foreign Languages, on the basis of the Double Anti-countermeasures, and in accordance with the Departmental Leap Forward Plan put forward by the Party Organisation of the Department, fully mobilised the masses, especially young teachers and students, to carry out a pedagogical overhaul and formulate a new syllabus for the practice of modern spoken and written English. In the course of the eleventh anniversary, various teaching materials and tools were prepared in conjunction with the requirements of the new syllabus in order to ensure its implementation.

title_en: Assessment of Capacity Constraints and Dilemmas of Participation in Global Value Chains for Artificial Intelligence Development in Russia
abstract_en: In order to address the challenges brought about by a new round of scientific and technological revolution,Russia has developed a grand artificial intelligence development planning,and has formulated a "two-wheel drive"strategy for both policy promotion and priority in the military sphere. According to the analysis of Russian artificial intelligence value chain through basic elements of artificial intelligence development,Russia enjoys some basic advantages in the development of artificial intelligence. Due to long-standing separation of Russian industries from the global value chain and weaknesses in electronics industry and semiconductor industry,independent construction of Russian artificial intelligence value chain is extremely handicapped.Russia may continue to be marginalized in the future global artificial intelligence value chain.

title_en: Changes in Russia's Ruling Elite in the New Era and Their Impact on Sino-Russian Relations
abstract_en: Russia’s diplomatic decision-making mechanism has obvious characteristics of elite politics. The pressure of the new situation of the political turmoil in Russia caused by the storm of parliamentary elections at the end of 2011 and the economic downturn caused by the deterioration of relations between Russia and the West after the Ukrainian crisis in 2014 forced the Putin government to adjust the members of the Russian ruling elite to consolidate the regime and reverse the declining tendency of the development of the national economy,however,the personnel changes did not affect the cores of power structure and diplomatic decision-making. On the basis of summarizing the characteristics of the changes of the ruling elite in Russia in the new period,this paper analyzes the core team of the Russian elite for the decision-making on China and their policy ideas from the two aspects: development of decision making and conceptual enlightenment. It also analyzes the characteristics of the implementation of Russia’s China policy by the Russian elite from two specific fields: Sino-Russian energy cooperation and subnational cooperation. The author believes that the current decision-making mechanism for Russian foreign policy with Putin as the core has not been fundamentally affected by the changes of the elite. The rise of the "China factor" in the concepts of the elite will help promote Sino-Russian cooperation; while the unpredictability of the political influence of the energy elite politics and the emergence of the phenomenon of "provincial affairs ministers"reflect the situation of the coexistence of challenges and opportunities for the development of Sino-Russian future relations.

title_en: Current international migration governance in Eurasia: a blueprint for the Russian experience
abstract_en: In recent years,with the Silk Road Economic Belt,the Eurasian Economic Union and the Great Eurasian Partnership being put forward and implemented,transnational population migration within the Eurasian region shows new features.First,the direction and the center of the transnational population migration are all the more evident. The transnational population migration within the region consists mainly of labor migration and migration for education,and China and Russia have become the two centers of the international migration in Eurasia. Secondly,the transnational population migration synchronizes with Eurasian regional development,and the deepening of regional integration promotes the activeness of population migration. Thirdly,the migration to Russia is the most active part of population migration within Eurasia.Therefore,both the extent of the Russian society to accept immigration and the regulations of the Russian government concerning immigration exert an influence on the situation of the population migration within the area that cannot be ignored.

title_en: Russia's position and role in the Asia-Pacific security system
abstract_en: The historical logic of the interaction between Russia and the Asia-Pacific space has not changed fundamentally since the 1860s. In the eyes of Asian countries,Russia is an outsider of the Asia-Pacific space. In Russia’s own view,they represent the historical process of the expansion of European civilization to Asia. The identity of the "other"makes Russia participatein the Asia-Pacific security system as an external factor only. When the Russia’s comprehensive national strength surpasses those of the Asia-Pacific countries,it can become a balance force in the Asian-Pacific security system. But when it is in a weak position in the regional power structure,the Russia’s role in the Asia-Pacific security system declines in fashion of cliff fall,becoming a marginal role similar to Yevgeny Onegin who was in the system but could not integrate into the evolution process of the system. The history of Russia’s participating in AsiaPacific security affairs is such a tidal movement that swings back and forth between these two states. After the Cold War,Russia has entered a new round of the cyclein which it is in a weak position in the Asia-Pacific affairs,and it has gradually slid to the edge of the Asia-Pacific security system with significant decline of its national power and the imbalance of its power between the Eurasian space and the Asia-Pacific space. In this case,the Russian intellectual elite put forward the ideas of building an Asian identity,"Greater Eurasian Partnership,"strengthening bilateral cooperationwith the Asia-Pacific pivot countries and other coping strategies,but due to the constraints of its comprehensive national strength and the international environment,their effects are not evident yet,and Russia caught in the dilemma in the Asia-Pacific security system is difficult to make significant progresses in the near future.

title_en: Russia's accession to the WTO and its implications
abstract_en: Russia's accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO) in 2011 marked a new stage in its socio-economic transformation; it ended Russia's longstanding isolation from the mechanisms for managing, organising and coordinating world trade, eliminated trade discrimination against its exports in the international market, and put it on an equal footing in the world trade system. This is of epoch-making significance for the promotion and expansion of Russia's foreign trade. Russia's commitment to WTO accession means a substantial change in its tariff system, industrial economy and trade in services, which is an unprecedented test for Russia's economic development. How to make use of the opportunity of WTO accession to promote the development of Russian economy towards diversification and modernisation is the main task facing Russia. In order to ensure that Russia's domestic industry to adapt to the WTO accession, the government has formulated a series of policies and introduced corresponding government subsidies. However, these measures still face the interference of many negative factors, affecting the smooth transition of Russia's industrial economy after WTO accession.

title_en: Putin's vision and practice of the development of the Russian party system
abstract_en: Putin's conception of Russian political parties and the party system is an important element of Putin's idea of a new Russia. By examining the development of the Russian party system during Putin's two terms as President and one term as Prime Minister, the article argues that Putin's conception and practice of the party system have consolidated and developed the Russian party system, stabilised Russian politics and gradually developed it in the direction of a multi-party system with the participation of "two, three or four parties". The article further points out that the formation, content and practice of Putin's conception of the party system are closely related to the reality of party politics in Russia.

title_en: Review of the situation and development trends in Russia and Eurasia
abstract_en: ＜The Eurasian region in 2021 has undergone a series of changes and multiple challenges. Although the Eurasian region has experienced a series of crises and risks, the overall situation is still under control. I. Review of the overall situation in the Eurasian region in 2021 (a) Domestic situation in Russia In the political sphere, from 17 to 19 September 2021, Russia held the election of deputies to the Eighth State Duma. The ruling United Russia party won a resounding victory, taking 324 seats and maintaining its constitutional majority.

title_en: Russia's Diplomatic Direction: Focus on Russia-US Relations
abstract_en: ＜The year 2017 is full of uncertainty in international politics, and the world is waiting for changes to take place. 2017 should be a good year for Russia. The trends are generally favourable for Russia. On the one hand, Russia has passed the most difficult stage and is more confident; on the other hand, Europe has many problems of its own, with refugees and terrorism overburdening it and making it difficult for it to concentrate on Russia; and above all, the inauguration of Donald Trump as president of the United States has made it difficult for Russia and the United States to focus on the Russian Federation and the United States.

title_en: Prospects for Russian-American relations and the direction of Russia's development
abstract_en: ＜The crisis in Ukraine has lasted for more than two years since political turmoil erupted in the country in November 2013, culminating in Russia's acquisition of Crimea by means of an "unconventional war" and a bitter armed conflict in the eastern part of the country, which has plunged relations between Russia and the West to their lowest point since the Cold War. The Ukrainian crisis has plunged Russia's relations with the West to the lowest point since the Cold War. on 12 February 2015, the Normandy Quartet, comprising the leaders of Russia, Ukraine, Germany and France, adopted a declaration in support of the mediation process in the Ukrainian conflict after 16 hours of marathon talks. Subsequently, the Contact Group signed a declaration of support for the mediation process in the Ukrainian conflict.

title_en: Study on the reasons for and implications of the conclusion of the Convention on the Legal Status of the Caspian Sea
abstract_en: Since the dissolution of the Soviet Union,the Caspian coastal countries have fallen into incessant debates over the legal status and the division of the Caspian Sea for more than 20 years. The Convention on the Legal Status of the Caspian Sea,signed at the Summit of the Caspian States（ the so-called "Caspian five"countries） on August 12,2018,puts an end to this situation temporarily. The signing of The Convention on the Legal Status of the Caspian Sea results from the compromises among the Caspian Sea countries under the new situations. The signature of this Convention not only lays a legal foundation for the establishment of a new system in the Caspian Sea region,but also will play an important role in the stability of the Caspian Sea region,the development and export of oil and gas resources and the maintenance of global energy security. Although the signature of this Convention demonstrates important positive significance,this Convention still implies some ambiguities on some key issues,such as the absence of specific and clear-cut dispute settlement solutions,the ambiguity of division rules for seabed and seafloor,etc. In conclusion,the signature of the Convention on the Legal Status of the Caspian Sea is of great significance,but it is not enough to resolve the Caspian Sea issue once and for all.

title_en: Impact of the evolution of Russian-Ukrainian relations on the Eurasian Union
abstract_en: The Eurasian Union is one of the great visions of Russia’s revival strategy. In this strategic vision,Ukraine is a very important component. But the Ukraine crisis has changed this situation,and various discrepancies exposed in the crisis affected the stability of the Eurasian Union as well. In early 2015,the establishment of the Eurasian Economic Union was officially announced,and Ukraine announced to join the European Union Association Agreement two months later,leading Ukraine to move away from the Eurasian Union further. Seen from the perspective of Russia’s strategic choices,the Eurasian Union will move forward,regardless of whether Ukraine joins.However,the strategy will face many difficulties in the future because of the impact of the relationship between Russia and Ukraine.

title_en: The "open mechanism" and the influence of the State on norm-setting - a study based on the field of cybersecurity
abstract_en: It can be frequently witnessed that states promote norm emergence through creating a new institution. But whether the founder can always be the main beneficiary of the new institution is questionable. Russia pushed for the creation of United Nations Open-Ended Working Group（OEWG） to undertake the mission of norm-making for cyber security issues. However, the influence that Russia gained during the operation of the institution cannot compete with what the United States and its allies acquired.Through “open-ended institution” that has unlimited quota for participants, states under different conditions can acquire different types of influence. The main benefit for Russia to launch OEWG was being recognized by more states as the “leader” of an inclusive, open norm-making process, which led to the improvement of reputation. In order to maintain this benefit, Russia prioritized the task of making sure that the institution can complete its mission on schedule, rather than striving for more support for its norm proposals. This left the United States and its allies an opportunity to mobilize states and non-state actors to make their norm proposals more supported in practice.The two sides acquired different types of influence, which varied in significance for states to improve influence on norm-making. The research shows that combining the creation of new institution with mobilization of support for norm proposals is difficult but important.

title_en: The Russia-Ukraine Conflict and the Course of U.S. Proxy Wars
abstract_en: Ukraine crisis is a major security issue of global concern.From the onset of the Ukraine crisis and civil war in 2014 until the outbreak of the Russia-Ukraine conflict in 2022,the United States has been pursuing proxy war against Russia in Ukraine,the total aim of which is to maintain its strategic interests in Europe and global hegemony by containing Russia.In this process,the specific goal of the America’s proxy war has been evolving from defeating the civilian armed forces in eastern Ukraine supported by Russia to dragging Russia into the“proxy war trap”.It should be noted that America’s proxy war in the Russia-Ukraine conflict has adjusted in some aspects,which is reflected in providing political and military assistance for Ukraine openly,waging proxy war through multilateral coalitions,and adopting mixed policy instruments.The trend of America’s proxy war in Ukraine is affected by domestic politics and support from allies,the battlefield capability of Ukraine and the countermeasures of Russia.Conflict is helpful for in-depth study and judgement of the future trend of the conflict.America’s proxy war in the Russia-Ukraine.

title_en: US-Russia tussle in Syria
abstract_en: The Syrian Civil War is a typical proxy war between the US and Russia.The US and most western countries supported the Syrian rebels while Russia lent aid to the government led by Bashar Assad. The interests of the US and Russia came into conflict with each other in the Syrian Civil War. The political transition required by the Syrian opposition is in line with the interests and values of the US,but it will deprive Russia of its last stronghold in the Middle East. Therefore,Russia will continue to support Assad’s regime in order to retain this important stronghold in the Middle East and the Mediterranean region. However,it does not mean that the US and Russia do not have common interests,which can be mainly reflected in three aspects,namely anti-terrorism,ending humanitarian disasters and seeking a political solution to the civil war. Through "chemical weapons for peace"and military intervention in the Syrian Civil War,Russia gained the upper hand in the competition. Moreover,Russia played a key role in handling important events in the Middle East for the first time during the post-Soviet period and emerged from the shadow of the Crimean crisis to a certain extent.

title_en: China-Russia relations: a comprehensive strategic partnership in the new era
abstract_en: As the most important bilateral relationship among international relations,China-Russia relations play a significant role in maintaining international and regional peace and stability and balancing global strategies. After evolving to "comprehensive strategic partnership of coordination"from previous "strategic partnership of coordination"in 2011,China-Russia relations entered the "new stage of comprehensive strategic partnership of coordination"in 2014. In 2019,both Chinese and Russian presidents elevated the bilateral relationship to a higher level,"comprehensive strategic partnership of coordination for new era". Since then,both countries have had unprecedented political mutual trust and strategic cooperation,witnessing groundbreaking progresses in military and science ＆ technology,fruitful cooperation in economy,finance,energy,road infrastructures,agriculture,region affairs and culture. China and Russia kept cooperating with each other to contain the spread of COVID-19 pandemic. Although the relations still face numerous external challenges and internal issues,the internal driving force for the bilateral relationship is powerful. In the new era,both China and Russia will enhance their political mutual trust,improve the bilateral trade structure and investment environment,and strengthen the early-stage feasibility researches for relevant projects,so as to promote the in-depth development of comprehensive strategic partnership of coordination for new era.

title_en: State Building, Democratisation Responses and the Making of Political Stability in Central Asia
abstract_en: The literature on the nation building in Central Asia traditionally paid more attention to the building of the nation-states in Central Asia,neglecting the organic connections between the concentration of state power and the building of institutional legitimacy that is closely related with nation building,and even avoiding the analysis of the institutional adaptability of Central Asian countries responding to the external environment. The formation of political stability in Central Asia has benefited from the triangle of stable order,namely the concentration of power,the strategy of legitimacy and the flexible response to the wave of international democratization. Specifically,the Central Asian political elite quickly adapted to the democratic diffusion process in the international community; on this basis,they have cultivated a unique electoral culture to improve the power framework of a presidential system to accumulate institutional legitimacy,fostering new political nationality through the building of political communities. These factors have strongly contributed to the stability of the political order in Central Asia. This situation of stability will continue for a long time.

title_en: Western sanctions against Russia in the light of the concept of "the other"
abstract_en: When the Russia-Ukraine conflict broke out in February 2022,the U.S. and the West broke with their usual practice and escalated sanctions against Russia,causing global anxiety.The West has long viewed Russia as an inferior“other”on multiple levels,such as religion,political system,geography,and economic development.Around the Russia-Ukraine conflict,Russia has intensified its claim to its unique civilization and security concept,thus continuously challenging the Western centrist ideology and institutional foundation,which pushed the West to strengthen its containment of Russia to protect Western hegemony.The pernicious effects of the West’s hostility and harsh sanctions against Russia are spilling over,triggering concerns in both the Western and non-Western worlds and consequently starting their strategic adjustments.All the adjustment is contrary to the development needs of the globalization era.Meanwhile,it detached from the international reality of sovereign equality in the post-colonial period.Thus the world’s future is full of uncertainties and challenges.

title_en: American Academic Perceptions of the Russian-Ukrainian Conflict and Their Commentary
abstract_en: At present,the Russia-Ukraine conflict is becoming a hot research topic in academia at home and abroad.There are many research results about Russia-Ukraine conflict in American academia.Scholars have carried out in-depth studies around the causes,impacts,prospects and solutions.of the Russia-Ukraine conflict.Their views are quite varied and there are some profound insights in them.However,due to the influence of national interests,ideology and western strategic culture,there are still some obvious limitations in the views of the American academia on the Russia-Ukraine conflict.For example,there are much fewer scholars who believe that the eastward expansion of NATO leads to the Russia-Ukraine conflict than those who believe that the responsibility for the conflict should be attributed to Russia;Many scholars tend to see the Russia-Ukraine conflict from the analytic framework of the democracy vs.autocracy;There is lack of due criticism and reflection on the United States’hegemonism strategy,especially its policy towards Russia after the Cold War.The key to resolving the Ukrainian issue lies in the correct security concept and the establishment of an inclusive security order.

title_en: Forward-looking analysis of the development of Russian-American relations
abstract_en: ＜Since the Ukrainian crisis and especially the return of Crimea to Russia, Russia's relations with the West, especially with the United States, have been at their lowest point since the end of the Cold War. The West has used economic sanctions, military threats, diplomatic isolation and a series of other all-round means to check and balance Russia, and the relationship between Russia and the U.S. has returned to the bipolar confrontation of the Cold War era. Russia under the rule of Vladimir Putin has completely lost trust in the U.S., convinced that the U.S. cannot really treat Russia as an equal and respect it, and Russia has psychologically

title_en: Changes in the Architecture of Central Asian Integration and Prospects for Development
abstract_en: The development of sub-regional integration is offected deeply by the region situation. Sub-regional countries,regional countries and extraterritorial countries serve as the main players in the integration process. Theoretically,sub-regional integration follows two goals and logics of "seeking survival"and "pursing development". Under the logic of "pursuing development",sub-regional integration runs ahead of regional integration from the perspective of maturity,and can maintain survival and set the pace for regional integration through sub-regional development. Under the logic of "seeking survival",sub-regional integration is outpaced by regional integration from the perspective of maturity. In order to avoid "being merged"by regional integration,it is advised to seek survival by uniting sub-regional countries,introducing new regional countries or leveraging the power of extraterritorial countries. While China become an Eurasian Countries,the external framework of Central Asian integration is reversed. Central Asian countries maintain solidarity and carry out cooperation,and make the best of the strengths of new regional country（ i. e.,China） and extraterritorial countries to seize the room for development of sub-regional integration in Central Asia. The development prospects of Central Asian integration depends on the logic application of "seeking survival"and the solutions to specific problems in Central Asian countries.

title_en: Korea's Arctic Strategy under the "New Northern Policy": Processes and Limits
abstract_en: After ROK President Moon Jae-in took office,he included energy,the Arctic waterway and other contents into "9 Bridges"Strategy framework of "New Northern Policy". By strengthening China-ROK relations and Russia-ROK relations to unfreeze its relations with DPRK,Moon Jae-in pushes the concepts of "New Economic Map of Korean Peninsula"and the "Northeast Asia + Responsible Community". Under various considerations（ such as enhancing regional discourse power,promoting economic development and ensuring energy security）,Moon Jae-in Administration places priorities over participation in Russia’s Arctic energy development,contribution to commercialization of the Arctic waterway and construction of the Arctic logistics system within the framework of "New Northern Policy". In the meantime,the construction of "Polar Cities",with local governments as the backbone,has also become the focus of the grand planning. ROK’s Arctic Strategy is confronted with the challenges from a series of issues,such as the complication of the US-DPRK relations,homogenized competition between ROK and Japan and the militarization of the Arctic. Although Moon Jaein Administration has made great progress in vigorous launch of the Arctic Strategy,the implementation of this strategy has been greatly restricted.

title_en: Civil War, Intervention, and International Order: Revisiting the Conflict in Ukraine
abstract_en: Civil wars and international interventions have become the main manifestation of the volatile international order,and the Ukraine crisis erupted in 2014 is such an example. This article analyzes the case of Ukraine from the three aspects. It begins with an analysis of the causes of the conflict by using the theory of security dilemma,arguing that the anarchy within Ukraine is the primary reason leading to the armed rebellion of ethnic Russians. The social mentality of hostility and fear,as well as the economic expectations of jeopardized interests,exacerbated the uncertainty and insecurity of both sides of the conflict. And geographical proximity to the foreign alliance provided an objective condition for the rebellion. It then analyzes the intervention roles played by the EU and Russia. The dilemma of Ukraine to choose an alliance between the West and Russia intensified its domestic conflict and led to the 2013 Crisis.From the perspective of keeping a balance of alliance politics,however,both the EU and Russia adopted a strategy of "conditionally supporting the alliance while abating the conflict". The final part evaluates the impact of the Ukraine conflict on the international order. Both the West and Russia have undermined the international order at different levels.

title_en: The Impact of the Ukrainian Crisis on Regional Competition and the Eurasian Order
abstract_en: The Eurasian region is Russia’s traditional area of influence and also the focus of Russian diplomacy.The Ukraine crisis has changed the basic paradigm of competition and cooperation in the Eurasian region.Great power competition has transformed into multi-level agency competition.Regional institutional competition has been weakened,and partner competition has been increased.Bilateral cooperation and panregional cooperation received attention from all countries.Affected by the changes in the competition and cooperation of great powers,the recovery and development of the regional economy is constrained,the fragmentation and diversification of the regional order will continue.Although it once became the focus of global attention,the global status of Eurasian region has not fundamentally changed.The Ukraine crisis gives extraterritorial third parties an opportunity to expand their influence,and the Eurasian region will be further integrated with the larger surrounding areas.China should actively promote cooperation in the Eurasian region and strive to maintain the stability of the regional order.

title_en: The Ukrainian Crisis and Turkey's Strategic Energy Position
abstract_en: The Ukraine crisis in 2014 provided a rare opportunity for Turkey to improve its strategic energy position. Turkey plays an important role in the big chess game of energy between Russia and Europe. On the one hand,Turkey is an important transit hub for the EU’s strategy of energy import diversification; on the other hand,Turkey also plays a key role in Russia’s aversion of energy transit risk and the stabilization of European energy markets. Improving energy status has a positive impact on the development of Turkey’s economic strength,the increase of its negotiating chips to the EU,and the expansion of regional influence. What cannot be ignored is there are a number of risks in Turkey as an energy transit country,which needs to be addressed by taking measures.

title_en: U.S. Policy on Ukraine: Strategic Goals and Prospects
abstract_en: Since the independence of Ukraine, the United States has actively carried  out diplomacy with Ukraine, gradually formed the strategic goals of securitization, democratization and westernization. The Biden administration’s Ukraine policy will continue the U. S. strategic goals, but will increase support for Ukraine to a limited extent, while maintaining engagement and containment with Russia, and seeking cooperation with European allies to urge stability and security in Ukraine. However, the inherent differences in U. S.-Ukraine relations have exacerbated the fragility of the bilateral relations. The attitudes of European allies will affect the effectiveness of resolving the Ukrainian crisis. The differences in the strategic goals of the U. S., Russia and Ukraine determine the instrumentality of Ukraine. Also,the four-party relationship between the United States, Russia, Ukraine and Europe will restrict the autonomy of Ukraine. It can be expected that the Ukrainian policy goals during the Biden administration will continue to adhere to securitization, democratization and westernization,but the implementation of its policies will still be subject to the above factors.

title_en: German rearmament and the turnaround in the Scholz government's diplomacy with Russia
abstract_en: After the Cold War, despite seeking international status as a world power,Germany was reluctant to rearm and continued to outsource its defense and security to NATO and the United States, creating an external image of a civil power that emphasized economic and trade relations and a commitment to conflict resolution. However,as the United States shifted its strategic focus from Europe and the Middle East to the Asia-Pacific, and with the outbreak of the Crimea Incident in 2014, Germany was forced to rethink the issue of rearmament and its contact policy with Russia. In February 2022, the Ukrainian Crisis led directly to the introduction of “watershed diplomacy” by the Scholz government, which led to a major shift in German diplomacy. Germany shifted from being reluctant to rearm to rearming, shifting its strategic orientation toward Russia from an accessible friend and partner to an adversary and enemy, and moving from being a civil power to a full-fledged one. Whether Scholz’s policy will go smoothly in the future, however, remains to be seen in the development of the Ukrainian Crisis, the situation in Europe, and the domestic political changes in Germany.

title_en: Cross-border peoples, integration and European security
abstract_en: Germany has been reunified for almost 30 years;however,Europe is facing the adverse effects of the crisis in Ukraine,the refugee crisis and the like.The development and changes of events show that cross-border ethnicity has become an important factor that affects the security of Europe.The divergent opinions on the integration of cross-border ethnicity have led to the intensification of the crisis in Ukraine.Integration has both positive and negative effects on cross-border ethnic issues.The integration at the regional level helps to reduce the development gap between different ethnic groups and to solve cross-border ethnic issues,while the integration at the national or ethnic level may intensify conflicts and lead to changes of the borders.The future of European security depends on the development of regional integration to have a more positive impact on cross-border ethnic issues.

title_en: Experience and Inspiration of the United States and Russia in Managing the Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons after the Breakup of the Soviet Union
abstract_en: In the early 1990s,how to dispose the huge nuclear arsenal left by the Soviet Union after its collapse was a huge security challenge facing the international community.Both Bush and Clinton administrations were highly concerned for this issue.By establishing the Cooperative Threat Reduction Program（the Nunn-Lugar Project）and through repeated consultations and bargaining with Russia,Ukraine,Kazakhstan,Belarus and other countries,the U.S.finally made the countries such as Ukraine agree to transport the nuclear weapons from their respective territories to Russia to dispose,ratify the START I Treaty,and join the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons as non-nuclear weapon states.These actions maintained the international nuclear non-proliferation regime and avoided possible nuclear proliferation.At the same time,the five permanent members of the Security Council also made security guarantees for Uzbekistan,Kazakhstan and Belarus,and the countries concerned have received economic compensation.

title_en: The U.S.-Russia INF Treaty Compliance Dispute and European Regional Security: Implications and Controls
abstract_en: In July 2014,the disputes over the issue of the INF Treaty compliance were erupted between the United States and Russia. At the official level,the governments of the United States and Russia accused each other of breaching the treaty,and the diplomatic confrontation is escalating continuously. At the level of civil society,there are opinions in both the US and Russia demanding their government to withdraw from the INF Treaty,leading to an uncertain future of the continuity of the treaty.Despite the INF Treaty is a bilateral treaty for arms control between the United States and Russia,it is the issue of European security in essence. If Russia ’s land-based medium-range missiles do reappear in Europe,and Europe,they will pose a serious threat to European national security and even strategic stability. European countries lack of counter-measures to deal with land-based medium-range missile,and there is also an issue of lack of credibility as to how the United States will respond to the extended threats to Europe. In order to prevent this compliance dispute to continue to escalate,the relevant parties should refrain from taking escalating measures and use existing channels to seek to address the compliance disputes in the short term. And in the long run,in view of the complex security concerns of the parties behind the disputes over the INF Treaty,the relevant parties should make efforts to resolve the security concerns of each other,seeking to ensure the security and strategic stability in Europe.

title_en: Changes in Northeast Asia's Geopolitical Environment and Strategic Opportunities for the Promotion of the Belt and Road Initiative
abstract_en: The geopolitical environment in Northeast Asia is undergoing historic changes,providing a new strategic opportunity for the advancement of the Belt and Road Initiative in the region.Achieving peace on the peninsula and implementing the systematic linkage of their infrastructures by the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea and the Republic of Korea is the primary prerequisite for this strategic opportunity.The full opening of the Russian Far East will provide a new space for the Belt and Road Initiative.The speedy signing of the China-Japan-South Korea Free Trade Agreement will lay the foundation for the new cooperation mechanism among the six countries.As a result,Northeast China will become the core area of the Belt and Road Initiative in Northeast Asia due to the revitalization plan.The United States will have to reconsider its strategic intent in Northeast Asia.

title_en: Political, economic and diplomatic challenges to the reconstruction of Syria
abstract_en: This article attempts to understand the current situation in Syria from the perspective of historical process by comparing the political,economic,and diplomatic differences in Syria before and after 2011,when the Syria civil war broke out.Based on this,it analyzes and predicts Syria’s process of political reconstruction and its challenges in the future.Politically,the seven years’civil war have caused Syrian’s traditional authoritarian regime with a military-centered political system to be severely damaged,and the"centralized"political structure has been replaced by the political reality of the"decentralization"by armed separatists.Economically,Syria’s domestic economic situation is deteriorating further,the development model of diversified economy strived to promote by Bashar to after he took power has also been sluggish due to the war.In terms of its external relations,the civil war over the years has weakened Syria’s external influence,and Syria has also downgraded from a"regional power"to an object influenced or even manipulated by regional and extraterritorial powers.These new changes are the realistic basis for Syria’s post-war reconstruction and will also determine the general direction of future Syria’s internal affairs and diplomacy.

title_en: Northeast Asian Regional Co-operation under World Changes: Opportunities and Challenges
abstract_en: The direction of Northeast Asian regional cooperation is currently an important issue in the background of profound changing world. As an important world economic center,the frontline of game between great powers and the core region of global geopolitics,Northeast Asia is characterized by complicated historical and national profiles,turbulent situations and long-standing intervention of extraterritorial forces,which present many specialties,sensitivities and risks. Northeast Asia should address some major issue: How to say goodbye to gloomy history,resolve the actual contradictions and conflicts,reshape the regional peace order and security relations and promote the building of"A Community of Shared Future for Mankind"in Northeast Asia. The great changes of the current world inevitably sweeps Northeast Asia and brings about major opportunities and challenges to regional cooperation. At present,the calls for peace has been louder,dialogues and exchanges have increased,and the atmosphere for cooperation has gradually turned for the better in Northeast Asia. A prelude to the re-establishment of regional order and security relations slowly resounds. China,Japan and ROK are promoting the construction of China-Japan-ROK Free Trade Area vigorously,thereby giving new impetuses for mutually benefit and win-win cooperation in Northeast Asia. However,dark side is still exposed by Northeast Asia against changing backdrop. There is an arduous and long way to promote regional cooperation and development of Northeast Asia.

title_en: Governance of Online Disinformation in the US, Germany and Russia in the Perspective of Media Norms
abstract_en: With the prevalence of internet media and digitalization in our society,we are facing strings of fast-moving,unwanted,false and bewildering information. Online disinformation is now becoming an increasing issue in the public sphere; yet the war against disinformation has just begun. On the one hand,the United States is burdened by the doctrine of marketplace of ideas,which leads to its inability to rebuild the legitimacy of the government on media regulation. On the other hand,Germany and Russia have taken actions to tackle the issue,but their explorations of regulatory boundaries and governance mode are far from complete while being pressured on domestic and international public opinions. From the perspective of policy analysis,the three countries have invariably re-examined the rights and responsibilities of technology companies and online platforms in supervision,but based on their different discourse atmosphere,the United States,Germany,and Russia have promoted their governance processes differently from the perspectives of democratic crisis,public values,and national security.

title_en: An Initial Exploration of Dispute Management Mechanisms in International Energy Trade--Taking the Response to the Russia-Europe-Ukraine Natural Gas Dispute as an Example
abstract_en: The energy dispute between Russia and Europe escalated with the Ukraine crisis. Russia and Europe have eased the energy relationship via the response mechanisms of energy crises such as early warning mechanism of energy crisis,international rules,and the tripartite talks. By analyzing how Russia and Europe dealt with the energy dispute,we know that peaceful settlement of disputes is a fundamental principle of responding to international energy dispute,while negotiation,investigation,mediation,reconciliation,expert determination,arbitration,judicial proceedings are its main approaches; the WTO law,the Energy Charter Treaty and other international law,and the European Energy Charter,the International Court of Justice and other international organizations,as well as international system composed of the conventions to deal with the dispute are its main tools. Countries should deal with international energy disputes by combining hard power and soft power,as well as political diplomacy and legal means,using "carrot and stick"to win the "smart power"and establish a comprehensive system of dealing with international energy disputes and maintain overseas energy interests.

title_en: Saudi Oil Decision-Making Mechanisms and Their Implications for the U.S.-Saudi Energy Security Relationship
abstract_en: The US-Saudi’s oil-for-alley alliance is not only a decision made by the US side,but also a series of political decisions made by Saudi Arabia,an oil producer and exporter,after considering various internal and external factors. These factors include the goals of economic interests in the great period of oil development,the anti-communist goals during the Cold War,the need to maintain regional stability after the Iranian revolution,and the need to stabilize the regime after the 9/11 incident. As one of the world’s largest countries in terms of crude oil reserve,Saudi Arabia’s decision-making mechanism for oil policy has profound international and domestic roots and has an important impact on the direction of the international energy market and the US-Saudi relationship of energy security. During the era of Salman and the Trump administration,the US-Saudi alliance is temporarily strengthened. In the future,this energy security relationship will continue to be maintained,but Saudi Arabia’s new round of oil policy changes will further touch the sensitive nerves of the relationship between the two countries. At the same time,due to the transformation of the US energy status,the internal division of OPEC,the "Vienna Alliance"formed among the non-OPEC countries such as Saudi Arabia and Russia and the renewed sanctions by the United States on Iran and other factors,the US-Saudi Arabia energy security relationship will face more tests.

title_en: On "Compulsory Arbitration" in the Dispute Settlement Mechanism of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea
abstract_en: The mandatory character of the dispute settlement mechanism in the UNCLOS is reflected in the aspect of "compulsory arbitration",that is,when the parties to a dispute cannot make the same choice from the four dispute settlement modes,the procedure of arbitration will be initiated as the "residual method".Compulsory arbitration cannot be applied in all cases,however,restrictions has been imposed on it by the UNCLOS.Seen from the perspective of practice,it seems that "compulsory arbitration"is not favored among nations,especially when the arbitral tribunal greatly expands its jurisdiction beyond the provisions of the UNCLOS.Recently,some nations refused to participate in the compulsory arbitration,such as Russia in the Arctic Sunrise Case and China in the South China Sea Case.This is the biggest issue faced by the mechanism of "compulsory arbitration"in the near future.If the compulsory arbitration cannot go back on the right track mandated by the UNCLOS,it will face more challenges in the future.

title_en: The Great Power Game of Sovereignty and Human Rights Principles in the Syrian Conflict
abstract_en: State behavior is determined by national interests,but state behavior is also affected by international norms. This is the case with the actions of the participating forces in the Syrian conflict,which are driven by interests on the one hand and influenced by norms such as the principles of sovereignty and human rights on the other.Although the participants in the Syrian conflict believe that the principles of sovereignty and human rights are both important and should be observed,in order to realize their respective interests well,they have shown different preferences for the two normative principles in their interaction: the interfering parties have shown a preference of“human rights principles take precedence over sovereignty principles”; anti-interventionists have shown a preference of “sovereignty principles take precedence over human rights principles”. In this way,the international normative question of “which is first,the principle of sovereignty or the principle of human rights”arises in the interactions between the two sides. This kind of interactive behaviors mainly includes: the struggle over whether to implement the “responsibility to protect”against Syria; the struggle over chemical weapons attacks in Syria; and the struggle over cross-border humanitarian assistance to Syria. In international struggle,it is of great significance for a country to accurately grasp the normative issues in the process of struggle to maintain the consistency of its international discourse and enhance its international discourse power.

title_en: Weaponisation of global financial public goods and their formation mechanisms
abstract_en: The weaponization of global financial public goods in this article refers to the United States and Western countries implementing global financial public goods as weapons in international competition, and imposing financial sanctions on other countries. Such policies requires several pre-conditions. First, Western countries have the privilege in providing such global public goods. Second, the United States have such hegemonic power over global financial public goods, and is capable of requiring allies to “take sides”. Third, trends of globalization made it difficult for sanctioned countries to get rid of their high dependence on global financial public goods. Fourth,weaponisation of global financial public goods would bring political benefits to the West countries. The above conditions led the Western countries to weaponize the global financial public good as main policy tool for suppressing their geopolitical rivals.

title_en: "Relying on China" or "Suppressing China": Analysing Vietnam's Diplomacy after the 12th Congress of the Communist Party of Vietnam (CPV)
abstract_en: Based on an analysis of the diplomatic practice of the Eleventh Central Committee of the Communist Party of Vietnam,this paper explores the diplomacy after the 12 th National Congress of Vietnam Communist Party. Stabilizing the relations with China and limiting China’s pressure and influence on Vietnam,will be the main line of Vietnamese diplomacy. The United States can contain China and in the South China Sea and it is strongly criticizing China on the issue of the South China Sea,which moves in line with the interests of Vietnam objectively,therefore,the Vietnamese diplomacy towards the US will be more active. The four neighboring countries contributed most to the Vietnamese efforts to "deter"China in the past five years,so they will still be the main objectives of Vietnamese diplomacy in the future to get more international forces that will be helpful to "deter"China. Vietnam will also "deter"the Chinese influence in its neighboring countries. Finally,it discusses several features of Vietnam’s diplomacy:（ 1） why treating the South China Sea like the East China Sea becomes a mainline Vietnam’s diplomacy;（ 2） the values of a favorable international environment and rich experience to Vietnam’s diplomacy;（ 3） why the relations of China and Vietnam with third countries are inversely related;（ 4） close economic ties do not imply close political relations;（ 5） pointing out Vietnam’s value is not high inany set of the bilateral relations with a discussion of Vietnam’s diplomacy.

title_en: Turkey's Dilemma in the Syrian Crisis: Causes and Prospects
abstract_en: Turkey’s domestic challenges and diplomatic predicaments are intertwined in the Syrian crisis.Turkey’s policy towards Syria is facing multiple predicaments such as the failure of the policy of overthrowing Bashar al-Assad,the emergence of the Kurdish militia in Syria by taking a ride with the trends,the backfire of the "Islamic State",the refugee problems,and diplomatic dilemmas.The very reasons are that the Justice and Development Party in Turkey is pursuing both Neo-Ottomanism and sectarianism,trying to reshape the order of the Middle East to compete for regional dominance by using Syria as a strategic fulcrum.The main internal causes include Turkey has misjudged the evolution of the Syrian crisis situation by overestimating its own strength and influence.The intricate gaming of extraregional powers and regional powers in Syria is the external cause that exacerbates the predicaments of Turkey’s policy towards Syria.For Turkey’s policy towards Syria to get out of the predicaments,it depends on the realist adjustments for diplomacy of the Justice and Development Party on the one hand;and it will also be influenced by the struggle of the United States and Russia in the Middle East,and the organizational factors of the Kurdistan and the "Islamic State" on the other hand.

title_en: Erdogan's Domestic and Foreign Affairs Adjustments after the Attempted Coup in Turkey
abstract_en: The failed military coup in July 2016 represents the culmination of Turkey’s domestic political power struggle. After the political cleansing and reform following the failed military coup,the process of re-Islamization in Turkey has been clearly accelerating,the military-political relations have reversed,the tutelary democracy has collapsed,the process of political reform with the presidential system as its core has accelerated,the situation in which the Justice and Development Party dominates is established,the social controls and the supervision of public opinion have been tightening,and the power of Erdogan regime has strengthened unprecedentedly. The failed military coup also led to the loss of the exemplary role of the Turkish Islamic democracy,worsening Turkey’s relations with the West,and stimulating Erdogan to speed up the adjustment of diplomatic direction to return to realism by mending the broken relations with Russia and actively improving relations with countries in the region to achieve a heterogeneous balance of foreign policy.

title_en: International attitudes towards R2P Pillar III - a preliminary analytical framework based on factors + mechanisms
abstract_en: Overall,the Responsibility to Protect（R2P） has become a basic consensus of the international society,with different degrees of acceptance for its three pillars.The controversy is primarily concerning whether the Pillar Three can be accepted by the international society,especially by the permanent members of the UN Security Council.As to the normative process of R2P,the positive or negative attitudes of each country stem from some similar considerations,so a unified analytical framework might exist.In view of this,this paper attempts to give a preliminary analytical framework of factor+mechanism.The differences in countries’ attitudes towards the Pillar Three are rooted in their varied positions on sovereignty and the principle of non-interference.Therefore,there is a need to consider factors that affect countries’ attitudes towards intervention.These factors can be divided into the two areas:the possibility of countries to be intervened and the possibility of countries to intervene.The variables that affect the likelihood of being intervened are mainly national power and the extent of domestic fragmentation,while the factors that affect the likelihood of intervening are overseas interests and negative externalities.

title_en: A test analysis of the prospects for the development of relations between Europe and the United States in the new situation
abstract_en: In the context of the profound evolution of the international system and the changes in the security order in Europe,the relationship between Europe and the United States during the Obama administration was strengthened because of the common guidelines of liberalism and Atlanticism. Trump,the newly elected President of the United States,is giving a dissenting voice on the transatlantic security alliance,the trade relations between Europe and the United States,European integration and other topics from those of his predecessor,Obama,causing great concerns of the European allies about the uncertainty over European-American Relations in the future. In view of Trump’s idea of governing of "America First"and the elevation of the political influence of extreme rightwing across the Atlantic,the relationship between Europe and the United States will encounter the dominance of the interests of nation states,populism,market protectionism,and a crisis of multilateralism and many other challenges. The United States and Europe will make a pragmatic compromise on the burden-sharing in the security alliance out of their own consideration for long-term strategic and realistic needs,while liberalism retrogrades toward nationalism to varying degrees,and this ideological change will determine the prospects of the development of the relations between Europe and the United States.

title_en: Sino-Russian-American relations and international structure: from multipolarity to bipolarity?
abstract_en: Unipolarism has set the theme of the international structure in the early days of post-Cold War; it then gave way to the overwhelming multipolarism. However,the rise of bipolarism in recent years has posed challenges against multipolarism,wherein,the two poles refer to China and the US,and their basic indicator is defined by the economic aggregate. Nevertheless,bipolarism has not yet gained unanimous consensus as China still has incomplete aggregative indicator. The co-existence of bipolarity and multipolarity in subjective cognition and objective reality marks a unique phenomenon of today’s international structure,and their relations can be defined by a bipolar structure in a multipolar framework,or a multipolar structure with two dominant poles. This is a mirror of the complexity and contradiction of the international structure in reality,and the status will be maintained in the long run with a trend of forming stronger bipolar structure features. As one of the poles,China should be guided by the general theory and concept of multilateralism instead of multipolarism. Decoupled from any specific international structure,multilateralism enables China to remain unaffected by changes in its own status,align its diplomatic theory with varied international structures,and contribute to hold the theoretical basis of Sino-Russian international cooperation.

title_en: Regional Cooperation Practices Guided by the Community of Human Destinies: An Example of the Construction of the China-North Korea-Russia-Korea Economic Corridor in Connection with the Belt and Road Construction
abstract_en: In the progress of the concrete practice of a community of common destiny for mankind,we must not only consider the concept clarification and the policy interpretations of a community of common destiny for mankind,but also implement them in China’s foreign engagement and the interaction between China and the world,in order to explain the realistic process and future trend of a community of common destiny for mankind.The key to interpreting China’s strategy towards Northeast Asia is that China’s own development,especially after the construction of the Belt and Road being proposed and promoted,provides a corresponding opportunity for China to implement the concept of a community of common destiny for mankind in the context of regional cooperation.For the specific process of linking the construction of the Belt and Road with the construction of the China-North/South Korea-Russia economic corridor,China can rely on the relevant ideas of the construction of the China-North/South Korea-Rus  sia economic corridor to exhibit the relevant layout and specific processes of China’s foreign engagement in the concrete practice of implementing the concept of community of common destiny for mankind.

title_en: The situation in the Middle East has taken on two new dimensions
abstract_en: ＜The first point of view is the Middle East policy of the United States after Trump took office. At present, it is difficult to see the complete framework of Trump's Middle East policy, mainly because Trump's specific Middle East policy ideas are in conflict with each other and lack of internal logic. However, it is certain that Trump's idiosyncratic behaviour cannot escape the constraints of the Middle East situation and US domestic politics. First of all, in the counter-terrorism policy and Syria policy, Trump has always stressed the priority of eliminating the "Islamic State" organisation, and hinted that he might cooperate with the Bashar regime in Syria as well as Russia in the fight against the "Islamic State" organisation, which is basically because he is unwilling to be involved in another war due to counter-terrorism issues. Trump also stressed that

title_en: Reflections on the interface between the "Belt and Road" and the development strategies of the pivotal countries along the Central Asian route
abstract_en: The successful advancement of the Belt and Road Initiative in the Central Asia depends on the policy communication and strategic docking between China and the Central Asian countries along the routes,especially the hub countries. Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan can be regarded as hub countries. By docking China’s Silk Road Economic Belt Initiative and Kazakhstan’s New Economic Policy named the Bright Road,China and Kazakhstan are expected to carry out intensive cooperation in the three fields of infrastructure,production capacity and finance. By synergizing China’s Silk Road Economic Belt Initiative with Uzbekistan’s Development Action Strategy,China and Uzbekistan are expected to carry out intensive cooperation in the fields of infrastructure,trade,investment and agriculture. The alignment between the Belt and Road Initiative and development strategies of Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan will not only propel the two countries to become the hubs of the Eurasian connectivity,but also help cope with the challenges brought by COVID-19 Pandemic to the economic cooperation between China and the two countries. However,it is also needed to invite Russia to jointly align the development strategy needs of the hub countries along Central Asian.

title_en: Patterns and paths of interface between the institutional design of the Eurasian Economic Union and the Belt and One Alliance
abstract_en: Eurasian Economic Union is an important institutional arrangement for regional integration. As a result of institutional design,Eurasian Economic Union is confronted with the challenges from a complex relationship between institutional legitimacy and effectiveness in the development course. This complex relationship not only restricts the development of Eurasian Economic Union,but also offects behaviors of Eurasian Economic Union. China and Eurasian Economic Union member countries have formed "5 + 1"Mode（ "Eurasian Economic Union + China"） and five separate "1 +1"modes（ "China + Members of Eurasian Economic Union"） in the practice of engagement with "The Belt and Union ". The"5 + 1 "mode explores the construction paths from the economic and trade agreement to the free trade zone,while the "1 + 1"mode developes the construction paths from project cooperation to engagement of national development strategy. Both mode and path have laid a solid foundation for engagement of "The Belt and Union".

title_en: The Third Huaihai Forum "Disorder or Normal Power Shift? --Great Power Relations in Post-Ukraine Crisis and South China Sea Tensions" was successfully held.
abstract_en: ＜The 3rd Huaihai Forum on Great Power Relations, co-organised by the Institute of International Relations of the Shanghai Academy of Social Sciences (SASS) and the Shanghai Association for Cultural Exchanges with Foreign Countries (SACEFC), was successfully held on 22-23 November 2015 in the auditorium of the Shanghai Academy of Social Sciences (SASS). The theme of this year's forum was "Disorder or Normal Power Shift - Great Power Relations in the Post-Ukraine Crisis and South China Sea Tension", and scholars from the United States, Russia, France, South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Belgium, together with scholars from Fudan University, Peking University, Renmin University of China, the Foreign Affairs College, the Shanghai Academy of Social Sciences and the Shanghai Institute of Foreign Cultural Exchange, attended the forum.

title_en: The first session of the strategic dialogue between Russian and Chinese think tanks was held
abstract_en: ＜The first Sino-Russian Think Tank Strategic Dialogue Conference "Challenges and Security and Economic Cooperation in Northeast Asia" was held on July 4 at the Shanghai Academy of Social Sciences. The international conference was co-organised by the Institute of International Studies of the Academy and the China-Russia-Central Asia Cooperation Research Centre. The conference pointed out that the security situation in East Asia is complicated. The U.S. and Japan are increasing their military and diplomatic encirclement of China through the "Asia-Pacific rebalance" strategy; tensions on the Korean Peninsula are developing further: the DPRK's nuclear and nuclear-related activities have become more and more serious.

title_en: Docking and Linkage: Building the Interest Chain of the Silk Road Economic Belt
abstract_en: At present,the construction of the economic belt of the Silk Road is in the assessment process of the projects,the rules,and the ways. The main affecting factors of building the interest chain are the changes in the external environment of the economic belt of the Silk Road and the presence of the gap between vision and reality of the countries along the Silk Road in terms of the Eurasian identity,the charisma of the pattern,and the driving force of the great power. The possible option of driving the economic belt of the Silk Road into the period of practice is to pay attention to the objective commonness of interests,the subjective construction,the realistic linkages and potential ties,the external challenges,and the cooperative cohesion with the "interest chain of the Silk Road"composed of individual,regional and multilateral interests to be built by the agenda,regional and industrial dovetailing and interlinking approach.

title_en: Summary of the seminar on "World in Transition: Great Power Relations and the Evolution of the International Landscape"
abstract_en: ＜On the occasion of the 100th anniversary of World War I and the 70th anniversary of the victory in the World Anti-Fascist War, the Shanghai Society of World History, the European Society and the Russian Society of Eastern Europe and Central Asia jointly organised an inter-society youth forum on "The World in Transition: Great Power Relations and the Evolution of the International Landscape". Wang Kemei, Director of the Department of Academic Societies of the Federation of Societies, delivered a speech at the forum, while Yu Jianhua, Vice-President of the World History Association and Vice-President of the Society of Russia, East Europe and Central Asia, and Cao Ziheng, Secretary General of the Society of Europe, presided over the meeting. Meng Zhongjie, Professor of the Department of History of East China Normal University, Li Kaisheng, Associate Researcher of the Institute of International Relations of Shanghai Academy of Social Sciences, Liu Jun, Professor of the Institute of International Relations and Regional Development of East China Normal University, Zhang Ji, Doctor of the School of International Relations and Public Affairs of Fudan University, Shanghai

title_en: Impact of economic globalisation on the strategic culture of emerging powers
abstract_en: The current transformation of the international system inevitably has a significant impact on the strategic culture of the major Powers. The new factors brought about by the transformation of the international system to strategic culture include: the internal and external factors affecting strategic culture have become more complex and diversified; consultation and cooperation have become the main means of settling international disputes; and there is a tendency for the strategic cultures of the major Powers to converge. Against this background, although the strategic cultures of the emerging powers (BRICS) have different historical manifestations, their strategic cultures are similar based on common historical opportunities and similar international status. The impact of economic globalisation on the strategic cultures of the emerging Powers is manifested in the following ways: first, it has changed the strategic thinking mode of the emerging Powers, which used to attach importance to ideology; second, it has led the emerging Powers to form a new mode of win-win relations in terms of competition and co-operation with the existing Powers; and, third, it has changed the emerging Powers' perceptions of the international organisations, and has attached importance to making use of the platform of the existing international mechanisms in pursuit of their national interests.

title_en: Progress, challenges and reflections on the development of the Trans-Caspian International Transport Corridor
abstract_en: The Trans-Caspian International Transport Route（TITR） starts from China,running through Kazakhstan, the Caspian Sea, the South Caucasus, overland to Turkey, also reach to other parts of Europe through the Black Sea. Since the escalation of the Russia-Ukraine conflict in 2022, freight traffic along the TITR has grown rapidly,making the TITR one of the alternative routes to the Northern Corridor. It is expected that by 2030, the freight volume through the Caspian Sea along the TITR will increase to three times its 2021 level, reaching 11 million tons. China’s participation in the construction of the TITR will contribute to high-quality Belt and Road Initiative cooperation, avoid geo-economic risks caused by geopolitical conflicts in the Eurasian continent to achieve the balanced and diversified development of the northern, central and southern lines of the China-Europe Railway Corridor. At the same time, the construction of the TITR also faces challenges such as cargo delays due to low transportation capacity, relatively backward infrastructure such as railways and ports, interruptions of cargo transportation due to climate change in the Caspian Sea, and differences in attitudes of stakeholders.
