China and the countries along the corridor can promote the construction of the TITR by improving the efficiency of multimodal transportation along the TITR, strengthening the electrification of railways and the construction of port transportation capacity along the TITR, jointly addressing impacts of climate change in the Caspian Sea, and stimulating the economic and social development of the regions along the TITR.

title_en: Analysing the dilemma and way out for the development of the BRICS countries in the context of the "circle of dependence".
abstract_en: The growth rates among the BRIC countries have been on the decline since 2012,so those countries are facing a crisis of "color fading"and the development of the BRIC countries needs to be revisited.From the perspective of unequal relations among countries,the authors argue that the BRIC countries are still in a peripheral position in the international system and their development depends on Western developed countries.In order to get out of the dependency predicament,the BRIC countries must recognize the development difficulties such as the obstruction from the international community,a lack of technological innovation on their own,and widening wealth gaps within their borders.Therefore,they should strengthen practical cooperation in terms of enhancing the consensus on development,eliminating the influence of neo-colonialism and adjusting economic structure.As the "leader"among them,the role of China is crucial to the development of the BRIC countries.

title_en: Strategic Review of India's "Connecting Central Asia Policy"
abstract_en: As a rising power and a participant of the ancient Silk Road,India has launched a strategy of"Connect to Central Asia Policy,"hoping to connect with the Eurasian continent through Central Asia in order to develop relations and to promote economic and trade exchanges with the countries in the region.In terms of the path,India’s new strategy includes the two parts of hardware and software,the former is based on the construction of traffic and energy channels,the latter is manifested in the negotiation of free trade area and joining the regional international organizations.In terms of measures,India is promoting the South-North traffic corridors and TAPI energy channels,linking to the Eurasian Union,and joining the Shanghai Cooperation Organization.India’s new strategy has made some progress,but it is also facing some great challenges,its domestic issues,India-Pakistan relations,the situation in Afghanistan,Iran’s nuclear crisis and the dynamics of great powers’game in Central A-sia have a great impact on the strategy.

title_en: The German Nuclear Deterrence Debate: Background, Focus and Implications
abstract_en: The German debate on nuclear deterrence has long been considered a“phantom debate”. Germany has had little response to either the U. S. proposal for“extended deterrence”or the French proposal for European deterrent force based on France and Germany. Since the 21st century,a series of factors such as the transformation and upgrading of U. S. and Russian strategic nuclear forces,the geopolitical changes in Europe due to the 2014 Ukraine crisis,and the Trump administration’s threat to withdraw the nuclear umbrella from Europe have set the stage for a new round of nuclear deterrence debates in Germany since 2016. The debate has centered on how Germany and Europe can be secured assuming the loss of the U. S. nuclear umbrella.This comprehensive,public,and ongoing debate and media coverage is particularly rare in Germany,where the debate itself caused a “political earthquake”. Multiple“nuclear options”are under discussion: pan-European deterrence or European deterrence,indigenous German nuclear deterrence and maintaining Germany’s nuclear potential. The debate is an important attempt by Germany to play a more active role in building European security and defense,to break the nuclear taboo,and to “test the waters”for nuclear ownership. Following the outbreak of the Russia-Ukraine conflict,2022 has seen new developments in the German nuclear deterrence debate that may have significant implications for future European security.

title_en: Challenges and opportunities for the EU in 2016
abstract_en: This paper argues that it is difficult for Europe to completely solve the Ukrainian crisis and the refugee crisis in 2016,but both crises can still be controlled through the efforts of the EU and its member states. Meanwhile,responding to the threat of terrorist attacks will be the top priority for Europe in 2016. In terms of European integration,there is a good chance that the UK will hold the referendum on its membership of the European Union in 2016,but the results of the referendum are hard to tell. Regardless of the referendum outcome,it will have a considerable negative impact on European integration,although this does not mean that the EU will disinte-grate. It is worth noting that the economic situation in Europe is more sanguine in2016,the Greek debt crisis can be eased and controlled,and the EU’s GDP growth rate is likely to exceed 2. 1%. Looking forward,the outlook of Europe seems to show the sign of the early light of dawn.

title_en: Theory and Practice: Basic Curriculum for the Discipline of International Relations
abstract_en: ＜The development of diplomatic practice and the innovation of theoretical research require the discipline of international relations to train more complex talents. When it comes to teaching, it is necessary to take into account both theoretical and practical needs when setting up basic courses for undergraduates. In this regard, our neighbouring country, Russia, has experience that we should learn from.

title_en: Summary of the Symposium on "Geopolitical Changes in the Middle East and Middle East Diplomacy of Great Powers with Chinese Characteristics"
abstract_en: ＜Sponsored by the Institute of International Studies of the Shanghai Academy of Social Sciences (SASS), the Middle East Society of China (MESC), and the Shanghai Society of World History (SSWH), co-sponsored by the Gulf Research Centre of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences (GRCS), and hosted by the Innovation Team of International Security Disciplines of the Shanghai Academy of Social Sciences (SASS), the Symposium on Geopolitical Changes in the Middle East and Middle East Diplomacy of the Great Powers of China with Special Characteristics (MIDPAC) was held on 12-13 April at the SASS. The symposium was held on 12-13 April at the Shanghai Academy of Social Sciences (SASS), and the participants came from many research institutes and colleges in Beijing, Shaanxi, Henan, Yunnan, Ningxia and Shanghai.

title_en: Comparative analysis of the Asia-Europe Meeting (ASEM) enlargement process under the "two-key principle"
abstract_en: To date,five rounds of enlargement of Asia-Europe Meeting（ ASEM） has been achieved. In addition to the general conditions,every candidate country must also comply with "two-key approach". In other words,every candidate country must at first obtain the support within its region,and then obtain the unanimous consent of all members of ASEM. In this process,EU and ASEAN play a key role in deciding on new membership. The entire enlargement process of ASEM can fall into three different categories: The first category is the membership admission of the respective EU members and ASEAN members. The second category is the process that Asian and European countries beyond the traditionally dominant regions of the EU and ASEAN join ASEM. The third category is the process that other countries with ambiguous regional identity join ASEM. Although ASEM is no longer a small-scale forum between the EU and the East Asia as both blocs,the EU and ASEAN have always been committed to maintaining the interregional characteristics of ASEM. In recent years, although ASEM has significantly slowed the pace of enlargement,under the new situation of Asia-Europe connectivity,a new enlargement process with more clear-cut directions and more distinct goals is worth looking forward to.

title_en: International law analyses and reflections on the establishment of an Arctic nuclear-weapon-free zone
abstract_en: Two major security threats faced by the mankind in the 21 st century are the effects of environmental change and the hazard of nuclear weapons,and the Arctic area is experiencing such a test because of its unique geographical location. In2007 the Canadian Pugwash Group advocated for establishing an Arctic NWFZ（ nuclear-weapon-free zone）,attracting a wide attention from the world. Although the legal systems such nuclear arms control treaties and resolutions of the UN General Assembly provides a basis of international law to establish an Arctic NWFZ,the establishment of the Arctic NWFZ involves the conclusion and entry into force of a multilateral treaty,as well as the obligations and responsibilities of the participants and other issues. As a nuclear-weapon country in the northern hemisphere,China also has both international and domestic law basis for the participation in security governance in the Arctic. Based on this,currently we can refer to the existing experience such as the Treaty of Tlatelolco and the Treaty of Rarotonga to explore the specific ways of establishing the Arctic NWFZ from the two different perspectives of the Arctic and non-Arctic states.

title_en: China's South China Sea Reef Construction and the Reactions of Extraterritorial Powers
abstract_en: From September 2013 onward,China began its staged construction on the islands and reefs in the South China Sea. In the meantime,Jane’s Defense Weekly in Britain and the Center for Strategic and International Studies in the U. S. published relevant photos,commentaries and reports in succession,causing widespread repercussions of the international community. According to their different national interests,extraterritorial powers responded differently at political,economic,military and diplomatic level. This paper attempts to explore the manifestations,causes and effects of the reaction of the five extraterritorial powers,i. e. the United States,Japan,Australia,India and Russia,and then propose appropriate countermeasures.

title_en: The dilemma of advancing EU strategic autonomy in the context of the Russia-Ukraine conflict: an analysis from a two-tier EU perspective
abstract_en: The EU’s strategic autonomy has been a long-sought strategic goal with defense,economy,and technology. The Russia-Ukraine conflict has impacted the geopolitical landscape at the EU level,the international economic and trade system and security situation. On the one hand,the complexity of strategic game among the major powers caused by the Russia-Ukraine conflict has made the EU consider how to safeguard its own interests between China and the US. The Russia-Ukraine conflict has caused dramatic turmoil in the geo-security situation in Europe,and the US has taken the opportunity to strengthen its dominant position in European security and restrain the EU ’s strategic autonomy. Finally,the European economy has suffered multiple shocks and the risk of recession has increased. This series of chain reactions has widened the gap between EU’s own capabilities and the goal of strategic autonomy; at the level of the member states,differences old and new EU members have also affected the realization and development. Nevertheless,the Russia-Ukraine conflict has strengthened the EU’s determination to pursue strategic autonomy. EU’s strategic autonomy currently focuses on defense and economic security. EU should reduce the impact of the Russia-Ukraine conflict on EU’s industrial and supply chains. The EU continues to set strategic autonomy as a future strategic direction on which to base its internal and external policies and actions.

title_en: Overview of changes in the Middle East
abstract_en: The upheaval in the Middle East since late 2010 is a phase product of the post-war nation-state building and the tortuous course of social development in the Middle East,the third wave of social and political changes after the nationalist revolution and the Islamic revivalist movement in the Middle East since the Second World War,and a regional manifestation of the major changes,major adjustments,and major developments of the global political and economic system in the post-Cold War era.The fundamental cause of this turbulent wave of the social and political changes in the Middle East stems from the internal structural conflicts in the modernization process of Arab countries.It not only has obvious characteristics such as suddenness,conductibility,and a domino effect,it also makes the Arab world in the Middle East into a sensitive period of social turbulence or a period more prone to political crises in which complicated and uncertain factors are evident.And they will continue to be so in the profound and difficult process of social transformation,developing in the general direction of"from changes,comes chaos;from chaos,comes governance"during the regional turmoil and pains.The changes in the Middle East over these years have had an important and widespread impact on regional politics and hotspot issues.Nowadays and in the years ahead,the balance of the strategic strength in the Middle East and the changes in international relations of the region are in a transition period in which they are from deconstruction,reconstruction to rebalancing.Facing the social and politic turmoil in the Middle East,major countries（groups）in the world,such as the United States,the EU and Russia,are actively planning their new Middle East strategies or making adjustments in relevant policies as well in order to be more favorable to maintain their strategic positions and interests in the Middle East.

title_en: Disorder or Normal Power Shift: Great Power Relations in Post-Ukrainian Crisis and South China Sea Tensions--Review of the 3rd Huaihai International Forum on Great Power Relations
abstract_en: ＜In recent years, there have been numerous regional hotspot issues on a global scale, from the Arab Spring to the Islamic State (IS), from the Ukraine crisis to the tension in the South China Sea, the emergence of old and new geopolitical contradictions has had a significant impact on the transformation of the current international order, and the game and cooperation between major powers, such as China, the United States, Russia, and Europe, have been further complicated. Against this background of international power game and international order change, the Institute of International Relations of Shanghai Academy of Social Sciences and Shanghai Association for Cultural Exchange with Foreign Countries jointly hosted the 3rd Huaihai International Forum on Great Power Relations, with the theme of "Disorder or Power Shift: Great Power Relations under the Tension of Post-Ukrainian Crisis and the South China Sea", and many famous scholars and experts from home and abroad.

title_en: International Symposium on "International Order in Transition" Held by the International Institute for International Studies
abstract_en: ＜On 14-15 October, the fourth Huaihai International Forum, co-sponsored by the Institute of International Studies of the Shanghai Academy of Social Sciences (SASS) and the Shanghai Association for Cultural Exchanges with Foreign Countries (SACECO), was held in the academy. The forum focused on the theme of "International Order in Transition: Global Challenges and Governance", and experts and scholars from China, the United States, Russia, the United Kingdom, Japan, South Korea, France, Iran and other countries attended the forum to discuss the challenges, opportunities, and good measures to deal with the transition of the current international order. The forum is centred on the "US rebalancing strategy in the post-Obama era", "instability in the Asia-Pacific region", "Russia's role in the world", "the role of the United States", and "the role of the United States".

title_en: Changes in the International Environment in 70 Years of New China's Diplomacy: Phasing, Evolution and Dynamics
abstract_en: During the 70 years of the establishment and development of the People’s Republic of China,the international environment has undergone profound changes by transitioning from the Cold War period of the US-Soviet confrontation to the multi-polarization period after the Cold War.The fact of increasing number and types of actors in the international environment,increasing complexity of international structure,and richer contents and fields of international topics shows developmental lines of the international environment that have gone from simple to complex and from fragmentation to integration.At present,the changes in the international structure have entered a critical period,the situation in which multiple processes coexist and compete will continue,and scientific and technological progress will continue to promote changes in the international environment.In the process of changing international environment,China is both an involved actor and an important force in promoting the changes of international environment.

title_en: Transnational Grid Development and Geopolitical Constructs
abstract_en: Transnational power grid is becoming an important energy carrier in the carbon-neutral era,and it can become a powerful tool for a country to shape a specific geopolitical order. According to the relational theory,this paper points out that countries can take the development of transnational power grid as a mode of relational operation,which could construct geopolitical relation in a particular region. There are at least three types of geopolitical relations constructed by transnational power grid: first,the network of political power,which creates a power grid dominated by one country and pursues the centrality of relationship; second,security network,which replaces the current power grid and pursues the security of relationship; third,communication network,which advocates new power grid construction and pursues the tightness of relationship. The impact of transnational power grid development on geopolitics is diverse,which may not only promote regional peace and stability,but also become a tool for individual countries to expand their power and court others． “Belt and Road Initiative”transnational power interconnection is a kind of “depoliticized ”cooperation,which does not undertake the intention or task of shaping geopolitics,but China should guard against the aggressive behaviors of other countries,and constantly enhance the openness and inclusiveness of cooperation.

title_en: Composite mechanism model: theoretical and practical directions for building the BRICS mechanism
abstract_en: A regime complex mainly refers to the complexity among the relations of mechanisms.Combined with the hierarchy and the forms of international mechanisms,such a regime complex can be designed as a model of a"mechanism of informal dialogue+formal binding mechanism",which has an important impact on the countries that are the main actors in international mechanisms.The BRICS mechanisms are in the process of institutionalization,in which a model of the regime complex is one of the important directions.In theory,a model of"informal dialogue mechanism+formal binding mechanism"for the BRICS cooperation mechanisms not only ensures the credibility of the mechanisms,but also maintains the flexibility of them.In practice,the establishment of the regime complex model of"informal dialogue mechanism+formal binding mechanism"realizes the unification of the theory and the practice of the institutionalization of mechanisms.The model of"informal dialogue mechanism+formal binding mechanism"is helpful to deal with the relations among the BRICS countries and the problem of the relationship between great powers and mechanisms,promoting the institutionalization and development of the BRICS cooperation mechanisms.

title_en: RAND Senior Researcher Dr. Tao-Ann Shih visited our institute.
abstract_en: ＜On the morning of May 29, Dr. Andrew Scobell, a senior researcher at the RAND Corporation, an American think tank, visited the Institute, and was received by Liu Ming, Executive Deputy Director of the Institute, Li Kaisheng, Deputy Director of the Think Tank Construction Division of the Institute, Zhang Jianrong, Deputy Director of the Centre for Russian Studies, and Li Lifan, Secretary General of the Centre for Shanghai-China Joint Cooperation (SJCJC) Studies. Dr Shi Dao'an is currently the chair of the US-China-Russia Relations Programme.

title_en: The "Belt and Road" Strategy and the Geo-Reshaping of the Neighbourhood
abstract_en: The Belt and Road Initiatives is transformed into a strategy,an important strategy pursued by China for diplomacy in the new era. They have far-reaching geopolitical implications and will play a role in reshaping the peripheral geopolitics.From a geostrategic point of view,the strategy of the Belt and Road Initiatives will help China to expand the geo-environment,integrate the geo-political,security and economic factors,gain the geo-affection,strengthen the geo-relations,and release the geo-economic energy,playing a positive role in reshaping the geopolitics in the periphery. However,the strategy of the Belt and Road Initiatives will likely intensify the geopolitical competition among great powers in China’s periphery,increase the spreading of geo-risks among the countries along the lines,and trigger a linked movement of the internal and external forces of Tibetan separatists and East Turkistan separatists at the same time. In order to implement the strategy of the Belt and Road Initiatives more effectively and promote an optimization of the peripheral geo-environment,we should let the geo-economy to be dominated in terms of the operation of geo-factors while keep an eye on other geo-effects,reduce geo-risks on the principle of rule-based cooperation,and achieve a co-ordination of multiple geo-factors from holistic perspectives.

title_en: The international situation in 2017 will enter a period of turbulence and reorganisation of relations between major powers - concluding remarks of the seminar "Prospects for the International Situation in 2017".
abstract_en: ＜The departure of the United Kingdom from the European Union and the election of Donald Trump as president of the United States in 2016 signalled the beginning of a major change in the international order. As the US is still a superpower, the fact that a headstrong and capricious businessman, who has risen from a completely apolitical system, is the president of the US will have a major impact on the US domestic and foreign policies as well as on the post-war international order. Trump's foreign policy philosophy may be the offensive isolationism of "I am the only one who is strong, I am the only one who is honourable, I am the only one who is right" and the extreme egoism of "America first", in which isolationism indicates that he will no longer assume the responsibility of safeguarding the "rule of the United States of America".

title_en: Path Dependency and National Autonomy of "Putinism"
abstract_en: Putinism is a generic term used to describe the political ideology and reform measures characterized with " nationalism" of the Russian President Vladimir Putin. Based on the theory of path dependence in both new institutional politics and historical institutionalism and seen from the historical and realistic perspective,this paper analyses the inheritance,feasibility,sustainability and the internal contradiction of Putinism and investigates the deepening way of transition reforms in Russia.

title_en: Impact of the principle of supply-demand balance on the success or failure of strategic alignment between countries
abstract_en: Countries need to focus on the principle of the balance of supply and demand in the process of strategic dovetailing. The countries that supply and the countries that demand should control the content and extent of strategic dovetailing to ensure it within the range of supply capacity and acceptable costs between them. When the supply amount or the demand amount goes beyond the maximum of the other side,the relationship of the balance of supply and demand will be broken and the strategic dovetailing cannot be achieved. To manage the cooperative contradiction is the key to maintain the sustainability of strategic dovetailing. And it requires the dovetailing countries actively to build bilateral or multilateral mechanisms,enhance the flexibility of the relations between supply and demand through international mechanisms,prevent contradictions of cooperation to become contradictions of competition,and keep the points of strategic dovetailing among them at the best position that is beneficial to both sides,ensuring the durability of the relations of strategic dovetailing.

title_en: Sino-Russian-European Energy Competition in Central Asia - Geopolitical and Interdependence Constraints
abstract_en: Central Asia has exhibited a complex structure of geopolitics and geo- economy because of its special geographical location and advantages of resource,and has become a focal point of international relations since the end of the Cold War.This article first explains the features in the evolution of the positions of China,Russia,and the EU in the energy landscape of Central Asia from the perspective of the great power relations,analyzes the impact of geopolitical factors on the energy relationships among China,Russia,and the EU as well as the constraints of the mutual interdependence of energy on the geopolitical competition on the basis of its explanations,and finally explore the possibilities and the paths of energy dialogue and cooperation in Central Asia among China,Russia,and the EU.

title_en: Militarisation and weaponisation of space and its governance
abstract_en: The militarization of space is characterized by the fact that satellites are widely used in the military field,with a lot of dedicated military satellites used to enhance strategic nuclear deterrent capability and other conventional military power,acting as force multipliers. The weaponization of space is to deploy offensive weapons in space for the purpose of striking the targets in space and the Earth. The international community has made extensive efforts to manage space militarization and weaponization since the Cold War era. At present,the international community focuses on the ban on the weaponization of space,having launched many initiatives. Because of many reasons,the international community has only limited success in the governance of space weaponization.

title_en: Analysis of new trends in Russian-Turkish geostrategic competition in the Black Sea
abstract_en: The Black Sea region has important strategic significance to the regional relations as well as international relations around the world. The geopolitical influence in the region can radiate to Russia,Central Asia,and the Middle East and surrounding areas.The region is considered as an important region for geostrategic and ideological competition by the U. S.,EU,Russia,and other countries and regions. This paper mainly analyzes the geostrategic changes of Russia and Turkey in the Black Sea region,examines the geopolitical transformation of the Black Sea region,investigates the new policies towards the Black Sea coastal countries of the two countries after the Russian-Georgian war,and focuses on the geostrategic characteristics of Russia,Turkey,and Western countries in the Black Sea region,to analyze and forecast the new trends in geostrategic development in the Black Sea region.

title_en: Reclaiming Cold War Thinking Focusing on Great Power Competition - Analysing and Interpreting the Report on the US National Security Strategy from a Strategic Perspective
abstract_en: ＜The U.S. National Security Strategy report released by the Trump administration in December 2017, with a strong Trumpian colour, is a synthesis of President Trump's campaign rhetoric, governing ideas and Washington establishment thinking by his national security team over the past year since he took office, a roadmap for the Trump administration's domestic and foreign policies over the next three years, and a way to study

title_en: Thoughts on the construction of a new order from Kissinger's World Order
abstract_en: ＜I. Kissinger's Diagnosis of the Causes of the World Order Disorder In his new book World Order, Kissinger argues that the world is moving in the direction of partial disorder. The reason why he says partial disorder is because he thinks that the overall world order still exists and the competition is still within the normal controllable range. He pointed out that the international community was seen as potentially transcending any stage of history, but that at present it had not developed a clear and coherent set of goals, modalities, and constraints - on the one hand, there were all sorts of threats posed by chaos, and on the other hand, there was an unprecedented degree of interdependence. Kissinger attributes the chaos of the current world order to three deficiencies: (1) a Europe that transcends the state, where the main

title_en: Russia makes every effort to stabilise the situation (English)
abstract_en: ＜正＞In 2023, during the stalemated Russian–Ukrainian crisis, Russia has adjusted its internal and external policies, sought to preserve battlefield gains, explored economic reorganization, opened up a new diplomatic front, reinforced domestic stability, and generally stabilized the overall situation.

title_en: Russia's economic policy in response to the crisis and its effectiveness (in English)
abstract_en: The Russian economy has continued to grow since the Ukraine crisis broke out in 2022, beating expectations despite many challenges.Sustaining this steady performance are a series of economic policy measures implemented by the Russian government, which cover the fiscal, monetary, industrial, trade, counter-crisis, and counter-sanctions dimensions. Russia intends to ensure the smooth functioning of its national economy and meet the needs of its “special military operation”in Ukraine. The results of the past three years show that Russia’s economic policy has largely achieved its objectives by maintaining moderate economic growth while, to a cer tain extent, expediting the long-anticipated economic restructuring, enabling the Russian government to mobilize resources to fund its “special military operation.”It is noteworthy, however, that these policy measures have also caused side effects, such as economic overheating, labor shortages, and a shrinking civilian economy. In the long run, the Russian economy still faces difficulties that the current policy cannot effectively tackle.

title_en: Russia's accelerated "turn to the East" and its prospects in the context of the Ukrainian crisis (in English)
abstract_en: Following the beginning of the Ukraine crisis in 2022, Russia accelerated its so-called pivot to East, using diplomacy, trade, energy,infrastructure logistics, and identity, due to the rapid decoupling from Russia by the United States and the West across all directions. The timing, depth, and significance of this pivot to East are unparalleled,but its implementation continues to face much uncertainty. At present,this turn to East does not entail a permanent turn away from the West on the part of Russia, nor does it mean that Russia will only rely on the East, and still less does it imply any transformation of Russia’s national identity. On the contrary, as a center of sovereignty in the world and with its unique national civilization, Russia will continue to rely more on its own strength and shoulder its unique historical mission in the current period of change in the international order.

title_en: Strengthening Conservatism: Russia's Foreign Policy Posture (in English)
abstract_en: The political essence of Russian conservatism is to respect the historical tradition and take a development path aligned with Russia’s national conditions. Since Putin came to power, Russian conservatism has developed into the mainstream official ideology, becoming the core concept of Russia’s current domestic and foreign policies. Russian conservatism is not only the guiding principle of Russia’s national foreign policy, but it is also the moral banner of Russia’s diplomacy, which reflects its foreign cognition and value system. Under the guidance of conservatism, Russia’s foreign policy has distinct offensive features, and Russia has intensified its efforts to counter the liberal international order dominated by the West. After the escalation of the Ukraine crisis, the status of conservatism as Russia’s mainstream ideology has been further consolidated, exerting a comprehensive inf luence on foreign policy.Against the background of extreme sanctions and isolation from the United States and the West, Russia has turned its diplomatic attention to non-Western countries, hoping to build a new international order.

title_en: Russia's Critical Minerals Strategy from a National Security Perspective (in English)
abstract_en: With rapid progress in the global green transition over recent years, the sustained and stable supply of critical minerals essential for the green transition has garnered increased attention. As the largest country by landmass, Russia has a wealth of natural resources, particularly fossil fuels and critical minerals. In the current context of major-country rivalries, geopolitical conf licts, Western sanctions, and the green transition, Russia hopes to reduce excessive dependency on the oil and gas industry and diversify its sources of revenue. More importantly, it intends to use critical minerals as a new strategic tool for a long-term confrontation with the West and effectively ensure its national security and development interests. Towards this end, Russia has formulated strategic plans, encouraged import substitution, increased policy support,promoted geological study and exploration, and accelerated Arctic development. However, Russia faces many constraints in critical mineral development. Whether Russia can consolidate its status as a resource power in the future depends not only on the intensity, depth, and breadth of Western sanctions but also on its ability to break through the Western blockade, sustain the import of necessary equipment and technologies,develop alternative technologies, and gradually transform itself to adapt to the new circumstances.

title_en: New Developments in Russia's Import Substitution Strategy (English)
abstract_en: Af ter Russia lau nched the special militar y operation, Western countries imposed unprecedentedly severe sanctions on Russia, jeopardizing the country’s key industrial sectors. Therefore, Russia has adjusted its mechanism and institution of import strategy, accelerated the revision of industry plans, implemented a series of supporting measures, further promoted the implementation of import substitution strategy, and placed greater emphasis on technical sovereignty, safety-related industries, and non-market means. However, Russia’s import substitution strategy is still constrained by multiple factors, such as limited path choice, weak foundations of industry and technology, and the urgent need to rebuild the production chain and supply chain. However, it should be noted that Russia’s import substitution does not imply allround substitution and comprehensive self-closure, nor will it be a short-term strategy. Simultaneously, parallel import will become an expedient measure for Russia to replace import substitution in the future, while strengthening cooperation with non-Western countries, particularly Asia–Pacific countries represented by China, is the general trend, so Sino–Russian pragmatic cooperation will bring along new economic growth opportunities.

title_en: Addressing the Challenges of Moving Towards a Carbon Neutral Era: Russia's Green New Deal (English)
abstract_en: Dealing with climate change has attracted global attention, and promoting carbon emission reduction and achieving carbon neutrality is the policy goal pursued by numerous countries. In the past year, to adapt to the trend of the global low-carbon transition, cope with extreme climate phenomena, reduce the impact of the EU carbon border tax, compete for the international discourse power, and seek breakthroughs in relations with the US and Europe, Russia’s cognition and position concerning climate change has changed signifcantly; Russia is taking increasingly active steps to achieve carbon neutrality goals. Therefore, it has launched a Green New Deal. However, due to restrictions by internal and external factors, it will be a long and difcult process for Russia’s real green transformation from concept to policy and action.

title_en: The US Indo-Pacific Strategy in Russia's Strategic Perspective (in English)
abstract_en: The Trump administration of the United States has accelerated the advancement of the "open and free Indo-Pacific" strategy since 2017.From a geopolitical point of view and in terms of its national interests,Russia has generally been critical of this strategy,believing it has posed certain challenges to its "Pivot to the East" strategy.Meanwhile,Russia is rejoicing for not being the primary target of US containment in the region and has sensed a new opportunity for exercising its Asia-Pacific diplomacy in the context of the Indo-Pacific strategy.Based on this situation,Russia has made a flexible and pragmatic policy response to it.However,Russia will inevitably face many restraints.In the future,Russia will seek to maximize its strategic interests on the basis of adhering to its inherent principles of Asia-Pacific diplomacy.

title_en: The Future of Russian Studies in China
abstract_en: China has made great progress in recent years in contemporary Russian research.However,because of changes in the two countries’national interests there is much more work to be done. The historical significance of Russia’s recent social transition and the implications for China mean that Russia research should be both wide-ranging and profound. Chinese scholars specializing in Russian studies should focus not only on strategic trends in politics,economics and social development,but also on the minute details of the changes Russia has undergone.New angles and new methodologies are required for Russian studies.

title_en: Indo-Russian Strategic Partnership
abstract_en: In recent years,the international strategic situation has been undergoing tremendous changes,while the pattern of international strategy has also experienced a profound shift.India-Russia relations have also been changing.As an important phenomenon in contemporary international politics,the relationship between India and Russia deserves close attention.

title_en: Changes in Russia's international strategic outlook and foreign policy adjustments
abstract_en: In the past years,the powerful resurgence of Russia became the most striking development of international order.Following the recovery of its physical power,Russian international strategy view significantly changed.In Russian view,the United States is losing its influence.The dominant position of the West leading the globalization is diminishing.An international order multi-centered is arriving.The conflict between Russia and George was a critical test of the new perception of international strategy.However,the increasing of physical power didn’t improve Russian external environment.The conflict in 2008 and the global financial crisis made its peripheral and international environment even worsening.Therefore Russia speeded up its adjustment of international strategy.In one hand it shows its determination to protect national interest.It endeavors to maintain its influence and power in former Soviet Union area and strengthen its cooperation with emerging powers.In another hand it tried to establish an equal strategic partnership with the US in the moment of Obama’s taking over power.Meanwhile it continues to deepen its interdependence with Europe and build up a united area between them.Along this way,Russia foreign policy will be shaped by its national power,its national identity definition,its resurgent way and its domestic politics.

title_en: The EU's road to eastward expansion: a contest with Russia
abstract_en: The Eastern enlargement of the EU was a process of assimilation by the countries of Central and Eastern Europe since the end of the Cold War,or the“Europeanization”of Central and Eastern European countries.Besides the obvious economic and security interests,“Return to Europe”also reflects the historical origins,geographical factors and psychological needs of Central and Eastern European countries.The continuing game between Europe and Russia triggered by Ukraine’s signing of the agreement with the associated country shows that the“Eastern Partnership”plan has a risk of rashness and does not take Russia’s influence in the region into account.The essence of the Ukrainian crisis also reflects to a great extent the two economic alliances—mature and influential.The hugely powerful EU and the emerging Euro-Asian Union with limited influence—a fierce battle for trade freedom and trade protection.Under the vision of advancing the establishment of the EU mechanism and overcoming disagreements among member states,the EU continues to push the“Eastern Partnership”plan as an important link for stabilizing its eastern border.The geopolitical competition between Russia-led Eurasian Union and the EU’s Eastern enlargement strategy on Ukraine will continue for a long time to come.

title_en: Comparison of India's military co-operation with Russia and the US
abstract_en: Military cooperation is a cornerstone of India’s strategic partnerships with both the United States and Russia. However, in recent years, the deepening defense relationship between India and the U.S. within the framework of the “Indo-Pacific Strategy” has introduced competitive characteristics between these two sets of military cooperation relationships, particularly in terms of consultation mechanisms, military interactions, and arms cooperation. Overall, U.S.-India military cooperation is underpinned and guaranteed by domestic legislation and bilateral agreements. Although administratively complex, it is characterized by clarity in cooperation details, greater initiative, planning, comprehensiveness, and uncertainty. Conversely, Russia-India military cooperation is more limited in scope and lacks long-term strategic goals, but the defense relationship between the two countries is historically robust and highly stable. Under the “Indo-Pacific Strategy, ” the increasingly strong U.S.-India military cooperation is likely to constrain the traditional military cooperation space between India and Russia, intensify U.S.-Russia competition in the Indian arms market, enhance the diffusion of U.S. military concepts within the Indian armed forces, and alter the strategic balance between Russia and India. However, these impacts have certain limitations: technological obstacles and strategic goal divergences in U.S.-India military cooperation, the resilience of the traditional Russia-India defense partnership, and India’s inherent multi-alignment diplomatic strategy will make it difficult for U.S.-India military cooperation to completely displace Russia-India military cooperation in the short term.

title_en: Russian-Chinese relations in the first decade of the 21st century
abstract_en: The Sino-Russian strategic coordination relationship has been made new progress in the 21<sup>st</sup> century.Cooperation in all areas is fruitful.However, the two countries are in different geopolitical environment with different objectives to be resolved and different interests to be pursued.It is not realistic to require them keep coherence and accordance in all aspects.The principle of nonalignment and not directed against any third party which was set in 1992 to instruct their new relations should still be the guideline for future cooperation.

title_en: The "Belt and Road" Initiative and the Reconstruction of the Regional Public Goods Supply System in the Eurasian Region
abstract_en: One of the major obstacles that impedes the development of the Eurasian region is the short supply of the regional public goods. During the post-Cold War era, there are two regional public goods supply models compete with each other: Russia-dominated "hegemonic way" and "collective way" dominated by the transatlantic group. Due to the geo-strategic competition factors, neither the Russia-dominated way nor the transatlantic group way could ensure effective supply of regional public goods. Thus, these two models were limited in the process of resolving the development issues in Eurasia.What make the Belt and Road Initiative possible to play an important role in the supply of regional public goods in Eurasia are the nature of its strong economic and weak geo-competitive characteristics. China provides regional public goods mainly through the"1+N" and "2+N" models in Eurasia area. Having China and Eurasian countries jointly built the "Belt and Road" is a useful addition to the regional public goods supply system for Eurasia and can increase the supply of development-oriented regional public goods. However, it will not fundamentally reconstruct the region’s public-goods supply system.

title_en: Research on Economic and Trade Co-operation between China and BRICS Countries under the New Normalcy
abstract_en: In the last decade,the status of BRICS countries in world trade has been on a constant rise with their fast economic growth.Since 2011,however,the BRICS countries have entered a "new normal" of economic slowdown and structural adjustment.With the comparative analysis of China’s economic and trade relations with the United States,Japan,and the EU,we measure the degree of trade integration between China and the other BRICS countries,their export structures,and some indexes like the Spearman’s rank correlation coefficient of their revealed comparative advantages.The results show that there is an extensive basis for the economic and trade cooperation between China and other BRICS countries.Although Brazil,Russia,India and South Africa mainly witness trade competition among each other,China’s accession has changed this competition pattern of economic relations within BRICS.China has a competitive trade relationship with India,but its complementary trade relations with Brazil,Russia,and India are more dominant.Therefore,we believe that in the long run,the economic and trade cooperation between China and other BRICS countries faces a promising future.

title_en: Non-Western Theories of International Relations - Perspectives on Social Consciousness and Intellectual Power
abstract_en: From the perspective of sociology of knowledge, this article will examine the emergence and development of international relations theories in five countries and regions, namely Republic of Korea, India, Russia, Japan and Africa, with economic basis, social consciousness, ideological structure and intellectual power as independent variables. The specific dimensions include: the influence of social being on social consciousness, the interaction between political power and intellectual power, the cultural hegemony of Western countries over non-Western countries, and intellectual power among scholars in various countries. The decolonization of international relations studies by scholars from non-Western countries through collective cooperation is a very important innovation path, which may become a common interest of scholars in China and other non-Western countries. The important task of Chinese international relations theorists is to contribute universal knowledge different from Western experience and modernity.

title_en: Development and Prospects of the Russian-Chinese Partnership for Comprehensive Strategic Collaboration
abstract_en: Sino-Russia overall strategic partnership is steady and is undergoing healthy development. The Treaty of Good Neighborly Friendship and Cooperation between Russia and the People’s Republic of China laid the solid political and legal foundation for SinoRussia relationship.As the expanding of economic cooperation, Russia and China are becoming important economic partners.The trust between two countries in military field is strengthening,and the military cooperation is deepening.The two countries witness the profound and close communication in the humanity and culture field.Russia and China always take same or similar stands for the important international issues,and they develop wide cooperation under the framework of Shanghai Cooperation Organization.As the deepening and developing of cooperation between two countries in different fields,Sino-Russia partnership will develop prosperously.

title_en: Urgent Issues and Strategic Opportunities for China's Energy Security under the New Circumstances
abstract_en: The Challenges of energy security facing China currently has broken through the paradigm of traditional security of supply,it is increasingly associated with negative externalities due to rapid economic growth over past three decades.The solutions of challenges are no longer confined to traditional going out policy but promoting energy revolutions driven by both marketoriented reform and technologic innovations,consequently a high-efficiency,saving and low-carbon energy system formed.At the same time,China should take full advantage of strategic opportunities under the new situation,increasing voice and voting in process of global energy governance reform,establishing common energy security system of Northeast Asia via promoting mutual energy connection,and building the Energy Triangle among China,Central Asia and Russia when Russia was pressed to readjust its foreign energy policy in the Ukraine Crisis.

title_en: Brazil's Active Non-Aligned Diplomacy in the 21st Century - Internal Motivations and Prospects
abstract_en: Since the beginning of the 21st century, Brazil, the largest developing country in the Western Hemisphere, has emerged as a major rising power with increasing international visibility. In the face of great power rivalries, Brazil has maintained a policy of non-alignment and has played an active role in easing certain international conflicts, making it a representative of “proactive non-alignment” diplomacy. Despite the volatile political landscape in Brazil, with fierce competition among left-wing, centrist, and right-wing parties, there is a consensus in their stance towards great power competition. All factions pursue an active non-alignment foreign policy, striving to avoid taking sides and seeking to maintain balance among major powers. This article focuses on Brazil’s stance in the context of great power rivalries since the beginning of the 21st century. It explores the intrinsic factors that have led to the formation of Brazil’s active non-alignment foreign policy and attempts to provide a forward-looking analysis of the future trajectory of Brazil’s foreign policy.

title_en: Paths and conditions for regional economic governance in Central Asia
abstract_en: Central Asia plays a strategic role on the geopolitical and geo-economic chess-board of AsiaEurope continent.However,the economy of Central Asia went downwards after the Ancient Silk Road disrupted.Especially in the post-Cold War era,Central Asia has become the "sunken" area on the Asia-Europe continent compared to the West Europe and East Asia.Promoting the level of economic development in Central Asia,which needs a regional cooperation between China,Russia and Central Asian countries,is not only a matter of prosperity of the area,but also related to the economic development of the Asia-Europe continent.In order to beyond the peripheral role of global economy,the regional cooperation should introduce international intra-product specialization,respect the market mechanisms,and lead the cooperation by the consultation on the basis of equality among the parties.For China and Russia,cooperation with Central Asian countries is also an important way to deepen the regional economic governance among BRICs.

title_en: "One Belt, One Road and China's Energy Cooperation in Central Asia: A Regional Public Goods Perspective
abstract_en: The paper focuses on the inter-relationship between the Belt and Road Initiatives and Central Asian energy cooperation,and what contributions the former can make for the later in the process of implementing the initiatives.The author argues that some defects exist in the current situation of energy cooperation in Central Asia,including diversity of the participants,decentralization and parallelization of the bilateral energy cooperation,and the low level of integration and institutionalizationin multilateral energy cooperation,especially the absenceof a regional institution that can integrate these diversified cooperationbecause of the insufficiency of regional public goods.The oil and gas resources in Central Asia are of great strategic importance for the Belt and Road Initiatives,and vice versa.Acting as a kind of regional public goods that China is engaged in providing in the world,the Belt and Silk Initiatives coincide with the Central Asian energy cooperation strategically,share some interests in common,and therefore can provide a new model of cooperation and a choice of constructing institution for the Central Asian energy cooperation.

title_en: Political Risks and Protection of Rights and Interests of Chinese Enterprises Investing in Countries Along the "Belt and Road" Route: The Case of the Central Route, North Route B and South Route
abstract_en: This article concentrates on the political risks and interests protection of Chinese enterprises which investing along "One Belt One Road" countries.It points out that one key link in the process of implementation of the strategy is how to handle the poEtical risks that Chinese enterprises faced.From the geopolitical point of view,a "social and political risk arc",covering Central South Peninsula,South Asia,Central Asia,West Asia and North Africa,has taken shape from the east to the west in the Eurasian continent.It overlaps the territory of the countries involved in China’s "One Belt One Road" Initiative and a number of key destinations for China’s outbound investment,and that escalates the risks for China’s overseas interests.Therefore,to protect the rights and interests of Chinese overseas investors,the management of overseas political risk has become an important factor that relates to the foreign investment and national economic security of our country.

title_en: Normative content and practical sources of global development initiatives
abstract_en: From the perspective of the reform of global governance,this paper conceptualizes the Global Development Initiative as a new type of international norm for comprehensive governance advocated by China.The essence of this new international norm lies in the priority development and people-centered principles,which are specifically manifested in a novel governance concept that integrates development with security and harmonizes the interests of people with those of nation-states.In practical terms, this new international norm has its roots in China’s recent successful efforts to reshape regional governance within its neighboring areas through institutions such as Lancang-Mekong Cooperation and Shanghai Cooperation Organization.For example,within the Lancang-Mekong Cooperation framework,China has not only addressed downstream countries’ requests for cross-border water resource cooperation but also fostered cross-border security cooperation and collaboration in social and cultural domains.This balances the existing mechanism’s inclination towards economic cooperation and inter-state collaboration while achieving integrated governance encompassing development,security,people,and state interests.Similarly,in the Shanghai Cooperation Organization,alongside advancing Russia’s preference for security cooperation,China has proposed economic cooperation and cultural exchange in Central Asia.This serves to balance an organizational bias towards security cooperation and inter-state coordination while realizing comprehensive governance integrating development with security considerations and reconciling individual interests with those of nation-states.

title_en: International financial security under the impact of the Russian-Ukrainian conflict: risk challenges and governance
abstract_en: International financial security plays a crucial role in global stability and development. The intertwining of the century’s pandemic and unprecedented changes has ushered the world into a new period of turbulence and transformation. The Russia-Ukraine conflict has further accelerated the evolution of the global landscape and the complex development of international political, economic, and financial dynamics. Since February 2022, the ongoing Russia-Ukraine war has extended its impact into the financial sector, posing significant challenges to international financial security and governance. The escalation of the Russia-Ukraine conflict, coupled with unprecedented sanctions imposed by the United States and Europe on Russia, has inflicted severe economic shocks on the international financial system. This has led to rising global prices and inflation, financial tightening, increased pressure on the international financial environment, heightened volatility in international financial markets, and increased fragility in the international banking sector, thereby elevating the risks to international financial stability. Moreover, the war has exerted substantial political pressure on the international financial system, accelerating the politicization of international finance, escalating financial warfare, highlighting the weaponization of finance by major powers, and inducing the fragmentation of international finance, all of which exacerbate the challenges to international financial governance. In this new context, China should accelerate the internationalization of the Renminbi; uphold financial globalization and promote high-level market openness; strengthen international financial governance cooperation and expand the provision of public goods; and enhance financial regulation to mitigate risks associated with financial fragility.

title_en: "Interdependent weaponisation" and hegemonic cybernetic power
abstract_en: ＜I have previously published a paper in World Economics and Politics entitled "Economic securitisation and hegemonic cyber power"<sup>(1)</sup>, which analyses interdependent weaponisation, hegemonic cyber power and its erosion. With the outbreak of the Russian-Ukrainian conflict, the Western developed countries have increasingly relied on their advantages in cyber power to launch economic sanctions against Russia. There are many similarities and differences. I started to expand and reflect on my previous article. That article analysed the use of cyber power by the hegemonic powers against the rising powers and drew a logical map of the hegemonic powers' implementation of cyber power. However, in the case of the Russia-Ukraine conflict, the economic sanctions were directed against Russia, another important country in the system other than the rising countries, whose characteristic is that its domestic economy is not deeply embedded in economic globalisation, but it has an important impact on the system. The use of cyber power by the hegemonic powers in a context of less intense interdependence, coupled with the fact that the sanctions were not targeted at the rising powers, inevitably led to a different mode of operation, specific objectives and impact of the weaponisation of interdependence. Based on this new case, I would like to revise the framework of the previous study to further expand the scope, refine the target and enhance the explanatory power.

title_en: "One Belt, One Road and China-Europe Cooperation: Opportunities and Obstacles for Docking Development
abstract_en: Under the strategic concept of the "One Belt,One Road"（OBOR）,Europe is considered as an integral part.This article analyses the EU’s initiatives and strategies in the related areas of the OBOR and discusses the opportunities and obstacles that China and the EU mightwork together on their strategies.The cooperation and interaction between the OBOR initiative and the EU Strategic Investment Plan could contribute to the development of China-EU strategic relations.However,whether China and the EU could expand the cooperation might depend on their abilitytodeal with the differences and address the challenges.In addition,China-EU cooperation can be affected and constrained by other factors such as Russia-EU relations and the Transatlantic Partnership.

title_en: China-Russia-India Triangular Interaction and the Provision of Public Goods in the Expanded SCO Region
abstract_en: The supply level of public goods is an important index to measure the function and development potential of an organization.Docking the demand of member countries and achieving the effective supply of regional public goods is the meaning of the sustainable development of the SCO.At the same time,with the entry of India and Pakistan,the supply environment of public goods in SCO region has undergone new changes,and the main bodies of supply have shown a new pattern.The "strategic triangle"between China,Russia and India,which has been mentioned since the end of the cold war,is revived within the SCO framework,and has a direct impact on the supply of regional public goods.According to the possible mode of triangle between China,Russia and India and its influence in the framework of the SCO,its necessary to promote the effective supply of public goods in SCO region with the institutional management of Sino-Russian-Indian triangle.By facing up to the coexistence of competition and cooperation between China,Russia and India,and shaping the"menage a trois",we can build a two-wheel drive of security and economy,and then achieve the balance between supply and demand of regional public goods in SCO region.

title_en: "Study on the interface between the Belt and Road Initiative and Central Asia's development strategy
abstract_en: Under the steady progress of the Belt and Road Initiative, the five Central Asian countries, as important countries along the "Silk Road Economic Belt",are the backbone of the Initiative’s success. The proposal of the "Community of a Shared Future" shows that the implementation of any strategy should not be unidirectional, instead, in order to achieve mutual benefit and common development, all involved parties need to perform a strategic integration. The integration between Belt and Road Initiative and Central Asian countries’ development strategies reflects this concept and is of great significance. At present, out of economic,security, and cultural considerations, Central Asian countries are generally positive about the Belt and Road initiative. Although the Initiative still faces some obstacles and challenges in its strategic integration with Central Asia, there are feasibility and broad prospects in this integration. Faced with the challenges, China should make strategic choices. The primary options are strengthening regional integration, enhancing the cooperation in the field of non-traditional security such as that of information safety, providing effective public goods, and increasing the examination of peripheral relations.

title_en: Shanghai Cooperation Organisation: Successes, Shortcomings and Future Development
abstract_en: The major achievements of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization（SCO） in the past 5 years lie in that it has survived turbulent changes of international situation.At the same time,the SCO made great progresses in building its concepts,images,institutions, and foreign relations.There are also many weaknesses for the SCO,such as lacking of resources,less effectiveness in economic cooperation,lower international status,unclear model of development,shortage of civil and social exchanges,etc.The future development of the SCO needs to address a series of problems,including model of development,orientation of functions, balance between security and economic cooperation, dealing with new political environment in Central Asia, regional stability,enlargement of organization,foreign relations,among others.

title_en: "Investment Risks and Control in Strategic Pivot Countries along the Belt and Road
abstract_en: The key to the proceeding and implementation of "the Belt and Road" initiative is the progress and benefits of Chinese investment in the pivotal states.However,Chinese investors have to face multiple challenges and risks in these countries.There are three major categories of risks,namely,political and public security risks,sovereign credit risks and legal risks associated with investment.Based on the research reports of relevant institutions and think tanks,this paper not only sorts out the risks of Chinese investment in the pivotal states,but also puts forward specific measures and suggestions to prevent and attenuate the risks from the perspectives of both the investors and our governments.

title_en: China's Economic Diplomacy in Central and Eastern Europe
abstract_en: In recent years, positive progress has been made in China’s cooperation with the central and eastern European countries（CEE）. Throughout the process of building cooperation mechanism between China and the CEE countries, the central and eastern European countries are not only passive recipient, but actually are the promoters for the "16 + 1" cooperation mechanism, which has resulted in a series of achievements in bilateral cooperation. However, as China’s political and economic influnce in central and eastern European countries is growing, the western powers, such as the EU, the United States, Russia and some central and eastern Europe countries are now having increased suspicion and dissatisfaction with China for geopolitical and economic reasons, which are hindering the bilateral cooperation between China and the CEE countries. In this context, it is advisable that China could strengthen the cooperation and coordination with the European Union through strategic interest trade-off and make joint investments to promote the peace and stability of central and eastern Europe. At the same time, China also needs to strengthen the concept of win-win cooperation among the great powers, avoid geopolitical confrontations, and implement a " new development strategy" in the central and eastern Europe.

title_en: Selective participation of BRICS countries in global development governance mechanisms
abstract_en: Nowadays BRICS countries have agreed on several important international development issues.Aiming at achieving growth-based inclusive development,BRICS will use the new development bank as a financing tool and invest in infrastructure building in developing countries.Besides,they are calling for an international institutional reform with the equal partnership at the core.This article chooses three international development regimes—OEOD-DAC,G20 and the United Nations Development Cooperation Forum as test grounds of BRICS’policies in international development regimes and it is argued that their participations are highly selective.BRICS countries hold different attitudes towards different regimes and pursue different agenda in each of them.BRICS countries have participated passively in OECD-DAC,refusing to group with traditional donors or assume the same responsibilities.In contrast,they have actively involved in G20 and the UN Development Cooperation Forum.In the UN Development Forum,their goals are two-folded—promoting the South-South Cooperation modality while emphasizing the developed countries should take most responsibilities in international development cooperation.

title_en: The Formation and Evolution of the System of Soviet and Russian Perspectives on the History of World War II - and Russia's Historical War with the West
abstract_en: The official Soviet system of views on the Second World War and the Patriotic War, formed on the basis of Stalin's theses, was first challenged by the West after the Cold War, then questioned and criticised under Khrushchev and then under Gorbachev, and then fragmented. In contemporary Russia, the history of the Second World War, including the history of the Patriotic War, serves the function of educating citizens in patriotism and ideological struggle against the West. The Russian authorities have reconstructed Russia's official view of the history of the Second World War through the preparation of history textbooks and monumental works on the history of the Patriotic War, while at the same time engaging in a fierce historical battle with the West over the history of the Second World War.

title_en: A Study of Russian Cold War History in the 21st Century
abstract_en: Since the beginning of the 21st century, the further declassification and opening of Soviet archival materials in Russia, the further development of academic forces in the history of the Cold War, and the extensive development of academic activities have provided a strong impetus for the development of research on the history of the Cold War in Russia. On this basis, Russian scholars of the history of the Cold War have actively carried out academic research activities, not only expanding the field of research and raising the level of research, but also producing a large number of research results and making breakthroughs in a number of fields. At the same time, they have also strengthened international academic exchanges and engaged in heated discussions with Western scholars on the origins of the Cold War, the responsibility for the outbreak of the Cold War, the end of the Cold War, and the "New Cold War". In the future, with the intensification of the game of great power relations and the changes in Russia-US relations, the attention to the study of the history of the Cold War in Russia will continue. Against this background, the study of the history of the Cold War in Russia will make further progress.

title_en: Interview with historian Medvedev
abstract_en: ＜On 5 November 2017, commissioned by Mr. Shen Zhihua, the author interviewed Roy Alexandrovich Medvedev, a famous Russian historian. Roy Medvedev was born in 1925 and is 93 years old. He is a witness to the Soviet and post-Soviet eras. His famous books "Let History Judge: The Origins of Stalinism and Its Consequences" and "The Last Year of the Soviet Union" are popular in China. The following is the transcript of the interview.

title_en: Cold War Soviet-Eastern European Relations Soviet Archive Profile
abstract_en: ＜At the end of the 1980s and the beginning of the 1990s, dramatic changes took place in Central and Eastern Europe, which led directly to the disintegration of the socialist camp and the end of the "Cold War", which had lasted for decades after the Second World War. The academic study of this major historical event of the 20th century is of great academic significance, and one of the issues that cannot be ignored in the study of this major problem is the change in the relations between the Soviet Union and the countries of Eastern Europe. To a large extent, it can be asserted that it was the Soviet Union's relaxation or even abandonment of its control over the countries of Eastern Europe that caused them to run wild like wild horses. Research in this area

title_en: Development and evolution of atomic energy management in the USSR
abstract_en: Viktor Alekseevich Sidorenko is an outstanding power engineer of the USSR and Russia, currently a corresponding member of the Russian Academy of Sciences, graduated from the Moscow Institute of Power Engineering in 1952, became the First Vice-Chairman of the State Committee for Supervision of Safe Operation of Nuclear Energy Work of the USSR in 1983, and later served as the First Vice-Minister of the USSR Ministry of Atomic Energy Industry, Vice-Minister of the Russian Ministry of Atomic Energy, and Director of the Kurchatov Research Institute of the Russian Science Centre, among other positions. Later, he served as First Deputy Minister of the USSR's Atomic Energy Industry, Deputy Minister of the Russian Atomic Energy Ministry, and Director of the Russian Scientific Centre. In particular, after the accident at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant in 1986, Sidorenko was in charge of the investigation of the causes of the accident. In this paper, Sidorenko, as a first-hand witness of the atomic energy management in the USSR, analyses the trajectory of the development and evolution of the atomic energy management institutions in the USSR (and later in Russia), pointing out that the management of nuclear power plants is a crossroads between the electric power system and the atomic energy system, and that the different styles of action of the relevant management institutions and the tensions between them are one of the most important factors contributing to the high number of accidents, and the major accidents that occurred at the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant made the originally decentralised atomic energy system in the USSR more difficult to deal with. The major accident at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant led to the centralisation of the Soviet Union's previously decentralised atomic energy authority and an increased emphasis on the safety of nuclear power plant operations. The dissolution of the USSR led to the transformation of the Russian atomic energy industry and the management of atomic energy into market relations. This new environment has also created new requirements and challenges for the management of atomic energy in Russia.

title_en: Overview of research papers on the history of international relations in academic journals in recent years (V)
abstract_en: The second, fourth, sixth and twelfth series of Studies in the History of Modern International Relations have published the catalogue of papers on the history of international relations in recent years, and the present series continues to publish them for the convenience of searching and using by colleagues. The first four series of bibliographies are mainly divided according to geographical areas, compared with the first four series, this series of bibliographies has made appropriate adjustments to the major categories, mainly divided into general and cross-regional studies, China's diplomacy and Sino-foreign relations, the history of international relations in Asia, the history of international relations in Africa, the history of international relations in Europe, the history of international relations in Oceania, the history of international relations in the Americas, and the dynamics of the research and the review of the topic, and then divided into subcategories according to the amount of content under each topic. Each bibliography contains the name of the paper, the author, the name of the journal, the issue number, and the starting and ending page numbers.

title_en: A study of the North-West White Guard during the civil war in Soviet Russia
abstract_en: The North-West White Guards led by Yudenich during the civil war in Soviet Russia took advantage of the international situation and geopolitical pattern of the Baltic Sea in the late stage of the First World War, recruited volunteers from the three Baltic States and organised two Petrograd marches, which posed a great threat to the Bolsheviks' "cradle of the revolution" Petrograd, but failed in the end because of the complexity and diversity of their internal composition and the loss of the support of the Allied Powers, the Baltic States and the Soviet Union. The defeat was due to the complexity and diversity of its internal composition and the loss of support from the Allied Powers, the Baltic States.

title_en: An Introduction to the Newly Declassified Cold War Russian Archives
abstract_en: This paper introduces the management system and institutions of the Cold War Russian archives, the major archives collecting Cold War Russian archives, and summarises the publication of the latest declassified Cold War Russian archival documents after the Cold War. At the same time, it introduces the collection of Cold War Russian archives in the relevant institutions in the United States, as well as the collection, collation, translation and publication of Cold War Russian archives by the Centre for International History of the Cold War of the East China Normal University in China, so as to enable the Chinese scholars to have a certain understanding of these archival documents and to strengthen the use of the Cold War Russian archival resources.

title_en: "Democratic Transformation" and the Remaking of the Middle East Order - New Essays on the Middle East Policy of the Bush Administration Jr.
abstract_en: After the "9-11" incident, "neo-conservatism" shaped the Middle East policy of the Bush administration. With this, the United States launched the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq one after another by means of ''pre-emptive strikes'' and overthrew the two major anti-American regimes in the Middle East. On this basis, the United States put forward the so-called "Greater Middle East Programme". On the one hand, the United States rebuilt the regimes in Afghanistan and Iraq on the basis of the Western democratic system. On the other hand, the United States is exporting democracy to other countries in the Middle East and even to pro-American countries. The strategic intention of the U.S. is to transform the Middle East through democracy in order to eliminate the soil of terrorism and extremism, subvert the anti-American countries in the Middle East, resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, and thus build a new order in the Middle East region as well as a pro-American political atmosphere. Looking back at history, the Middle East policy of George Bush Jr. has had a profound impact on the Middle East region, even though it ended in failure. It has objectively weakened the rule of the Middle East countries and has become an important cause of the current turmoil in the Middle East.

title_en: Sino-Russian relations - from the collapse of the "alliance" to the search for a new model of international relations
abstract_en: ＜What is an "alliance"? The Dictionary of International Relations Law, second edition, edited by the Institute of International Law (Sanshodo, 2005) defines it as "an alliance is a pact or a system of co-operation between states for security and safety purposes" (Mitsunao Tsuchiyama). Other dictionaries also provide similar definitions. An "alliance" cannot be a honeymoon for both sides forever. Tsuchiyama explains the term "alliance" in the following way.

title_en: Synthesis of research papers on the history of international relations in recent years in academic collections (II)
abstract_en: The emergence of academic journals is one of the more prominent cultural phenomena in recent years, and has attracted widespread attention in the academic world. Although these academic journals have different styles, there is no lack of fine papers in them. As published in book form, highly specialised, and seldom included in various search systems, so the circulation is not widespread, the use of more difficult.
