Based on this phenomenon, the second series of Studies in the History of Modern International Relations published a catalogue of papers on the history of international relations in recent years, and this series will continue to publish the catalogue for the convenience of colleagues in searching and using. This catalogue is divided into nine major parts according to geographical regions, together with the topics of international relations theory, selected historical materials, academic developments and book reviews. Each part is further divided into subheadings according to the amount of content. Each bibliography includes the name of the paper, author, collection name, collection issue number, starting and ending page number, etc. The catalogue is a part of the Beijing Education Committee Social Science Research Centre, which is the largest and most comprehensive social science research centre in China. This catalogue is a key project of the Social Science Programme of Beijing Municipal Commission of Education (SZ201010028010), and a stage result of the Beijing Philosophy and Social Science Planning Project (10BaLS054): Arrangement and Research of Historical Materials on the History of International Relations (Phase I). It should be noted that this catalogue is the result of the collective work of the "Archives of the History of International Relations Group" of the School of History of Capital Normal University. Yao Baihui from the School of History of Capital Normal University, the supervisor of the group, provided comprehensive guidance in the selection of topics, searching for materials, and classification of the catalogue, while members of the group, Di Anliu, Li Yunxiao, Yu Wei, Ai Rongrong, Sun Mengjie, and Zhao Yuanyuan, took part in the work of collation. Ms. Nie Wenjuan from the Foreign Affairs College assisted in classifying the contents of International Relations Theory, and Prof. Yang Yusheng from the China University of Political Science and Law helped a lot in the production of the catalogue of the Academic Collection, for which we would like to express our gratitude.

title_en: "New Historical Materials, New Problems and New Methods": Synthesis of the First Forum of Young Scholars in Russian History
abstract_en: ＜On 16-18 June 2023, the First Forum for Young Scholars in Russian History was held at the Academic Exchange Centre of East China Normal University (ECNU), Putuo Campus. With the theme of "New Historical Materials, New Problems and New Methods in the Study of Russian History", the forum was hosted by the Institute of Socialist History and Literature and the Centre for the Study of the History of the USSR and Eastern Europe of East China Normal University, and co-sponsored by the Department of History, and was attended by over 70 young scholars and doctoral and post-graduate students from more than 20 colleges and universities both at home and abroad. The call for papers, the selection of papers and the seminars of the forum all adhered to the idea of "new historical materials, new problems and new methods", and provided a platform for the exchange of the young force of the research team of Russian history in China.

title_en: Soviet Military Presence in the South China Sea during the Cold War and Its Implications
abstract_en: During the cold war period, the Soviet Union began to develop its naval power on the basis of its judgement of the international situation and its maritime security. With the development of its naval power, the Soviet Union shifted its maritime strategy from coastal defence to oceanic attack, and constantly sought a military presence in the strategic area of the South China Sea, which was mainly manifested in its acquisition and strategic operation of Cam Ranh Bay in Viet Nam. At the same time, the Soviet Union's Pacific Fleet has become increasingly active in the South China Sea, competing with the United States naval forces. Due to the lack of economic impetus and the counteraction of the United States, China and Southeast Asian countries, the Soviet Union's military presence in the South China Sea was constantly limited, and eventually withdrew from the region as the Soviet Union declined. However, the maritime traditions formed during the Soviet era have been inherited by present-day Russia, as evidenced by its increased presence in the South China Sea in recent years.

title_en: The Evolution of Russia's Strategic Perception of the United States and Its Policy Effects
abstract_en: The paper reviews the three-stage evolution of Russia’s strategic perception of the US: friendship and cooperation, heightened competition and intensified confrontation. Russia’s assertive diplomatic and security policies can be observed through its hard-line strategic posture towards the US and NATO, and its pursuit of diplomatic and security objectives beyond its national strength. Although a mutual shaping relationship between the evolution of Russia’s strategic perception and its colliding interests with the United States can be seen clearly in Russia-US interactions, changes in Russia’s strategic perception are not merely determined by national interest considerations. Historical and psychological factors that shape Russia’s strategic perception play a very important role in making people understand why Russia has placed a high premium on NATO’s eastward expansion, the situation in Ukraine and its actions in Syria with a massive investment of resources. Many policies and actions adopted by the United States do not pay any attention to these historical and psychological factors, which is deemed as "insulting" or "threatening" by Russia, thus giving rise to a spiral of enmity and antagonism between the two sides. Due to Russia’s unique historical memory and great-power complex, Russia has made drastic responses to the conflicts of interests with the United States. Although these responses are not conducive to Russia’s national strength and overall national interests, they may still be justified. Now that Russia’s strategic perception of the US is beginning to take shape, it is quite difficult to "restart" the Russia-US relations in the short term. Viewed from the case study of Russia’s strategic perception of the US, strategic perception in itself has its relative independence, which is not only affected by conflicts of interests but also influenced by social and cultural factors so that a country’s foreign policies may not always follow the path of rationalism.

title_en: Statehood signalling release and Russian military intervention in Syria
abstract_en: Russia began its military intervention in Syrian crisis since September 2015.It still remains a highly contentious issue in the academic circle at home and abroad as to why Russia launched its military intervention and chose airstrikes as its means of intervention.This paper argues that Russia’s intervention is to release a series of status signals to different target audiences like the Assad Regime,the Syrian opposition forces,the ISIL and other terrorist organizations,the US-led western coalition in order to consolidate and reshape Russia’s great power status.With regard to different target audiences,Russia employed four kinds of signal transmission strategies including"conspicuous consumption","communal sharing","tendentious interpretation",and"exploratory fighting".As far as the effects are concerned,Russia’s military intervention has basically achieved its expected goals.With the analysis of the goals and strategies of Russia’s military intervention in Syria from the perspective of releasing status signals,this paper not only provides a new analytical framework for understanding state behaviors but also renders an insight and inspiration for promoting the settlement of the Syrian crisis.

title_en: Emotional Motives for Russian Military Intervention in the Syrian Crisis
abstract_en: Since September 30,2015,Russia began its military intervention of the Syria Crisis.The academic research so far has been conducted in a rational approach both in China and abroad.They supposed that Russia’s military intervention is based on interests.However,this paper suggests that,from an emotional perspective,Russia’s military intervention is mainly driven by its dissatisfaction with the United States whose intervention in Syria holds in contempt Russia’s great power status.Long-term interactions between Russia and the West after the Cold War has left Russia feeling "disrespected" and consequently humiliated by the West.What the United States did in Syrian crisis worsens the grudges on Russia’s side,which sparks Russia’s sense of "humiliation" and "outrage".Hence,Russia decided to intervene in Syrian crisis as a "revenge" and at the same time warned the West to pay due respect to Russia.By clarifying the logic of Russia’s military intervention in Syria,this paper helps predict the future development of the Russia- West relations.It can also give some insights into the Sino-Russia relations in the construction of "One Belt and One Road".

title_en: A Study of Counter-Terrorism Crisis Management in Russia
abstract_en: Since the mid-1990s, "counter-terrorism" has become an important element in ensuring national security and social stability in the Russian Federation. As an important component of the Russian crisis management system, the Russian counter-terrorism management system has been gradually developed in the course of preventing, suppressing and combating terrorist activities in the country. However, unlike the United States, the United Kingdom, France and other countries, the threat of terrorism in Russia comes mainly from within its borders, which makes it more difficult to prevent and identify terrorist activities in Russia. The serious terrorist situation determines to a large extent the cruelty, longevity and complexity of Russia's counter-terrorism struggle, and also determines that Russia's counter-terrorism management mechanism will continue to be in the process of continuous development and adjustment.

title_en: Shifts in Russia's Foreign Policy Since Medvedev's Rule
abstract_en: Since Medvedev came to power, Russia's foreign policy has been dominated by relations with the United States, which have undergone a shift from hard-line resistance to soft dialogue. This indicates that Russia's foreign policy is in a period of transition, i.e., from dogmatic rigidity to flexibility and pragmatism, which is constructive, social and institutional in nature. The obstacles posed by the international system to Russia are the focus of its foreign policy breakthroughs, and understanding the overall transformation of Russian society is a fundamental factor in measuring the direction of foreign policy. The essence of the transformation of Russia's foreign policy lies in the enhancement of Russia's position in the world economic landscape and its attempts to create a new international economic system in which it will have a say, to become a new rule-setter and to provide a favourable international economic environment for the preferences of domestic actors.

title_en: Paradoxes in the Future Development Trends of Russia's Siberia and the Far East and Their Impact on Sino-Russian Relations
abstract_en: From a cultural point of view, Russian culture is neither Western nor Eastern; from the point of view of psychological identity, Russians are neither Westerners nor Easterners. This unique historical experience and development of the Russian nation makes Siberia and the Far East a kind of paradox in the future development trend of vacuum and orientalisation. There are many reasons for this paradox, and it will have a significant impact on Sino-Russian relations. When dealing with Sino-Russian relations in the future, China must, in the light of this special situation, take economic co-operation as the basis, agricultural co-operation as the forerunner, pay attention to the interests of the local governments and local residents of Siberia and the Far East, strengthen Sino-Russian cultural exchanges, carry out propaganda work with Russia based on the core concept of harmonious coexistence and at the same time make use of the Shanghai Co-operation Organisation for the comprehensive development of co-operation with Russia.

title_en: "Troops in - Troops out" and the realisation of Russia's geopolitical objectives in Syria
abstract_en: It was in the fifth year after the outbreak of Syria crisis that Russia formally sent troops to Syria and became an important force in fighting against the Islamic State. Through military actions, Russia successfully prevented the spread of terrorist activities, enhanced its international influence and gained a strategic advantage in the Middle East. At present, conflicts among different groups remain complex and multi lateral forces continue their in-depth game playing. Russia announced the withdrawal of troops from Syria twice and demonstrated its "smart power" in a military and diplomatic linkage mechanism. Thanks to its ingenious maneuvers, Russia was able to gain strategic dividends and attain part of its defined geopolitical goals. However, Russia’s prolonged involvement in Syria’s geopolitical competition with the United States and the West has undoubtedly become a heavy burden on the country’s rejuvenation. The lasting unrest in Syria and in-depth intervention of external major powers made it impossible for Russia to completely withdraw from Syria. Scrambling for the dominance and international discourse power centered on Syria and the Middle East will be repeatedly staged among major powers. As Putin is at the helm of the state in his fourth term of presidency, Russia will still face severe challenges in addressing the Syrian crisis, breaking down Western sanctions and revitalizing its national economy. Therefore, Putin and the elites of Russia are supposed to explore and come up with "new ideas" to tackle these problems.

title_en: Shifts in Russia's Perception of National Security Threats
abstract_en: ＜Xue Xingguo, in "The Evolution of Russia's National Security Strategy" (in Studies in Military History, No. 2, 2010), points out that on 13 May 2009 Russia published the National Security Strategy of the Russian Federation for the period up to 2020, replacing the two previous versions of the 1997 and 2000 Concepts of National Security of the Russian Federation. Unlike the previous two Concepts, the Strategy published on this occasion was shaped against the background of the world financial crisis and includes the economy,

title_en: Three stages in the evolution of Russia's national security strategy
abstract_en: ＜Xue Xingguo pointed out in "The Evolution of Russia's National Security Strategy" (in Studies in Military History, No. 2, 2010) that since the founding of the Russian Federation, Russia's national security strategy has centred on the revival of the Great Powers, and has generally undergone an evolutionary process from "passive defence" to "active defence" and then to "strategic counter-offensive". The Strategy for the National Security of the Russian Federation for the period up to 2020, published in May 2009, shows that Russia has ended the period of transition.

title_en: Russian Foreign Policy from a Constructivist Perspective
abstract_en: Starting from the analysis of anarchic structure, the constructivist theory establishes the position of social practice in the process of constructing the international system, realises the return of culture, identity and norms to the theory of international relations, and creates the theory of social structure of the international system with the main content of concepts and culture. This theory provides an important analytical perspective for the study of the characteristics of the international system in which Russia is situated and of its foreign policy, and has a strong explanatory function for the study of the transformation of Russian diplomacy.

title_en: Objectives of the Russian National Security Strategy
abstract_en: ＜In his article "Russia's National Security Strategy for the period up to 2020 and the direction of its internal and external policies", published in Russia's Central Asian and East European Markets, No. 1, 2010, Zhang Jing summarized the strategic goals and basic policies for ensuring national security set forth in the Russian Security Strategy in three points, one of which is: in terms of national defence, state and social security, national security resources should be concentrated on the development of national innovation systems and investment in human capital. developing national innovation systems, investing in human capital.

title_en: The Clash of Cultures Behind the Origins of the Cold War - and a Review of the Differences between Russian and Western Civilisation
abstract_en: The origins of the Cold War can be analysed in terms of the conflict triggered by the differences between different civilizations. On the one hand, through the setbacks suffered by the Russian civilisation in the process of striving for the development of westernisation and the discrimination and containment mentality of the West towards the Russian civilisation, it is possible to see that the West has unfriendly or even hostile attitudes towards the Russian civilisation, and this ideological conflict brought about by civilisational differences has to a large extent aggravated the formation of the Cold War situation. On the other hand, the "salvationism" of the Christian Orthodox cultural background gave rise to the "sense of mission" of the Russian nation, while the "sense of mission" of Protestant Christians and the "model of the world" concept of the United States gave rise to the "sense of mission" of the United States. These two kinds of "sense of mission" expanded dramatically with the rapid growth of their respective power after the Second World War, which led to the escalation of the conflict between the two sides in their diplomatic concepts and foreign policies.

title_en: An Analysis of the Causes of the Bush Administration's Policy Towards Russia
abstract_en: The U.S. policy towards Russia is mainly determined by the U.S. position of strength in the international system, domestic factors, the U.S. perception of Russia and other factors. After the Cold War, due to the disparity in national power, the United States holds the initiative in U.S.-Russian relations; the early 21st century, the U.S. Republican government came to power, by virtue of "a super" position of strength, the pursuit of dominating the world order of the "unipolar" strategy, in foreign policy to pursue the U.S. interests above all "unilateralism", emphasising geopolitical interests, attaching importance to traditional security, the U.S. policy towards Russia and other factors. The interests of the United States first "unilateralism", emphasising geopolitical interests, attaching importance to traditional security, strength and confrontation to solve problems; Russia's great power tendency, diplomatic strategy, the country's "non-democratic" characteristics of the U.S. to Russia's non-beneficial perception of Russia and so on makes the Bush administration as Russia as a strategic competitor, the implementation of a weak, weak, weak, weak, weak, weak, weak, weak, weak, weak, weak and weak. The Bush administration regards Russia as a strategic competitor and implements a policy of weakness and defence against Russia.

title_en: Maritime strategy in the process of modernisation of Russia
abstract_en: Russia is a world maritime power and a maritime power. With the re-emergence of Russia, Russia's maritime strategy is becoming clearer and clearer, and the goals of its maritime strategy are far-reaching, involving not only the coastal sea but also the world's major oceans; it attaches importance to security interests but also to the development of marine resources. In Russia's maritime strategy, the Arctic is the focus of its attention, and the Antarctic is also a region of concern. At the same time, Russia has also strengthened its naval force in the Pacific to enhance its influence in the Northeast Asian region.

title_en: A Political Science Examination of Structural Corruption in Russia
abstract_en: In today's international community, Russia can be called one of the most serious structural corruption, its structural corruption presents a typical Russian characteristics, structural corruption in the 1990s India was the most, so it will be called "India disease", but today is the most typical of Russia, so here image will be referred to as the "Russian disease." Russian disease" is mainly due to Russia's recent years of drastic transformation and development of the formation of a "hybrid system", as well as the transformation of the system's own shortcomings and deficiencies brought about by the high degree of vulnerability of the national integrity system. It is worthwhile for Russia to learn from and absorb the lessons learnt by foreign countries in combating corruption in depth, and at the same time to create a strategy for combating corruption in depth with Russian characteristics in accordance with Russia's national conditions, so that the anti-corruption struggle, which has just been initiated in Hungry Russia, will be transformed into an anti-corruption campaign in depth, so as to achieve the effect of the system of combating corruption desired by the Russian people.

title_en: An Exploration of the Generation Mechanism of India-Russia High Arms Dependence Relationship - An Analysis Based on Active Locking Strategy
abstract_en: Dependency varies from slight dependency, moderate dependency to heavy dependency. There are three criteria for judging the degree of dependency between countries: whether there exist supply and demand, whether it involves strategic resources, and whether the conversion cost can be borne. Armaments cooperation between India and Russia has reached a stage of heavy dependency that does not arise naturally but is created and reinforced by Russia’s adoption of proactive lock-in tactics as a resource supplier. Through a series of proactive tactics featuring “demonstration-supply-stimulation-binding,” Russia has succeeded in reinforcing India’s heavy dependency on its arms supply, which prompts India’s defense development model and military doctrines to be deeply branded with a strong Russian imprint. The strengthened arms dependency has, on the one hand, proactively consolidated India-Russia relations and, on the other hand, undermined India’s strategic flexibility by dragging India into the risk of opportunism. At present, intensified competition in the international arms export market, arms trade friction between India and Russia, and the development of US-India military relations are playing a more important role in impacting the stability of India-Russia armament dependency.

title_en: Analysis of Sino-Russian Cooperation on Maritime Security
abstract_en: China and Russia have many common maritime security objectives and interests in the Pacific Ocean, the Arctic Ocean and other maritime areas. Cooperation between the two sides in the field of maritime security can not only enrich the connotation of international maritime security cooperation at the theoretical level, but also improve the maritime security environment faced by the two countries, safeguard their maritime security rights and interests and make due contributions to global maritime security governance at the realistic level. Since the beginning of the 21 st century, the changes in the international situation and positiveefforts made by the two countries have created a favorable diplomatic environment for China and Russia to further their maritime security cooperation. The multi-level and multi-field cooperation mechanism has provided an effective exchange and communication platform for maritime security cooperation between China and Russia. The Arctic region, as a new frontier, has brought new cooperation opportunities to the two countries. China’s "Belt and Road" initiative and Russia’s "looking east" policy are constantly expanding the common interests of both sides in terms of maritime security. However, the current maritime security cooperation between China and Russia also faces such issues as insufficient trust, different maritime defense focuses as well as the complex and sensitive marine environment in the global context. Under such circumstances, the challenges facing bilateral maritime security cooperation can be effectively addressed by strengthening Sino-Russian cooperation in the marine economy, actively building a community of maritime security interests and rationally planning the priorities and expanding space in Sino-Russian maritime security cooperation. In the meantime, promoting the establishment of a multilateral maritime security cooperation mechanism will not only protect the deepening maritime security cooperation between China and Russia in the new era, but also facilitate the institutionalization of the global maritime security governance.

title_en: The Russian-American energy policy game in Transcaucasia
abstract_en: The Transcaucasus region is not only of important geostrategic value, but also rich in oil, gas and mineral resources." After the September 11 incident, the United States entered the region with NATO, and the geopolitical struggle between Russia and the United States in the region intensified, behind which there is no lack of strategic considerations for controlling the direction of the Caspian Sea's energy resources and pipelines. Russia is striving to maintain its traditional advantages and gain control over key energy facilities, while the United States is endeavouring to reshape the regional energy pattern, closely linking the energy issue with national security, foreign strategy and geopolitical issues, and attempting to break Russia's monopoly of energy in Central Asia. The energy policies of Russia and the United States towards the Transcaucasus region and the diplomatic games between the two countries over oil and gas transport routes show that Russian-American "pipeline diplomacy" is driven by deeper political, economic and strategic interests, and will have a significant and far-reaching impact on the situation in the region and on the relations between Russia and the United States and Europe.

title_en: Three Pairs of Contradictions on the Road to Russia's Rise to Power
abstract_en: Russia's deployment of troops to South Ossetia has once again demonstrated its determination to re-emerge as a world power. However, Russia is bound to encounter three pairs of contradictions on the road to emergence: in its political system, the contradiction between strengthening the centralisation of power and the implementation of liberal democracy; in economic development, the contradiction between relying on the energy pillar and improving the structure of the economy; and in diplomatic strategy, the contradiction between sticking to biding one's time with patience and taking a tough stance. Whether Russia can truly become a world power depends to a large extent on whether it can resolve these three pairs of contradictions.

title_en: Security Protection of Chinese Overseas Chinese and Chinese Enterprises in Russia and Sino-Russian Police Cooperation
abstract_en: Recent years have witnessed a frequent occurrence of crimes against overseas Chinese and Chinese enterprises in Russia. What is lying behind this grim situation is rather complicated. To address this problem, it is imperative that all relevant state agencies should take full responsibility for security protection and enhance Sino-Russian bilateral police security cooperation. Furthermore, the Chinese government should educate Chinese citizens to cultivate a strong awareness of overseas security and help them develop appropriate skills for self-protection, which should be a long-term undertaking for the Chinese government to implement. Efforts should also be made to reinforce the government’s guidance and resource-sharing so as to create a more favorable environment for theimplementation of the Belt and Road Initiative. Moreover, the benefits yielded by high-level mutual trust shall be delivered to the middle and lower levels, bilateral cooperation should also be expanded from the senior policing to the low-level policing. Correspondingly, security measures to be taken in Russia should be long-term preventive ones and operated on a daily basis. Therefore, it is of paramount importance that the construction of normalized policing cooperation channels between China and Russia should be strengthened, the functional transformation of policing liaison should be accelerated, activities should be regularly launched to improve the relations between Russian police and overseas Chinese citizens, awareness of "community of common interests" should also be enhanced and the standardization of law enforcement by the Russian police towards overseas Chinese citizens should be gradually improved for the sake of fairness. On the occasion of the "China-Russia Local Cooperation and Exchange Year" in 2018 and 2019, both parties shall endeavor to strengthen security cooperation in bilateral law enforcement, increase the sense of security for outbound entrepreneurs and enhance friendship and well-being of both peoples.

title_en: Changes in National Identity and the Establishment of the Sino-Russian Partnership for Strategic Collaboration
abstract_en: After the end of the Cold War, Sino-Russian relations developed rapidly, moving up three levels in four years, from 1992, when the two sides "regarded each other as friendly countries", to 1994, when it was confirmed that the two countries had entered into a "new type of constructive partnership", to 1996, when it was announced that they had developed a "partnership of strategic collaboration". The model of the "strategic partnership", which provides for equal relations between the partners and the resolution of all problems in a spirit of mutual trust, is a significant contribution by Russia and China to the establishment of a new multipolar international order after the end of the cold war.

title_en: Analysis of the INF Treaty and global strategic stability
abstract_en: The INF Treaty, an important arms control treaty reached by the United States and the Soviet Union during the Cold War, served as one of the major pillars of global strategic stability. In August 2019, the United States and Russia withdrew from the INF Treaty one after another, arousing great concerns from the international community. The misgivings are that their withdrawal from the treaty will affect global strategic stability and security situations in Europe and Asia, trigger a new round of arms race and undermine the international arms control system. China has been taken by the United States as an important excuse for its withdrawal, so the demise of the treaty is bound to exert a profound impact on China’s external security environment. This paper intends to review the creation, development and termination of the INF Treaty, analyze its evolutionary causes on the international, domestic and personal levels and concludes that changes in the international landscape have played a decisive role in making the treaty rise and fall. In the 1980s, changes in the balance of power between the Soviet Union and the United States led to the birth of the INF Treaty. In the 21st centurary, pressures from NATO and the proliferation of missile technology prompted Russia to launch the initiative to globalize the INF Treaty. In recent years, the relative decline of the US hegemonic position has created the environment for the US to opt out of the INF Treaty. At the same time, domestic politics and leadership changes in the United States and Russia have also exerted profound influence on the timing and mode of the "creation, evolution and demise" of the treaty. Mikhail Gorbachev’s "new thinking" reforms and the upsurge in nuclear disarmament movement in the 1980s provided a special political and social context for the birth of the INF Treaty. The "America First" concept pursued by the Donald Trump administration has prompted the United States to withdraw from various international treaties and organizations, making the INF Treaty one of the victims. In different historical periods, the role of the INF varied in maintaining global strategic stability. In the early 1960s, it was the backbone of the central deterrence of the United States and the Soviet Union. In the 1970s and 1980s, INF became an important factor affecting extended deterrence. In the 21st century, it has become a tool for Russia to fight against the US missile defense system. At present, INF plays an increasingly important role in cross-domain deterrence. The world is now witnessing a recurrence of the INF competition among big powers, but the new round of competition will surely demonstrate many new characteristics different from those of the past.

title_en: China's Security Risks in Transcaucasus and Their Avoidance
abstract_en: Armenia, Georgia, and Azerbaijan are the three important Transcaucasian countries along the ancient Silk Road. They hold great geopolitical significance for China’s "Belt and Road" initiative that connects China with Europe through Central Asia. Since 1991, great powers have been striving to win over these countries due to their unique strategic position. Under the framework of the "Belt and Road" initiative, China has established close cooperation with them. The three Transcaucasian countries have taken a positive attitude toward the initiative and deemed it as a golden opportunity for their economic development. The political and academic circles as well as the media have been particularly cooperative in promoting the initiative. In this favorable context, many cooperation projects between China and relevant countries have been well under way and China’s influence over the Caucasus region has been further strengthened. However, China may also need to deal with, at different levels, the varied nature and complexity of a range of domestic issues of relevant countries. This paper intends to discuss the possible risks in the future cooperation between China and the Transcaucasian countries under the framework of the "Belt and Road" initiative from four aspects: the domestic socio-political issues in the three countries, the complex and fragile trilateral relations, the exogenous terrorism of relevant countries and the impending geopolitical changes that the Caucasus region may face. Today, the great power contest in a certain region could also spill over to other regions and even cause resonance across the globe. Given that China has enormous vested geopolitical, geo-economic and geo-cultural interests in the Caucasus region, these security risks must be evaluated carefully and addressed properly.

title_en: Changes in the security situation in Central Asia and their implications
abstract_en: The security situations in Central Asia have undergone a series of changes since 2014.With the frequent cross-border incursions of Taliban,the constant penetration of ISIS,and the increasing cross- border drug trafficking,the security in Central Asia is faced with escalating pressure.Behind these changes lie complex reasons:the adjusted US’ Middle Eastern and Afghanistan policies,the repercussion of the transformation in Central Asian political,economic and military systems,and the intertwined historical and ethnic problems.These changes have also delayed social and political transformation of Central Asian countries,affected the contending powers in the region,such as Russia,the USA and Europe,especially Russia in particular,and brought grave challenges to China’s northwest border security and its implementation of the "Silk Road Economic Belt" strategy.Although the overall security situations in Central Asia are manageable,the prospect of resolving its security issues is still full of uncertainty.Security situations in Central Asia can hardly be improved in a short term.International cooperation on multilateral,bilateral and individual levels needs be strengthened in the future so as to effectively respond to the threats resulting from Central Asian security problems.

title_en: Threat to Central Asia and Russia from the transfer and return of foreign terrorist fighters
abstract_en: Since 2011, the Middle East upheaval, especially the rise of the "Islamic State", has attracted tens of thousands of foreign terrorist combatants to Iraq and Syria to engage in wars. As the "Islamic State" has met its Waterloo, the flowing and returning Foreign Terrorist Fighters（ FTFs） will exert a far-reaching impact on international security. It is difficult to evaluate the acute and growing threat posed by Foreign Terrorist Fighters comprehensively if they are just viewed as separate fighters. The study should be conducted on the following three levels: the global strategic layout of the "Islamic State", the development and restructuring of indigenous terrorist organizations in accordance with local issues and actual situations, and the linkage of the nets of Foreign Terrorist Fighters’activities. On these three levels, Russia and Central Asiaare facing increasingly grave security risks. First of all, both Russia and Central Asia have a tremendous scale of Foreign Terrorist Fighters, most of whom have been the main force of the " Islamic State " and its branches and have repeatedly launched terrorist attacks in various parts of the world. Second, Foreign Terrorist Fighters in both Russia and Central Asia are highly organized. The allegiance organizations and branches of the " Islamic State", especially the " Khorasan", will become important carriers for the flowing and returning Foreign Terrorist Fighters. Third, the flowing and returning Foreign Terrorist Fighters will not only accelerate the infiltration of violent extremism such as the Jihadi-Salafism but also enhance the internationalization of the local terrorism in Russia and Central Asia. Therefore, how to strengthen antiterrorism capabilities of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization and the Collective Security Treaty Organization and further enhance institutional cooperation among different countries is of paramount significance to the maintenance of regional security.

title_en: Why the SCO is not enough to support China's north-west perimeter security strategy
abstract_en: At present,the Northwest perimeter security situation has been the practical basis of formulating perimeter security strategy in this region.Currently,the surrounding areas in Northwest China is becoming more and more important in the international political arena and generalizes extensive and profound impact on China.Since the SCO was established,it has played a positive role in promoting regional cooperation and development of member states;however,it also has certain limitations.To some extent,the establishment and development of SCO have met with the needs of the Northwest perimeter security strategy,and it can be used as a supporting platform for the northwest perimeter security strategy.However,due to the status of SCO and the security situation in the Northwest it should not rely on SCO alone.

title_en: A study of the Trump administration's motivation to reorganise nuclear armaments
abstract_en: After being elected as the 45 th President of the United States, Donald Trump is committed to reshaping nuclear armament and vigorously promoting modernization of the US nuclear weapons system. The main driving forces behind this policy are that the United States believes that Russia is actively pursuing world power status, China’s economic and military power is growing rapidly, other emerging powers are rising collectively, world politics is returning to great-power geopolitical competition and the US global hegemony is faced with severe challenges. After the end of the Cold War, nuclear forces have been regarded as a cornerstone for Russia’s world power status. Russia makes every effort to promote its development and deployment of strategic nuclear weapons and tries to rebuild its tactical nuclear forces. At the same time, China’s nuclear weapons modernization has made considerable headway. North Korea and Iran have also made great progress in building their nuclear arsenal. These developments have aroused a lot of conjecture and surmise on the part of the United States. The US strategic nuclear forces have become less important in the US national security strategy as a result of such military doctrines as precision strike deterrence. Insufficient long-term investment and aging nuclear arsenal have also damaged the combat effectiveness of the US nuclear forces. Since the odds have been small that a nuclear war would break out after the Cold War, the US nuclear forces have slacked off in their combat readiness and been caught up in mismanagement. Although the Trump administration’s reshaping of the US nuclear armament can enhance the predominant position of the US strategic nuclear forces, it may also weaken the competitive edge of the US conventional military forces with the possibility that marginal gains are smaller than marginal costs. The US reshaping of its nuclear armament will inevitably trigger another round of nuclear arms race and endanger global strategic stability.

title_en: China-US-Russia-Japan Relations and Their Impact on Regional Security in Northeast Asia
abstract_en: Since the end of the cold war, profound changes have taken place in the relations among the four countries of China, the United States, Russia and Japan, and cooperation has become the mainstream of their relations. Cooperation among the four countries has become more and more extensive and in-depth in the economic and non-traditional security fields, as well as in the area of regional security. Moreover, with the growing role of economic factors in international competition and the increasing severity of non-traditional security threats, cooperation among the four countries in these areas is becoming more and more strategic. However, in the areas of military security and ideology, the relationship between the United States, Japan and China and Russia is still somewhat confrontational, and it is difficult to establish strategic mutual trust, with the shadow of the Cold War pattern appearing from time to time. The complexity of the relations among the four countries determines that the security situation in North-East Asia will remain a "cold peace" for a long time to come.

title_en: The "New Pan-Turkism" Movement and China's Ideological Security: Challenges and Responses
abstract_en: Pan-Turkism has enjoyed a new impetus since the Turkish Justice and Development Party came to power again and began to implement "neo-Ottomanism" policy in 2007.In 2009,the Turkish authorities officially took neo-Ottomanism as the guideline for their domestic and foreign policies,openly confirming their previous principles.In fact,Pan-Turkism is ideologically compatible with neo-Ottomanism.In comparison with its Pan-Turkism development from 1991 to 2005,what is going on currently can be labeled "neo Pan-Turkism",which is more actively and openly pursued by the Turkish authorities.The interactions between Turkey on the one hand and Central Asia and Caucasia on the other are becoming more frequent.The authorities in Central Asia and Caucasia boast closer cooperation.A platform for Turkic- speaking countries for multilateral cooperation mechanism has been established.Turkish politicians use this platform not only to unite its people domestically,but also to gain geo-civilization and geopolitical advantages on the "Grand Chessboard" of Central Asia and Caucasia and to expand the Turkish sphere of influence.The fierce competition in Eastern Europe and Middle East between Russia,the West and Turkey is bound to have its impact on the situations in Central Asia,which are closely related to the security of China.Pan-Turkism will possibly pose a challenge to the ideology and culture and even security of China.Therefore,the Pan-Turkism situation and trend must be closely followed and proactively tackled.

title_en: China-Russia view of international political security order: a comparative study based on empirical analyses
abstract_en: The view of international politico-security order is the aggregation of a country’s positions, propositions and opinions about the nature, development trend and means of maintenance of the international politico-security order, and how the order relates to the country itself. As an abstract concept that exerts a paramount influence on the country’s international behavior, the view of international politico-security order is not only reflected in the country’s foreign policy statements but also embodied in its actual behaviors while addressing international politico-security issues. This article first compares the views of both China and Russia on international politico-security order in their foreign policy documents, and then moves to the empirical side, that is, deciphering their views on international politico-security order through their voting choices in the UN Security Council. The combination of text analysis and action observation may provide a more comprehensive understanding of the views of the two countries. By no means shall China and Russia be viewed as "revisionist countries" as both of them advocate maintaining the stability of the UN-centered international politico-security order, promoting the development of a multi-polarized order in a more fair and reasonable direction, safeguarding international fairness and justice, opposing arms races and the militarization of outer space, as well as fighting against hegemonism and power politics. At the same time, it should be noted that the two countries differ in their understandings of multi-polarization, means to maintain international political security, the Eurasian regional order and non-traditional security. They have also demonstrated different degrees of respect for the UN-centered international security system. Comparatively speaking, China has displayed more consistency between its words（statements on international politico-security order） and deeds（behaviors in maintaining that order）.

title_en: Strategic gains, integration and third-State sanctions evasion
abstract_en: When facing profitable sanctions-busting scenarios, why do some third-party states directly choose the aid-based sanctions busting, while some prefer indirect tradebased sanctions busting? Existing studies have mainly analyzed the behavioral logic of third-party states from the perspectives of international institutions, public choices and alliance politics, ignoring their different integration levels into the international economic system, which constrains their policy autonomy in sanctions disputes. Based on the theory of economic sanctions busting, this paper further points out that when sanctions busting yields high strategic benefits, third-party states’ integration level into the existing international economic system shapes their strategic choices of sanctionsbusting activities. The 2022 US-Russia sanctions dispute is a case in point. On Iran’s part, the strategic benefits of busting US sanctions against Russia are relatively high, and its integration into the existing international economic system is relatively low, which prompts Iran to adopt a direct sanctions-busting strategy by providing military assistance to Russia, regardless of the secondary sanctions threat from the Western countries. As for India, helping Russia bust US sanctions is strategically profitable, but India’s high-level integration into the existing international economic system has made it adopt indirect trade-based sanctions busting.

title_en: A brief discussion of the formation of "unrecognised non-state actors" and their international recognition - the cases of Abkhazia, South Ossetia, Kosovo and Northern Cyprus
abstract_en: An "unrecognized non-state actor" refers to an entity in Europe and Asia which has the characteristics of a state and yet has not been thus internationally recognized under international law.Strongly supported by external forces,it is legally part of,and yet no longer under the jurisdiction of,an internationally recognized nation.Taking Abkhazia,South Ossetia,Kosovo and Northern Cyprus as examples,this paper analyzes the characteristics,reasons of the rise of these actors,and the different degrees of their recognition,and indicates that it is result of the joint effects of ethnic confrontations and intervention of external forces.Marking the deterioration of the instability to international situation,they lead to isolation and marginalization,a reverse process of European integration.Often short of international recognition,they would stay at its present status for a long period of time.In view of their current internal situation and international impact,their occurrence is not something to be encouraged.

title_en: On the Security of State Recognition
abstract_en: Maintaining security constitutes the basis and an important motivation for State behaviors. National security includes both material security on the realistic dimension and identity security on the conceptual dimension. The core connotation of national identity security is the certainty of identity forged by the combination of external recognition and internal stability of national identity. Only by simultaneously obtaining ontological security and recognition security can the State ensure its identity security. Recognition security is a sense of satisfaction that derives from the recognition by others of the self-understanding held by an actor about its essential attributes. This sense of satisfaction has two sources: the fulfillment of the actor’s basic needs for recognition, and the smooth generation and development of the actor’s identity. More specifically, the foundation for the establishment of recognition security is the self-affirmation brought about by the consistency between the actor’s self-understanding and the other’s understanding of the actor. This self-affirmation is a positive result of the actor’s action of satisfying its recognition needs and realizing its identity generation, thus constituting a direct source of the actor’s sense of satisfaction, which ensures its sense of security in terms of recognition. On the contrary, the source of recognition insecurity is the self-doubt brought about by the inconsistency between the actor’s self-understanding and the other’s understanding of the actor. This self-doubt is a negative result of the actor’s inability to meet its recognition needs and the unsuccessful identity generation, which blocks the formation of the actor’s sense of satisfaction and thus leads to the sense of insecurity in terms of recognition. Recognition insecurity will cause the State to experience anxiety characterized by excessive worrying, and resentment dominated by the impulse to retaliate, both of which will prompt the State to engage in destructive behaviors of high uncertainty. The recognition security problem and its international consequences in the processes of national identity construction by Russia and Turkey can provide preliminary empirical verification for the theoretical findings on recognition security.

title_en: The Hidden Role of Religious Factors in the Dissolution of the Soviet Union
abstract_en: Religion is an important part of the traditional culture of the Russian nation. The reversal of the anti-religious and religious policies of the Soviet period, the complex intertwining of political and religious relations, and the religious and national issues made the religious factor play a cumulative and contributory role in the disintegration of the USSR; its role in the disintegration of the USSR may be more hidden, but it is a causal factor that cannot be ignored.

title_en: Countering Weaponisation in an "Interdependent Weaponisation" Landscape
abstract_en: “Weaponized Interdependence”（WI） is defined as a condition under which a state leverages economic interdependence as a tool to inflict harm on a target state. Correspondingly, counter-weaponization refers to the defensive strategies adopted by the target state to evade or mitigate such harm. Based on the sources of the initiating state’s power, WI can be categorized into three types: the one featured by the supply-based power that is rooted in the initiator’s control over natural resources or high-tech products, the one featured by the chokepoint-based power that is derived from the dominance of the initiator over strategic channels and critical infrastructure, and the one featured by the market-based power that is anchored in the initiator’s large domestic market and consumption capacity. As a strategic interaction between the target state and the initiator, the counter-weaponization process highlights tailored strategies. To counter supply-based WI, the target state must enhance its supply chain resilience through self-sufficiency or import diversification, reducing reliance on the initiator’s resources or technology. In response to chokepoint-based WI, the target state needs to diversify its transportation modes, optimize logistics and upgrade its infrastructure to decrease dependence on the initiator’s strategic channels. When facing market-based WI, the target state should actively explore new markets, sustain its international revenue streams, and mitigate reliance on the initiator’s market. Cases such as the ROK’s response to Japan’s export restrictions on semiconductor materials, Qatar’s coping measures during the diplomatic crisis, and Russia’s reaction to Western energy sanctions exemplify these counter-weaponization strategies.

title_en: The Eastward Shift of the US Strategic Centre of Gravity and China-Russia Geo-Security Cooperation
abstract_en: The eastward shift of the United States strategic centre of gravity has had a significant negative impact on the security situation in East Asia and on the security interests of China and Russia. The strong "return" of the United States has increased the basis and space for geopolitical security cooperation between China and Russia and has even given rise to the possibility of a "quasi-alliance", but because of the divisive and provocative policy adopted by the United States, the field, degree and level of security cooperation between China and Russia are not unlimited. In the process of shifting its strategic centre of gravity and returning to East Asia, the U.S. has played a beautiful combination of punches, and through its own advantages and "smart power", it has "activated" and made use of the contradictions between China and its neighbouring countries to create political mutual suspicion and an arms race. The United States initiatives are not in keeping with the booming and closely linked economic development of the East Asian region, are contrary to the trend of the times of peace and development, and are not in keeping with the shift of the United States focus from counter-terrorism to economy first, which is not appropriate and cannot be sustained. The simultaneous strikes of the United States in the centre and on the periphery of Eurasia, which are even more difficult in the face of the overall decline in national power, are in essence a defence by attack.

title_en: Great Powers' Arctic Game and China's Arctic Energy Security--An Essay on the Path of Promoting the Silk Road on Ice
abstract_en: From the perspectives of "sea power theory", "no man’s land" and "co-ownership", the ownership of the Arctic region, particularly the allocation of the Arctic energy resources remains unresolved. In recent years, in the context of accelerated changes in the Arctic environment, the strengthened capabilities of relevant countries in their polar activities as well as the increasingly fierce energy competition across the globe, there is a growing and pressing demand for countries to broaden and expand their energy access channels. Both the Arctic countries represented by Russia and the "non-Arctic countries" represented by China have made more and more energy rights claims and higher demands for maintaining energy security in the Arctic region. Centered on the demarcation of public and private attributes, the choices between inclusive and exclusive policies as well as the power-sharing standards, multiple rounds of contests have been comprehensively carried out in the Arctic region. At present, against the backdrop of "consistent ideas coexisting with conflicting objectives" relevant countries find it more difficult to work together in the Arctic region, especially in the field of energy development. As for China, advocate of the construction of the "Ice Silk Road", it should proactively engage with those countries with the most influence in the Arctic region by sharing ideas, coordinating agendas and promoting cooperation in order to play an actively role in Arctic affairs, better safeguard its energy security, avoid strategic losses caused by vicious competition and lay a solid foundation for raising China’s voice in the Arctic energy development.

title_en: NATO's Nuclear Policy and Posture in Retrospect and Prospect
abstract_en: Since its establishment,NATO,as a military alliance,has mainly relied on the "extended deterrence"of the US as its security backup. During the Cold War era,Europe was an important battlefield where the Soviet Union and the United States scrambled for world hegemony. A fanatic nuclear arms race was carried out the two countries and Europe was shrouded in dark clouds of nuclear fear for a long time. When the Cold War was over,European countries successfully stepped out from the nuclear haze. Dominated by the United States,NATO gradually reached its heyday. Based on an optimistic judgment over the international security situation in the post-Cold War era,NATO shifted its concern and focus from purely traditional military defense to a broader non-traditional security area,which weakened the importance of nuclear weapons in NATO’s defense strategies and led to a cut-down on nuclear forces. However,this situation didn’t last long. The Ukraine crisis in 2014 had a tremendous impact on the strategic pattern of Europe and the relationships between Russia and the United States/Europe had dropped to a point close to freezing.These two big powers began to exhibit their respective nuclear power,thus recasting a nuclear shadow over Europe. Reviewing the historical evolution of NATO in its nuclear situation and examining the impact of Ukraine crisis on NATO’s nuclear posture,people can get a glimpse of its future security trend. The current changes in NATO and Russia’s nuclear postures suggest that the competition mode and nuclear risk in the future will differ from those in the Cold War era,which gives rise to a lower nuclear threshold and an increased possibility of the use of nuclear weapons. These changes will exert a profound impact on the global nuclear non-proliferation mechanism,the nuclear disarmament process and the model of military rivalry.

title_en: Détente and Multipolarity are Strong Hegemony and Cold War Thinking Persist - An Overview of the International Situation in 1997
abstract_en: The people of the world spent the extraordinary year 1997 under the mainstream of the times, which is the need for peace, cooperation and development. The main features of the international situation over the past year are: the trend towards multipolarity has seen new developments in the political and economic spheres at the global or regional level; there have been new divisions and combinations of forces in the world; and various regional and intercontinental cooperation organisations have been more active than ever before. At the same time, however, the hegemony and power politics of the United States, currently the sole super-Power, have become very aggressive; the security situation in the world is favourable, with local wars and regional conflicts generally cooling down and the tendency towards peace talks and reconciliation increasing. However, there is instability in stability, some regions are still at war, and some countries are in chaos again, so the world is not at peace; the world economy is generally growing, but the development of the North and South is unbalanced, and there are all kinds of intricate contradictions and struggles; our country's situation is very good, and its international status has risen, which has made it an important factor in the promotion of peace, stability and development of the world; however, the plans to curb China are still going on one after the other. Looking ahead to 1998, the international situation will continue to develop in a favourable direction on the basis of 1997; some of the world's hot spots may be further cooled down through negotiation and political settlement; the Palestinian-Israeli negotiations in the Middle East may make some progress; and the Asia-Pacific region will continue to maintain the situation of development and stability.

title_en: Indivisibility of Security: Theoretical Connotations and Paths to Realisation - and Global Security Initiatives
abstract_en: The principle of indivisible security is an important principle of the Global Security Initiative. This concept has gone through four stages of development: indivisibility of peace, indivisibility of European security, indivisibility of RussiaAtlantic security, and indivisibility of global security. Theoretically, it advocates the indivisibility of inter-subjective security, the indivisibility of Security Risk Complex, and the indivisibility of a global security society. Practically, it advocates the indivisibility between individual security and common security, between traditional security and non-traditional security, between security rights and security obligations, and between security and development. The Global Security Initiative is based on a balanced, effective, and sustainable security architecture aimed at promoting the indivisible and universal security for the international community through threat-driven, interest-driven, and identity-driven approaches. The principle of indivisible security reflects the core values of the Global Security Initiative, which are China’s efforts to contribute to world peace, prosperity, and stability.

title_en: A comparative analysis of British and Russian colonial systems of governance
abstract_en: The history of Western colonialist expansion has permeated the entire development process of human society in recent times. The colonial onslaught from the West directly determined the path of development of the colonial countries in recent centuries, and the effects of this onslaught continue to be felt in the political and economic life of the world to this day. Both Britain and Russia were the largest colonial sovereigns in this history, and their colonial expansion has profoundly influenced the geopolitical pattern of the world today. The geopolitical contrasts are an important reason for the differences between the British and Russian colonial systems of governance. On the one hand, Britain's colonialist system of administration brought deep disasters to civilisations outside the West, and on the other hand, objectively brought the advanced political system and advanced civilisation of capitalism to the whole world; on the other hand, Russia's colonialist system of administration brought to its Eastern colonies the overwhelmingly negative impact of the Russian-style authoritarian system.

title_en: Dynamics and divergences in US-EU collaboration on science and technology sanctions: an EU-based perspective
abstract_en: Technology sanctions have been playing a critical role in both military conflicts and peacetime geopolitics. The European Union and the United States are the biggest senders of sanctions, and their collaboration on sanctions has been influential in many regions and areas. Despite the high frequency of collaboration on technology sanctions, many divergences arise between the EU and the US in terms of sanction policies. Starting from such dimensions as common values, security threats, and secondary sanctions, this paper aims to establish a theoretical framework for analyzing the motivating factors that facilitate collaboration and the contributing factors that induce divergences in the EU and US technology sanctions. It has selected three cases related to Russia, Iran and China for comparison. The findings are that the EU and the US have the highest level of collaboration on imposing sanctions against Russia. In the case of Iran, more prominent divergences related to secondary sanctions have appeared. As regards China, no clear consensus on technology sanctions has been reached yet. This paper argues that common values, urgency of security threats and pressure of secondary sanctions are important driving factors for the EU to collaborate with the US on technology sanctions. However, different foreign policy concepts, misalignment of security perceptions and the countervailing force of secondary sanctions also make it difficult to bridge the differences between the EU and the US, thus significantly reducing the efficiency of sanctions.

title_en: Basic connotation of ecological security
New Perceptions of China's Neighbourhood Security: Characteristics, Functions and Trends
abstract_en: With the rise of China,the issue of neighboring security has been increasingly important for China’s future development.As a concept,the meaning of "neighboring" has gone beyond the geographical boundaries,becoming a comprehensive research domain of geographical,political,economic and cultural significance.Based on comparative studies of the understanding of "neighboring" among major countries,the authors seek to get a more comprehensive understanding of the characteristics and the method to deal with neighboring issues.In general,China’s neighboring security is characterized as complexity,functionality,integrity and global,which has an important impact on China’s modernization process.Despite the many hot issues and conflicts in the neighboring areas of China,overall speaking,China has made a positive progress in promoting cooperation with its neighbors in fields of economy,transportation,non-traditional security,and humanities,education and other fields.There are great potentials and opportunities for future cooperation between China and its neighbors.In the new period of globalization,guided by the principles of co-development and win-win cooperation,China can work with its neighboring countries to achieve long-term cooperation and stability in neighboring areas.

title_en: Waiting for the "Opportunity": Turkey's Involvement in the Second Naqqa Conflict from a Window of Opportunity Perspective
abstract_en: Turkey’s high-profile involvement in the second Nagorno-Karabakh conflict,which broke out in September 2020,epitomizes Turkey’s risky moves in the South Caucasus.Why did Turkey choose to intervene in the conflict when faced with multiple risks? Applying the “window of opportunity” framework to the explanation of this phenomenon,this paper argues that Turkey’s aggressive involvement in the second Nagorno-Karabakh conflict is inseparable from its awareness and grasp of the “window of opportunity.” The “window of opportunity” involves factors like emergence of “crisis events,” changes in the international situation and domestic political mobilization.The emergence of the crisis event of the Azerbaijan-Armenia border conflict was the catalyst for Turkey to initiate relevant actions after an overall consideration of domestic and international factors.The international factors considered by Turkey at that time included the implications of the game among major powers in the South Caucasus and the power contrast between Azerbaijan and Armenia.There were also domestic factors for the Turkish intervention:a series of changes in its political system and elite alliances,changes in mainstream cultural trends,and changes in its relations with the countries in conflict.These changes jointly prompted the Turkish government to launch internal political mobilization,which further gave legitimacy to the Turkish intervention in the second Nagorno-Karabakh conflict and facilitated the Turkish government’s actions to seize the opportunity.Analyzing the processes of Turkey’s waiting in the wings before and after the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict can not only rationalize its “reckless” intervention,but also provide a deeper understanding of the “aggressive” foreign policies implemented by the Turkish government in recent years.

title_en: Overview of national economic security issues
abstract_en: The issue of economic security arose with the birth of the sovereign State. With the end of the cold war, and especially today, when "peace, development and cooperation" is the theme of the times, national security has become less related to war and peace in the traditional sense and more closely related to stability and development. Economic globalisation has made a country's economic security inextricably linked to the development and stability of the world economy, and economic security has gained a higher status in the context of national security, with expanded connotations, a complex environment, diverse threats and increased risks. Economic security must be ensured on both the domestic and foreign fronts, but the foundation of economic security lies within the country, and the centre of gravity of security lies within the country.

title_en: Analysis of Chinese and Russian Energy Interests within the Framework of the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO)
abstract_en: Since the beginning of the twenty-first century, the competition for energy resources among the world's major Powers has intensified, and the hinterland of the Eurasian continent (especially Central Asia) is increasingly becoming an arena of intense competition among the major Powers. As the two major neighbours of Central Asia, China and Russia attach great importance to the region for the sake of commercial interests, national security and geopolitical concerns, and rely on each other in preventing other powers from meddling in the affairs of Central Asia and in maintaining regional security and stability. Central Asia is an indispensable geostrategic space for the future development of China and Russia, and competition between them and the possible negative impact of such competition are unavoidable, but this also creates an opportunity for broader and deeper cooperation between China and Russia. As a regional cooperation and security structure, the SCO balances the interests of the two major powers in the region, reflects the common needs of China and Russia to maintain security in Eurasia, and enables the Central Asian countries to explore ways to promote cooperation and security with the major powers in the region on an equal footing, thus building a good platform for coordinating Sino-Russian energy relations in Central Asia and strengthening cooperation.

title_en: National security strategy and guaranteeing personal security
abstract_en: ＜In his article "Russia's National Security Strategy for the period up to the year 2020 and the direction of its internal and external policy", published in Russia's Central Asian and East European Markets, Issue No. 1, 2010, Zhang Jing summarised the strategic goals and basic guidelines and policies for guaranteeing national security set out in Russia's National Security Strategy as three points, the third of which is: in terms of guaranteeing personal security and a high standard of living and quality of life for Russian citizens, to reduce the social wealth of the population, and to reduce the social wealth of the population, and to reduce the social wealth of the population. To reduce the social and financial vulnerability of the population.

title_en: Political and economic interaction: a study of international security from an economic perspective
Behavioural logic of weak States in escalating asymmetrical territorial disputes
abstract_en: In territorial disputes with a stronger State, why does a weaker State initiate the use of force and escalate territorial disputes? The existing research has largely overlooked the asymmetric form of territorial disputes and the behavioral logic behind the weaker state’s choices. Due to the power gap between the disputing parties, the asymmetric territorial disputes have an important impact on the weaker state’s behaviors and the interaction between the weaker State and its stronger counterpart. The weaker State policymakers’ evaluation of the punishment possibility and the victim mentality of its domestic society are the two key contributing factors that affect the weaker state’s escalation behaviors in asymmetric territorial disputes. The policymakers’ supposition that the escalation behaviors will not trigger severe punishment from the stronger State could lead them to be optimistic about the cost-benefit outcome of their choices, which contributes to the weaker state’s efforts to escalate territorial disputes. The victim mentality that the weaker State develops in its interactions with the stronger State prompts it to accept the potential risks of using force, which constitutes a strategic motivation for the weaker State to escalate territorial disputes. Two cases, the Argentine-British Malvinas War of 1982 and the Russia-Georgia Conflict of 2008, can provide empirical evidence for this analytical framework. The paper contributes to a theoretical understanding of the outbreak and escalation of asymmetrical territorial disputes, and at the same time provide practical insights into the recurrence of territorial disputes in China’s periphery.

title_en: Common orientation of the new Arctic policies of the Arctic countries and reflections on countermeasures
abstract_en: While bringing new development opportunities to the Arctic region and its inhabitants, the warming of the Arctic has also created many new and unknown challenges and has led to profound changes in international politics and the development of new and complex international relations. The Arctic countries have launched a new Arctic policy, the common starting point of which is the interests of resources, the environment, and the needs of the region's economic and social development, with the United States, Russia and other countries including the United States of America having far-reaching security interests to take into account. At the same time of strengthening competition, countries also put forward the idea of "international governance", but the scope is usually confined to the Arctic countries, showing the limited and exclusive nature of their international cooperation. In this regard, China should expeditiously carry out an assessment of its national interests in the Arctic region, intensify its efforts in scientific research and investigation of the Arctic region, strengthen exchanges and cooperation with Arctic countries and international organisations such as the Arctic Council, and seek and expand its right to participate in Arctic affairs.

title_en: The Direction of China-US Relations and the Change of International Patterns (by Famous Writers)
abstract_en: Sino-US relations are one of the most important bilateral relations in the world. The sound and steady development of the relations not only conforms to the fundamental interests of both countries and peoples, but also contributes to the future world security order. However, US policies towards China have been undergoing significant changes since President Trump assumed power, leading to intensifying strategic competition between the two countries and making the bilateral relationship more complex, uncertain and uncontrollable. In the face of enormous difficulties, more efforts should be made to stabilize and further develop Sino-US relations now standing at a juncture. This has sparked a wave of discussion and debate among scholars both at home and abroad. How to view Sino-US relations in a comprehensive, objective, rational and pragmatic manner has become a major subject worth further exploration and clarification. Against this backdrop, on September 19, 2020, the Editorial Department of Journal of International Security Studies of UIR and the PLA Information Engineering University（Luoyang Campus） successfully co-hosted the 13th "Expert Forum" on the subject of "Assessing Sino-US relations" in Luoyang, Henan Province. Under the framework of "future development of Sino-US relations and the world security order", distinguished scholars and researchers from all around China discussed such major issues as difficulties and development trends of Sino-US relations, US domestic political landscape and its policies towards China, as well as the construction of the future world security order and China’s strategic responses. Some of the viewpoints of the scholars and researchers are now offered to our readers.

title_en: BRICS Economic and Trade Security Cooperation: Challenges and Countermeasures
abstract_en: The international landscape has changed significantly due to the rise of emerging economies. However,the global governance system does not well reflect this changing trend. The transformative power represented by BRICS countries began to ascend the stage of global security governance. Analyses of economic and financial security cooperation among BRICS countries show that positive trade momentum has waned as a result of trade protectionism and the reversal in globalization. BRICS countries are facing the pressure of decreasing FDI net inflow owing to hiking interest rates by the US Federal Reserve,intervention policies of FDI,political unrest,economic weakening,etc. Energy security cooperation among BRICS countries is plagued by the sharp fluctuations of international bulk commodity prices. Financial security cooperation among BRICS countries moves forward slowly. Therefore,this paper argues that BRICS countries should keep deepening reforms in various fields and speeding up the adjustment of their economic structures so as to lay a solid foundation for security cooperation among BRICS countries. By means of linking development strategies of BRICS countries and promoting the level of security cooperation,the BRICS countries will strengthen their mutual communication and coordination,enrich the connotation of their security cooperation,and actively participate in global governance.

title_en: A study of the evolution of the geo-security pattern of the Arctic shipping routes
