abstract_en: Background and Role of Russia's Accession to the Paris Club Li Jingyu Zhang Xianggeng Every major diplomatic development since Russia replaced the Soviet Union in 1992 has attracted the world's attention.In 1997, Russia finally exchanged a heavy price for a ticket to the Paris Club, bringing to fruition years of hard work and more than two years of negotiations. Russia's entry into the Paris Club not only eased the much-needed...

title_en: The Impact of Homogenisation of Energy Interactions between Russia and Central Asia on Eurasian Energy Security
abstract_en: Resource power, channel power, and market power are the core powers in the geopolitical game of oil. Russia’s traditional west-oriented energy strategic orientation quickly shifted to Asia–Pacific Since Feb. 2022. As an oil and gas resource-rich area with a closer geographical location to the Asia–Pacific region and an important partner in the diversification of energy supply in Europe, the energy geography and power status of Central Asian energy countries have shown a significant upward trend. Driven by the comprehensive decoupling of oil power between Russia and Europe, the rapid rise of emerging market power states in the Asia–Pacific, and the diversification strategy of Central Asian energy countries, the main characteristics are mutual checks and balances of channel rights, mutual dependence of market power, and diversified differentiation of resource power. Russia–Central Asia energy interaction is gradually developing in a balanced direction. This trend will not only promote cooperation in energy supply, channel connectivity and resource rights among energy countries in Europe and Central Asia, but will also further enhance the consumer market power of emerging market countries in East Asia and intensify the game for control of cross-border oil and gas channels and competition for market share in South Asia. At the same time, the coordination and cooperation on energy trade shares, prices and channels between the resourcerich countries in the Middle East and Central Asia and Russia will also be strengthened.

title_en: Russia's economic policy in response to the crisis and its effectiveness
abstract_en: Since the outbreak of the Ukraine crisis, the Russian economy has unexpectedly shown a growth trend. A series of economic policies implemented by the Russian government have been important factors contributing to the stable economic growth. Russia has established a comprehensive set of economic policies covering various aspects, including fiscal, monetary, industrial, trade, anticrisis, and anti-sanction measures. The objective of these policies is to ensure both the normal operation of the national economy and meet the requirements of the special military operation. The practice has proven that Russia’s economic policies have basically achieved this goal. They have not only ensured a moderate rate of economic growth but also, to a certain extent, promoted the improvement of the Russian economic structure, enabling Russia to have sufficient resources for the special military operation. However, these economic policies has also given rise to some problems, such as economic overheating, a shortage of the labor force, and a decline in the proportion of the civilian economy. They can maintain the stability of the Russian economy in the short term, and domestic consumption will become the main driving force for economic growth in the coming period. In the long run, the Russian economy still faces a series of development bottlenecks that are difficult to be resolved by the current economic policies.

title_en: New Trends in Russia's Import Substitution Strategy
abstract_en: After Russia launched the“Special military action,”western countries imposed unprecedented severe sanctions on Russia, and Russia’s key industrial sectors have been hit hard. To this end, Russia has adjusted its system and mechanism, accelerated the revision of industry planning and issued supporting measures to promote the import substitution strategy. It put more emphasis on technological sovereignty, security-related industries, and using nonmarket means. However, Russia’s import substitution strategy is faced with multiple constraints. At the same time, Russia’s import substitution does not mean all-field substitution and total self-isolation, nor will it be a short-term strategy. Parallel imports will become an expedient way for Russia’s import substitution in the future.Strengthening cooperation with non-western countries, especially Asia Pacific countries such as China, is a general trend. Therefore, there will be new opportunities in the pragmatic cooperation between China and Russia.

title_en: A Review of Russia's "Return to Africa" Strategy
abstract_en: In October 2019, Russia and African countries hosted the first Russia-Africa summit, which marked the official launch of Russia's "Back to Africa" strategy. Russia's "return to Africa" strategy is fuelled by the West's continued sanctions against Russia, the rising status of African countries, and Russia's quest to revive its status as a great power." The "Back to Africa" strategy is characterised by comprehensiveness, economic pragmatism, cultural soft power orientation and multi-dimensionality. Looking to the future, Russia will steadily pursue its "back-to-Africa" strategy in a pragmatic manner in order to achieve the goals of its interests in Africa.

title_en: Analysis of NATO's security strategy towards Russia and its transformation after the Ukrainian crisis
abstract_en: After the Ukrainian crisis, NATO's strategic stance towards Russia has changed considerably in terms of its position, path and scope, with Russia being regarded as an adversary and subjected to a variety of tactics, and the scope of the struggle between the two sides has widened. The changes in NATO's strategy towards Russia have created many problems, including logical contradictions in NATO's strategy towards Russia, NATO's inability to remove the contradictions of the various security bodies, counter-attacks by Russia, the impact of the internal security environment in Europe, and the influence of U.S. diplomacy. NATO's strategy towards Russia will not be reversed in the short term, but in the long term it will return to the geopolitical track, and the European security architecture will be divided.

title_en: The Ukrainian Crisis and Russia's Options in 2015
abstract_en: ＜The Ukrainian crisis is one of the biggest international hot issues in 2014. The direct cause of the Ukrainian crisis is that in 2013 Ukraine abandoned the strategy of East-West balance and chose to sign the Association Agreement with the European Union (EU), preparing for substantial strategic cooperation with the EU. The Ukrainian President Yanukovych made the subversive mistake of inappropriately choosing sides between Russia and the EU: first, he approached the EU, then "temporarily suspended" the signing of the Association Agreement with the EU, and finally turned back to Russia. In a short period of time, Ukraine's foreign policy has swung dramatically, seriously shaking its strategic position and creating a high degree of political and social fragmentation in the country. From the point of view of the Great Powers' game, the European Union is counting on the cooperation with Ukraine.

title_en: Analysing Russia's New Asia-Pacific Strategy
abstract_en: The background of Russia's Asia-Pacific strategy is that the Asia-Pacific region, with its sustained economic development, is enjoying a significant increase in its international influence; the United States is returning to the Asia-Pacific region in order to curb the rise of China; and Europe is caught in a debt crisis. The goals of Russia's Asia-Pacific strategy are: in the political and security aspects, to participate in the construction of the Asia-Pacific political and security system and mechanism, and to play a third-party balancing role in China's game with the West and the Asia-Pacific countries; in the economic aspects, to actively integrate into the process of Asia-Pacific economic integration, and to face the Asia-Pacific market to develop Siberia and the Far East. The latter is dominant. The priorities of Russia's foreign policy have not changed radically, and Europe remains Russia's most important political and economic partner. Russia will take a more active part in the Asia-Pacific region and will integrate the Russian Far East, and Russia as a whole, into the process of economic integration in the Asia-Pacific region.

title_en: Social Transformation in Russia: Contradictions and Problems
abstract_en: After the collapse of the Soviet Union, Russia began a comprehensive process of social transformation. However, the experience of more than a decade has proved that Russia's social transformation has not fulfilled the ideal expectations of its political elite, but has given rise to many contradictions and problems. Politically, the construction of the new state system lacks both well-designed institutional arrangements and a political culture that fully respects the concept of democracy, leading to political instability and frequent power crises; economically, full-scale privatisation has not led to the establishment of a free-market economy, and the contest between the oligarchs and state capitalism shows that Russia's model of economic development has not yet taken shape; socially, the restructuring of power has not eradicated the "persistent problems" of the old system; the restructuring of the political elite has not been able to achieve its ideal expectations, but has given rise to a number of contradictions and problems. In society, the reorganisation of power has not eradicated the old system's "persistent problems", and the "continuation of the elite" under the new packaging has resulted in the retention of many of the old modes and styles of management in the new system; diplomatically, the ambiguity of "national identity" has kept Russia's foreign policy in a state of ambivalence. Diplomatically, the ambiguity of "national identity" keeps Russia's foreign policy in a state of contradiction. The pain of Russia's transition is a lesson that should be learnt by any country undergoing social transformation. Summarising the contradictions and problems that emerged in the process of Russia's social transformation is of great theoretical and practical significance.

title_en: Stage-by-Stage Summary of the Evolution of Russia's Foreign Policy - A Review of Contemporary Russian Foreign Policy and Security (1991-2002)
Russia's new energy diplomacy and its impact
abstract_en: After "9-11", a striking change in the international energy market is the re-emergence of Russia as a major energy power and the active development of energy diplomacy. At present, Russia to "breakthrough in North America, stabilise Western Europe, the Caspian Sea, explore the East, challenge OPEC" as the overall idea, to strengthen the construction of oil and gas pipelines, attracting oil and gas investment, occupation of the international market, and training cadres of energy diplomacy as a means to comprehensively expand the energy diplomacy, the status of the international energy market has risen significantly. This will certainly have a far-reaching impact on the international energy security pattern.

title_en: Russian foreign policy and security issues
abstract_en: ＜With regard to Russia's strategy towards the CIS, several options have been drawn up. We should make a clear choice as soon as possible. The first option is neo-isolationism, which is essentially an extension of the ultra-democratic romanticism that has encountered the collapse of the idyllic new internationalism in which it had pinned its hopes. What does Russia's departure from Central Asia and the North Caucasus actually mean? First of all, the change of borders cost billions of dollars, and, above all, politically: the separation of the Russian-speaking population from Russia (first and foremost in the North Caucasus) by the new borders will have unforeseeable consequences.

title_en: Outlook for the situation in Russia in 1993
abstract_en: The Russian economy will not take a favourable turn, on the contrary, it is most likely that it will go on sliding into the trough of crisis. Although the Russian government is determined to cary on the economic reform, it can’t be optimistic about the effect. The political situation will remain unstable. There will be a fierce political rivalry around the referendum in April and the 8th people’s congress, thus possibly triggering off a new governmental crisis. The process of division and realignment of various political forces is speeding up, while the desposition of power among the president. government and parliament will get some adjustment. The social contradictions will become intenser. Taking advantage of the referendum and adoption of the new federal constitution, the national separationists and local autonomists will ask for more rights from the central government. Strikes, protests and crimes can be. found everywhere with Mafia forces expanding wildly and social tension being diffcult to be relaxed.

title_en: Western Economic Sanctions against Russia under the Russia-Ukraine Conflict
abstract_en: In the Russia-Ukraine conflict of 2022, the fight on the military battlefield is taking place simultaneously with the fight on the economic battlefield. Western countries have imposed large-scale, all-encompassing and highintensity economic sanctions against Russia in various fields, including finance and trade. In response, Russia has taken a number of active countermeasures. The impact of this economic warfare between great powers, triggered by geopolitical conflicts, is extremely far-reaching. If it continues for a long time, it will not only further weaken Russia’s economy but will also threaten the stability of the global market, as well as the recovery process of the global economy after the COVID-19 pandemic. Moreover, this economic warfare will further undermine the fragile process of economic globalization and the liberal international economic system, highlighting the importance of defending national economic security and thus becoming a powerful force in reshaping the global political and economic order.

title_en: Russia's New Round of Far East Development and Sino-Russian Cooperation
abstract_en: Since 2014, in order to get rid of the Western isolation and sanctions triggered by the Ukrainian crisis, ride the Asia-Pacific economic express train and promote the Eurasian integration process, the Russian government has set off a new round of development in the Far East: it has set up a "forward social and economic development zone", created a free port in Vladivostok, introduced a bill on the "one-hectare of land in the Far East", constructed international transport corridors, and organised three consecutive sessions of the Oriental Economic Forum in order to attract foreign investment. At present, the main indicators of economic and social development in the Russian Far East have recovered, but the actual achievements and long-term effects of development remain to be seen. China's participation in the development of the Far East is a historic opportunity, but at the same time, it needs to maintain a prudent attitude.

title_en: Russia's strategic concept of "Greater Eurasia" and its implications
abstract_en: The Greater Eurasian Partnership (GEP), proposed by Vladimir Putin in June 2016, is an ambitious strategic concept after the Eurasian Economic Union and the "Turn to the East." The "Greater Eurasian Partnership" comprises three levels: geo-economic, geo-political and world order. Geo-economics and geopolitics are its starting point, and world order is its ultimate goal. In terms of geo-economics, "Greater Eurasia" aims to develop Russia's eastern regions of Siberia and the Far East, as well as to promote regional economic integration in the Asia-Pacific region; in terms of geo-politics, "Greater Eurasia" intends to make Russia a powerful country in the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans, as well as the centre of the Eurasian continent; in terms of world order, Russia hopes to build "Greater Eurasia" into the birthplace of the new world order and a carrier, as an alternative to the unipolar world. The concept of "Greater Eurasia" has already been developed. The concept of "Greater Eurasia" has already been launched, and subsequent measures will be introduced one after another. However, owing to various objective obstacles and subjective uncertainties, Russia is focusing more on the geo-economic goals of the "Greater Eurasia" strategic concept.

title_en: Russia-NATO relations: problems and prospects
abstract_en: Since the end of the Cold War, Russia's relations with NATO have been affected by the issue of NATO's eastward expansion, the two sides' deep-rooted mutual suspicion and the United States factor, and have generally shown the development of "more differences than consensus, more conflict than cooperation". In recent years, driven by the restart of Russia-US relations and the urgent need for Russia's help in Afghanistan and other issues, NATO's position on a series of issues related to Russia's core interests is undergoing significant changes, and a new interactive trend has emerged between Russia and NATO, with relations between the two sides expected to usher in a new stage of development in which cooperation increases and conflict decreases. However, in view of the fact that the existing problems between Russia and NATO are "too numerous to be resolved", substantive improvement of relations between the two sides is still "a long way off", and it is unlikely that Russia will be able to join NATO in the future.

title_en: Russia and Syrian National Reconstruction
abstract_en: As the situation in Syria stabilises, its post-war reconstruction has become one of the main focuses of Russian foreign policy. Russia's involvement in the reconstruction of the Syrian State is mainly motivated by the following reasons: to serve its global strategy as a world power, to shape the regional order in the Middle East in Russia's favour and to consolidate its post-war interests. To this end, Russia has taken a variety of initiatives to support the reconstruction of Syria in the security, political and economic spheres, such as multilateral peacekeeping and assistance in the reconstruction of security mechanisms, promotion of the formation and operation of the Constitutional Council, and the provision of international assistance. These initiatives have a distinctly Russian character, namely, a pragmatic philosophy, a multilateral approach and the use of military force. However, the effectiveness and prospects of Russia's participation in the reconstruction of Syria are complicated and uncertain because of the increasing difficulty of reconstruction, the lack of capacity, the decline in its willingness to do so, and the intensification of the game among the major Powers.

title_en: Russia in the World Power Structure of the 21st Century
abstract_en: This article, which was delivered by Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov on 1 December 2012 at the annual international conference "Russia in the World Power Structure of the 21st Century", the 20th anniversary of the establishment of the Council on Foreign and Defence Policy, and the 10th anniversary of the launching of the magazine "Russia in Global Politics", reflects to a large extent the basic position of Russia on the future development of the system of international relations and the principles of Russia's foreign policy. Lavrov believes that the world is in a state of flux. According to Lavrov, the world is undergoing profound changes, and in the future it will be a multipolar world where unipolar hegemony has no future. He also explained how Russia should respond to the new situation.

title_en: Russian Interest Groups and Diplomatic Decision-Making
abstract_en: Interest groups play an important role in foreign policy-making in contemporary Russia. This article analyses in depth the conditions necessary for the participation and influence of interest groups in foreign policy-making and the nature of their influence on foreign policy-making, and at the same time summarizes the ways and means by which interest groups influence foreign policy-making and evaluates the actual effects of such influence.

title_en: New Changes in Russian Military Doctrine
abstract_en: Endorsed by President Putin, the new edition of Russian military theory draft become effective recently. The new theory provides fresh assessment and prediction on the international military and political situation and makes a profound analysis of the internal and external threats to Russian military security. Compared with the military doctrine in 1993, this draft has changed in  many ways, which can be reflected in the following aspects: 1) it reiterates that the United States and NATO remain as the biggest threats to Russia; 2) it reemphasizes the development of nuclear deterrent forces and extensive use of nuclear weapons; 3) it lays stress on the tremendous impact of  high technology on future wars; 4) it sets score on space wars and active air defense; 5) it advocates bigger defense spending and the promotion of war industry complex; 6) it stresses the development of conventional armed forces; and 7) it stresses CIS’collective security system and military integration. These changes exhibit Russia’s basic concept for safeguarding national security in the new century and mark the formation of a new military strategy. The new military doctrine is a natural outcome of Russia’s constant frustration in combating with the West. It indicates that Russia’s relations with the West would enter a new period pregnant with competition and confrontation.

title_en: Diplomatic security strategy of Belarus in the context of the Ukrainian crisis
abstract_en: The outbreak of the Ukraine crisis in 2022 has changed the international strategic landscape and worsened the security environment for Belarus. In response to the ensuing risks and challenges, Belarus has made timely adjustments to its diplomatic priorities and military strategy, further consolidating its alliance with Russia and strengthening mutually beneficial cooperation with China and other developing countries, while engaging in a fierce tit-for-tat struggle with the United States and the West. As the US and the West intensify their efforts to contain and suppress Russia and Belarus, Belarus’ diplomatic and security strategy will become more pronounced with the features of “uniting Russia, relying on China, resisting the US and pulling Europe” while expanding its military preparations and improving its defense capabilities.

title_en: U.S. Deterrence Strategy and the Russia-Ukraine Conflict
abstract_en: Since the Crimea Crisis in 2014, the United States had drawn up a strategic framework of deterrence strategy on Ukraine and launched European Deterrence Initiative（EDI） to deter Russia. The US strengthened security cooperation with Ukraine to improve its deterrence capacity. In November 2021, Russia-Ukraine relations deteriorated again. The US repeatedly threatened Russia with large-scale economic sanctions. Meanwhile, in order to deter Russia from taking military actions, the US continuously disclosed intelligence about Russia’s military operations, strengthened its military presence in Eastern Europe, and increased military assistance to Ukraine. Although failed, the United States has formed a new phrase of deterrence by unprecedented sanctions against Russia and large-scale military assistance to Ukraine. Discussing Biden’s operation of deterrence and its failure is conducive to our understanding of US policy on the Ukrainian issue and the Taiwan question.

title_en: Changes in Russia's international outlook and foreign policy adjustments
abstract_en: One of the notable changes in the international landscape in recent years has been the strong emergence of Russia. Along with the revival of its national power, Russia's international strategic outlook has also undergone important changes. Russia believes that the influence of the United States is declining, the West is losing its dominance of globalisation, and a polycentric international order is emerging. The Russian-Georgian conflict is an important test of Russia's new international strategic outlook. However, the rise of Russia's national power has not improved its external environment, and the Russian-Georgian conflict and the global financial crisis in 2008 have led to the deterioration of Russia's neighbourhood and the international environment. Russia has therefore accelerated the adjustment of its foreign policy, on the one hand, declaring its determination to resolutely safeguard its national interests, endeavouring to maintain its position and influence in the former Soviet Union region, and intensifying its cooperation with the emerging powers, and on the other hand, attempting to build a "strategic partnership" on equal terms with the United States by taking advantage of the coming to power of Barack Obama. On the other hand, it tries to take the opportunity of Obama's coming to power to establish a "strategic partnership" with the United States on an equal footing, and at the same time continue to strengthen the interdependence between Russia and Europe and build a "unified space" between Russia and Europe. In the future, Russia's foreign policy will be influenced by factors such as Russia's national strength, its national identity, the way it rises to power and its domestic politics.

title_en: Analysis of US Strategy Towards Russia - Basis, Objectives, Framework, Changes
abstract_en: This article attempts to grasp the broad outlines of the United States' strategy towards Russia after the collapse of the Soviet Union from both static and dynamic perspectives. The article argues that, based on the historical connection, the position of Russia in the US global strategy, the important role of Russia in the shaping of the US "transition country", the influence of the "third party" factor, and other strategic bases, the US established the overall strategic objectives of "democratisation, westernisation, and post-imperialisation" towards Russia, and established a profound and profound relationship with Russia. Democratisation, westernisation and post-imperialisation" as the overall goal of the US strategy towards Russia, and formed the basic framework of US-Russia relations in the post-Soviet era in the profound interaction with Russia. In the wake of the Iraq war, and with the new changes in United States-Russian relations, the United States strategy towards Russia will be adjusted accordingly under the basic guidelines of "patient contact, firm precaution and careful management".

title_en: Putin's strategy of "integration" into Europe and an assessment of its prospects
abstract_en: Russia is a trans-Eurasian country, and the question of whether it belongs to Europe or Asia is not only a question of objective orientation, but also a question of the direction of its development. Putin proposed that Russia should be "integrated" into Europe, is to clear understanding of the issue, the cohesion of domestic views and strength, to seize the opportunity of the profound changes taking place in Europe, on the basis of "new common values", and Europe to build a "unified political, economic and security space". A "unified political, economic and security space" is being built with Europe on the basis of "new common values", so that Russia can get on the "train" of the European Union and European integration and realise its aspirations to revitalise the country. However, although Europe, with the European Union at its centre, also proposes to build a "unified space" with Russia, it is not prepared to include Russia in the process of European integration they envisage, but merely wants to use it as a means of establishing more stable relations of cooperation and a mechanism for promoting the continuation of the Russian Federation. Instead, they want to use it as a means of establishing more stable relations of cooperation with Russia and a mechanism to promote Russia's continued reforms in the direction of "democratisation", as the West would like it to be. This difference in goals will certainly affect the breadth and depth of Russian-European cooperation, and Putin's efforts to "integrate" into European diplomacy, although beneficial to Russia, will be a long and winding road with limited success.

title_en: Changes and challenges to the Russian Federation system
abstract_en: In view of the lessons learnt from the collapse of the Soviet Union and the threat of disintegration of the Russian federal system, post-independence Russia has attached great importance to the strengthening of federalism. The Yeltsin regime's tinkering with the existing system was followed by President Putin's reinvigorated reforms. However, Russian federalism still faces many challenges in the future.

title_en: A New Direction for U.S.-Russia Relations
abstract_en: After the "9-11 incident", U.S.-Russian relations have attracted great attention from all sides, and their future direction has also been widely debated. This article is an attempt to give a clearer answer to this question.

title_en: Developments in Russian-NATO relations
abstract_en: Russia's relations with NATO are an important part of today's international relations, and since the outbreak of the Ukrainian crisis in 2014, relations between Russia and NATO have taken a sharp turn for the worse, plunging them into acute antagonism, with a certain degree of impact on the regional situation and the geopolitical environment. There are big differences between Russia and NATO in terms of geopolitical values, and there is a lack of common interests in key areas where cooperation is needed, so it will be difficult to significantly improve their relations in the short term, and the original structural contradictions will not disappear; however, limited cooperation in the relevant areas will continue, and opportunities for détente will still exist.

title_en: Analysis of Russia-US relations and their trends after the Trump administration
abstract_en: US-Russia relations have been very acrimonious since Donald Trump came into office.The reasons include post-Cold War mutual mistrust,solidified hostile perspectives,conflicting world views,structural contradiction in real interests,US diplomatic system’s constraints.In the foreseeable future,it is difficult for the bilateral relations to be improved;there will be more fierce rivalry between them rather than a large scale conflict or the second Cold War.

title_en: Analysing the prospects for the development of the Eurasian Economic Union
abstract_en: On 1 January 2015, Russia, Belarus and Kazakhstan formally established the Eurasian Economic Union, which was followed by Armenia's accession on 2 January and Kyrgyzstan's signing of the accession treaty on 8 May, implying that the Eurasian integration that Russia has been promoting for many years has entered a new stage. The Eurasian region is Russia's strategic support, and the Central Asian countries have a strong dependence on Russia in the economic sphere for historical reasons, and this mutual demand is the motive for the establishment of the Eurasian Economic Union. However, according to the analysis of the current situation, the Eurasian Economic Union lacks realistic conditions for monetary and deep integration. The success of regional economic integration is determined by whether the economic benefits of integration for the member States are sufficient to offset the costs incurred, and in this respect the Eurasian Economic Union does not seem to be a cause for optimism.

title_en: Russia is an indispensable member of the G-20 mechanism
abstract_en: The rise of G20 is a landmark event in the current world economy and international relations. 29 October 2009, the editorial board of Modern International Relations of China Institute of Modern International Relations invited more than 20 famous experts and scholars from relevant research units of the central ministries and commissions and the People's Liberation Army, as well as from some famous universities and research institutes in Beijing and Shanghai, to hold a symposium on the topic of the "Rise of the G20 and the Great International Changes", including the following topics: What are the deep-rooted reasons for the rise of G20? The topics of the conference include: the deep-seated reasons for the rise of the G20? What is its relationship with the financial crisis, changes in the world power structure and globalisation, and what is the impact and significance of the rise of the G20? Does it mean the beginning of the transformation of the international system? Does it mean the democratisation of international relations and the strengthening of global governance? Will the G20 return to mediocrity after the crisis or replace the G8 as the primary mechanism for world economic coordination and cooperation? If the G20 is truly institutionalised, how will it deal with its relationship with the G8, the UN and other organisations, and what does the rise of the G20 mean for China? How should China look at and make use of the G20, and so on. Participants discussed and even exchanged views on these issues, and put forward a lot of new ideas, depth, strategic vision and forward-looking insights. title_en: The Role and Influence of Orthodox Christianity in Russian Political Life
abstract_en: Historically, the Orthodox Church was part of the Russian state apparatus. However, during the Soviet period, the Orthodox Church not only lost its status as a state religion, but also often became the object of dictatorship, and the Church was completely marginalised in the political life of the country. The Russian authorities seriously learnt the lessons of the Soviet Union in religious policy, re-evaluated the role of Orthodoxy, and intended to use Orthodoxy to unite the society, enhance national cohesion, and make it a "quasi-state religion" again. The Orthodox Church has also taken the opportunity to expand its power, intensify the development of the Church's business, and actively participate in the political life of the country, and has become a very striking social force, playing a pivotal role in the political life of Russia.

title_en: Russian policy towards Bosnia and Herzegovina
abstract_en: ＜At the beginning of its independence, Russia was constrained by the difficult situation at home and was unable to intervene in international affairs. In the face of the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Russia basically "stood idly by" and did not put forward its own unique ideas, except for the fact that, as a permanent member of the United Nations Security Council, it took a position similar to that of the West when voting on the resolution on Bosnia and Herzegovina. Since the beginning of this year, Russia's attitude has changed and it is endeavouring to exert its own influence on the peace process in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

title_en: Status and Trends of Russian Arms Exports
abstract_en: After entering the 21st century, Russia's arms exports have been growing at a high rate, and Russia has now become a major arms exporting country on a par with the United States. From the structure of Russian arms exports, air and naval equipment accounted for the main proportion, China and India is the main market. The rapid growth of Russian arms exports is closely related to its domestic economic development, external market demand and the adjustment of Russian export strategy. In the future, Russian arms exports will be constrained by a number of factors, including the production capacity of the Russian military-industrial system, changes in the pattern of supply in the international arms market and cyclical fluctuations in the operation of the world economy.

title_en: Cognitive Conflict and the U.S.-Russian Geopolitical Tug-of-War
abstract_en: The collapse of the Soviet Union did not make the United States and Russia from now on to shake hands and make peace, on the contrary, the two countries after a short honeymoon period, in the former Soviet East geopolitical arrangements on the contradictions gradually exposed, and with the new round of NATO enlargement and the United States in the deployment of anti-ballistic missile system in Eastern Europe nearly intensified. The U.S.-Russian geopolitical rivalry is closely related to the conflict of their mutual perceptions. The U.S. usually regards Russia as a defeated adversary, requiring it to accept the U.S. definition of its international status and "guidance" on its internal and external policies, and if it violates them, it is regarded as a centralising tendency or an attempt at empire that needs to be resisted. In order to contain the challenges that this might pose and to push Russia in the direction that the United States wants it to evolve, the United States has continually weakened the capital that Russia relies on for confrontation. In Russia's view, the embrace of the West and strategic compromises have not resulted in the expected recognition of the West and its respect for Russia's security space; instead, the United States has pressed Russia strategically. The policy choices of the United States and Russia under this mutual perception will largely affect the concrete process of the geopolitical competition between the United States and Russia.

title_en: Russia's Eastern Energy Diplomacy and Sino-Russian Energy Cooperation
abstract_en: Against the background of rising international energy prices, Russia, as a major energy exporting country, not only wants to expand its energy export market, but also wants to take the opportunity of hosting the G8 summit to promote the establishment of a new global energy system, in order to highlight its unique image as a world power. Strengthen energy diplomacy, promote Russian energy to China, Japan, South Korea, India and other eastern countries to export a large number of Putin's current diplomacy has become an important goal, but also Russia to ensure the security of its energy exports and the sustainable development of the national economy is an important condition. China-Russia energy co-operation is complex and convoluted, but also in solid progress, with the deepening of the two countries' strategic partnership, China-Russia energy co-operation will continue to move to a new level.

title_en: Globalisation and Russian Awareness
Russia's great power diplomacy and international status and role
abstract_en: Abstract  At the turn of the century, Russia pursues big power diplomacy and sets its strategic objective of obtaining a favourable position in the coming multipolar world. Its principal approaches are as follows: （1）advocating multipolar world and making active play of its special role as an independent pole in the world; （2） further adjusting the policy toward CIR and consolidating its sphere of influences in the region; （3） deepening the relations with the Asia-Pacific countries and establishing its Eurasian big power status. But there are still major difficuties in realizing above targets, mostly due to the weakening of Russia’s millitary superiority and the heavy hardship in revitalizing its economy at the beginning of next centry. As a result, Russia can make few progress in diplomacy.      In the future, Russia will be positioned inferiorly  in the multipolar world. However, in taking advantege of its geo-advantege and current millitary ability, Russia could still play an active and stable role in building a fair and reasonable new international political and economic order, and keeping the regional prosperity and development.

title_en: Russia's strategic outlook from a modernisation strategy
abstract_en: Russian President Dmitry Medvedev has put forward a strategy of "comprehensive modernisation", the basic requirements of which are a more democratic politics and a smarter economy, so as to attract more capital, technology and talents from the West and achieve Russia's goal of becoming a stronger country. The difference between this strategy and Putin's philosophy of governance has left an impression that President Medvedev needs to get out of Putin's shadow before the new round of presidential elections, especially his desire to modernise his country with the help of Western forces, which has once again made people see the uncertainty of Russia's strategic outlook.

title_en: Russia ushers in a new era of the "Merkel-Prussian duo".
abstract_en: The Russian presidential election has been settled, and Dmitry Medvedev has won the election with a high number of votes. The support of Vladimir Putin, the recognition of the public and the qualities of Medvedev have ensured that he has become the biggest winner in the election. In the future, Dmitry Medvedev will certainly implement Putin's pioneering concepts of governance and policies, and will make the maintenance of political stability, the promotion of economic growth, the pursuit of an independent foreign policy and the comprehensive revitalisation of Russia the central tasks of his future administration. When the new government is formed, May will strongly invite Putin to become the head of government, and Russia may usher in a new era of "May-Putin combination".

title_en: Analysing Russia's National Development Strategy
abstract_en: Russia's national development strategy has gone through a complex process of development from general and vague to specific and clear. In the early years of Russia's independence, Boris Yeltsin pursued integration into the West and pursued a development strategy that relied entirely on the West, resulting in a loss of independence and initiative in Russia's national development. After Putin came to power, he put forward a "strategy of strengthening the country" in line with Russia's situation, with the goal of revitalising the Russian economy and restoring Russia's status as a world power. From the present point of view, Putin's development ideas are basically consistent with the actual situation in Russia, and has won the support of the general public in the country, and its future prospects are generally favourable. However, the constraints of Russia's internal opposition, as well as the West's dissatisfaction, fear and obstruction, will surely make Putin's road to power full of difficulties and challenges.

title_en: Russian society in silhouette
abstract_en: ＜Not long ago, I was in Russia on a six-month visit and study tour, and in order to get a better environment for practising the Russian language and to save money on rent, I often stayed in the homes of ordinary people. There was a landlady who was in her forties, in poor health and no longer working, and her lover went to work in the Far East and was not always at home. We got along very well, and in the evenings she used to invite me to watch TV in the living room, but she never watched the news, not even when there was a big event like the Russian Congress of People's Deputies held in December last year. Curious, I asked her why she didn't care. She said: "I'm not interested, the upper echelons are fighting for special powers and superior living conditions, but not really for the people". She didn't care whether she was in favour of or against President Yeltsin, thinking that if Yeltsin couldn't do it right, others might not be able to either.

Energy as a strategic resource, in the future there is the possibility of destroying the relationship between Europe and Russia as a "weapon", but also may become closer to the relationship between Europe and Russia as a "glue". Under the influence of European and Russian political relations, the EU's energy diplomacy with Russia has obvious contradictions and limitations.

title_en: The Eurasian Economic Union and its world impact
abstract_en: The Eurasian Economic Union, which began functioning in January 2015, is the international economic organisation with the highest level of economic integration led by Russia in the CIS space. For Russia, maintaining and consolidating its sphere of influence in the CIS region, improving its international status, creating a favourable surrounding environment for economic development, and protecting the interests of its compatriots abroad are its main motives for promoting the establishment of the Union; for other countries of the Union, obtaining reliable guarantees of national security and social stability from the Union and maximizing economic benefits are their main strategic considerations. The establishment of the Eurasian Economic Union has important global implications. From the standpoint of the world economy, it has had a wide-ranging impact on the evolution of the economic pattern in the Eurasian region, the development of economic globalisation and integration, geo-economic competition with the West, the position and influence of third parties in the space of the Union, and international economic co-operation, etc. Though the extent of its impact has been limited on the whole, its influence in certain areas should not be underestimated. From the standpoint of world politics, it has enhanced Russia's international prestige and status, promoted the trend towards multipolarity in the world and will intensify the geopolitical struggle between Russia and the West.

title_en: UK-Russia diplomatic crisis amid spy furore
abstract_en: Since Putin's presidency, Britain and Russia in the economic field, especially in the deepening of cooperation in the energy sector, but in the political field of co-operation has been in the doldrums, the relationship between the two countries can be described as "political cold and economic heat". 2007 July, Britain tried to take the escalation of the crisis to achieve the extradition of "secret agent" suspects, thus triggering the largest since the end of the Cold War Britain and Russia since the end of a diplomatic crisis. On the surface, the spy fiasco is undoubtedly a trigger, but from a larger context, the two countries are at war both at the international level in Europe and the United States and Russia, the root cause of the deterioration of relations between the two countries, but also Britain and Russia's respective political considerations. The British-Russian diplomatic crisis will have a negative impact on relations between the two countries, and even on the Russian-European relations will have far-reaching implications. However, because of the two countries have a huge economic dependence, British-Russian relations will not go into an irresolvable dead end.

title_en: Russia's CIS policy and its trends
abstract_en: For Russia, the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) plays the dual role of a strategic barrier and a strategic borrower, and is one of the conditions on which Russia's national revival depends. However, as a result of the many mistakes in Russia's CIS policy, the growing sense of autonomy in the newly independent States, and the dividing of the CIS by the United States and the West through a combination of inducements and pressure, the CIS is currently in a state of disintegration, and relations between Russia and the other CIS member States are generally more contentious than cooperative. After the various "colour revolutions" in the CIS, the internal contradictions in the CIS will widen in the future, and it remains to be seen who will be the final winner in the competition between Russia, the United States and the West for the post-Soviet strategic space.

The new leadership led by Putin will implement more flexible and practical policy: inside the country, they will establish a powerful regime and pursue a reform course in accordance Russia’s own conditions; externally, they will continue to push forward the world’s multipolarization, and adhere to the all-sided diplomatic principle. title_en: Review of Russia's Powerful Rise
abstract_en: After the smooth transfer of power in 2008, Russia introduced a new power structure, the "Mepo combination", to continue to strengthen the ruling power and further implement the "Putin policy", thus laying a solid political foundation for its rise to power. In the face of the impact of the global financial crisis on the Russian economy, Meipu has taken a series of emergency rescue measures to strengthen the state's control over the economy and actively participate in the reconstruction of the international financial system. In the diplomatic sphere, MEP repositioned Russia strategically, took the initiative to respond to the challenges of the US and the West, tried to play a leading role in the new geopolitical situation, and enhanced Russia's status as a great power. In order to cope with NATO's eastward expansion and other security threats, Russia has accelerated its military reform, significantly increased its military budget, accelerated the process of army modernisation, and sought to maintain national security through "asymmetric deterrence". 2009, the top priority of the Mep authorities will be to free the country from the economic crisis as soon as possible, and to do its utmost to maintain domestic political stability. Externally, Mep will take advantage of the arrival of the new U.S. president to try to improve Russia's relations with the West and create a favourable external environment for Russia's rise to power.

title_en: Five years of Russia's economic transition
abstract_en: At the beginning of 1992,  proceeding  ahead  with  the "Shock Therapy", Russia started  to  transform  to market economy. Confronting the serious economic situation,  the  Russian goverment continues to adjust its policy.  It is probing a new way of reform and  development  which fit  the  conditions  in  Russia  under  the  prerequisite of its persistence in the  transition  to market economy.      The tendency of its current major policies  is:   strengthening the adjustment and  control  of  its  macroeconomy,   slowing  down  the  speed  of  the  privatization,   making  "Development   Budget",    trying to stimulate the investment and  production  and enhance the social guarantee. title_en: Prospects for the Modernisation of the Russian Economy
abstract_en: The global financial crisis of 2008 exposed the fatal flaws in Russia's economic development model, and in response the Russian President proposed a strategy for modernising the Russian economy, with the goal of transforming Russia over the next 10 years from a country that relies on energy and raw materials for its wealth into a powerful country that relies on knowledge, science and technology for its wealth. However, the inertia of Russia's resource-based model of economic development, which is difficult to overcome, coupled with the country's lack of scientific and technological innovation capacity and the lack of funds for modernisation, have made the road to modernisation difficult. In view of the uncertain economic outlook for the next 10 years and the immaturity of political conditions in Russia, it is unlikely that Russia will achieve its modernisation goals.

abstract_en: In 2009, the Russian economy failed to emerge from the crisis, and the "Mepo combination" took the initiative to adjust its development strategy, establishing a new goal of comprehensive economic and social "modernisation"; it also stepped up its efforts in the area of social protection and sought to minimise the impact of the crisis on people's lives. The economic crisis has not changed Russia's dream of becoming a "strong country", and Russia has taken the opportunity of the adjustment of the international situation and relations between the major Powers to re-examine the international environment, emphasise diplomatic initiative, pragmatism and diplomacy in the service of the economy, and seek to achieve the status of a world power in the new situation.

title_en: A Review of the Strategy for the Development and Opening of Russia's Eastern Regions
abstract_en: In early 2010, the Russian Government formally approved the Strategy for the Development of the Far East and the Baikal Region of the Russian Federation for the period up to 2025, which means that the development and opening up of the eastern part of the Russian Federation has become one of its most important national strategies. The strategy's policy vision is to gradually achieve economic and social prosperity and development in the eastern part of the Russian Federation, based on energy cooperation, focusing on Russia's geopolitical advantage of straddling the Eurasian continent, strengthening high-technology cooperation, and promoting cooperation and exchanges between Russia and the Asia-Pacific region. The implementation of the strategy for the development and opening up of the eastern part of the Russian Federation will help to promote the process of economic integration in the Asia-Pacific region, consolidate relations between Russia and the countries of the Asia-Pacific region and have an impact on the geopolitical situation in North-East Asia and the Asia-Pacific region.

title_en: Analysis of the prospects for the Commonwealth of Independent States
abstract_en: Since its establishment, CIS has been entrusted with the important task of maintaining economic, cultural and political ties among the former Soviet republics and creating conditions for their joint development and prosperity. At the same time, however, it has been a loose and irregular inter-State organisation, whose 15 years of operation have shown that its operational capacity is low and that the integration process has not progressed substantially, either in terms of speed or depth. At present, the CIS is seriously divided. Internally, Russia, as the leading force, does not and cannot play a central role; externally, the influence of the United States and other Western powers has increased the centrifugal tendencies in the CIS. In the future, the CIS may change its shape and develop in the direction of "smallness" and "refinement", with a limited international role.

title_en: Western and Russian Interference and Counter-Interference
abstract_en: In recent years, relations between the West and Russia have continued to deteriorate, especially since the Ukrainian crisis, when relations between the two sides plunged to the lowest point since the "cold war". The U.S. and Europe regard Russia as a major strategic threat and competitor, and have launched an all-round intervention in Russia; the field of intervention has been expanding and intensifying, in an attempt to disrupt Russia's internal order, sabotage its economic development, and ultimately force Vladimir Putin to step down, so as to reduce the threat it poses to the West. In response to the strong interference of the West, Putin's government has launched an all-out counterattack and gradually formed a set of effective practices to safeguard sovereign independence and regime security: strengthening top-level design, improving relevant laws and regulations, and constructing legal barriers against external interference; establishing a mainstream ideology to cope with the challenge of Western values; and closely monitoring the network and building up a firm line of security defence, etc. At the same time, Russia has also taken the initiative to build up a security defence line, and has been trying to disrupt its internal order and economic development, and eventually forced Putin to step down, thus reducing its threat to the West. At the same time, Russia has also taken the initiative to take the initiative to fight with the West, expanding the room for manoeuvre and doing its utmost to safeguard its own security and national interests. However, Russia has also paid a price in its fight against Western interference, and its experience and lessons are worth exploring.

title_en: Russian-American relations: a new beginning?
abstract_en: After Barack Obama came to power, the new US administration began to adjust its policy towards Russia, and received a positive response from the Russian side, which led to a new development in Russia-US interaction. The Bush administration's policy of "squeezing and weakening" Russia has been thwarted, the U.S. and Russian forces are in a constant state of flux, and the impact of the world financial crisis, as well as the existence of a wide range of common interests between Russia and the U.S., are the main reasons for Obama's adjustment of his policy towards Russia. Taking the adjustment of Obama's policy towards Russia as an opportunity, Russia-United States relations are expected to enter a "constructive" phase in the future, in which "cooperation will be strengthened and confrontation will be reduced".

title_en: International Political Interpretation of the Russian-Georgian Conflict
abstract_en: The military conflict between Russia and Georgia appears on the surface to be a military dispute between the two sides over the issue of South Ossetia, but the deep-seated reason behind it is the inevitable result of the long-term strategic squeeze by the United States of America on Russia after the end of the cold war. The U.S. ignores Russia's traditional security interests and obstinately pursues such initiatives as the eastward expansion of NATO, the deployment of a missile defence system in Europe and the incitement of "colour revolutions", which is essentially the result of its hegemonic global expansion of power, which is not subject to any checks and balances. The tense relations between Russia and the United States over the Georgian issue are the root cause of the inherent instability of the international power structure under the unipolar system, and the United States-Russia conflict thus reflects the "structural" contradictions of the current international system.

title_en: How close can Russia and the US get?
abstract_en: After the "9-1-1 incident", the Russian authorities accelerated the strategic adjustment of relations with the United States in accordance with the development of the situation: proactive cooperation with the United States in counter-terrorism, the closure of military bases in Vietnam and Cuba, the position on the ABM Treaty also appeared to be loosened, and has repeatedly claimed that it wants to join NATO. The U.S. side also responded positively, no longer called Russia a potential rival, but called "friends of cooperation" and "allies in the fight against terrorism". Bush even Putin to his Texas home as a guest, even with his relationship with the most "iron" Mexican President has not enjoyed such courtesy. Russia and the U.S. relationship has changed? How close can they get? What impact will it have on the international situation and triangular relations between China, Russia and the United States? With these issues of general concern, this issue we invited the China Institute of Modern International Relations 6 experts held a dialogue, to provide you with their analyses and opinions

title_en: The situation in Russia: retrospect and prospects
abstract_en: In 1998, there were two changes of government in Russia, a financial crisis, social protests and a rise in local separatism. Throughout the year, the Russian political scene was characterised by three features: (a) President Boris Yeltsin's credibility declined; in March and August, Yeltsin dissolved the government twice, triggering a crisis of power, intensifying the conflicts between political forces, and placing himself in an unfavourable and passive position...

title_en: Motivations and Implications of the US Deployment of an ABM System in Eastern Europe
abstract_en: As an important part of its latest global strategic adjustments, the United States has decided to deploy an anti-missile defence system in Eastern Europe in order to achieve the goals of "weakening Russia", "curbing Russia", preventing the European Union (EU) from breaking away from the constraints of the United States and becoming a separate pole in the world, and preventing the EU from getting closer to Russia. The U.S. move may prompt Russia to accelerate the pace of its military revival, intensify its military-political rivalry with the U.S., and further reduce its willingness to cooperate with the U.S. on international affairs and regional issues. It is very likely that the United States will eventually accept the European Union's proposal to establish a Europe-wide anti-missile system within the NATO framework.

title_en: Characteristics, Dynamics and Trends of the Adjustment of Great Power Relations at the Present Stage
abstract_en: According to the latest ranking of China's foreign strategy, relations with developed countries are at the top of the priority list. Great power relations are the core part of this, which is of key significance to the overall pattern of international relations in the post-cold war period, as well as to China's strategic posture in this pattern. This paper focuses on the characteristics and basic dynamics of the current stage of the adjustment of great power relations and the basic trend of its development in the near and medium term.

title_en: On the Russian Factor in the EU Common Defence and Security Policy
abstract_en: The Soviet military threat during the Cold War was a major factor influencing the EC's common security policy. After the Cold War, the Russian threat to EU security is no longer a priority, but it remains an important factor influencing the EU's Common Security Policy (CSP). During the Cold War period, the Western European Common Security Policy was more limited to defence, while after the Cold War, it has shown an expansionary trend. Currently Russia supports the EU's Common Security Policy and efforts to create an independent European defence. The development of the EU's common defence and security depends to a considerable extent on the mutual trust in EU-Russia relations. Since the cooperation between the EU and Russia is based on Russia's weakness and the inability to ignore its role in European security issues, they will be both co-operative and competitive in European security issues, both mutual needs and struggles, compromises and contradictions coexist.

title_en: The Russian Factor in Post-Cold War U.S.-China Relations
abstract_en: The development of Sino-Russian relations after the Cold War has enabled the Russian factor to emerge in Sino-US relations and to exert an influence in favour of China, an influence that is likely to persist, but which is currently limited and has potential to be tapped. There are still uncertainties in Sino-Russian relations, in order for the Russian factor to continue to have a positive impact on Sino-US relations, we should be careful and properly deal with these issues. The limitations of the role of the Russian factor also shows that, after the Cold War in the relations between the major powers of the colour has been diluted, seeking cooperation to promote their own interests has gradually become a new trend, from the perspective of the balance of power to rely too much on one country to counterbalance the other, is neither necessary nor wise.

title_en: The direction of the main political forces in Russia at the turn of the century
abstract_en: Abstract  The social democratic forces represented by Yeltsin  regime are still the dominant power of Russian society.  The future successor of the presidency may come from these forces.  Given the hard troubles lying ahead of Yeltsin regime, it will be difficult to lead Russia onto a road of revitalization.       The Russian Communist Party has gradually enhanced  its  political power in struggle, but due to its failure in the presidential campaign, it has lost the opportunity  to assume power.   At  the  turn  of  the century it is committed with a historical mission  of  having  changes through innovations, reshaping itself and  remaking  future  while  it will see little expectation of coming  to  power  in  the  foreseeable future.         The  third  forces  represented  by  Lebid  haven’t  yet  formed  an independent political identity in the  Russian  society.     With  the passage of time it will lose  influence  day  by  day  and  can’t  act successively in Russia at the turn of the century.

title_en: Analysis of Russia's New European Security Concept
abstract_en: The European security system is a complex and fragmented hybrid, and the long-standing "security gap" between Eastern and Western Europe has not been "bridged" by the end of the cold war and the dismantling of the Berlin Wall; on the contrary, the differences between Europe and the United States and Russia on the issue of security in Europe continue to widen. Russia has recently proposed a new "draft treaty on European security", which aims to rebuild the "European security building" with the participation of all European countries and NATO member states, but it has met with a cold reception and opposition from Europe and the United States. It will take a long time to build mutual trust between Russia and Europe and the United States.

title_en: U.S. Foreign Policy and Russian-American Relations
abstract_en: In the post-cold-war period, and especially since 11 September, the United States has been seeking to consolidate the unipolar order under its leadership and its status as a super-Power, which has led to scepticism on the part of many countries about the democratic nature of the United States as a "world leader" and its methods of managing the world. At present, Russia and the United States do not share a common assessment of their common interests and are not ready to establish a strategic partnership on an equal footing. One of the main reasons for this is the different understanding of the challenges and threats of the era of globalisation, as well as of the global dimension of the activities of the two countries. The United States foreign policy has further complicated international relations, and the United States should put the establishment of a new international order and the definition of its role in it on the agenda as soon as possible. The new international order should be a repetition of the "concerto" of the world's great Powers and should be the basis for changing the contemporary world and maintaining balance in all spheres.

title_en: A Review of America's NATO Eastward Expansion Strategy
abstract_en: A Review of the U.S. Strategy of NATO's Eastward Expansion Wang Weimin, Nanjing Institute of International Relations On 22 October 1996, U.S. President Bill Clinton, who was giving a campaign speech in Detroit, defied Russia's objections and the misgivings of NATO's allies, and determinedly pushed forward the repeatedly delayed process of NATO's Eastward Expansion, claiming that the U.S. hoped to admit the first batch of former Warsaw Pact member countries as full-fledged members of the NATO by the end of 1999. Although not...
