abstract_en: The first democratic multi-party parliamentary elections since independence were held in the Russian Federation on 12 December last year by the Chairman of the Liberal Democratic Party of Russia (LDPR), V. V. Zhirinovsky Gurry, Qiu Guirong. The Liberal Democratic Party of Russia (LDPR), led by V. V. Zhirinovsky, topped the list of the 13 parties that contested the election, and jumped to become a major influential party in the parliament. The result was unexpected by many...

title_en: Free Economic Zones in Russia and Eastern European Countries
abstract_en: Free Economic Zones in Russia and Eastern European Countries Li Zhen In the process of economic reform in Russia and Eastern European countries, the establishment of free economic zones within a certain scope of the country is an important measure for their transition to a market economy and integration with the world economy. In the free economic zones, investors are exempted from import and export tariffs and various other preferential policies to achieve the introduction of foreign capital, new technologies and advanced management methods, as well as...

title_en: The "New Non-Aligned" Movement in the Global South
abstract_en: Since the outbreak of the Ukraine crisis, countries of the Global South have not blindly followed the West’s demands to isolate and sanction Russia, but have adhered to a new nonalignment stance of not taking sides. It is specifically manifested in the Global South’s passive response or even active opposition to the West’s isolation of Russia in international multilateral mechanisms, their passive cooperation or even active resistance to various sanctions imposed by the West on Russia, and their continued maintenance or even strengthening of friendly exchanges with Russia in bilateral relations. The Global South has made such choices for historical and realistic reasons. The new non-alignment movement of the Global South not only gives Russia the confidence to continue confronting the West on the Ukrainian battlefield to a considerable extent, but also provides support for China to break through the strategic containment of the United States. In addition, it has also made the Global South a new pole in the international system. The Global South is becoming an essential stabilizer during the period of new turbulence and transformation in international relations and is promoting multipolarization in the international pattern.

title_en: Analysing Russia's "Arctic 2035" strategic system
abstract_en: The year 2020 is an important point in the construction of Russia's "Arctic 2035" strategic system. The escalation of competition among Arctic powers due to the "new normal" US-Russia conflict, the reconstruction of the Arctic security pattern by militarisation, and the change in the expectation of benefits from the Arctic development have together given birth to Russia's strategic adjustment from the "oath of rights" and "priority of development" to "security-oriented development". Russia's "Arctic 2035" strategy focuses on strengthening the coordination of internal interests, seeking dominance in international cooperation and the "local effect" of development, emphasising a comprehensive view of security and safeguarding the status of the Arctic as an Arctic superpower, and attaching importance to the systematisation of the strategy and its implementation. Looking ahead, the strategy may break the "competitive balance" in the Arctic, trigger the "pan-security" of international cooperation, accelerate the "blue enclosure" movement and the "green regulation" process, and bring new opportunities and challenges to Sino-Russian cooperation on sustainable development in the Arctic.

title_en: An Exploration of the Impact of the Russian-Georgian Conflict on International Relations
abstract_en: The Russian-Georgian conflict is the first time since the collapse of the Soviet Union that Russian troops have fought outside the country. Various analyses and commentaries have been made in the academic community on this issue, generally fearing that the conflict will lead to the beginning of a "new cold war" and suspecting major changes in the international scene. In reality, Russia was forced to take military action after Georgia's surprise attack on South Ossetia, which was under the protection of the peacekeeping forces, simply to stop NATO's continued eastward expansion. The conflict did not change the overall international environment of "American strength and Russian weakness" or even the Eurasian regional pattern of "American attack and Russian defence". The Russian-Georgian conflict is a "reaction" to the power politics pursued by the United States in various parts of the world since the end of the cold war, and it has given rise to profound reflection on the repeated violation of the norms of international relations in the post-cold-war period.

title_en: Eight years of Putin's diplomacy and its evaluation
abstract_en: The eight years of Putin's diplomacy have left behind a rich "legacy", the essence of which, in a nutshell, includes Russia's positioning as a world power, its multi-polar world structure, its strategic layout based on Eurasia and oriented towards Europe and the United States, its long-term goal of CIS integration, and its two main pillars of energy and the military. Putin's diplomacy is not without its problems and weaknesses: its CIS diplomacy has had its share of gains and losses, Russia's international environment has deteriorated, it has few friends, it is sometimes too pragmatic, and its "hard power" is hard and its "soft power" is soft. Putin's diplomacy is a mixture of many elements, but its basic attribute is a return to tradition.

title_en: Russia's year of strength
abstract_en: In 2006, the adjustment of international pattern accelerated, the world hotspot issue heated up, the coordination of big powers further unfolded, and China's diplomacy was full of fruitful results; in 2007, the world will enter into a deep adjustment, the international situation tends to be moderate in general, but local tensions may be intensified, especially Iran's nuclear issue may be escalated, and China's diplomacy is likely to encounter more complicated challenges in the face of new opportunities. In view of this, the editorial board of Modern International Relations held a seminar on "Prospect of International Situation in 2007" on 6 January 2007, inviting more than 30 experts and scholars from inside and outside Beijing to make prospective analyses of the international situation and the trend of China's diplomacy in 2007, on the basis of summarising and reviewing the international situation in 2006, with emphasis on the changes in China's foreign affairs. The main views of the seminar are summarised here. The main views of the seminar are summarised below, with a view to helping readers grasp the direction of the international situation more accurately.

title_en: Status and direction of U.S.-Russian relations
abstract_en: After "9-1-1", Russia's positive attitude towards the United States and cooperation, had made all parties think that the U.S.-Russia relations have entered a new "honeymoon period", the U.S.-Russia "strategic partnership" claim In the decision-making level of the two countries also gained considerable recognition. However, around the Iraq war, Russia with France and Germany together with the resolute anti-war attitude is greatly unexpected by the United States, and when the United States after the war to France and Germany "unforgivable", but to Russia to "forget about the past" differentiation policy, Yukos President was indicted, the Russian Duma election of right-wing politicians, the United States and Russia have entered a new "honeymoon". Prosecution, the Russian Duma elections, the right wing "total wipeout" and other events, but let the United States "deeply disappointed", to Russia's criticism and even criticism of the voice of endless; Russia naturally not willing to show weakness, in the domestic issues are still "I do what I do", and still "I do what I do", and still "I do what I do", and still "I do what I do", and still "I do what I do", and still "I do not do what I do". I do what I want", in Central Asia and the United States on the issue of military presence, and at the end of January and early February this year, held the largest strategic manoeuvres in more than 20 years. For a time, the U.S.-Russia relations have caused great concern, some even think that U.S.-Russia relations will enter a "small cold war" state. So, exactly how should we judge the current situation of U.S.-Russian relations? What will be its future trend? In this issue, we invite several experts from the China Institute of Modern International Relations to hold an in-depth dialogue around the theme of "the current state and direction of U.S.-Russian relations", hoping that their insights will help you to further deepen your thinking on this issue.

title_en: On Russian Political Parties in Institutional Transition
abstract_en: The 1990s was an important period in the development of political parties in Russia from their embryonic form to stability, and Putin called for the establishment of an effective multi-party system after he came to power, so that it could become a bond of social unity and a political pillar of reform. The election of the third Duma and the promulgation of the Law on Political Parties marked a new stage in the development of political parties in Russia, and the multi-party system pattern dominated by the "centre-right" and "left-right" parties, with the middle faction being strong and the extremist forces being squeezed, has emerged. The current presidential system of government, the maturity of civil society, and the ideological and organisational development of political parties are the three main factors affecting the development of political parties in Russia during the transition period. Russia is at the initial stage of establishing a relatively stable multi-party system; party politics is party politics within the system of "authoritarian democracy"; political parties have not become, and cannot become, the main political mediators between the regime and the society; the status and role of political parties in the life of the country during the transition period are limited.

title_en: New developments in Russian-Japanese relations
abstract_en: AbstractSince 1997, the long-stalemated relations between Russia and Japan has seen a strong momentum of development.  Along with their frequent high-level contacts they have improved their political relations rapidly, and strengthened their economic exchanges and security cooperation. This is a reflection of big powers’ readjustment of their international strategies and their relations among each other in the post-Cold War era.  By promoting its ties with Japan, Russia intends to counterbalance the influence of NATO’s eastward expansion so as to leave more leeway for itself in the international relations, while it wants to take advantage of Japan’s investment and technology to develop its Far East area so as to restore and reinforce its economic capacity as soon as possible.  As far as Japan is concerned, under the condition that its long-time effort in getting back the Northern Territories from Russia could not have a good effect, it expects to change a way of solving the dispute by giving up the principle that "economy must be bound up with politics" and putting forward the three principles of  "mutual confidence, mutual benefit and long-term point of view" in the hope of creating conditions for a final solution of the territorial dispute through cemented political and economic cooperation with Russia.  The improvement of Russian-Japanese relations will contribute to the formation of a multi-polar pattern in the Asia-Pacific region.  However, there will be a lot of obstacles and unstable factors in this course.

title_en: Adjustment of Japan's strategy towards Russia after the Cold War
abstract_en: A striking phenomenon in the development of post-cold-war relations among the major Powers is the improvement of Japan-Russia relations. The two arch-enemies of the past century are gradually shaking off the shackles of the cold war and their ideological rivalry and moving towards "peace and friendship". In this process, Japan has taken proactive diplomatic actions and made significant adjustments to its strategy towards Russia, abandoning the rigid dogma of "political and economic indivisibility" and adopting a "multilayered" approach...

title_en: The economic situation in Russia before the elections
abstract_en: As Russia’s economy is still under the double effects of the economic crisis beginning in last August as well as the long-accumulated problems, it is short of enough impetus to sustained recovery, and can’t improve the comprehensive development condition essentially. The frequent changes of the government and the forthcoming parliamentary and presidential elections have caused direct shock on the country’s economy which has become increasingly the tool of political struggle, and no economic programs and policies could be carried out completely and efficiently in any administration. Russia is confronted with various difficulties such as the lack of incentives for economic growth, the decrease of investment, the decline of people’s living conditions, the reduction of purchasing power, the increase of unemployment and the shrinkage of its foreign trade, etc.. Up to now, Russia hasn’t selected an economic development model which is compatible with its national situation, while the government’s economic regulation is temporary in the main. In face of today’s swift development of the economic globalization, whether Russia can keep its advantageous position in the more and more intensified international competition is decided not only by its domestic economic reform, but also by whether it can join the WTO smoothly as soon as possible and establish an equal trade-partnership with the West. If the intermediate alliance led by Yevgeni Primakov and Yuri Luzhkov can win in the general election, they will not reverse Russia’s reform, and will completely push ahead with the society-oriented market economy and put in central place the revitalization of the national industry. It is estimated that during the early 10 years of the next century Russia’s GDP may be up to 3-5%, and its GDP and overall national strength being expected to rank among the first 10 nations in the world in 2020 or so.

title_en: Main practices and prospects of the Russian military build-up
abstract_en: ＜As the pace of the formation of national armies in the other CIS countries accelerated, Russia changed its original intention of maintaining the unified armed forces of the CIS and, on 16 March 1992, Yeltsin issued a decree on the establishment of an army, and on 7 April he formally announced the start of the formation of Russia's own armed forces. It was initially envisaged that Russia would have a professional armed force with a full range of military branches, great strategic potential and a high degree of mobility, totalling 1.5 million men.

title_en: Current status and prospects for building a common energy market in the Eurasian Economic Union
abstract_en: The construction of a common energy market is a core element of the Eurasian Economic Union's move towards deeper integration. At present, this process is gradually moving from conceptual construction to concrete implementation, with a clear road map for action. As Russia and Kazakhstan seek eastward energy export market demand and China's goal of diversifying energy import sources, infrastructure and industrial cooperation in the field of energy constitutes an important element of the strategic docking between the Silk Road Economic Belt and the Eurasian Economic Union. A comprehensive examination of the construction of a common energy market in the Eurasian Economic Union will undoubtedly be of great significance to the promotion of energy cooperation between the Silk Road Economic Belt and the Eurasian Economic Union.

title_en: Russia's Political Trend in Light of Pre-Election Rivalry
abstract_en: The year 2011 is a key year in the Russian political process. All political forces in Russia are now preparing for the elections and are actively adjusting their campaign strategies with a view to winning the initiative in the December 2011 parliamentary elections and thus laying a good foundation for the March 2012 presidential elections. In the future, the Russian political scene will continue to be dominated by the United Russia Party, while the other parties will continue to be dominated by each other. However, the presidential election in Russia is highly variable, which may end the "Mepo combination" and "double-headed eagle" regime structure and usher in a new governing model, which will have a great impact on the future political ecology of Russia.

title_en: U.S. "Indo-Pacific Strategy" in Russia's Strategic Perspective
abstract_en: Since 2017,the Trump administration has accelerated its"open,free Indo-Pacific strategy."Russia is generally critical of the strategy since it is a challenge to Russia’s"turn east"strategy. At the same time,Russia is glad to see that it is not the main target of US in the region,so there are still new opportunities for its Asia-Pacific diplomacy. Russia adopts a flexible and pragmatic policy,but the policy faces many obstacles. Russia will uphold its inherent principles of Asia-Pacific diplomacy and seek to maximize its strategic benefits.

title_en: Evolution and trend of Russia's policy on the Korean Peninsula
abstract_en: Russia in the North Korean nuclear crisis in the active mediation, played an important role, showing that its peninsula policy has undergone a major change, the reasons for this, how it will develop, this paper through a systematic review of the evolution of Russia's peninsula policy since the end of the Cold War, the future direction of Russia's policy on the peninsula made an analysis and prediction that although Russia will still basically maintain the "balance between North and South "principle, but will take North Korea as an entry point to deal with peninsular affairs, and increase its influence on the situation on the peninsula.

title_en: The direction of Russian-American relations under the Biden administration
abstract_en: ＜The Trump era is drawing to a close. Despite his promise to repair Russia-US relations when he came to power in 2016, the four years of Trump's presidency have been a period of sharp deterioration in Russia-US relations due to the constraints of both international and domestic factors. With Biden's victory in the 2020 presidential election, the future of Russian-American relations has entered a new cycle of development. President Vladimir Putin, in his assessment of the future of Russian-US relations, has expressed the following: Russian-US relations "have been destroyed", "an already bad relationship can not be further destroyed", "we noticed his (Biden) quite sharp anti-Russian rhetoric, but, unfortunately, we are already used to it".

title_en: A test of the prospects for United States-Russian negotiations on tactical nuclear arms reductions
abstract_en: To date, tactical nuclear weapons are an issue that has not been substantively addressed in the United States-Russian nuclear arms control treaty. Tactical nuclear weapons account for a considerable number of items in the nuclear arsenals of the United States and the Russian Federation and are, in a sense, more dangerous than strategic nuclear weapons. The United States and Russia cannot avoid the issue of the reduction of tactical nuclear weapons in the course of the global initiative to move towards a nuclear-free world. Given the differences between the tactical nuclear forces of the United States and the Russian Federation in terms of the size of their arsenals, their security role and deployment posture, as well as the controversy between the two sides over the definition, verification and counting of tactical nuclear weapons, the process of disarmament negotiations on tactical nuclear weapons between the United States and the Russian Federation in the future is going to be difficult, complex and lengthy.

title_en: Russia-US Strategic Engagement and Its Implications for China
abstract_en: After the end of the cold war, the United States made the prevention and containment of Russia's re-emergence an important element of its global political-security policy. This policy has led to the widening and deepening of the contradictions between Russia and the United States in the field of military security and has triggered a series of strategic exchanges between the two sides. The contradictions and exchanges between Russia and the United States in the field of military security have a direct impact on the security and stability of the world and have had a serious negative impact on China's security.

title_en: Features and trends in Russian-American relations
abstract_en: The "debut official state visit" by the Russian President to the United States last June sent a clear message that Russia-US relationship has got breakthrough since Boris Yeltsin assumed office. The two sides called this visit a sign of fundamental change in the bilateral political, economic and military relations and a symbol of the beginning of a new era between the two countries. Politically, the two seem to attempt to form a new "alliance". Yeltsin stressed Russia’s willingness to mold political alliance with NATO headed by the United States. In international affairs,Russia is now satisfied with a minor role and will avoid offending the United States in any ways since both at present and in the foreseeable future Russia will have to seek the bounties of the Unied States on many respects. The bilateral military and intelligent cooperation are being enhanced. The nuclear disarmament between the two will keep going, even it means that the US will regain strategic superiority. There are, however, bugs in the relations. Inklings of political frictions are felt and the trade and economic relations are mediocre at best. In this sense, though Yeltsin’s Washington visit in June gave some impetus to the improvement and development of the overall relations between Russia and the United States, to form a partnership and alliance relations tantamount to that between US and Europe or Japan is still inaccessible in the near future.

title_en: Political situation in Russia after the referendum
abstract_en: ＜A referendum was held in Russia on 25 April, in which 64.5 per cent of the total number of voters (106 million) took part. According to the official results announced by Russia's Central Election Commission on May 5, citizens responded to four questions: (1) whether they trusted the president, with 58.7% of voters expressing their trust; (2) whether they approved of the president's socio-economic policies, with 53% of voters expressing their support; (3) whether there was a need for early elections of the president, with 31.7% in favour; (4) whether there was a need for early elections of the people's representatives, with 31.7% in favour; and (5) whether there was a need for early elections of the people's representatives, with 31.7% in favour. (3) On the necessity of early elections of the President, 31.7 per cent of voters were in favour; (4) on the necessity of early elections of people's deputies, 43.1 per cent of voters were in favour. In accordance with the method of vote counting established by the Russian Constitutional Court, the first two questions were adopted and the last two were rejected.

title_en: A Test of Russian Foreign Policy Adjustment
abstract_en: Since 2009, on the basis of Prime Minister Vladimir Putin's "Innovation Programme", President Medvedev has proposed a programme of "comprehensive modernization" of the country. In order to realise this programme, Russia has begun to adjust its foreign policy, emphasising the principle of "pragmatism" and "modernisation". In the context of this restructuring, Russia still adheres to the principle of a balance between East and West and attaches great importance to its relations with the Asia-Pacific region and the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS), but its open emphasis on the establishment of a "modernisation alliance" with Europe and the United States is unusual.

title_en: The Moscow Treaty and United States-Russian nuclear disarmament
abstract_en: After a brief period of rapid progress in nuclear disarmament in the early 1990s, the United States and Russia have been in a decade-long stalemate, and it was not until the 21st century that the United States and Russia made a new breakthrough in nuclear disarmament, and in May 2002, the United States and Russia signed the Moscow Treaty on the further reduction of strategic nuclear weapons. However, the new U.S.-Russian nuclear disarmament is no longer the same as the traditional nuclear disarmament. The Moscow Treaty, which was concluded under the auspices of the United States and does not impose strict limits on the reduction of strategic nuclear weapons and provide for verification measures, cannot be called real and irreversible nuclear disarmament. It is unlikely that there will be any new progress in United States-Russian nuclear disarmament in the foreseeable future.

title_en: The Problem of Capital Flight from Russia and its Implications
abstract_en: Since the mid of 1990s, a lot of Russia’s capital has  flowed  abroad. The total amount of Russia’s capital outflow is 9% of GDP.   The  deep reasons for Russia’s capital outflow are the instability of  political situation, the wrong selection on economic mode  of  transition,   the instability of macro-economy envioronment,   the  heavy  demestic  and foreign debt, the crisis of financial system and the serious corruption. The capital outflow brings Russia’s economy many bad effects, such  as serious decline  on  the  investment  capital  for  demestic  economic development, bad effects on the balance of international trade and the stability of exchange rate, enlarged risks on debt, etc.   To  conquer these bad effects, the below-listed measures should be taken:  keeping a stable situation  for  politics  and  economy,   further  perfecting management on current account, improving efficiency for controlling on international trade  and  foreign  exchange  rate,   speeding  up  the  reforming  step  of  modern  enterprise  system,   building  a  sound enterprise self-control system,  strengrhening  information  exchanges and international cooperation with other countries  so  as  to  better follow up Russia’s oversea capital,   taking  effective  meassures  to enhance the outflow capital back. Russia’s capital  outflow  shows  us some enlightening Guidances, which are listed below: we should well  treat  the  relationship  among  reform,   development  and  stability,   process sysmatically to push all reform measures to be realized, reform  state-owned enterprises positively and effectively,  and  build  a  vigorous micro-mechanism, enforce the building of legal system  and  completely control the economic activities,positively and safely  push  financial reform and  build a finacial system to  fit  for  the  development  of market economy as soon as possible, and use foreign capital rationally and efficiently

title_en: Russian practice of "hybrid warfare" and its implications
abstract_en: The theory of "hybrid war" was first put forward in 2005 by United States military academics and has since been used by Western scholars to refer to Russia's military actions in the Ukrainian and Syrian crises. The theory is also recognised in Russia and is known as the "Gerasimov doctrine". Russia has used the theory of "hybrid war" as a theoretical guide for its military operations in Ukraine and Syria, and has carried out drills and training in actual combat, creating a distinctive Russian style of "hybrid war," which has achieved good results." The advent of "hybrid warfare" may have a certain impact on future military development.

title_en: Putin's vision of the Eurasian Union: background, goals and its possibilities
abstract_en: Against the backdrop of major changes in the international landscape and the resumption of Russian-American relations, Vladimir Putin published an article in the Russian newspaper Kommersant on 3 October 2011 entitled "A new Eurasian integration plan: the future is born today", in which he put forward the idea of establishing a Eurasian Union in the region of the former USSR, linking the European part of the former USSR with the Asia-Pacific region. The idea of a Eurasian Union is the logical corollary of Russia's long-standing systematic and well-planned efforts to advance the process of Eurasian integration. Russia is attempting to move towards a Eurasian Economic Union economically through the CIS Free Trade Area, the Customs Union within the framework of the Eurasian Economic Community and the Unified Economic Space, and militarily through the Collective Security Treaty Organisation (CSTO), which will give it greater control over regional security matters. The ultimate goal is to achieve the integration of the former Soviet region, including the political union, and to make it a pole in a multipolar world.

Recently, the deepening of cooperation in the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO) and the establishment of United States military bases in Central Asian countries have aroused even greater concern. title_en: NATO-Russian-European relations

Because of the interaction between Russian-European and Russian-North relations, Russia must at the same time strengthen its relations with NATO in order to ensure the success of its policy of giving priority to the development of its relations with Europe. In view of the complex relations between Russia, the European Union, NATO and the United States, the development of Russo-European relations could further promote the institutionalisation of Russian-North American cooperation and reduce the role of NATO as an instrument of American global strategy. However, due to strategic and economic differences and contradictions, there are obvious limitations in Russian-European cooperation, which will lead to a significant limitation of the influence and role of Russian-European relations in the above-mentioned areas.

abstract_en: Central and Eastern Europe（CEE）has long been the arena for big powers to fight for sphere of influence.Recently,it has again been a geopolitical hot spot,where a fierce game is going on among the US,Russia,Europe and CEE countries.The US tries to use CEE as a geopolitical tool to contain Russia,control Europe and exert influence on the development of EU-Russian relationship.Russia combines both toughness and tolerance,endeavouring to prevent the emergence of a united"anti-Russian front",maintaining the CEE role as a buffer zone between Russia and the West,and safeguarding the traditional Russian influence.The EU has been weakened,thus losing some control over CEE countries,suffering from accumulated worries about external intervention,especially Russian "penetration",so it is fighting hard for its leading role in the CEE region.As for CEE countries,they are still positioned on the political battlefield among the EU,US and Russia.However,they are turning to be proactive geopolitical players.It is remarkable that they changed what we used to call"Lean to one side",and demonstrated a diversified and pragmatic foreign policy,which expanded their autonomy.

The Strategic Game of the Parties Behind the Second Naqqa War
abstract_en: In September 2020, the largest war in the Nagorno-Karabakh region since the 1990s erupted, fuelled by historical, religious and inter-ethnic grievances, as well as by practical factors. In the war, not only Azerbaijan and Armenia, as the two parties to the conflict, were deeply involved, but also the regional countries Turkey, Iran and Russia, as well as the external Western Powers, the United States and France, chose their own positions and intervened in the direction of the war to varying degrees. As a result, the impact of the war went beyond the conflict itself. Russia has consolidated its unique influence in the region through active coordination, the West has shrunk its non-core interests in the face of its declining power, and Turkey, as a regional power, has entered the chaos as a dark horse in an attempt to fill the vacuum of great power. Against the backdrop of a more complex game among the major powers, the Naka issue is far from over and will continue to pose new threats to regional security and stability in the future.

title_en: Japan's Initiatives and Strategic Concepts in Response to the Russia-Ukraine Conflict
abstract_en: Since the outbreak of the Russia-Ukraine conflict, Japan has been promoting shuttle diplomacy with the United States, Europe, East Asian countries and Ukraine’s neighbors, exploring the opportunity of sanctioning Russia to promote its national strategy and maximize its national interests. Japan has regarded the conflict as an important leverage to subvert the post-World War II international order. It has tried to reconstruct a new international order dominated by military, technology and economy with the United States and Europe. Japan has exerted pressure on Russia. It has also taken the opportunity of the conflict to exaggerate the“China threat”,strengthen the QUAD, build its military and security cooperation with NATO, and instigate regional confrontation,trying to obtain the new benefits similar in the Cold War.

title_en: On the New Relationship between China and Russia
Evolution and development of EU-US-Russia-China relations

After the "9-11 incident", the perception of the globalisation of insecurity has strengthened the sense of maintaining the Atlantic Alliance between Europe and the United States, and the conflicts have been eased, and the cohesion of the Atlantic Alliance has risen. But in the medium and long term, Europe and the United States both co-operation and competition of the overall situation will not change. After the "9-11 incident" Russia and the United States of America's rapid proximity to make the European-Russian relations some "dark", but this is only the surface phenomenon, the basic factors affecting the European-Russian relations have not changed. The European Union occupies the same or even a priority position with the United States in Russia's foreign strategy. The EU's policy towards China is still based on cooperation and dialogue. The ever-expanding economic, political and strategic interests between Europe and China have laid a good foundation for the maintenance of long-term stable and cooperative relations between the two sides.

title_en: Russian Government Crisis Review
abstract_en: Abstract There existed deep background behind the Russian administration’s crisis: Politically, the threat from the opposition has diminished, the struggle for benefit between the financial groups and political groups has accelerated.  The contradictions in the center of the upper powers have come to surface.  The main social contradictions have shifted from the strife between the authority and the opposition to internal one among the ruling groups.  Economically,although the economy has been  picking up,its accumulated problems remain unsolved.  Yeltsin has two purposes to achieve in changing the government: one is to solidify the president’s centralized status, to reduce the financial group’s influence on the government and to make early preparations for next presidential election; the other is to completely solve the economic problems that the Chernomyrdin administration could not afford to cope with so as to ensure the economic growth.  Therefore, Yeltsin required the new government to implement the "twelve major affairs" the former government had set based on social harmony and stability while pursuing administrative reforms to reduce the staff and raise the efficiency of the administration,  straightening out the relations between the central and local governments, enhancing state’s macro-control, ensuring the stability of the national finance, promoting productive investment and strengthening social security. But the new government faces many challenges and difficulties which may make the government’s tough economic policy unworkable, such as the possibility for the congress and financial magnates to make trouble, the government’s daily work being likely to be interfered by early preparation for next election and so many economic difficulties and social problems lingering ahead.

title_en: China-US-Russia Strategic Relations in a Multidimensional Perspective
abstract_en: Since the end of the cold war and, in particular, since 11 September, relations between China, the United States and the Russian Federation have undergone profound changes, revealing new features. It is no longer possible to apply the unilinear or one-dimensional thinking of the cold war and earlier periods, in which relations between countries were seen as "either enemies or friends". At present, China, the United States and Russia are partners in many areas. The fact that the three countries are geostrategic and traditional security rivals is not only not a major aspect of trilateral relations, but has become a kind of pressure that makes them pay attention to the development of trilateral relations. Driven by their common interests, the three countries are actively developing their relations with the other two, seeking cooperation and avoiding confrontation. For the sake of the interests of the three countries and the peace, security and development of the world, China, the United States and the Russian Federation should abandon the cold war mentality and the traditional power politics and, on the basis of the principles of peace, equality and cooperation, construct a new type of trilateral relations characterised by complementarity, mutual benefit and win-win cooperation.

abstract_en: Oil and international relations For a hundred years the "oil factor" has been an important aspect of international relations. "The American Oil Company, the Anglo-Dutch Oil Company, the British Petroleum Company were the initiators of many world political events and their complication, and contributed to the development of extremely important foreign policy by the governments of the leading Western countries. The American Oil Company, the Anglo-Dutch Oil Company, and the British Petroleum Company were the initiators of many of the world's political events and complications at the time, and were the driving force behind the foreign policies of the major Western governments.

abstract_en: The current situation and development trend of the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS), Liu Guiling, has been established for more than six years, with many twists and turns, and has travelled a tortuous and bumpy road of development. At present, the basic direction of CIS integration has been determined, but the process is slow, difficult and lurking many crises, and the international community is generally concerned about its development prospects. After the establishment of the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) in December 1991, the independent States went through the process of "association" and...

abstract_en: Liu Guiling and Feng Yujun, Russia's foreign policy has been adjusted several times in the five years since Russia's independence, shifting from "sharp contraction" and "Western orientation" at the beginning of independence to an all-round diplomacy of "restoring the influence of the great powers" and "restoring the influence of the great powers". The foreign policy of Russia has been adjusted several times in the past five years since its independence. After Yeltsin was re-elected president, the basic foreign policy will not change, but will make some adjustments to specific policies. First, after the adjustment of the preliminary orientation of the foreign policy (a) from the pro-Western to "...

title_en: Strategic reorientation of Russian-Japanese relations towards the twenty-first century
abstract_en: AbstractTaking advantage of the readjustment  of major power relations at the turn of the century, Russia and Japan endeavor  to improve their relations.  During their recent informal meeting, the heads  of the two countries decided to strive for the conclusion of peace treaty before the year 2000 so as to solve the territorial dispute or at least find out an option for the settlement of it, thus making a turnaround change for the long-stalemated and cooled relations of the two countries in the post-World War.  The improvement of Russo-Japanese relations reflect their respective considerations.  On the part of Russia, its intentions are:（1） to speed up the process of entering into Asia-Pacific circle in a bid to set its status as an Eurasian Major power; （2）"to make use of the relationship with the East to push ahead that with the West "so as to alter the unfavorable position in its diplomacy to the West; （3） by attracting Japanese capital and technology to facilitate the rejuvenation of Russian economy.  From the Japanese point of view, it has following aspirations: （1） to be accepted as a permanent member of UN security council needs Russian support; （2） through improving the relations with Russia, to define its new diplomatic agenda oriented to the Asia-Pacific region in the 21th century; （3） to rely on Russia’s help in the need of energy resources in the years ahead.  However, the development of Russo-Japanese relations is restricted by the territorial disputes and the relationship of major powers.

title_en: EU sanctions against Russia since the Ukraine crisis and their impact
abstract_en: Since the Ukraine crisis broke out in February 2022, the EU has issued 12 packages of sanctions against Russia. In terms of its evolution, it has mainly experienced three stages: rapid escalation, highlighting restrictions in the energy sectors, and cracking down on sanctions evasion. EU sanctions against Russia mainly target finance, energy, transport, trade, technology, and other industries. The scales and strengths of such sanctions against Russia have escalated; key areas and development trends of sanctions are extending to the third parties. EU sanctions against Russia not only have direct impacts on Russia, but also have complex impacts on the EU itself. However, the effectiveness of EU sanctions against Russia is increasingly limited, mainly due to the internal constraints of the EU and the weakness caused by its energy predicament, Russia’s economic and social resilience, and Russia’s appropriate responses to sanctions.

title_en: Analysing the situation in Central Asia in two directions
abstract_en: As the heart of the Eurasian continent, the importance of Central Asia in world geopolitics is self-evident, and its position has been further accentuated by the active involvement of the major Powers in the aftermath of 11 September. Beginning in 2005, the Central Asian countries will enter a period of political change marked by parliamentary and presidential elections. Because of the rampant extremism, terrorism and separatism in the region; the economic development of the countries has not yet entered a benign state; the successive "revolutions" in Georgia and Ukraine have had a certain demonstration and inspirational effect on the Central Asian opposition; and the complicated relations of the big powers in Central Asia, the situation in Central Asia is full of many variables. In order to have a more accurate grasp of the direction of the situation in Central Asia, the Expert Forum of Modern International Relations, in cooperation with the Eurasian Office of the China Institute of Modern International Relations, held a one-day seminar on the theme of "Analysis and Prospects of the Situation in Central Asia" on 19 January 2005 at Wanshoushan Zhuang. A one-day seminar was held on 19 January 2005 at Wanshou Mountain. Scholars and experts from Beijing, Shanghai, Lanzhou and Ningxia held serious and in-depth discussions on the situation in Central Asia from various perspectives in the spirit of truth-seeking and pragmatism. The speeches of the participants are hereby published in the hope that they will help you to think about the relevant issues and promote the deepening of the study of Central Asia.

title_en: Russian military reform at the turn of the century
The "colour revolution" and the future course of the CIS
abstract_en: The "colour revolution" is a continuation of the establishment of a new national identity for the former Soviet States following the collapse of the Soviet Union. If the break-up of the Soviet Union solved the problem of "who to leave" in these countries, the "colour revolutions" will solve the problem of "who to approach". At present, the possibility of "colour revolutions" in the CIS countries still exists, with Georgia and Ukraine mulling the formation of the "Democratic Alternative Union" and the "GUAM Union" trying to make a comeback. Russia's means of maintaining the CIS. Given Russia's limited means of maintaining the CIS and its flawed policy, the CIS will face a series of serious challenges in its future development.

title_en: Sino-Russian relations: ally or partner?
abstract_en: After experiencing many ups and downs in their relationship,China and Russia have forged a strategic partnership since the advent of the 21 st century. While Russia’s relations with the United States and the European Union have hit a rough patch,its ties with China are on an upward trend. Meanwhile,the United States and Europe are closely watching the two big neighbors in case of the event of a creation of an anti- Western "axis. "Grounded in an analysis of the unique advantages of China- Russia relations,this paper argues that the two countries have established a high level of political trust and will continue to work in concert on all fronts. It also looks back at how China entered into alliances throughout its history and the lessons it has learned from those experiences. It emphasizes that China does not deem the establishment of exclusive alliances or political blocs as a foreign policy option.

title_en: Central Asian Caucasus a focus of great power rivalry
abstract_en: Central Asia and the Caucasus have become the focus of competition among major powers Feng Yujun Ma Xiangyun I. After the collapse of the Soviet Union, the Central Asia and Caucasus region around the Caspian Sea has seen a "power vacuum", and all kinds of international forces want to intervene in the affairs of the region. Especially recently, as the wave of oil and gas resources development in the Caspian Sea region continues to heat up and the struggle between Russia and the United States over the issue of NATO's eastward expansion has been put to rest, the United States, Russia and other world powers, as well as Turkey, I...

abstract_en: U.S.-Russian military theory and its practice Warm-flavoured several After the end of the Cold War, the U.S. and Russian research on military theory, especially on the shape of modern warfare, entered a new phase, and many new theories, concepts, and policies were put forward. At present, the U.S. and Russian military services are adjusting their strategies and tactics in accordance with these new theories, concepts and policies. Compared with the Cold War period, there are six major developments and changes. First, national security ...

title_en: New changes in Russian-Indian relations and their prospects
abstract_en: Russia-India relations are relatively stable among major powers. However, in recent years, due to the profound adjustment of the international and regional strategic environment, the two countries’ foreign strategies have become more and more divergent. Besides, the traditional momentum of bilateral cooperation has weakened, and the differences between the two countries have gradually increased and come into the open. In particular, different views and policies on the"Indo-Pacific"have become major strategic differences between the two countries. In the foreseeable future, the foundation of Russia-India strategic cooperation may not be fundamentally shaken, but the trend of the two countries’ foreign strategies"drifting apart"will be difficult to reverse, and the differences between the two countries will exist and possibly widen. The change of Russia-India relations will affect the international and regional situation. For China, the overall stability of Russia-India relations is in its interest.

title_en: United States missile defence plans and their implications
abstract_en: The United States missile defence programme has undergone a long period of development and evolution. After the end of the cold war, the United States gradually formed a relatively complete set of missile defence doctrines and began to formally deploy anti-missile systems during the presidency of George W. Bush. The US missile defence programme in the new era has objectively stimulated the global missile and missile defence race. The role of missile defence is imaginary, but the arms race triggered by it is real. The future course of the United States missile defence programme is still full of uncertainties.

title_en: Problems and Issues in the Caucasus
abstract_en: At present, Caucasus is highlighted with hot-spot issues: 1) Russia and Chechen come to a deadlock over Chechen’s breakaway issue; 2) Disputes over the Nagorno-Karabakh region between Armenia and Azerbaijan are still outstanding; 3) Georgians and Abkhazians in the Georgia Republic are still at war for Abkhazia’s independence; 4) North Ossetia and Ingushetia see no hope to resolve their territory disputes. These hot-spot issues were caused by ethnic, religious, social, economic and international factors. From the point of view of development, Caucasus has an uncertain future because a series of contradictions and problems are hard to be resolved and the situation there is hard to be stabilized. 1) The final political status of Chechen is hard to be defined; 2) The international Islamic extremists and terrorists will continue to encroach on regional affairs and create incidents in the region; 3) Governments of regional countries work out no way to solve the territory disputes; 4) Russia and the United States will continue to scramble for spheres of influence in the region; 5) Political and economic situation can not be improved in a short period.
