title_en: Russia's "Eurasian Union" Strategy and Its Impact on Sino-Russian Relations
abstract_en: In the 20 years since the dissolution of the Soviet Union, two different trends have emerged within the Commonwealth: on the one hand, the fragmentation of the organisation and, on the other, the regrouping of its member States and the strengthening of their integration in different areas and at different levels. Vladimir Putin has proposed the gradual establishment of a comprehensive Eurasian Union on the basis of the Customs Union of Russia, Belarus and Kazakhstan and the Eurasian Economic Community, which will become a new organisation for the integration of the CIS region and a basis for Russia's strategy of pursuing the goal of becoming a "powerful pole of the world". Russia's efforts to promote the Eurasian Union may have a certain impact on Sino-Russian relations and on relations between China and other countries in the Eurasian region, as well as on the SCO.

title_en: An analysis of the "BRICs phenomenon"
abstract_en: In October 2003, the Goldman Sachs Investment Company of the United States published a study entitled "The Dream of BRICs: The Road to 2050", which has caused a great deal of repercussions in the international community. The report predicted the development prospects of four large developing countries, such as Brazil, Russia, India and China, and concluded that the rapid economic growth of the four countries would continue until about 2050, and that their total economic output would reach half of the "G6" group of the United States, Japan, Germany, the United Kingdom, France, Italy and so on in 2025; and that they would surpass the "G6" group in 2045. Regardless of whether this prediction is accurate or not, the report reveals the "BRICs phenomenon" is worthy of serious discussion in the academic community. What does the report reflect? What does it mean? How do we look at the development of the four countries and their interrelationships? With these questions in mind, we invite six experts from the China Institute of Modern International Relations (CIMIR) to hold a dialogue, in the hope of attracting your attention and thinking about further economic and political explanations of this phenomenon.

title_en: Russia's political situation after the change of government
abstract_en: On 12 May, President Yeltsin dissolved the Primakov government and appointed First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of the Interior Stepashin as Acting Prime Minister; on 19 May, the Russian Duma approved the nomination of a new Prime Minister by an absolute majority in the first round of voting. The dissolution of the Prussian government is the inevitable result of the fierce competition between the upper echelons of the Russian political forces in recent times, which has plunged Russia into a new round of political and economic crisis. I. The Prussian government...

title_en: The situation in the CIS in retrospect and prospect
abstract_en: Review and Prospects of the CIS This year marks the fifth anniversary of the founding of the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS), which has travelled a tortuous and bumpy road over the past five years, with its member States oscillating between "independence" and "association". To date, this nascent international organisation has neither become a vibrant entity nor has it died out. Over the past two years, the CIS has become more "centred" and is actively seeking a place in the world...

title_en: Prospects for the development of good-neighbourly relations between China and Russia
Reflections on the Changing Relationship between China, Russia and the United States
abstract_en: The war in Iraq and the Korean nuclear crisis are the two major events that have attracted the most global attention. The controversies and changes triggered in the world around these two major events, especially the former, cannot but make everyone concerned about international affairs and the fate of their respective countries fall into contemplation: will international politics and international relations enter a new historical period from now on? How to grasp the direction and characteristics of the international situation? What do all these changes mean for China? How should China adjust its foreign policy to the times in order to maximise its strategic interests? It is undoubtedly necessary and practical to go beyond the progress of specific events to explore these important issues in depth and rationally from a more forward-looking perspective. For this reason, the Expert Forum of Modern International Relations held a one-day seminar at Wanshoushan Villa on 28 March with the theme of "China's Diplomacy under the New Circumstances", in which some renowned scholars and experts from Beijing and Shanghai conducted in-depth analyses and discussions on this issue from different professional perspectives. I am pleased to publish it here, calling for its sound and seeking for its friends' voices. At the time of printing, the war in Iraq is almost over, and North Korea has also sent a message of willingness to accept multilateral consultations, so I asked the relevant representatives to make additions and corrections. Hereby, I would like to make a statement.

title_en: The Caspian Sea region is becoming a new world hotspot
abstract_en: The Caspian Sea region1 was a battleground for the world's great powers in the 19th century, but in the 1990s, with the dissolution of the Soviet Union and the transformation of the region's former Soviet republics into independent nation-states, and with the exploration and imminent exploitation of its rich oil and gas resources, American, European, and Western powers stepped in to exert ever greater influence. It is expected that by the beginning of the next century, the situation surrounding...

title_en: Strategic analyses and lessons for the "reboot" of Russian-American relations
abstract_en: Since the Obama administration restarted its policy towards Russia, Russia and the United States have resumed cooperation on strategic issues such as strategic arms reduction, sanctions against Iran and counter-terrorism in Afghanistan. Due to the major differences between Russia and the United States in terms of strategic goals, fundamental interests and values, the restarted Russian-American relations are still full of uncertainties. Doubts and objections to the restart of U.S.-Russian relations within the two countries are affecting the future trend of relations between the two countries. How far Obama's policy of restarting U.S.-Russia relations will go, and whether Russia-U.S. relations will be able to break out of the cycle of sudden easing followed by rapid deterioration, are crucial to the trend of changes in the global landscape. An analysis of the elements of Russia-United States relations can serve as a reference for the study of trends in China-United States relations.

title_en: Deeper Causes and Implications of the Russian-Georgian Conflict
abstract_en: At the end of September 2006, the "spy fiasco" between Russia and Georgia triggered the most serious crisis in relations between the two countries since the collapse of the Soviet Union. Behind the Russian-Georgian contradictions and conflicts are the conflicting interests of the two countries over Abkhazia and South Ossetia, as well as Russia's geopolitical rivalry with the West over Georgia. The deterioration of Russian-Georgian relations will have a number of important consequences for the situation in Georgia and the Transcaucasian region, for the future of the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) and for Russian-Western relations.

title_en: An Exploration of Germany's Dual-Track Policy Towards Russia Since the Ukraine Crisis
abstract_en: Germany and Russia are two important countries in Europe and in the world. Germany’s policy toward Russia is one of its most important foreign policies. In March 2018,the new governments of Germany and Russia came to power one after another. Since the outbreak of the Ukraine crisis in 2014,the relations between Germany and Russia have fallen into the doldrums. Germany’s policy toward Russia faces a dilemma and is committed to the two track path of sanctions and dialogue. There are multiple reasons for this,including domestic,international factors,political,security and economic issues. Germany’s policy toward Russia not only affects the bilateral relations,but also has an impact on Europe and the international relations.

title_en: A Review of the Independence of the Diplomatic Strategies of the Central Asian States
abstract_en: Influenced by various factors, including the Ukraine crisis, competition among major countries, and the COVID-19 pandemic, Central Asian countries are gradually displaying characteristics of independence and autonomy in their foreign policies. However, the West often narrowly interprets the independent foreign policies of Central Asian countries as derussification. Currently, Central Asian countries are placing greater emphasis on achieving external strategic independence and autonomy while remaining pragmatic in their approach, seeking to maximize their interests. This does not constitute a substantive derussification nor a shift towards the West, let alone a complete transformation of their foreign policies and national identity. On the contrary, the Central Asian countries, recognizing the fact that the Western model, which was more attractive more than 30 years ago, is in deep crisis, are searching for ways to maintain the independence and autonomy of their countries’ political and economic development in the light of the historical opportunity presented by the shift in great-power rivalry towards the Central Asian geopolitical zone in the wake of the Ukraine crisis.

title_en: Analysing Russia's "Turn to Asia" Strategy
abstract_en: The global financial crisis of 2008 led to a period of major adjustments in the international landscape and a rapid shift of the world's political and economic centre to the Asia-Pacific region. In order to cope with the current complex and volatile international situation, consolidate the status of a great power, achieve the task of modernising the domestic economy, revitalise Siberia and the Far East, and integrate into the Asia-Pacific integration process and other multiple considerations, the Russian political and academic circles in the past two years have put forward the "shift to Asia", which includes geostrategic shifts, economic shifts, and parallel shifts in the three major parts of the Russian policy. However, Russia's Asian policy is to a large extent subject to its traditional European identity positioning, Russian-European relations, Russian-American relations and other constraints, its "turn to Asia" will be limited and strategic.

title_en: Putin's Economic Thought and Prospects for Russian Economic Development
abstract_en: Putin ruled Russia, pay special attention to economic development, put forward to "catch up" as the characteristics of the economic development of ideas, asking the government to put forward "ambitious" economic revitalisation plan, and strive in the next 10-20 years, to enter the ranks of the world's developed countries. In the next 10-20 years, to enter the ranks of the world's developed countries. The article argues that the Russian government's medium- and long-term programme is pragmatic and feasible, although it does not quite meet the president's requirement of "high-speed development". The article briefly analyses and evaluates Putin's main ideas of economic development and Russia's development trends in the next decade.

title_en: Basic directions of the diplomacy of the CIS countries
abstract_en: The establishment of the Commonwealth of Independent States, formally declaring the complete dissolution and elimination of the Soviet Union, was followed by the fact that each republic entered onto the world stage as an independent state one after another. Russia once put forwarda suggestion of setting up a general institute to coordinate the foreign policies of the Commonwealth of Independent States, but got no response from the other which acted on each’s will in diplomacy. Having inherited the diplomatic status of the former USSR, Russia will further pursue the "new thinking" diplomacy centering on the western countries, in which Russia-US relatios are its top priority, due to its urgent need in the economic and political fields. with huge potential resources, Russia, still one of the global powers, also has to pay attention to the width of its international contacts. The Central Asian countries are located in a specific geographical position and possess an important strategic status. Being rich in mineral resources, they are bogged down in a quagmire and are urgently in need of foreign aid, a case accounting for the active entry into this region in succession by the US and other western countries. At the same time, the Central Asian countries arc energetically unfolding geodiplornacy by means of their deep historical origins with the neighbouring Muslim world in the aspects of races, religions, languages and cultural traditions. As an European power, Ukraine puts its diplomatic emphasis on the West and meanwhile attaches importance to developing the relations with the other countries and regions, particularly the oil-rich countries in the Middle East. Since it is only three months after the establishment of the Commonwealth of Independent States, there still exist complicated contradictions among the member states, and each is beset with various troubles, further observation and studies are needed on the evolution of their foreign policies.

title_en: My view of great power relations
abstract_en: Since "9-1-1", the relations among the great powers have undergone a number of intriguing and substantive changes. How to understand these changes, and theoretically summarise and conclude the essence of these changes, undoubtedly has an important practical significance, but also a forward-looking subject, worthy of great attention in the field of international relations and in-depth, rational discussion. On 1 March, the Expert Forum of Modern International Relations invited authoritative scholars and experts on international issues in Beijing to hold a one-day seminar, and conducted in-depth theoretical discussions and analyses on the above issues from different perspectives. The seminar is now presented to you as a "welcome gift" for the establishment of the Expert Forum on Modern International Relations, in the hope of promoting further in-depth exploration of this issue in the academic circles.

title_en: Looking Around the World Looking Ahead - Summary of the Symposium on the International Situation
abstract_en: More than 20 specialists and scholars from various units in Beijing were invited by the editorial department of Contemporary International Relations to participated a symposium entitled"The International Situation in Retrospect and Prospect"on Dec. 7. 1992. In the symposium, they freeiy aired from various angles their own views based on the latest development. They reviewed and analyzed the newly appeared phenomenon and predicted the future developing trend of the international situation and situation in some regions and countries after the disintegration of the former Soviet Union. The main points of their talks are covered in this issue and they are related with the following aspects: （1） the world political and economic situations; （2） Europe and the United States; （3） the Commonwealth of Independent States, Russia in particular; （1） Asia: and （5） the Middle East, Africa and Latin America.

title_en: Russia's strategic direction in the light of its new National Security Strategy
abstract_en: In July 2021, Russia published its new National Security Strategy, which was updated extensively and it revealed several new features. The Russia’s strategy is very inward-looking in a foreseeable future based on the analysis of Russia’s new National Security Strategy and Russia’s policies in recent years.Domestic policies will be more conservative, diplomacy will generally be on the defensive, and the economic policies will place more emphasis on security and independence. Russia’s inward-looking strategy is not totally defensive, it is to accumulate its strength and wait for changes. Russia’s inward-looking strategy makes it difficult to have good relations with the West. China-Russia relations will continue to develop steadily. At the same time, Russia will pay more attention to the balance of great powers.

title_en: Need to worry about rising Chinese influence in Central Asia?
abstract_en: In December 2012 Vorobyov published an article in the magazine "Russia in Global Politics", in which he expressed his views on China's Central Asian policy and on the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO). He believes that Central Asia is of strategic importance for China, that friendly and cooperative relations between China and Central Asian countries are deepening, that the "China model" is attractive to Central Asian countries, that the establishment of the SCO provides institutional guarantees for the further development of China's relations with Central Asian countries, and that Russia and China have common interests in Central Asia and can coexist harmoniously.

title_en: "Construction of the Nord Stream-2 pipeline and the Russian-American-European energy game
abstract_en: At the end of 2019, the United States introduced a sanctions bill against the "Nord Stream-2" gas pipeline, forcing the construction of the project to be suspended, Russia, the European Union and the United States around the project game has aroused widespread concern in the international community, reflecting the strategic considerations of the parties behind the energy issue. The European Union's efforts to resist U.S. pressure to release the construction of the Nord Stream-2 pipeline reflect its own strategic intentions in the energy sector. Russia, on the other hand, hopes to seek a strategic breakthrough from Western sanctions by developing energy cooperation with the EU. The United States, in addition to considering its domestic gas exports, is worried that the improvement of relations between Russia and the EU in the energy sector will reduce its leverage to contain Russia, and the changes in the international energy situation caused by the global epidemic in 2020 will have a new impact on the construction of the Nord Stream-2 pipeline. Once the "Nord Stream-2" pipeline is put into operation, it may realise the "rebalancing" of Europe's energy power towards the United States, and the distorted European energy pattern due to the Russian-American-European game may also be readjusted.

title_en: The Balkans - a powder keg that has not been extinguished
abstract_en: On 10 June, the United Nations, through the seven Western countries, reached a peace agreement with the Russian Government on a political settlement of the Kosovo crisis; on 20 June, about 40,000 Federal Republic of Yugoslavia troops and police were withdrawn from Kosovo, and NATO Secretary-General Solana announced the cessation of bombing in the south, thus officially ending the 11-week-long NATO war of aggression against the south. But the road to real peace in Kosovo will be long and bumpy, and the whole ba...

title_en: Views on several hot issues in the international situation
CIS advances towards integration
abstract_en: On 2 April this year, Russian President Boris Yeltsin and Belarusian President Petro Lukashenko signed a treaty on the establishment of a Russian-Belarusian "community" in Moscow. According to Yeltsin, the treaty "will open a new stage in the history of two fraternal peoples, two sovereign states". Lukashenko praised Russia and Belarus for "a historic step forward" in cooperation, and that the two countries "will...

title_en: The Chechnya issue is a difficult one to resolve
"Transition countries" and United States strategy
abstract_en: The United States divides the major countries of the world into four categories such as “allies”, “periphery States”, “Pariah States” and “the Transforming States”. The U.S. treats each of the four countries in different approaches. At present, since the U.S. has completed its basic strategic readjustments towards the first three categories, “the Transforming Nations” are likely to become the top priority of the U.S. global strategy in the future. “The Transforming Nations” mainly refers to the three major powers like Russia, China and India. They are evolving at the direction of political democratization and economic liberalization, though prospect still not clear. In the American points of view, there not only exists great “uncertainty” in the development of the three countries, but the three countries have the “potentials” to unite into an anti-American strategic alliance, which will constitute a major “potential threat”. Therefore, the U.S. is ready to take two layers of strategies in response to this situation,  Firstly, to carry out a policy of “Constructive Engagement”, to lead those countries to a direction in favor of the United States; Secondly, to implement a strategy of  “divide and rule” or checking neighbors against one another, in order to prevent them from organizing alliance. Among these three countries, what the U.S. worries the most is China, which is not only left still a Communist country, but also a power rising rapidly. In the future, it is probable that the U.S. reinforce its relationships with Russia and India to check and balance against China. China should seek strategic balance of power among the U.S., Russia, and India.

title_en: A test analysis of the new dynamics in Northeast Asia after the U.S.-DPRK nuclear deal
abstract_en: A test analysis of the new situation in Northeast Asia after the U.S.-DPRK nuclear agreement Zhang Ruhai The U.S. and the DPRK formally signed an Agreed Framework on the resolution of the DPRK nuclear issue in Geneva on 21 October last year. The signing of the framework agreement has become a new opportunity for Northeast Asia to move towards détente, and has led to the most subtle change in the situation in the region since the post-war period. This paper attempts to examine the policy intentions of the countries concerned in Northeast Asia and their mutual...

title_en: Shifting the centre of gravity of power in global economic governance: the G20 and the strategies of the great powers
abstract_en: The formation of the G20 mechanism is considered to mark a shift in the centre of gravity of global economic governance, but the further development of the G20 faces challenges. On the one hand, although Europe tends to strengthen this mechanism, the United States is still the dominant player and defender of the current international economic order, and Japan is strongly opposed to replacing the G8 with the G20; on the other hand, the limitations of its own strength and the constraints of its domestic problems will inevitably affect the emerging powers to play a greater role in the G20. The shift in the centre of gravity of global economic governance is a general trend, and the emerging economies represented by the BRICS countries should actively promote the development of the G20 and contribute to the promotion of this shift.

title_en: Exploration of a United Nations management model for the Tumen River Development Zone
abstract_en: ＜With the active support and promotion of the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), China, the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK), Russia and other countries concerned are stepping up their efforts to promote international cooperation in the development of the Tumen River region. There are two "Golden Triangles" in the Tumen River Delta: the Big Triangle consists of Yanji in China, Chongjin in North Korea, and Vladivostok in Russia, covering an area of about 10,000 square kilometres; and the Small Triangle refers to the areas of Jingxin in China, southern Hassan in Russia, and Rojin and Pioneer in North Korea, which is about 1,000 square kilometres in size. The mode of international co-operation in the Tumen River Small Triangle Development Zone can take various forms. For example, China, Russia and the DPRK can establish their own development zones, which can be coordinated or co-managed by the three countries, or managed by multinational corporations, etc. The main focus here is on the development zone managed by the United Nations. Here we will mainly discuss the model managed by the United Nations. The concept of this model is: (1) under the auspices of the United Nations, six countries, namely China, Russia, the DPRK, South Korea, Japan and Mongolia, sign an international agreement and decide to establish a special cooperation zone; (2) the legislatures of the countries concerned adopt the "Basic Law", which is the basic law for the establishment of a special cooperation zone.

title_en: The Islamic factor in the Chechen crisis
The US-Russia INF Treaty Compliance Dispute and Its Future Direction
abstract_en: In July 2014,the U. S. State Department,in its arms-control annual report,accused Russia of violating the INF Treaty signed by the U. S. and the USSR in 1987,triggering a new round of diplomatic confrontation between the two countries. The reasons for the frequent U. S.-Russia disputes on the INF Treaty are multiple,including historical roots,security concerns and realistic political factors of the both sides. The future of the INF Treaty will depend on the dynamic evolution of both U. S. and Russian politics and its impact on the security environment of the two countries. In the short term,the U. S. and Russia will continue to focus on solving the problems of implementing the treaty; in the long term,the U. S. and Russia are likely to transform the INFT into a multilateral treaty.

title_en: Analysis of the prospects for a "reset" in US-Russia relations
abstract_en: After Obama became President of the United States, he began to "restart" United States-Russian relations. The United States and Russia signed a new Treaty on the Reduction and Limitation of Offensive Arms, to strengthen cooperation on counter-terrorism in Afghanistan and the Iranian nuclear issue, the resumption and deepening of bilateral military cooperation, but also the establishment of the two countries' Presidential Commission, bilateral cooperation to the economy, the humanities and other areas of expansion. However, the current improvement of U.S.-Russian relations is difficult to break through the structural contradictions between the two countries, the U.S. is determined to deploy a missile defence system, insisting on the eastward expansion of NATO, the two countries on the Georgian issue of tit-for-tat, in Central Asia, strategic competition remains. Due to the difficulty of reconciling the goals of the United States and Russia, it is difficult to achieve a substantive breakthrough in relations between the two countries.

title_en: Monthly Review of Events (January)
The World Strategy of Western Conservatism - A Review of National Strategies: Responding to a Changing World
Study on China's policy towards Central and Eastern European countries
abstract_en: After the end of the Cold War, the Central and Eastern European countries got rid of the shackles of "Yalta system", and their geopolitics and geo-economics have undergone important changes, and the EU, the United States and Russia have made the policy towards Central and Eastern Europe an important part of their respective strategies. National security interests and economic interests are the basic starting point of the foreign policy of the Central and Eastern European countries, and the alliance with NATO and the European Union and the development of friendly relations with Russia and other neighbouring countries are the priorities of their foreign policy choices. China's relations with Central and Eastern European countries have a friendly tradition, and in recent years there has been a good momentum of development. With the accession of Central and Eastern European countries to the European Union, China's policy towards this region will be integrated into the overall framework of its policy towards Europe, and China should be more proactive in promoting the further development of its relations with them.

title_en: The Ukrainian Crisis and German-Russian Relations and Their Evolutionary Trends
abstract_en: After the Cold War, German-Russian relations have remained generally cordial, but since 2009, they have become more distant, and the festering crisis in Ukraine has added to the differences and contradictions in German-Russian relations, causing them to turn into a serious confrontation. In the current German-Russian confrontation, Germany takes the initiative, while Russia is more passive: Putin is reluctant to confront Germany, while Angela Merkel intends to do so. The current German-Russian confrontation is a prelude to the German elite's repositioning of German-Russian relations and their desire to compete with Russia in Europe, but it will not last long.

title_en: Trends in the world economic landscape and their global implications
abstract_en: The current world economy is dominated by the United States, Europe and Japan, but the imbalance in development, which is determined by the configuration of economic factors, is changing this pattern. In the next 20 years, the ranking of economic development rates from highest to lowest will be China, India, Russia, South Korea, Pakistan, the United States, Europe and Japan. The resulting changes will not be too obvious by 2010, but by 2016 a qualitative change will begin to appear, and by 2026 the world economy will evolve into a new pattern with China, the United States and the European Union as the dominant force, and India as the main pursuer. The new pattern will result in a more democratic, open and stable world economy.

title_en: NATO's Involvement in Arctic Affairs and Implications
abstract_en: Since the outbreak of the Ukraine crisis, NATO has increasingly increased its involvement in Arctic affairs.In addition to actively absorbing Sweden and Finland into NATO, NATO has also strengthened its influence on Arctic affairs in recent years through capacity building, mechanism building, and guidance issues.NATO’s increased involvement in the Arctic is the result of NATO’s strategic transformation, Arctic geopolitics and the flaws in the existing Arctic order.In the short term, it will intensify military tensions in the region. In the long term, it may even promote the formation of a security dilemma in the region, forcing the Arctic to accelerate into global geopolitical confrontation, causing a serious impact on the existing Arctic order.However, increasing involvement in Arctic affairs may be constrained by limitations in its own capabilities and resource investment, as well as international resistance.For China, the current focus should be on how to respond to NATO pressure while promoting its own participation in Arctic affairs, promoting the restoration of the international environment for Arctic cooperation, and helping the Arctic order return to the track of dialogue.

title_en: The Basis and Path of Building a New Type of Great Power Relationship between China and Russia
abstract_en: Russia is one of the core external factors concerning China's strategic opportunity and whether China can truly rise, and Sino-Russian relations are a model for China to build a new type of great power relations. However, China-Russia relations are still facing problems such as the widening power gap between the two countries, great power checks and balances, and "hot politics and cold economics". Enhancing endogeneity, permeability and co-prosperity is the key to ensuring the stable development of Sino-Russian relations in the future. China needs to address the Russian side's concerns, insist on common prosperity, upgrade the mode of cooperation, improve the trade structure, expand the ties of interest, and endeavour to mitigate the adverse impact on China brought about by Russia's attempts to control China, so as to inject more positive energy into Sino-Russian relations.

title_en: A few observations on the meeting of the Seven Western Heads of State
abstract_en: A Few Thoughts on the Meeting of the Seven Western Heads of State Chen Fengying Zheng Yu The 22nd Meeting of the Seven Western Heads of State was held in Lyon, France, from 27 to 29 June. The scale of this meeting exceeded the previous ones, and in addition to the participation of Russian Prime Minister Chernomyrdin in the second phase of the political conference, the heads of the United Nations, the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the World Trade Organisation were specially invited to attend. The meeting discussed...

title_en: Adjustment of the dynamics of great power relations: the United States strengthens its hegemonic position
abstract_en: The relations between the US and other major countries such as China,Russia,Europe and Japan have been negatively affected due to Trump administration’s hard-line and unilateral diplomacy. However,owing to Europe and Japan’s high dependence on the US in terms of geopolitics and security,European countries and Japan follow the United States to adopt tougher policy toward China and Russia. In the transition of the major country relations,the US has strengthened its status as a global hegemony.

title_en: The Crisis in Ukraine and the New Realignment of Transatlantic Relations
abstract_en: The Ukraine crisis has affected the adjustments of transatlantic relations. The overall security cooperation between the US and Europe has been strengthened, and it focuses on resisting Russia and supporting Ukraine. Meanwhile, the synergy in Indo-Pacific affairs has been strengthened. This can mainly be attributed to the increased sense of insecurity among Atlantic countries caused by the Ukraine crisis, the US’ efforts to promote transatlantic cooperation, and the influence of CEE countries on the US–European game. In the future, transatlantic alliance will place more emphasis on security; the alliance’s functions will become more comprehensive. However, its cohesion will be insufficient, and the collective actions of the alliance in various fields will face difficulties. The autonomy dilemma of European countries will increase. China should continue to consolidate the market foundation of Sino–European economic and trade cooperation, and utilize the multilateral order and free trade system.

title_en: Russia-US rivalry and trends on nuclear arms control issues
Impact of the Ukrainian Crisis and Implications
abstract_en: Over the past year, the Ukraine crisis has been escalated in an all-round way, which has had a significant and far-reaching impact on international politics, economy and military affairs. The post-Cold War international order is collapsing, where the tendency of bloc politics and reverse globalization in international economies is increasing; the global arms race is intensifying; and the application of new military technologies is leading human beings into a “new era of war.” The United States made use of Ukraine to fight a proxy war with Russia, and took this opportunity to strengthen its alliance system as well as achieved its triple objectives of promoting internal stability, drawing over Europe and sanctioning Russia, therefore becoming the biggest beneficiary of this crisis. With the support of the Western countries, Ukraine’s fighting capability will increase, and neither Russia nor Ukraine will reconcile easily. The standoff between Russia and Ukraine will prolong the conflict, pushing up the risk of a nuclear war. At the same time, the possibility of managing this crisis by negotiations cannot be ruled out. The crisis reminds Europe of the importance of strategic autonomy, and warns Asian countries to be vigilant against the United States provoking new proxy wars in Asia. China’s Global Security Initiative and China’s Position on the Political Settlement of the Ukraine Crisis provide new ideas for the parties concerned to get out of the crisis and for the international community to build lasting peace.

title_en: Monthly Events Review
The Dilemma and Way Out of NATO's Eastward Expansion in Light of Montenegro's Accession to the Alliance
abstract_en: Montenegro became the 29th member of NATO.It is NATO enlargement achievement,but it also discloses problems the eastward expansion of NATO faces.Is it the enlargement strengthening NATO itself or containing Russia?Is enlarged NATO becoming strong or weak?Is eastward expansion of NATO making more profits or more troubles?How does enlarged NATO unify its goal and practice?Enlargement has resulted in conflict escalation between NATO and Russia and political and security instability in Europe.Its development depends on NATO’s strategic orientation,practice and European political and security changes.

title_en: The economic situation and its impact
abstract_en: As the heart of the Eurasian continent, the importance of Central Asia in world geopolitics is self-evident, and its position has been further accentuated by the active involvement of the major Powers in the aftermath of 11 September. Beginning in 2005, the Central Asian countries will enter a period of political change marked by parliamentary and presidential elections. Because of the rampant extremism, terrorism and separatism in the region; the economic development of the countries has not yet entered a benign state; the successive "revolutions" in Georgia and Ukraine have had a certain demonstration and inspirational effect on the Central Asian opposition; and the complicated relations of the big powers in Central Asia, the situation in Central Asia is full of many variables. In order to have a more accurate grasp of the direction of the situation in Central Asia, the Expert Forum of Modern International Relations, in cooperation with the Eurasian Office of the China Institute of Modern International Relations, held a one-day seminar on 19 January 2005 at Wanshou Villa under the theme of "Analysis and Prospect of the Situation in Central Asia". Scholars and experts from Beijing, Shanghai, Lanzhou and Ningxia held serious and in-depth discussions on the situation in Central Asia from various perspectives in the spirit of seeking truth and seeking reality. The speeches made by the participants are now published in the hope that they will help you to think about the relevant issues and thus promote the deepening of the study of Central Asia.

title_en: China-Russia Strategic Collaborative Partnership Moves Towards a Solid Path
abstract_en: AbstractSino-Russian strategic cooperative partnership has built up a solid political           foundation through recent years of development, which can be reflected in the following           aspects: 1) the partnership is an embodiment of historical experiences and lessons from the           association between China and Russia for decades; 2) the partnership is a natural outcome           based on the all-round and gradual development of Sino-Russian relations; 3) the partnership           signifies an increase of common strategic interests between the two countries; 4) the           partnership is guided by a series of principles of new-types state-to-state relationships; 5) the           partnership has a series of mechanism to coordinate the contradictions and conflicts between           the two sides. At present, there still exist many negative factors in Sino-Russian relations, but           they are being diminished, especially that the bottle-neck problem in their bilateral economic           and trade cooperation has taken a turn for the better  since Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji’s visit           to Moscow early this year. The two leaders have strengthened their resolve to take practical           steps to enlarge cooperation between each other. What’s more, the two governments have also           worked out a way for expanding economic and trade cooperation from a realistic perspective. In           the long run, with the advent of spring in Sino-Russian economic cooperation, the connotation of           their strategic cooperative partnership will become more substantial and their political ties will           turn to be more stable, therefore,  the future for the development of Sino-Russian relations is           bright.

title_en: Adjustment of British policy towards Central Asia and its assessment
abstract_en: In the past three years, under the impact of the Ukraine crisis, Central Asia has increasingly become a hub for geopolitical games among major countries. Thus, the UK government once again attaches importance to the Central Asian region. The reasons are not only the domestic drive to implement the “Global Britain” strategy, the guarantee of energy and resource security for the UK and its allies, but also considerations of the external environment, such as the growing importance of the geostrategic value of the Central Asian region and the changes in the Central Asian strategies of the US and Europe. The UK has made major adjustments to its policies toward Central Asia. The new policies have regained their value orientation and enhanced the consensus between the UK and Central Asian countries; they have strengthened cooperation with Central Asian countries with development aid as the center; and they have promoted the decoupling of Central Asian countries from Russia and weakened Russia’s regional influence. However, the continuing decline of Britain’s comprehensive national strength has limited its ability to achieve its policy goals. Moreover, the situation in Central Asia is relatively complex, and the game between the great powers in Central Asia has intensified. It is difficult for Britain’s new Central Asia policy to be fully implemented, and its prospects are highly uncertain.

title_en: The Complete List for 2002
Growing local separatism in the Russian Federation
abstract_en: ＜The Russian Federation is a multinational State comprising 89 constituent entities (21 republics, 1 autonomous region, 10 autonomous districts, 6 krais, 49 oblasts and 2 municipalities) and more than 100 nationalities. Before the collapse of the Soviet Union, separatism in the constituent entities of the Russian Federation had already appeared; after the collapse of the Soviet Union, separatism spread rapidly and threatened the integrity and unity of the Russian Federation. The Russian weekly newspaper Arguments and Facts, in its issue No. 2 of this year, acknowledged that "the axis of collapse of the Russian Federation from Chechnya to Karelia - Tatarstan - Bashkortostan - Yakutia - Buryatia is now clearly visible". ". This article is intended as a preliminary discussion of the situation.

title_en: A Review of Putin's New Deal
abstract_en: At the beginning of 2012, Vladimir Putin was reelected as the President of Russia, opening a new round of "Putin era". Putin faces the greatest pressure from within Russia: Russia's political ecology has changed dramatically, the new middle class put forward to accelerate the political reform, improve the efficiency of state management and other political demands; part of the population due to the economic downturn and corruption of officials to the authorities feel disappointed, social dissatisfaction continues to accumulate; Russia's economic structure is slow to reform, relying on the energy exports of the growth model has not been fundamentally changed, and modernisation has been hampered. In the face of the serious and complex situation, Putin has adjusted his ideas of governance and taken a series of measures in the domestic, economic and diplomatic fields, with the intention of consolidating his ruling position, ensuring political and economic stability, maintaining and enhancing Russia's international status, and laying the foundation for Russia's rise to power.

title_en: Great Powers Space Defence Posture and Its Implications
abstract_en: The importance of space is increasing. The satellite is a military multiplier and enbler. According to their own space strategies,the great space powers adopt different space defense strategies,thus forming space defense postures,which include the great space powers conducting space military construction,building space military departments,pursuing anti-space weapons,promoting the overall space power as the foundation for the construction of space defense. The defense postures of the great space powers have obvious gaming characteristics,which is composed of space control vs. anti-space control,a space offensive alliance between Japan and the United States vs.space defense quasi-alliance between China and Russia,and asymmetric means for the space game among the great space powers. The space defense postures have intensified the anti-missile and space arms race,resulting in the decrease of the first attack stability in space and the risk of nuclear war,which has led to the hindering of nuclear disarmament and the process of nuclear arms control. In the foreseeable future,the great powers will only intensify tensions in space.

title_en: Lessons learnt and insights gained from the economic reform in the former Soviet East region
abstract_en: The Lessons and Implications of Economic Reform in the Former Soviet Union and Eastern Europe Yang Bin, Institute of Industrial Economics, Chinese Academy of Social Sciences (CASS), said that the Soviet Union and the Eastern European countries generally adopted radical reforms after the "dramatic changes" in the former Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. The new rulers admired the political and economic systems of the developed countries in the West, but they lacked the understanding of the complexity and risk of economic system changes, and thought that as long as they fully emulated the Western economic model, they would not be able to achieve their goals...

title_en: The "Reset" of Russian-American Relations and New Changes in Russian Diplomacy
abstract_en: Since the restart of Russian-American relations in early 2009, Russian diplomacy has undergone a significant "westward" adjustment, giving priority to the development of relations with the West, with the aim of realising Russia's comprehensive modernisation through the latter's efforts. However, in view of the deep-rooted contradictions between Russia and the West, relations between the two sides will not see substantial improvement in the short term, and the possibility of Russia's diplomacy once again "tilting" to the West is unlikely. Another focus of Russian diplomacy is the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS). Because Russia does not have the hard and soft power to dominate the future development of the CIS, its desire to reshape the CIS "hegemony" status of the goal is also difficult to achieve in the short term. In the face of China's rapid rise, Russia's strategic misgivings about China are on the rise, and "borrowing" and "preventing" will be the norm in Russia's future diplomacy with China.

title_en: "The more you fight, the more you fear", why?
abstract_en: The "9-11 incident" is the most iconic event after the end of the Cold War. On the occasion of the fifth anniversary of 9-11, the editorial board of Modern International Relations organised a symposium on "Changes in the International Situation and China's Diplomacy since 9-11", inviting more than 20 experts on international issues in Beijing to discuss the changes in the international situation in the past five years, the situation of counter-terrorism, the deep-rooted contradictions in the current international system, and the problems of great powers. More than 20 international experts in Beijing were invited to make in-depth analyses and discussions on the changes in the international situation in the past five years, the situation of counter-terrorism, the deep-rooted contradictions in the current international system, the adjustments in the relations among major powers, the evolution of the international pattern, the gains and losses of the U.S. in counter-terrorism, the rise and fall of the U.S. international status and strength, and China's international status and international strategy. The main views of the participating experts and scholars are summarised and published here, with a view to benefiting readers in grasping the international strategic situation and understanding China's foreign strategy.

title_en: New Dynamics of Regional Diplomacy of Great Powers in Central Asia
abstract_en: In recent years,there has been a trend of ‘return’of the traditional thinking of geopolitical competition,and the geopolitical competition among major powers at global and regional levels has been intensified as well.The competition among great powers in Central Asia is a typical manifestation of great powers’ geopolitical game at the regional level. Several major powers have adjusted their Central Asian policies and deepened their engagement in Central Asian affairs,which created the primary drivers of the new diplomatic dynamics in Central Asia. In addition,new characteristics of current diplomacy in Central Asia are emerging. The new trends pose challenges and opportunities for China. In terms of challenges,major powers have paid increased attentions and efforts in Central Asia,urging China to act prudently to avoid regional tensions or chaos. In terms of opportunities,China can fully take advantage of its economic strength,its partnership with Central Asian countries established over the past three decades,and its cooperation mechanisms to promote the mutual trust and cooperation among China and Central Asian countries.

title_en: Trends in the Arctic Ocean sovereignty dispute
abstract_en: In August 2007, a Russian research team planted a Russian flag on the floor of the Arctic Ocean, a move that signalled Russia's intention to incorporate the vast waters south of the North Pole and its continental shelf into the Russian territory, and thus provoked a strong reaction from neighbouring countries of the Arctic Ocean. Whether the issue of competing sovereignty over the Arctic Ocean and its continental shelf can be resolved in the future in accordance with the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, and whether the countries concerned can formulate an Arctic Ocean Convention or a similar legal document under the auspices of the United Nations, will become the key to the issues related to the Arctic and the Arctic Ocean.

title_en: The "colour revolution" and its geopolitical implications
abstract_en: Since October 2003, there have been changes of leadership in Georgia, Ukraine and Kyrgyzstan in the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS), which have been described in the media as "colour revolutions" and which are reminiscent of the dramatic changes in the Soviet Union at the end of the 1980s and the beginning of the 1990s. Why is there a "revolution" here again, just over a decade after the collapse of the Soviet Union? Will this "revolution" continue to develop like dominoes? What impact will it have on the geopolitical landscape? Today, we have invited some experts from the China Institute of Modern International Relations to discuss these questions and present our basic views.

title_en: Energy Factor Mix and US-China-Russia Energy Strategy Cooperation
abstract_en: The global system of energy supply and demand determines the basic direction of strategic energy cooperation between the United States, China and Russia. The combination of various strategic elements constitutes the framework and characteristics of the two types of strategic energy cooperation between the United States and China. Energy cooperation between China and the United States is global and complementary in nature, and its core is to prevent the rise of various security threats to the main sources and corridors of energy, and at the same time to prevent the differences in the energy strategic interests of the two countries from leading to confrontation. China-Russia energy cooperation, on the other hand, is more regional and mutually beneficial, and its core will be a more long-term and institutionalised relationship between the two countries' energy supply and demand, as well as the promotion of geopolitical-economic integration of the two regions of Northeast Asia and Central Asia. As a result of global climate change and the rise of the low-carbon economy, China, the United States and Russia have begun to make strategic adjustments to their energy structures, and new trends have emerged in their strategic energy cooperation.

title_en: Shanghai Cooperation Organisation: assessment and development issues
abstract_en: The main success of the SCO over the past four years has been its ability to withstand the drastic changes in the international situation, as well as its success in conceptualisation, image-building, organisational development and external relations. There are also shortcomings in the SCO, particularly in terms of insufficient resources, the lack of significant results in economic cooperation, the need to improve its international status, the lack of clarity in the development model, and the lack of civil and social contacts and exchanges. The future development of the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation requires the resolution of a number of issues, including the development model, the positioning of its functions, the balance between security and the economy, the response to the new political environment in Central Asia, regional stability, the expansion of the organisation, external relations, and so on.

title_en: Origins, development and direction of the issue of the four northern islands between Russia and Japan
abstract_en: On 13 November 1998, Russian President Boris Yeltsin and Japanese Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi signed the Moscow Declaration on the establishment of a constructive partnership between Russia and Japan. The two sides stated that they would make every effort to conclude a peace treaty by the year 2000, and to this end set up a sub-committee on border demarcation and a sub-committee on economic co-operation on the four northern islands. The key to the conclusion of a peace treaty between Russia and Japan is how to deal with the four northern islands...

title_en: A Few Perceptual Issues Regarding Putin's Policies
abstract_en: Much controversy exists inside and outside Russia over President Vladmir Putin’s policies.  His attempt at strengthening the central authority can not be blamed as personal usurpation of dictatorial power because it satisfies the needs for political stability and economic progress. That explains its support from the Russian people in general. Instead, political power building should be further deepened in the country.  In fact, Russia’s economic recovery awaits straightening out the central  local relationship. President Putin is actually exploring a model for speeding up economic expansion by giving full play to freedom in the economic arena, while retaining state macro control at the indispensable minimum.  He will most probably not copy mechanically the free market economy model, thus steering clear of the same old disastrous course taken by his predecessor. His relationship with the political opposition, the Communist Party in particular, consists of struggling, cooperation and utilization with possible expansion of shared views.  This will find its manifestation in the selection of a development path geared to Russia’s national conditions through mutual restraints. The young Russian top leader elevates his multi  dimensional foreign policy to the theoretical level of seeking equilibrium, a matter determined by Russia’s state interests in the new transition period, albeit with emphasis in its implementation. Western media accusations of President Putin in pulling Russia back to the former Soviet Union fly in the face of realities. The Russian President Putin is trying to integrate the three major ideological trends of liberalism, socialism and nationalism in his country. This has invited Western resentment.

title_en: The reorientation of the European Union's Central Asia policy: strategic autonomy and two-tier commitment
abstract_en: In the context of the ongoing Ukraine crisis and major country competition, the EU have catered to the diversified development of foreign relations and increased autonomy in Central Asia, and stepped up adjustments to their Central Asia policy to obtain gains in specific areas.The level of the meeting mechanism between the EU and Central Asian countries has been upgraded and institutionalized. The interaction between leaders has increased significantly. EU member states have actively participated in Central Asian affairs. The EU’s Central Asia policy has become more political and independent. It shows a development trend of dual commitment, which is conducive to enhancing policy effects, but the EU’s proactive actions complicate regional competition and cooperation and stimulate the competitive awareness of Russia and other countries. The EU’s strategic autonomy will also affect the coordination between the United States and Europe. The EU’s unbalanced and short-term Central Asia policy hardly increases the trust of Central Asian countries. In view of the increasingly complex competition and cooperation between major countries in Central Asia, the pragmatic EU’s Central Asia policy is facing a test, and the EU’s competitiveness still has limitations.

title_en: Assessment of the current security situation in the five Central Asian States
abstract_en: The security situation in the five Central Asian States faces three main threats: the intensification of the geopolitical rivalry between Russia and the United States may have an impact on the stability of Central Asia; disputes over natural resources and borders between Central Asian States, the "three forces" in the region, and ethnic contradictions may lead to inter-State conflicts; and the long-standing centralisation of presidential power in the five Central Asian States is accompanied by a lack of smooth changes of power, with the risk of political turmoil in the Kyrgyz Republic and the Tartar Republic. At present, the factors that maintain the stability of the situation in Central Asia prevail for the time being: Russia and the United States hope to maintain stability in Central Asia on the basis of strategic considerations; regional co-operation in Central Asia is committed to alleviating regional contradictions; and the authoritarian regimes of the five Central Asian countries are still conducive to the maintenance of domestic political stability. In the long term, however, it will be difficult to eliminate the hidden security problems in Central Asia.

title_en: United States secondary sanctions and the international response
abstract_en: Since 2010, secondary sanctions have acquired growing visibility in US economic sanctions tool-kits.The seeming effectiveness of US secondary sanctions in deterring third parties are undergirded by three factors,namely, the moral ground that the US has gained after the September 11 attacks in battling global terrorism and preventing nuclear proliferation with secondary sanctions, the seamless integration of the US dollar hegemony and America’s intelligence machines, and the asymmetric strike that“smart sanctions”are able to launch on third parties. However, with America’s increasingly abusive use of secondary sanctions, the above three supportive factors are being undermined irreversibly. More countries have realized that the only viable way to successfully neutralize US secondary sanctions is to push for dedollarization in the long run.

title_en: The Great Global Change and the New World Order
abstract_en: The world is undergoing tremendous changes. Old world order has been broken and a new one is not built yet. Every Major power speculates on the construction of future global order,and each country is facing with various problems and difficulties. China has enjoyed rising international influence,at the same time,it suffers from the risk of economic slowdown. Based on historical tradition and national condition,China has its own view on world order and global system. Cooperation between countries is needed for the construction of a new world order.

title_en: Proceedings of the Seminar on Major Contradictions in the World
Problems of Russian-Chinese international cooperation in the new situation
abstract_en: Problems of Sino-Russian International Cooperation in the New Situation - Summary of the International Symposium On 4-5 October 1995, the Institute of Modern International Relations of China (IMIRC) and the Institute of Far Eastern Studies of the Russian Academy of Sciences (IFES) jointly convened the "Problems of Sino-Russian International Cooperation in Beijing " international symposium. This was the third international conference held by the two institutes on the problems of Sino-Russian relations after 1992 and 1994. more than 30 participants with...

title_en: An Exploration of Canada's Arctic Security Policy
abstract_en: Since the outbreak of the Ukraine Crisis, Canada’s Arctic security policy has undergone significant changes, from socially focused to militarily focused, from supporting regional governance to endorsing alliance politics, from opposing NATO’s influence in the Arctic to welcoming it. The reason is that climate change in the Arctic region has made the United States and the West believe that competition for interests in the region has intensified and security risks have increased. The Ukraine crisis has prompted a change in the judgment of NATO countries, including Canada, on the security situation in the Arctic and the security threat posed by Russia in it. The United States has elevated Arctic security to an unprecedented strategic level and asked NATO allies to act in concert with its actions. There are growing calls in Canada to increase defense investment. Compliance with the United States will continue to be the keynote of Canada’s Arctic security policy, which has brought greater uncertainty to the security situation in the Arctic region.

title_en: Monthly Events Review
abstract_en: Events in November 1998: 1. President Jiang Zemin visited Russia. At the invitation of President Boris Yeltsin, Chinese President Jiang Zemin visited Russia from 22 to 25 November and issued a Joint Press Communiqué and a Joint Statement on the Results of the High-Level Russian-Chinese Meetings, while the two sides reached a series of important agreements on specific issues of bilateral relations through their talks. title_en: Diplomatic Trajectories and Directions of Northeast Asian Countries
abstract_en: Since the 1980s, the diplomatic activities of the Northeast Asian countries were unfolded basically on the following tracks; First, the proposal of the"new thinking"diplomacy by the former Soviet Union, South Korea’s Practice of"north-oriented diplomacy"and China’s pursuit of ’’peaceful diplomacy"towards the neighbouring countries resulted in the great chnges in the pattern of the diplomatic relations of the Northeast Asian countries; Second, the summit conference between South Korea and Japan reassured the security system among the US, Japan and South Korea; Third, Yeltsin’s visit to China and India drew apart the curtain of his"oriental diplomacy".The foreign policies of the northeast Asian countries will present the following new trends: （1） South Korea will strengthen its diplomatic activities with the US and Japan and establish a balanced relations with America, Japan, Russia and China. （2） Russia will continue to devote itself to promoting its relations with South Korea, India and China, while solving the crux of Russia-Japan"relations. （3） Japan will strengthen its"great-nation diplomacy"with the aim of raising its status in internaitonal politics. （4） China will widen the range of its"peaceful diplomacy".

title_en: The process of strategic arms reductions in the United States and Russia and their trends
abstract_en: The negotiation between the United States and Russia on reducing strategic weapons has been lasting for more than 30 years. Though there are some progress, the implementation of the treaty is met with tremendous difficulties. Especially the United States demands, in disregard of the strong protest from Russia and the international community, revision of the anti  ballistic missile treaty and put forward to develop and deploy the NMD and TMD systems, which seriously damaged the world strategic detente established in mid 1990s. At the moment, Washington insists to have its own way and sticks to the expensive NMD scheme, which lay bare its selfish and overbearing nature of seeking “absolute security” and hegemonism. As for Russia, it on one hand pursues vigorously an omni  dimensional diplomacy of “advancing public relations”, “drumming up support” and “putting forward suggestions” so as to mobilize every political force to safeguard the anti  ballistic missile treaty which serves as the basis for international strategic stability. This has won wide support from the international community. On the other hand, Russia has to make preparations in the military field so as to get ready to break the US strategic monopoly when necessary. In regard to the future trend of the negotiation on reducing strategic weapons, the United States will not easily give up the NMD scheme, but might make some adjustments, for instance, implement the TMD first, and then deploy the NMD when technology and political time become ripe. But for Russia, if its efforts to unite the international forces to safeguard the anti  ballistic missile treaty and impede the US NMD scheme failed, it will withdraw from all the strategic weapon treaties signed with Washington, which will inflict a heavy blow on the international strategic weapons reduction cause and damage the international strategic balance and stability, leading to another round of arms race

title_en: New directions in international disarmament and arms control
abstract_en: With the end of the bipolar confrontation, major powers, one after another, began readjusting their own strategies, which, therefore, have led to new developments in international disarmament and armscontrol process.The US and Russia have coordinated to speed up nuclear reduction and reached an agreement which allows only 3000-3500 strategic nuclear warheads as a whole for each after stage-by-stage reducing process. Coordination and tough talks by big powers have also produced a convention draft of internationall prohibition of use of biological and chemical weapons, and a new agreement on force ceiling in coventional armed forces talks in Europe. All these new developments are favorable to international military detente. However, the US and Russia remains two superpowers in terms of nuclear capacity. The US intends to dismantle Russian of its threat to the former through nuclear reduction and newly-developed high-tech weapons, therefore ensuring the military superpower status of the US.In the pose-bipolar world,new nationalism is emerging. In the regions as Eastern Europe and Midde East, regional conflicts are rising one after another. And a number of countries began expanding their military forces out of their own security concerns. On one hand the US becomes the No. 1 arms dealer in the world, on the other it initiates to push international coordination in curbing nuclear proliferation, MTCR, and preventing the overseas US interests from being impaired. It is requested in international community that both the US and Russia, the US in particular, take further initiatives to promote both nuclear and conventiohal arms reduction.

abstract_en: How China-Russia economic and trade cooperation can enter a pragmatic stage Li Jingyu, Liaoning Normal University While countries are actively implementing aggressive strategies for the new century and trying to establish a favourable international environment, the leaders of China and Russia are committed to the "establishment of a strategic partnership of cooperation between the two countries", and are pushing the political and trade relations between the two sides to a higher level of development. In this regard, the author believes that the two sides should make further efforts to resolve bilateral economic and trade co-operation...

title_en: The situation in Central Asia more than a year after the collapse of the Soviet Union
abstract_en: The disintegration of the former Soviet Union turned her 5 Central Asian States-Kazakstan, Uzbekistan, Kirghiziastan, Tadzhikistan and Turkmenistan-into fully independent sovereign countries in the international arena. One year later, all these countries are comparatively stable except Tadzhikistan, but economically awkward without exception. In an attempt to get out of the predicament, all of these countries are pursuing economic reform in various forms without notable success. The immediate economic picture is not sound for most of them. In foreign affairs, while giving priority to its relations with Muslim countries, they pay high attention to developing relations with Russia, China and west countries and have made certain achievements in fostering the regional cooperation among themselves.

However, there are still many uncertainties in Russia, intense power struggle in the upper echelons, the economic situation has not improved, people's dissatisfaction increased, the international environment is unfavourable and so on a series of difficult problems are still plagued by Yeltsin,...

abstract_en: On regional cooperation in North-East Asia Ji Zhiye North-East Asia is one of the most important and complex regions in the world. It is a place where China, a great population power, Russia, a great military power, and Japan, a great economic power, are concentrated; there are economically developed or sub-developed countries, as well as countries with economies in transition and developing countries; there are countries with the fastest rate of economic development in the world, as well as those whose economies are in a state of crisis; and there are both countries...

abstract_en: Ukraine's new parliamentary election preliminary analysis Sun Runyu, Shu Xiangdi March-April this year, Ukraine held the first parliamentary elections since independence, after two rounds of intense competition, has produced 337 seats. This is a major event in the political life of Ukraine, the birth of the new parliament will have an important impact on the future development of the situation in Ukraine. The election of the new Ukrainian Parliament was held in the context of the domestic political, economic...

title_en: World Outlook 2005
abstract_en: Following the launch of "World Facts Ahead 2003" and "World Facts Ahead 2004", the response from readers has been overwhelming. Although there were differences of opinion, there was more recognition, praise and encouragement. This gives us more confidence, but at the same time, we feel more pressure. Indeed, scholars who study international issues often have the feeling of "seeing flowers in the fog", and it is not easy to abstract the general trend of world development! Unlike the "Year of War" in 2003, the evolution of the situation in 2004 was mainly reflected in the "invisible fronts", and therefore, to grasp the world situation in 2005, it is necessary to know the subtleties of the situation and the integration and collision of multiple fields. In order to live up to the expectation of our readers, at the beginning of the New Year, we invited Mr Lu Zhongwei, President of the China Institutes of Modern International Relations, and 13 experts in related fields to hold a dialogue, hoping that this article, "Outlook on the World Situation in 2005", will help you to think further and strike a new inspiration in you.

title_en: Main trends and salient features of the current international strategic security situation
abstract_en: ＜The international strategic security situation is at its most volatile since the end of the cold war. Multipolarity in the world is deepening, and the game of major powers is more intense than ever. The momentum of economic globalisation has been blocked or even seriously reversed. The regional situation, especially in Europe, has been plunged into war and chaos, and the Eurasian continent is in a state of crisis. Energy security, food security and environmental security are intertwined and overlapping, and humankind is facing unprecedented challenges. The two major issues of global peace and development have become more prominent, and the world is once again at the crossroads of history.

title_en: Current status, impact and prospects of transnational gas pipeline construction in Central Asia
abstract_en: The Central Asian countries are rich in natural gas resources, and because they are landlocked, pipelines have become the only means of exporting natural gas from Central Asia. By actively promoting the construction of gas pipelines, the Central Asian countries have changed the situation of their heavy dependence on Russia, increased gas production and export prices, and strengthened the position of the Central Asian countries in the regional energy market and power pattern. However, a number of factors, including financial resources, control capacity, consumer markets and relations with transit countries and security, pose serious constraints on the future construction of gas pipelines in the Central Asian countries. Participation in resource development and pipeline construction in Central Asia is in line with China's national interests, and is conducive to promoting the Belt and Road Initiative, enhancing China's energy security, improving urban air quality and achieving emission reduction targets. The Chinese Government should promote pipeline gas cooperation with Central Asian countries through the integration of various resources, the implementation of domestic market reforms and the establishment of overseas investment protection mechanisms.

title_en: Cooperation and Divergence in China-US-Russia Relations in the Framework of the International System
abstract_en: With the growing trend of globalisation and multipolarity, the use of the international system to regulate inter-State relations is becoming a consensus among China, the United States and Russia in their mutual relations. Due to differences in values and interests, in the process of cooperation among China, the United States and Russia under the framework of the international system, the phenomenon of deviation from the international system often arises among the actors, with the United States showing the most serious manifestation. How to look at the phenomenon of cooperation and deviation between China, the United States and Russia in the framework of the international system is becoming a new topic in the study of the theory of the international system.

title_en: Geopolitical and economic impact of the Ukrainian crisis on the Belt and Road Initiative
abstract_en: ＜The outbreak of the current major international crises is a chain reaction caused by the adjustment of the global strategy of the United States. The core of the U.S. global strategic adjustment is the containment of China, and the eastward expansion of NATO and the complete weakening of Russia are only part of this global strategic adjustment. The Ukraine crisis is the most significant "geopolitical mutation" since the collapse of the Soviet Union and the end of the Cold War, while the "One Belt, One Road" is the largest "geo-economic gradual change" since economic globalisation in the 1990s. The "Belt and Road" is the biggest "geo-economic gradual change" since economic globalisation in the 1990s. The "sudden change" and the "gradual change" are intertwined.

title_en: Monthly Events Review
Some new trends in the development of the CIS
abstract_en: Since its establishment a little over one year, the Commonwealth of Independent States （CIS） has shifted from a loose"temporary transitional organ"towards the direction that make it institutionalized, legalized and integrated economically. The main reasons for that change are as follows; after declaring independence, various states of the former soviet Union have become aware of the fact that they can never get rid of predicament and make new progress in economic field by developing their respective economy single — handedly and cutting off their mutual traditional ties shaped over decades; leaders of the States of CIS have from practice come to realize that CIS can not only serve as a political consultative organ, but also play an important role in the eco- nomic cooperation as well. In the days to come, in the framework of CIS, there will be some progress of bilateral and multilateral cooperation in different spheres and at various levels. Nevertheless, given the old and new contradictions in CIS being rather complicated, there will be troubles, strife and twists on the way of its development.

abstract_en: New changes in Europe-Russia relations Hong Jianjun Recently, the political and diplomatic relations between Western Europe and Russia have seen a new momentum of strong development, with frequent visits by European and Russian leaders, and a rapid expansion of cooperation between the two sides in the political, economic and security spheres. In connection with the recent deepening of the Russian-American conflict and the increasingly complex relations between Europe and the United States, the new trend of European-Russian relations has attracted extensive international attention.
