title_en: Pakistan's Great Power Diplomatic Realignment in Perspective
abstract_en: In recent years, the major country diplomacy of Pakistan has undergone significant adjustments. This is highlighted by the significant changes in Pakistan’s policies toward the United States and Russia. At the same time, Pakistan has continued the main tone of Pakistan–India confrontation and Pakistan–China friendship, but there have also been some new changes and trends. For example, Pakistan and India also seek to manage the crisis in the overall confrontation situation, so as to prevent conflicts from getting out of control and detonating wars. While continuing the friendly exchanges, Pakistan and China focuson promoting practical cooperation such as the China–Pakistan Economic Corridor at present. The above adjustment of Pakistan stems from multiple internal and external factors. Externally, it mainly stems from the US implementation of the Indo-Pacific Strategy and the catalytic effect of the Ukraine crisis. Internally, it is mainly due to major changes in the leadership, political and economic difficulties, and the urgent need for external support, especially from major countries, to improve the domestic situation. The major country diplomacy adjustment of Pakistan has had certain geopolitical and security implications at both the global and regional levels. But Pakistan still faces structural challenges in managing relations with major powers.

title_en: Impact of the Russian-Ukrainian conflict on global food security
abstract_en: The Russia-Ukraine conflict has stifled food production and trade, further weakening the domination of Russia and Ukraine in the global food system. The current conflict is also adding fuel to the soaring fertilizer prices and intensifying fertilizer shortage. Global food production has decreased and food prices have hit record high amid the conflict, which are both jeopardizing food security around the world. The current conflict also has long-term ramifications. Global food security is becoming a major issue in global governance. Soaring food prices and political unrests in fragile countries will change the power balance between developed and developing countries. Major foodproducing countries are increasingly using food as weapons for strategic competition. As a result, the undergoing profound changes unseen in a century will face more uncertainties in the future.

title_en: Forecast of China's relations with major powers
An analysis of "economic separatism" in the Russian Federation
abstract_en: AbstractAt           the time of the end of summer and early autumn last year, under the financial and economic           shadows, some entities in the Russian Federation advocated “economic separatism" reflected           in the following aspects: （a） local leaders overtly challenged the authority of the Federal           government; （b） local governments set up customs barriers without permission of the central           government; （c） Setting up rules and regulations contrary to the Federal laws; （d） Making direct           trade and economic contact with foreign countries. The causes for economic separatism are: （a）           Some entities tried to get rid of the bondage of the Federal government, seeking self existence           and development; （b） the central government has been weakened. The local government took           the opportunity to enlarge its power; （c） the elected governor’s dependence on the Federal           President has diminished. In view of the fact that the political situation was not stable in           Russia, its economic prospect is hard to turn for the better in a short time, it is difficult to           contain the momentum of economic separatism in one or two years’ time. Judging from the           developing trend, Russia will further determine its reform guidelines and development road           after the presidential election next year. The constitution reform will solve the problem of           rationally distributing power and perfecting its federal system. The good handling of these two           events will in a large degree overcome the danger of economic separatism.

From Shanghai to Moscow, from Moscow to Almaty...

title_en: Economic cooperation in North-East Asia and its prospects
abstract_en: Due to the end of the cold war in the 1990s, some changes have occured in the enviornment of geographical polities and economy in Northeast Asia and the prospects of its economic cooperation become brighter than before. The neighbo（?）ring countries are getting more identical in the following targets: （1） turning"the sea of the cold war"into"the sea of peace"; （2） changing"the economic rusty belt"into"the magnetic field of development"; （3） seeking the access to sea and shortening the distance to the main channel of Pacific trade. And this will contribute greatly to the promotion of the economic exploitation in this region. But on the other hand, as most of the participants are located in the"shady belt"of economy in their own countries and are far from industrial and trade centres, and it is very difficult for themselves to spark off vitality without the radiation of the"sunny belt". Besides, the econome relations in this region are short of the integral function of dynamic equilibrium, therefore, a live cooperation system is difficult to he created. We have to admit that the success of the economic cooperation in this region will be a long-term and complicated process. As far as the overall conception of the economic cooperation of Northeast Aain in the 1990s is concerned, it should be free from the fetters of traditional thinking and expand and readjust it in the following way: first, stepping forward to"regional economic rims"from"local economic circles", placing the regional economic cooperation in the framwork of the Asiapacific market, and striving for the expansion of the economic ties with Japan, the US and Europe; second, developing"the cooperation by air"while conducting"the cooperation around a Sea", namely, establishing electronics-processing zones in Tokyo, Moscow, Chabarovsk, Harbin, Shenyang and Seol and forming a"few-hour economic circle"through some air corridor.

title_en: Changes in Poland's Foreign Relations and Opportunities and Challenges for Sino-Polish Relations
abstract_en: Soon after winning the parliament elections in Poland in October 2015,the"Law and Justice"Party（PiS）took power.A series of changes have taken place in Poland’s foreign policies.It relations with the EU become tenser due to the"democracy"issue.It keeps close ties with the UK,but alienates itself from France and Germany.It takes an increasingly tough attitude towards Russia and relies more on the U.S and NATO for its security.At the same time,Polish policy toward China is getting more active,and the China-Poland strategic cooperation has entered a new era.Poland actively responds to China’s One Belt and One Road Initiative and will play an important role in it.

title_en: Cluster analysis of current international patterns
NATO's new posture of strategic expansion and the EU's response
abstract_en: Since the end of the cold war, NATO's strategic expansion has continued, and its operational space and capacity expansion have taken on a distinctly global colour. As the provider of European security and the main platform for U.S.-European relations, NATO is promoting security co-operation with the European Union through building partnerships, and its strategic expansion has also brought about a multifaceted impact on the European Union, not only weakening the European Union's ability to build and rectify corrective measures in the NATO mechanism, but also lowering the position of the European Union and European security in NATO's security agenda, and weakening the European Union's dominant power over European security. Influenced by the US diplomacy, the UK's withdrawal from the European Union, the German-French differences and other factors, the EU will make efforts to adjust and shape its co-operative relationship with NATO through calibrating the strategic positioning of NATO, coping with the limited shock of the US-EU relationship, and maintaining the multiple diplomatic relations, etc., and in the process, establish and maintain the strategic autonomy of the EU.

title_en: U.S.-Russia-Europe-Central Europe Interaction: The Role of the European Union and Its Policy Orientation
abstract_en: At present, geopolitical competition in the world is becoming more and more intense, with major countries pursuing the maximisation of their economic, political and military power. The interaction between the United States, Russia, Europe and China is more prominent and their relations more complex, with the European Union in a unique position. As a consortium of small and medium-sized countries, the EU has an unprecedented sense of crisis and urgency, fearing that it will not be able to effectively safeguard its own interests, and even become a venue for the big powers to compete, and therefore has begun to adjust its great power diplomacy and global policy, including strengthening the construction of strategic autonomy, increasing the bargaining chips for dialogue with the big powers; trying to maintain its relative independence, and playing the role of a coordinator and balancer in the relations between the big powers; and menuising and thematising its co-operation with the big powers; and striving to safeguard its economic, political and military power. We should try to maintain relative independence and play the role of coordinator and balancer in the relations among the big powers, menuise cooperation with the big powers and make it more topical, and strive to maintain the overall stability of the relations among the big powers and the international multilateral mechanism. The maintenance and reform of the world order depend on good relations among the major powers. China is actively participating in the reform and construction of the global governance system and needs partners and co-operators. China and Europe have more commonalities than differences in the concepts of win-win situation and interdependence of the world, as well as in the opposition to power politics and the maintenance of multilateral order. There is much room for cooperation between China and Europe in promoting positive interaction among the four major forces of the United States, Russia, Europe and China, restraining hegemony and unilateralism, and safeguarding multilateralism in the international order.

title_en: Changes in the security situation in North-East Asia after the Cold War
abstract_en: The end of the cold war has had a profound impact on the security situation in North-East Asia. On the one hand, the countries of the region have moved from the sharp ideological confrontation of the Cold War to the competition of national interests, leading to significant changes in existing alliances and state relations, and the regional security environment surrounding the Korean Peninsula issue has ebbed and flowed towards détente. On the other hand, the Cold War mentality still prevails, with the U.S. and Japan strengthening their security alliance...

title_en: Multilateral joint diplomacy in the "key intermediate countries"
abstract_en: Key middle countries possess significant economic scale, substantial development potential, relatively robust international political influence, and they desire to play a leading role on specific international issues. In the midst of accelerating changes unseen in a century and escalating competitions among major countries, key middle countries are actively and flexibly engaging in multi-alignment diplomacy. Although key middle countries have strengthened military ties with the United States, they generally refuse to join the military camp of the United States to contain China and Russia. Their economic relations with the United States have improved. At the same time, they have not fundamentally changed the pace of economic cooperation with China and Russia. They enjoy closer strategic ties with the United States, and they have made even greater progress in strategic cooperation with China and Russia to lead the common development of the Global South. The decisive reasons why key middle countries implement multi-alignment diplomacy are their disappointment to the United States and the Western countries, their desire for cooperation with China and Russia and their confidence in the multi-polarization of the international order. The multialignment diplomacy of key middle countries has led to a rise of the new non-alignment movement in the Global South, providing China and Russia ample room to maneuver in the face of the strategic containment of the United States. The intensity and destructive degree of competitions among major countries have also been greatly weakened, making multipolarization easier to realize in the world. While there is a bright future for multi-alignment diplomacy among key middle countries, it will be an arduous road that requires more patience and efforts.

title_en: Strategic positioning and development direction of the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation
abstract_en: The Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO), after a nascent stage, has the initial potential to become a "stabiliser" for the Eurasian continent and is continuing to move in that direction. As an international system of multilateralism, the core values of the SCO in the future should be based on a new "Eurasianist ideology". This idea sees the Eurasian hinterland as a unified geopolitical block, a unified geo-economic network and a platform for multicultural exchanges. In the coming period, the SCO's important agenda is to transform itself into a multifunctional organisation encompassing political, economic and security co-operation; secondly, to expand from a sub-regional co-operation organisation focusing on Central Asia to include such countries as India, Pakistan, Mongolia, Afghanistan, Iran, etc., so as to become a regional co-operation community of Eurasia, based on the core values of the "New Eurasianism". Eurasian community of regional cooperation with "new Eurasianism" as its core value.

title_en: New changes in Russian-Japanese relations since the end of the Cold War
abstract_en: In the post-cold-war period, Russian-Japanese relations have undergone profound changes, with the two sides moving away from ideological constraints and from confrontation to cooperation. In recent years, positive progress has been made in relations between the two countries on international hot-spot issues, security issues in the Asia-Pacific region and bilateral economic cooperation. However, the unresolved issue of the "northern territories" has always been a constraint on the normalisation of relations between the two countries. A speedy settlement of the territorial problem is an urgent issue for Russia and Japan. In the long term, regardless of how the territorial issue is resolved in the future, the positive trend of mutual needs, mutual reliance and cooperation between Russia and Japan will not be reversed.

title_en: Exploration of Cooperation in the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation Community of Destiny
abstract_en: The world is undergoing profound changes unseen in a century, and has entered a new period of transformation and turbulence. The complexity of the international situation has seriously affected the stability and development of the Eurasian continent, posing unprecedented challenges to the development of the SCO in this region, while at the same time providing new and important opportunities for building an even closer SCO community with a shared future. In the context of fragmentation of global governance system, the SCO’s governance concepts and experience have highlighted its advanced nature, providing a unique opportunity for the Organization to further participate in global governance and to enhance its international influence. Russia’s increasing strategic reliance on the SCO has also added new impetus to SCO cooperation. More importantly, as the external environment becomes increasingly severe and volatile, the SCO member states are gaining greater expectations and demands for the SCO, and their policies tend to be more positive. As an important and constructive force in international and regional affairs, the SCO should, under the new situation, seek advantages and avoid disadvantages, overcome difficulties, and continue to carry forward the “Shanghai Spirit.” The SCO should also build an even closer SCO community with a shared future in terms of its conceptual interpretation, mechanism construction, practical cooperation, as well as in-depth participation in global governance.

title_en: The Role and Impact of Non-State Actors from the Russia-Ukraine Conflict
abstract_en: The Russia-Ukraine conflict is not only a rare direct conflict between European major powers after the end of the Cold War, leading to fierce confrontation between Western countries and Russia, but also triggering the extensive involvement of non-state actors such as capital giants, small and micro technology individuals, and emerging transnational platforms. The role and influence of non-state actors in international politics has entered a new stage. Benefiting from the accelerated evolution of globalization and the digital age, non-state actors have had a major impact on the international landscape by intervening in competition among countries, participating in the process of global governance, and influencing public opinion trends, and have increasingly become an important variable affecting unprecedented global changes. The rising role of non-state actors has many implications for China to expand its power and safeguard national interests and security.

title_en: The Withdrawal of US Troops in Afghanistan and the Challenges and Responses Facing SCO Member States
abstract_en: The situation in Afghanistan has entered a new phase with the withdrawal of United States forces from the country. The Government of Afghanistan has to assume more tasks and responsibilities in the areas of security and reconstruction, but its capacity is limited, which leads to increased uncertainty and risks in the political, economic and security spheres. This will inevitably have a direct or indirect impact on the SCO member States, which are in close proximity or geographical proximity to it. On the whole, the SCO member States will face security challenges arising from the unstable situation in Afghanistan, such as the rebound of international terrorist forces, the threat of extremist forces in the region and drug trafficking. The concerns of the member States are different, and so are their policy measures to address these challenges. The impact of the United States withdrawal and the different responses of other SCO member States have added new variables to the regional situation, inevitably affecting China, which faces new opportunities and challenges.

title_en: Multiple perspectives on international trends
abstract_en: ＜In the past 2014, the pattern of global economic growth tended to diverge, the number of regional hotspots increased, the impact was wide, the complexity of relations between major countries and the sharpness of the contradictions highlighted, China's diplomacy has won a bumper harvest, but also earned a lot of eyeballs. We may follow the changes in 2014, from the following angles to observe and analyse the international trend in 2015. (I) In the economic and political interaction to see the strengths and weaknesses of countries. The current world economy, in addition to the overall weak growth, there are changes that deserve attention. The first is the intensification of differentiation. In developed countries, the U.S. economy is growing well, while Japan and Europe are trapped in weak growth and can hardly extricate themselves; in the

title_en: Impact of United States financial sanctions on the international standing of the United States dollar
abstract_en: To analyze the influence of the abuse of financial sanctions by the United States on the international status of the dollar, it is necessary to answer a question that exceeds expectations in reality: the United States restrictions on the foreign exchange flow of the Russian Central bank and other measures, the use of financial management power as a strategic chip will inevitably reduce the attractiveness of dollar assets. Why does this move not substantially accelerate the process of de-dollarization of the world, especially the US dollar reserves in the global international currency reserves rather than decline in status? From the perspective of international security, countries and actors that feel insecure because of US financial sanctions have different currency choices from those that feel safer because of US financial sanctions. On the one hand, US financial sanctions strengthen the security of the sanctioning coalition, reinforcing the security of countries that do not implement the sanctions but largely agree with their targets. Despite the increased economic costs of the US, these countries are willing to accept the “safety premium” of the US dollar for geopolitical reasons. On the other hand, the aggressive use of financial sanctions by the United States makes more countries fear that their behavior will be sanctioned, thus increasing the motivation of de-dollarization, which may weaken the hegemony of the dollar. In the short term, geopolitical logic has replaced international economic logic as the main driving force for the change in the status of the US dollar’s global foreign exchange reserves, which is positive for the US dollar and makes it more attractive as a foreign exchange reserve. However, de-dollarization has not yet formed economies of scale, and its impact on the status of the dollar is insufficient. In the long run, as economic and security constraints change, the choices of countries that accept the international role of the dollar and those that seek to de-dollarize may also change. The author discusses four possible scenarios: the dominance of the dollar is not threatened, the international monetary system has become camp-oriented, the international monetary system is fragmented, and the dominance of the dollar falls.

title_en: "United-2003" and its significance
abstract_en: When the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO) was established two years ago, one of the two documents it published was the Convention on Counter-Terrorism. At that time, international public opinion tended to be rather unimpressed, and some even thought that the member States of the Organisation were making a fuss about it. However, with the outbreak of the September 11 attacks less than three months later, counter-terrorism became a common task for the entire international community. With the continuous construction and improvement of the organisation's mechanism, the five SCO member states held a joint anti-terrorist exercise from 6 to 12 August 2003, code-named "Joint-2003". World public opinion paid great attention to this joint exercise, in which China participated for the first time. So, is this exercise necessary in the current situation? What are its salient features? What is its real purpose? Will the SCO develop into a regional military alliance? What is the significance of this joint anti-terrorist exercise? The dialogue in this issue is an attempt to provide preliminary answers to these questions, and we hope it will help you to think about them.

title_en: Making the World Safe for America - U.S. Foreign Policy Rantu
abstract_en: The Heritage Foundation is an important policy research institution in the United States, and the policy research reports it publishes have a certain influence on the policy formulation of the Republican administration of the United States. This paper, published in April this year, is a set of foreign policy strategies formulated by the Foundation on how to safeguard the interests of the United States as a superpower in the post-cold war era. It is an important reference for understanding and studying the policy thinking of American conservatives. The following are excerpts.

title_en: New Beginning, New Tasks - Rethinking the Development of Sino-Russian Relations in the New Century
abstract_en: Sino-Russia relations is one  of  the most important bilateral relations in the  contemporary  international relations. The strategic and cooperative relationship set up  by  both sides is unprecedented in the contemporary international relations. In dealing with many bilateral and international critical problems, China and Russia can often agree with each other without prior consultation, Their attitudes are identical, and they can cooperate well  with  each other. All these show that their strategic and cooperative relationship is mature.     At present,   Sino-Russia  rlations  is  at  a  historically  new starting point: （1） It requires to deepen Sino-Russia  reltions  that  the new president Putin’s task is to strengthen his country. （2） China’s reform has entered into the second period of its “three steps” strategy. Thus, on the timetable, China’s “three steps” strategy  is  consistent with Russia’s economic development strategy before  2010. （3） The changes in the international situation require the  two  countries  to further enhance their cooperation standard under the premise of  multi-polarity and mutual promotion. All these will add new energy to Sino-Russia strategic and cooperative partnership.       In the new period, as strategic and cooperative  partners,   China and Russia, in the international fields, will mainly devote to push the multi-world to be formed, and to set up a new world order for a justice, equal and reasonable international politics, economy and security;  in the  bilateral  relationship,   they  should  enhance  their  economic cooperation, make efforts to overcome those  difficult  problems  that hinder their cooperation on economy and trade, as to make their  trade relationship step onto a new stage and to  make  their  political  and economic relationship developed well.

title_en: A Test of the Islamic Factor in Chinese and Russian Security Interests
abstract_en: Abstract Since the end of the cold war, the radical Islamic forces which have become even more radical, exclusive, expansive and destructive have expanded rapidly in the world.     The penetration and expansion of outside Islamic forces pose a threat to Russia’s security interests:  Russia  might lose central Asia, "the Intermediate Zone", affecting Russia’s relations with central Asian countries and accelerating tensions in its south border areas; the internal separatism of Islamic radicals and terrorism also pose a threat to Russia’s unity and stability; Chechnya has speeded up its separatist pace,  there exists a danger of the Dagestan Republic’s splitting from the Russia Federal, the Islamic trend in north  Caucasus is enhanced.     Influenced by outside Islamic forces and other hostile forces, China’s internal ethnic separatists gang up with outside separatist forces to intensify their separatist activities, constituting a serious threat to our security and stability in Xinjiang region.  The separatist activities are reflected in: religious and cultural infiltration; advocating Islamic "holy war";  producing terrorism etc..There exist common security interests between China and Russia with regard to guarding against and striking Islamic radical forces. The potential cooperative fields are: developing relations with various countries in Central Asia; strengthening trade and economic relations with them; making joint efforts to strike separatist activities of Pan-Islamitism and Pan-Turkism; improving bilateral relations with neighboring Islamic countries.

title_en: Adjustments in the nuclear strategies of the major Powers and their implications
abstract_en: On 8 January this year, the US Department of Defense submitted its Nuclear Posture Review to Congress. On the following day, the media published the foreword written by Rumsfeld for the Report and introduced some of its contents. March 9, the United States "Los Angeles Times" disclosed the "report" on the Russia, China, Iraq, Iran, North Korea, Libya and Syria as the object of nuclear attack, and the Korean Peninsula conflict, the Arab-Israeli war and the Taiwan Straits conflict as a prerequisite for the first U.S. use of nuclear weapons and other confidential content. After the news came out, the political, military, academic and public opinion circles in various countries were in an uproar, and our scholars also commented on it, but most of them focused on the assessment of the Report itself and its impact. In this column, we invite six scholars from the China Institute of Modern International Relations to talk to each other in an attempt to explore some compelling questions from the depth of history and a wider range of concerns: what changes have occurred in the nuclear strategies of the United States, Russia and other nuclear powers? What impact will these changes have on the military strategies of various countries, the international arms control process, the world security situation and China's security interests? How should we face them? It is hoped that these discussions will provide some references for the in-depth study of related issues by academics.

title_en: Question of the international implications of the collapse of the Soviet Union
abstract_en: ＜The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR), which was established five years after the victory of the October Revolution and had stood as a giant in the world, was suddenly dissolved after 69 years. Each of the 15 former republics of the USSR declared itself an independent sovereign state, and 11 of them, after a tortuous struggle and compromise, formed the "Commonwealth of Independent States", which was "neither a state nor a supranational entity". The decline and collapse of the Soviet Union in recent years has had, and will continue to have, an enormous and far-reaching impact on international relations.

title_en: EU Energy Security Policy Realignment and its Implications
abstract_en: The EU has significantly adjusted its energy security policy in line with the new energy and geo-security situation it is facing, which is characterised by weaponisation, nationalisation and neglect of environmental considerations, and its core objective has shifted from safeguarding security of energy supply to serving the Russian-Western strategic confrontation. The reshaping of the political perception of energy by the concept of geo-security, the generalisation of security of supply concerns and the economic challenges of the energy crisis have been the main driving factors behind the adjustment of the EU's energy policy. At present, the adjustment of the EU energy security policy has led to a weakening of the European-Russian energy interdependence, but it is difficult to change the situation of the EU's high external dependence and vulnerability of energy supply, and it has brought about a greater negative impact on the global energy pattern and the process of low-carbon development.

title_en: Challenges to India's tradition of strategic autonomy from Indo-US security cooperation
abstract_en: India-US security cooperation has been accelerated in the past years. The overall defense cooperation framework has become more comprehensive. The scale of India’s import of weapons from the United States has continued to expand,while the bilateral military exchanges have been more frequent. Since 2014,the Modi’s government has signed two basic military cooperation agreements with the United States,paving the way for further upgrading of bilateral defense cooperation in the future. The anti-terrorism cooperation between India and the United States has strengthened the security cooperation,which has a negative impact on India’s foreign strategy,particularly the long-standing strategic autonomy tradition. It has deteriorated India’s geopolitical environment,which is not conducive to the realization of the Indian Dream.

title_en: Actively promoting the westward strategy
abstract_en: The year 2010 is a year of China's accelerated rise, but also a year in which China faces many diplomatic challenges and tests. In the face of all kinds of frictions and conflicts between the United States, Japan and neighbouring countries and China, and in the face of waves of international noises such as the "China threat theory", "China collapse theory", "China toughness theory", "China arrogance theory" and the complex challenges hidden in these noises, what adjustments should be made to China's diplomacy? With the change of China's power and the change of the world's perception of China, how should China's foreign strategic objectives be positioned? Focusing on these questions, the journal Modern International Relations of the China Institute of Modern International Relations (CIMIR) held an academic seminar on 9 November 2010, entitled "China's Diplomacy and Foreign Strategy in the New Situation". More than 20 experts and scholars from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Peking University, Renmin University of China, the Party School of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China (CPC), the National Defence University, Beijing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Beijing University of Foreign Studies, the Communication University of China and the China Institute of Modern International Relations attended the seminar. They had a warm and in-depth discussion on China's current strategic environment and strategic choices from different perspectives. The main views of some of the participating experts and scholars are summarised below for the benefit of the readers.

title_en: World economic situation and prospects
The Kosovo issue and the new changes in the world situation
abstract_en: As we all know, the Kosovo issue was originally an internal Yugoslav problem that should have been resolved by the Yugoslav parties themselves. However, the question of Kosovo has now become a question of the world situation. The unique political geography of Yugoslavia makes it regarded as a stumbling block to NATO's eastward expansion and the United States' strategy of sole global hegemony, and thus an inevitable victim of the United States' pursuit of its new hegemony. Since the end of the Cold War, the United States has accelerated...

title_en: Five-Party Multi-Pronged Relationships in the Asia-Pacific Region
abstract_en: The relations between China, USA and Japan constitute the most important triangle in the various relationship among Asia-Pacific countries. It is a kind of unbalanced triangular relationship developed on the basis of US-Japanese alliance with cooperation and competition as well. It is currently in a relatively good condition of development. Today there exists no threat posted by one side to the other in the Chinese-Russian-American triangle, and the relationship between China and Russia is more stable than that between China and USA and that between Russia and USA, for they are closely related on geopolitical, economic and security matters. Now it is time for the three parties to abandon the thinking and practice prevailed in the Cold War period to establish a friendly cooperative relationship. The relationship between Russia, USA and Japan has significantly improved, and in which detente has replaced confrontation. But there are still some obstacles to the further development as USA and Japan have still some unesiness about Russia and the problem of Four Nothern Islands remains unsolved between Japan and Russia. Asean, while maintaining good relations with all the big powers, keeps certain distance from them so as to create a mechanism of mutual containment and balance of power. In the Asia-Pacific region, the relationship of mutual interdependence and mutual containment among China, USA, Japan, Russia and Asean will in the end form a certain kind of balanced and relatively stable political structure, which will contribute to the prevention of the emergence of some dominating force and promoting peace and development in the region.

title_en: NATO's Future from the Prague Summit
abstract_en: The NATO Summit will be held in the Czech capital, Prague, on 21 and 22 January this year. This is another important meeting after the NATO Washington Summit in 1999. Because the summit will have "turning significance" for the development of NATO, it has attracted great attention from countries all over the world. After the "9-1-1 incident", although NATO for the first time in history to start the "fifth article", but did not come in handy in the war in Afghanistan. Foreign public opinion, this is after the collapse of the Soviet Union, NATO is facing another major "existential crisis". NATO Prague summit will be how to respond to this? What are the commonalities and differences between this summit and the 1999 summit? In the face of new security threats and challenges, NATO's functions will be adjusted? What will be the main changes in NATO reform? What will be the impact on NATO's development of the expanding and prominent U.S.-European conflict? What is the development prospect and status of NATO? With these questions in mind, we invited several experts from the China Institute of Modern International Relations (CIMR) to have a dialogue with us, so as to promote our further research on NATO.

title_en: Characteristics of U.S., Japanese and Russian Policies on the Korean Peninsula and Their Trends in the New Era
abstract_en: Abstract  After the Cold War,   the  US,   Japan  and  Russia   constantly   adjusted   their  policies towards the Korean  Peninsular.   The  US  replaced its  early  "strategic  retraction"  with  active  "domination  of  the  new   order".     It  successfully  executed   soft-landing   in   its  relations with the DPRK and carried  out  flexible  policy to decentralise powers to the  ROK.   Japan  pursued a two- Koreas  policy,   but  due  to  the  restriction of the US and the ROK, it  could  only  follow the US  and  seek  economic  benefits  when  appropriate. Russia carried out a balanced  policy  towards the two Koreas.      The above policies  pursued  by  the  three  big  powers  stem  from  their   respective   strategic  interests. The US aims to safeguard its  interests  in Asia, Japan wishes to become a world  political  and military power, the  Russia’s  equal-distance  diplomacy is part of Yelsin’s  policy  to  restore  its powerful status.      By the early  21st  century,   the  above  three  power’s   Korean   policies   will   not   undergo  fundamental change.  The  basic  picture  will  be  US  domination  assisted  by  Japan,  and  Russia’s  reassertion. But they will be curbed by the  sense  of self-independence of the DPRK and the  ROK  and  will have overt or covert  struggle  which  is  to  have some impact on the Korean peninsular.

title_en: Leftist parties in the former Soviet region are reviving
Monthly Review of Events (February)
Japan makes major foreign policy changes towards Russia
abstract_en: Abstract  After forming his second cabinet on January  3  this  year,   the  Hashimoto administration formally decided to  readjust  Japan’s  foreign  policy toward Russia, shifting the principle of "expanded equilibrium" to the new one of "multi-level engagement". The reasons are: （1）Judging  from a pragmatic approach, Japan will not allow  the  Northern  territories issue involving Japan and Russia  to  be aserious  deterrence  to  the development of their bilateral relations.  （2） It is in Japan’s  favor of becoming a permanent member of the UN security council this year.（3） Based  on  the  fresh  understanding  of   Russia   and  international development in the post-Cold War era,  it  takes  account  of  Japan’s security and the stability in the Northeast Asia Region. In short, the Japan’s readjustment of its foreign policy toward Russia is  conducive to the improvement of Japan-Russia relations and the reinforcement  of Japan’s international status and influence, thus finally  contributing to the economic cooperation in the northeast Asia region.

title_en: Military factors affecting the regional situation
abstract_en: As the heart of the Eurasian continent, the importance of Central Asia in world geopolitics is self-evident, and its position has been further accentuated by the active involvement of the major Powers in the aftermath of 11 September. Beginning in 2005, the Central Asian countries will enter a period of political change marked by parliamentary and presidential elections. Because of the rampant extremism, terrorism and separatism in the region; the economic development of the countries has not yet entered a benign state; the successive "revolutions" in Georgia and Ukraine have had a certain demonstration and inspirational effect on the Central Asian opposition; and the complicated relations of the big powers in Central Asia, the situation in Central Asia is full of many variables. In order to have a more accurate grasp of the direction of the situation in Central Asia, the Expert Forum of Modern International Relations, in cooperation with the Eurasian Office of the China Institute of Modern International Relations, held a one-day seminar on 19 January 2005 at Wanshou Villa under the theme of "Analysis and Prospect of the Situation in Central Asia". Scholars and experts from Beijing, Shanghai, Lanzhou and Ningxia held serious and in-depth discussions on the situation in Central Asia from various perspectives in the spirit of seeking truth and seeking reality. The speeches made by the participants are now published in the hope that they will help you to think about the relevant issues and thus promote the deepening of the study of Central Asia.

title_en: Signs of a soft landing in the Korean nuclear crisis
abstract_en: ＜On 29 August, the Beijing Six-Party Talks ended smoothly under the close scrutiny of the international community, with China, the United States, the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK), the Republic of Korea (ROK), Japan, and the Russian Federation (RPRK) reaching a consensus on the general direction of denuclearisation of the Peninsula, and the United States and the DPRK, although still antagonistic on the way to resolve the nuclear issue, were able to maintain a constructive stance with relative restraint. This not only makes it possible to continue the six-sided framework, but also provides a good start for a soft landing on the Korean nuclear issue. First, the United States has begun to explore ways for a peaceful solution. Since the nuclear issue heated up in October last year, the United States has adopted an unconditional abandonment of the DPRK's nuclear programme.

title_en: Competitive dynamics and challenges of the Central Asian Regional Cooperation Mechanism (CARCM)
abstract_en: In recent years, regional cooperation in Central Asia has exhibited a trend of increasing competition. This phenomenon is not only the result of contested multilateralism influenced by major powers, but also a regional cooperation model accepted by the Central Asian states. Through international institutional competition among great powers, Central Asian states can attain more autonomy and better implement their multi-directional and balanced foreign policies. This trend of institutional competition is evident in various ways: both the United States and Russia are committed to improving the level of “C5+1” regime to maintain regional equilibrium. The EU is strengthening its cooperation with Central Asia to seize more opportunities. Regional powers are developing cooperation frameworks with Central Asia to maximize their benefits. China is expanding its cooperation with Central Asia to establish a comprehensive cooperation system. The competition among cooperation models in Central Asia is primarily influenced by three factors: changes in the regional security environment, shifts in great power relations, and alterations in the foreign policies of Central Asian states. In the future, major countries will increase competition for regional resources in order to obtain investment returns, and will focus on leveraging their comparative advantages to shape regional governance norms. Central Asian states will continue to bolster their diplomatic autonomy to secure more development opportunities.

title_en: Global rebalancing of the US national security strategy
abstract_en: The United States has adopted a retrenchment strategy on national security issues since the Obama administration, attempting to reduce its power projection in Europe and the Middle East and shifting its strategic priority to the Asia-Pacific. However, this subjective strategic design has brought an imbalance in the United States’ global strategy, leading to the outbreak of the Ukraine crisis and Gaza conflict. The United States had to withdraw some strategic and diplomatic resources to Europe and the Middle East. As a result, America’s national security strategy has achieved a global rebalance, which not only reflects the balance mechanism of power flow and strategic resource allocation among major countries, but also demonstrates strategic consequences of the US’s adherence to relative benefit thinking. Due to the limited strategic and diplomatic resources, the United States will find it difficult to balance the three regions of Europe, the Middle East, and the “Indo–Pacific.” The Ukraine crisis and Gaza conflict are facing the risk of escalation, and the US national security strategy is at a crossroads, with the historical peak of its pivot to Asia-Pacific possibly already over.

title_en: Monthly Events Review
U.S. Cognitive Domain Strategic Layout and the Great Power Game
abstract_en: The cognitive domain has been elevated to a new strategic battleground among major powers in recent years. The cognitive warfare projects of the US and NATO are evolving from academic research to formulating strategies, developing methods, and operations and practice. The general concepts, objectives, methodology, and specific means and methods are becoming more lucid. The US has developed a clearer fundamental scheme and strategic directions in the cognitive domain: a balanced emphasis on the offensive and defensive realism, an expansive geopolitical strategy driven by the concept of absolute security, and a long-term, intensified strategic competition with China and Russia. The ongoing Russia-Ukraine conflict is a vivid example of the cognitive warfare launched by the NATO. Therefore, it is necessary for China to examine the practices of the US and the West and analyze their repercussions.

title_en: The strategic situation in North-East Asia and China
abstract_en: The strategic stability of the Korean Peninsula is a core factor in guaranteeing the security and stability of Northeast Asia, and thus has always been a matter of great concern to the relevant countries in Northeast Asia, including China. the changes in the political scene in North Korea brought about by the death of North Korean leader Kim Jong-il at the end of 2011, as well as the different reactions of the relevant parties, once again call for us to further rationally examine the new changes that may emerge in Northeast Asia, judge in what direction the situation in Northeast Asia and the world is evolving, and consider what policy or strategic adjustments and responses China should make in the face of the changing situation. What direction will these changes push the situation in Northeast Asia and the world to evolve in, and what kind of policy or strategic adjustments China should make to cope with the changing situation. In this regard, on 6 January 2012, the Modern International Relations magazine held a seminar on "New Changes in Northeast Asia and Their Strategic Implications", inviting more than 20 experts and scholars from Peking University, Tsinghua University, Renmin University of China, Nankai University, National Defence University, Beijing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Jilin University and the China Institute of Modern International Relations to participate in the seminar to discuss the above issues in depth. More than 20 experts and scholars from famous universities and research institutes in China attended the meeting and discussed the above issues in depth. The views of some of the participants are summarised below for the benefit of the readers.

title_en: Commentary on the Convention on the Legal Status of the Caspian Sea
abstract_en: The Convention on the Legal Status of the Caspian Sea,which signed in 2018 by the five countries bordering the Caspian Sea,is the final result of the three-phase negotiations to resolve the dispute over the legal status of the Caspian Sea and promote energy development.On the basis of fully considering the relevant agreements had reached by the coastal countries,the Convention gives the Caspian Sea a special legal status of non-lake and nonsea and both lake and sea,and establishes a legal system of the Caspian Sea which is similar to the modern marine system.The Convention pays more attention to the security of the Caspian Sea region.However,the Convention still has insufficiencies in the method of demarcation and security systems.In general,the Convention creates opportunities for the development and transportation of Caspian energy,provides the guarantee for the security,stability and prosperity of the Caspian Sea region,and has important influence on countries inside and outside the region.It is also important for China to strengthen energy cooperation with the coastal countries and promote the construction of the Belt and Road Initiative to the Eurasian continent,and it also brings certain challenges of financing,technology and energy security to China’s participation in the Caspian Sea cooperation.

title_en: Mongolia's New Diplomacy
abstract_en: Mongolia's New Diplomacy Sun ShuliMongolia: NewForeignPolicy ¥Inrecentyears,foradaptingitselftothechangeableinternationalsituation,Mongoliahasmadeacomp...

title_en: New features of geopolitical competition in the Arctic
abstract_en: With the warming of the Arctic and the melting of sea ice, the large-scale exploitation of Arctic resources and the commercial operation of Arctic shipping lanes are gradually entering the operational phase. These changes have prompted the Arctic countries to pay more attention to the Arctic, which in turn has triggered competition for the Arctic. As a result, the Arctic region has become one of the hot spots in international politics. On the basis of the special geopolitical conditions of the Arctic region and under the influence of the post-cold-war process of democratisation of international politics, a large number of international political actors are actively involved in Arctic affairs, resulting in increasingly complex geopolitical relations in the Arctic and geopolitical competition in the Arctic that combines both traditional and new features.

title_en: America's New European Security Strategy
abstract_en: U.S. New European Security Strategy Li Yiyan I U.S. President Bill Clinton made his first trip to Europe after taking office earlier this year, attending the NATO summit in Brussels, meeting with the leaders of the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Poland, and Hungary in Prague, and then visiting Russia, Ukraine, and Belarus. During his trip to Europe, Clinton presented his set of proposals for a European security...

title_en: An Analysis of the U.S. "New Silk Road" Programme
abstract_en: In July 2011, the United States proposed the construction of a "new Silk Road", with Afghanistan as the pivot linking South Asia, Central Asia and West Asia, in order to realise the plan of "energy going south" and "commodities going north". This shows that the United States strategy in Afghanistan has undergone a transformation from focusing on the role of NATO and pursuing military first and economic second, to relying on regional countries and focusing on economic and social development. This change is not only forced by the United States to face the pressure of weak domestic economic growth and rising public aversion to war, but also the situation in Afghanistan and the United States of America's global strategic adjustments, the objective need for the eastward shift of the centre of gravity of the strategy." The "New Silk Road" programme is still at the exploratory stage, and its implementation will be challenged by a number of uncertainties and a volatile regional situation.

title_en: Prospects and problems of Russian-Chinese cooperation in the security sphere
abstract_en: After the Cold War, Sino-Russian relations have developed steadily, and the two sides have established a multi-level, multi-faceted strategic partnership based on mutual respect and trust.The basis for the development of the Sino-Russian strategic partnership in the twenty-first century will be common security interests. China and Russia should grasp the historical opportunity to attach importance to and strengthen security in the historical process of re-adjustment of international relations at the turn of the century and the development of multi-polarisation...

title_en: New developments in the situation in Syria and the game played by the parties
abstract_en: Since the beginning of October 2019, in the United States withdrew troops, Turkey launched a military operation in northern Syria in the background, the situation in Syria continued to be volatile changes: the Syrian North Federation tends to be reduced to nothing, the situation in Syria has entered a new historical stage; the two major extra-regional forces, "U.S. withdrawal and Russian advancement", the influence of the two sides; the United States-Turkey relations "stop falling" and is expected to "rebound", the alliance may be strengthened; the relationship between Turkey and the Syrian government under the mediation of Russia may be reconciled. The relationship between Turkey and the Syrian government in the Russian mediation of the possibility of reconciliation. Of course, in early November, the U.S. military announced that it would "return" to the north of Syria to "protect the oil fields", adding variables to the development of the situation in Syria.

title_en: Dilemmas and ways out of cyber arms control
abstract_en: The militarisation of cyberspace has become an indisputable fact, and the cyber arms race is intensifying, seriously threatening international security and stability. The international community has called for the development of cyberweapons to be restrained by a treaty, but there are many obstacles and difficulties to be overcome, including the lack of consensus on the definition of the concepts of cyberweapons and cyberattacks, the inability of the existing international law to determine whether cyberwarfare is an "armed conflict", the conflicting strategic interests of various countries in the development of cyberweapons, and the bottlenecks in the verification of cyberarmaments technology, and so on. This paper argues that the establishment of national norms of cyber behaviour and the adoption of transparency and confidence-building measures are the basis for the conclusion of a cyber arms control treaty; changes in the status quo of international Internet governance will help to reduce the intensity of the cyber arms race and contribute to the conclusion of the treaty; and the treaty on cyber arms control will also require necessary amendments to the existing Law of Armed Conflict to adapt it to the reality of cyber warfare that has already emerged.

title_en: China's Experience in Emerging from the Crisis and Russian-Chinese Cooperation
abstract_en: Both China and Russia have withstood the impact of the international financial crisis, and China's anti-crisis measures to boost domestic demand, stabilise the society, and structural adjustment have achieved remarkable results, and its experience in resisting and escaping from the crisis is worthy of Russia's reference. Russia's energy-dependent growth model has been hit hard by the financial crisis, so economic restructuring is a must, and innovative economy is a fundamental way out of the crisis and economic revival. China's and Russia's economic restructuring strategy provides a broad space for future cooperation between the two countries.

title_en: Putin takes first step towards political reform
The international situation after the dramatic changes in the Soviet Union
abstract_en: There have been new developments and changes in the international situation since the disintegration of the Soviet Union. While the blpolar pattern that existed in the Cold War period has totally collapsed, a new pattern consisting of one superpower, three economic centres and five political powers is emerging. Although the United States has in fact remained as the sole superpower, it is facing challenges from Japan and the EC. The US, Japan and the EC have appeared as three economic centres in the world. In terms of comprehensive strength, the US, Japan, the EC, Russia and China will be five political powers in an emerging new world pattern. While East-West contradictions have basically disappeared, West-West contradictions and South-South contradictions arising, and the contradictions between a few western countries and the majority ones adhering to the principle of independence of sovereignty have come to the fore. Although the threat of immediate military confrontation and conflict among nuclear powers is gradually fading away, regional problems and ethnic conflicts have become the main threat that triggers off global turmoil and regional instability. Confronted with a new international environment, many countries have put forward various proposals to establish a new international order and adjusted their own security strategics so as to take advantageous positions for themselves in the future international pattern. New regional orders （?） being s（?）t up or considered to be formed in Europe, the Asian-Pacific region and the Middle East. With the ending of the bipolar pattern, the decline of the threat of world war and the quickened steps of disarmament by major powers, qualitative and regional arms races are still making headway. It has become an important task to prevent arms proliferation in the arms control process.

title_en: The EU Gas Supply Security Dilemma and Its Countermeasures
abstract_en: Access to a stable supply of natural gas has been one of the priorities of EU energy security policy in recent years. The relative scarcity of natural gas resources in the EU and the growing trend of internal demand have led to increased external dependence, while the over-concentration of sources of imports and the relatively homogeneous transport routes have posed a serious challenge to the EU's security of natural gas supply. In this regard, the EU has recently formulated a series of policies and measures to address the situation. In the long run, the EU energy security strategy and policies will have a positive impact on the security of gas supply, but in the short and medium term, the EU will not be able to fundamentally solve the structural problems of imbalance between supply and demand and a high degree of dependence on the outside world, and the outlook for the security of the EU's gas supply is not optimistic.

title_en: The international nuclear order and the challenges it faces
abstract_en: A series of international nuclear norms,including nuclear disarmament and nuclear arms control,prohibition of the use of nuclear weapons,and nuclear non-proliferation institutions have been formed with the joint efforts of international community in the wake of public concerns about the consequences of nuclear war.These international norms and institutions have effectively impacted nuclear activities of sovereign states,prevented the outbreak of nuclear war and limited the number of nuclear-weapon states.Since the 21st century,great changes have taken place in the international strategic environment.The nuclear and missile technology is accelerating.Iran has increased its nuclear capability.The DPRK has succeeded in acquiring nuclear weapons.After Trump came to power,he rejected Obama’s policy of a nuclear-free world.The Trump administration proposes to develop a strong missile defense system and new strategic weapons,build low-yield nuclear bombs and pull out of Iran’s nuclear deal.Trump’s policy has opened up a new round of nuclear technology race,impacted strategic stability among major powers,and magnified limitations of the international nuclear order.

title_en: Characteristics of the security environment and its sensitivities in North-East Asia
abstract_en: ＜The end of the cold war between the United States and the Soviet Union has had a significant impact on North-East Asia, and the security environment in the region is in a state of flux. However, compared with other regions such as Europe, North-East Asia is relatively stable. This is a situation to be cherished. How to maintain and develop this favourable situation? It is important to pay attention to the basic characteristics of the region and its sensitivity. The security environment in North-East Asia is still marked by a number of factors that are difficult to ascertain. But its basic characteristics can be summed up in six words.

title_en: International Relations and China's New Journey of Diplomacy under Changing Circumstances - Overview of the Colloquium on Prospects of International Situation in 2023
abstract_en: ＜Cheng＞ The world today has entered a new period of turbulence and change, and the instability and uncertainty of the global strategic pattern and international relations have been highlighted. The 20th CPC National Congress has put forward new requirements for the comprehensive promotion of great power diplomacy with Chinese characteristics in the new era. In order to properly cope with the world's century-old changes and better serve the great rejuvenation of the Chinese nation, it is necessary to closely follow and study the development of the international and regional situation, apply dialectical thinking, and strive to explore and optimise the environment and path of great power diplomacy with Chinese characteristics in the new era. The Institute of International Studies of the Shanghai Academy of Social Sciences, the Editorial Board of Modern International Relations of the Chinese Academy of Modern International Relations, the Shanghai Institute of International Relations, and the Editorial Board of Studies in International Relations jointly organised a symposium on "Prospect of the International Situation in 2023: International Relations and China's Diplomacy in a New Journey under the Changing Circumstances. More than 30 experts and scholars from research institutes and colleges in Beijing, Shanghai and Wuhan gathered at the Shanghai Academy of Social Sciences to discuss the international order under the accelerated evolution of the world's century-long changes, the Ukraine crisis, great power relations and China's diplomacy in a lively and inspiring manner.

title_en: External strategy and policy trends of the German Red-Green Coalition Government
Sino-Russian Relations in the New Situation - Proceedings of the International Symposium
abstract_en: The seminar on"the Sino-Russian relations in the new international situation"was held in Beijing on November 11-13, 1992. Both Chinese and Russian scholars had an exploratory discussion on the world and Asia Pacific situations in the new era and the status quo and prospects for Sino-Russian relations. They all held that the disintegration of the USSR sped up the development of multi-polarization in the world. The Asia-Pacific region is entering the era of comparative stableness in politics and continuing development in economy. Peace and stableness have become the major tendency of the Asia-Pacific region in the 1990s, while cooperation and development are the main melody of this region striding forward towards the new century. China. Russia, the US and Japan are actively playing their important parts in this region. It is for the first time that the relations among the four countries are no longer in the position of confrontation, but seeking understanding, cooperation and the establishment of partnership. In maintaining a good momentum in their economic relations, the Sino-Russian relations are developing their diplomatic relations healthily. There are still great potential and broad prospects for the development of the relations between the two countries. Abiding by the national interests of each country, both sides will refuse to form an alliance, and allow no ideological struggles between them.

title_en: China-Europe Land-Sea Express and the Balkan Pivot of the "One Belt, One Road" Logistics Network
abstract_en: Ensuring the smooth flow of transnational logistics network is an important part of the implementation of the strategic concept of "Belt and Road". This paper elaborates on the necessity of constructing the China-Europe land-sea express line from the aspects of background, infrastructure, railway technology standard and existing transport modes, focuses on the analysis of the importance of the Balkan Peninsula to China-Europe international multimodal transport, and considers that the construction of the China-Europe land-sea express line through the Balkan Peninsula is a solid plan of China's Silk Road Diplomacy. The most urgent task in the construction of the China-Europe land-sea express line is to ensure the early completion of the Hungarian-Serbian railway and its extension, which requires Chinese enterprises to improve their ability to assess and avoid risks in the construction and investment of the project.

title_en: Group of Eight and China
abstract_en: On 1-3 June, the Group of Eight (G8) held its annual summit in Evian, a small city in south-eastern France. China attended as one of the representatives of the "Southern" countries, together with India, Brazil, Mexico and other major countries of the "South", on behalf of the "Southern" countries and the G8 dialogue. Because this is the first time China and the G8 positive contact, is the two sides "first handshake", this G8 summit is also extraordinarily compelling. What is the special international political significance of China's positive contact with the G8? What does it portend for China? What does it portend for China? What does it portend for the G8? What direction will the G8 take? How will the relationship between China and the G8 change and develop? All these are the focus of attention of the international community. For this reason, this issue specially invited several experts from the China Institute of Modern International Relations to discuss these issues, which are now compiled as follows, for the benefit of our readers.

title_en: German and French speakers on the international situation and Europe-China relations
abstract_en: German and French people talk about the international situation and Europe-China relations In late May and early June this year, the China Institute of Modern International Relations visited Germany at the invitation of the German Adenauer Foundation, with a delegation led by Song Baoxian, deputy director of the Institute; and visited Paris at the invitation of the French National Defence Review. The purpose of the trip was to discuss German-Chinese-French-Chinese relations, European security and the world landscape with officials and scholars of the two countries. German and French sources inter...

title_en: Evolution and practice of the "Intermediate Corridor" programme in Europe and Asia
abstract_en: Türkiye officially launched the Middle Corridor program in 2008, aiming to build a strategic transport link between Europe and Asia. Since its inception, the construction of the Middle Corridor has gone through three stages: from 2008 to 2015, it focused on the signing of cooperation agreements between Türkiye and the countries along the route, laying the groundwork for the initial construction of the corridor; from 2016 to 2021, it focused on the establishment of a joint working mechanism for the systematic construction of infrastructure; since 2022, the Middle Corridor has become the focus of global attention, and its strategic position has been significantly enhanced. The rise of the Middle Corridor program results from the combined effect of multiple factors. Changes in the world and Eurasian situations have brought important opportunities; Central Asian countries have been constantly making efforts in practice; and European and American countries have increased strategic investment. At the same time, China and the countries along the route have promoted the deep docking of the Belt and Road Initiative and the Middle Corridor, strengthening the strategic value of the Middle Corridor. However, the construction of the Middle Corridor faces a number of challenges, such as the insufficient modernization level of infrastructure and political stability in countries along the route and the lack of coordination among major countries outside the region, which still need to be addressed in the future.

title_en: Security cooperation and trends in the Eurasian region
abstract_en: The Eurasian continent, which is regarded as an important geopolitical plate in global politics, has always been an area of concern for major strategic forces. After "9-1-1", the security pattern of the region has entered a new stage of development: various forces, such as NATO, the European Union, the Collective Security Treaty Organisation (CSTO) of the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS), the Central Asian Union (CAU), the Eurasian Economic Community (EurAsEC), and the countries of Eurasia are all looking for new partners and new political combinations for the purpose of constructing a multi-pronged framework of stability in the region. The emergence and development of the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO) has added new models and concepts to international cooperation in this region. The second summit of the SCO on 7 June this year and its results have once again made the region a focus of attention and research. How will the different forces in the region combine? How will their different interests be coordinated, and what will be the impact of the new regional security pattern on the political and economic development of the Eurasian region? What role will the new mechanism of the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO) play in security cooperation in the region? What are the challenges and prospects for its development? With these questions in mind, in this issue we invite several experts from the China Institute of Modern International Relations to have a dialogue, with a view to promoting in-depth research in this field.

title_en: Historic Challenges to the International System and China's Response
abstract_en: At present, the international system is facing three major historic challenges: the development of relations between the major powers, in which cooperation is the mainstay and competition is the mainstay, has shifted to a track in which competition is the mainstay and cooperation is the mainstay, and the question of whether the international system will continue to move towards convergence or towards gradual fragmentation has become a major issue in international politics; the failure of the international anti-terrorist coalition and the rise of extremist forces such as the Islamic State have led to a total collapse of the order in the Middle East, and the West's dominance of the Middle East is facing unprecedented challenges. The dominant position of the West in the Middle East is facing unprecedented challenges, and this has given rise to the global challenge of the increasing division between the 1.6 billion Muslims in the world and their host countries and the international community; the system of global governance is close to dysfunction due to its serious detachment from the realities of globalisation, and the determination of the United States to safeguard its hegemony against the backdrop of the world's economic and political upheavals as well as strategic competition among the major powers have caused the reform of global governance to lose its synergy, and the ever-expanding deficit in global governance will bring us a dangerous and unsuccessful world in the not-too-distant future. The widening global governance deficit may bring us a dangerous and failed world in the near future. In the face of these historic challenges, it is of great significance for China to pursue a new type of international relations strategy globally, dissolve the moulding of hostile relations and focus on the establishment of universal partnership.

title_en: U.S. Central Asian Strategy and Implications for China's Security Environment
Ukrainian diplomacy in the context of NATO's eastward expansion
abstract_en: Ukrainian Diplomacy in the Context of NATO's Eastward Expansion Zi Shufang Ukraine is uniquely situated geopolitically in the middle of NATO and Russia, as well as the rest of the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS). What kind of foreign policy Ukraine conducts will have a significant impact on the stability and security of Europe and the CIS as a whole. Especially in the case of NATO's eastward expansion has become a foregone conclusion, the international community has aroused widespread concern about what direction Ukraine will take...

title_en: Analysis of NATO's new strategic concept
abstract_en: Three changes in NATO's new strategic concept are noteworthy: in the assessment of the "security environment", the possibility of NATO being attacked by traditional military forces is reduced, while "new threats" such as the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction (WMD) and cyber-attacks are becoming more and more serious; in the area of threat response, it is proposed to strengthen the construction of "new capabilities" such as anti-missile defence systems and the application of comprehensive crisis management methods, including political, civil and military ones, and to carry out wider international cooperation; in the area of relations with Russia, "new thinking" has been demonstrated, which no longer considers Russia to be the main security threat and "seeks to establish a genuine strategic partnership with Russia". In terms of relations with Russia, NATO has demonstrated a "new mindset", no longer considering Russia to be a major security threat, and "seeking to establish a genuine strategic partnership with Russia". The new strategic concept will have an impact on the future development of NATO, the transatlantic alliance and the West's relations with Russia: the global character of NATO will become more pronounced, its position in the transatlantic alliance will be elevated, and the relations between NATO and its member States and Russia will enter into a new phase of less confrontation and more cooperation.

title_en: Biden Administration's Food Security Cooperation with Africa
abstract_en: In the context of the Biden administration’s coordinated implementation of promoting great power competition and addressing global challenges, the issue of food security has become an important tool to achieve the international strategic goals of the United States. The Biden administration has set a wide range of agenda items for food security cooperation in Africa, including food trade, climate-smart agriculture, food aid, and “democratic governance” of food security, which is fundamentally motivated by strengthening great power competition with China and Russia in Africa, improving the United States’ ability to access Africa’s critical mineral resources, and opening up the African food and agricultural market. However, there is a mismatch and contradiction between the strategic supply of the United States and the strategic demand of Africa, and it is difficult for the Biden administration to improve Africa’s food security in the long run. Driven by the US strategy of great power competition, the Biden administration’s cooperation on food security in Africa will intensify China–US–Africa infrastructure competition, threaten China–Africa cooperation in science and technology supply chains, and squeeze China’s influence on global development governance.

title_en: International Carbon Neutral Development Trends and Prospects
abstract_en: With the full implementation of the Paris Agreement, carbon neutrality has become the focus of international attention. More and more economies are announcing carbon neutrality targets and adopting more stringent emission reduction measures, and the scale and impact of international action on carbon neutrality is growing. However, there is still a large policy and cognitive gap between economies, the asymmetry and imbalance of carbon neutral actions are still prominent, and countries are also facing many internal challenges such as political economy and technology. The overly aggressive emission reduction targets and politicisation of climate issues in some countries have triggered a series of shocks, including soaring international energy prices, green trade protectionism and intensified geopolitical competition. In order to successfully promote the global low-carbon transition, appropriate emission reduction strategies and pacing are indispensable, and countries need to grasp the dynamic balance between development, security and environmental protection, and deepen international low-carbon cooperation as builders to actively narrow the global carbon neutrality gap.

title_en: An Assessment of the U.S. Global Energy Strategic Control Posture
abstract_en: The United States is the world's largest oil consumer and importer, in order to ensure the adequate supply of oil consumption and diversification of sources, the United States, with the help of its strong military and economic power, controls the world's major sea and land energy corridors, and has formed a control posture over global energy. This paper describes and makes a preliminary assessment of the United States' global energy strategic control posture from three aspects: the global energy market, major oil reserves and production areas, and energy transport corridors.

title_en: Trends in the changing power dynamics of the European Union in the context of the Ukrainian crisis and their implications
abstract_en: The outbreak of the Ukraine crisis has accelerated the adjustment and changing power pattern of the European Union. Germany does not play the role model as it used to, its willingness and ability to make contributions have declined, and it has become a follower rather than a leader in crisis response. The “Atlantics” dominated the EU, and the “Europeans” were weakened. Germany’s all-round dependence on the United States has increased. France has lost traction on the EU, the German–French axis is absent, and the Central and Eastern European and Northern European countries are gaining momentum. Compared with other EU institutions and member states, the status and influence of the European Commission has been enhanced, leading the sanctions against Russia, participating more in the common security and defense policy, and contributing to the geo-politicization of EU economic policies.
