These changes will increase internal disputes within the EU, weaken the EU’s international status and influence, and reduce the stability and predictability of the EU’s China policy.

title_en: Forecast of China's relations with major powers
Synthesis of the seminar on "The way forward in Afghanistan after the withdrawal of the United States forces"
abstract_en: Afghanistan is known as the "graveyard of empires", where the British Empire and the Soviet Union once lost their war chests. The United States, which has been waging a war against terrorism in Afghanistan for nearly 20 years, has not only incurred huge costs, but has also become more and more fearful and deeply mired in the quagmire, and the Biden administration is eager to get out of it. The hasty withdrawal of the United States has left a mess in this troubled country and made its situation even more volatile. With the Taliban's power and influence expanding, the war in Afghanistan is likely to be plunged into a tug-of-war; and the terrorist forces will take the opportunity to grow in strength, with far-reaching implications for regional security and global counter-terrorism. The major stakeholders will start a new round of games around the Afghan issue, and the neighbouring countries may play a leading role in the situation in Afghanistan in the future. China has multiple concerns in Afghanistan and should respond appropriately to changes in the situation there.

title_en: Characteristics and trends of the international situation in 1993
abstract_en: The world continues to develop towards multipolarization in the eventful year of 1993. In general, the world situation has the following nine major features: （1） Although it has generally tended to mitigate, international situation remains unstable. （2） With the further rising of Asia—Pacific region, this region has become an arena of fierce rivalry among all political powers. （3） The end of the Cold War has led to the explosions of all kinds of troubles in Western countries and the worsening of contradictions among them, making it more difficult to coordinate and compromise. （4） Runnig into snags in his reforms and foreign policies, Clinton has not attained much achievements and will not be easy to improve in the near future. （5） The political situation in Russia is still unstable though the situation of "dual—government" has been terminated. The future development is hard to forecast. （6） Hot spots in some regions remain unchanged and even become hotter, though in some other regions they have cooled down. Regional conflicts are still major sources of threat to world stability. （7） International arms control and disarmament have developed in further depth. Prevention of nuclear proliferation and overall prohibition on nuclear tests have drawn more and more attention from international community. （8） There has been great progress in internationalization of world economy, especially the grouping of regional economy. （9） China has made great achievements in its reform and open policies. International environment continues to develop in favour of China, but in the meantime China is also confronted with quite a few new problems and challenges.

title_en: Carbon Neutrality and the New International Energy Politics
abstract_en: The international energy low-carbon transition is accelerated by the carbon neutral target. The world consumption of traditional energy is entering a bottleneck, the development of new and renewable energy isaccelerating, and the trend of energy electrification, energy networking and energy digitalization is increasing. At the same time, under the impact of the COVID-19, some radical and political emission reduction measures in the lowcarbon transition process have also exacerbated an international energy short-term supply-demand imbalance which has resulted in soaring energy prices and electricity shortages in many countries. The ongoing global energy shortage underlines the complexity of the international energy transition, and foreshadows that the low-carbon transition process will face many energy security problems. The global energy geopolitical landscape is brewing many new changes.

title_en: Prospects for the European Union in the light of the Ukrainian crisis
abstract_en: The Ukrainian crisis is the geopolitical event that has had the greatest impact on Europe since the end of the Cold War, and will greatly affect the development prospects of the EU. It has significantly changed the EU’s economic development and operating logic, and brought more serious long-term impacts on the EU than the previous debt crisis; interrupted the EU’s strategic autonomy process; brought new momentum to integration. At the same time, it has increased the negative factors hindering integration within the EU. The Ukraine crisis will further weaken the EU’s strength and international influence, accelerate the EU’s marginalization in the world’s geopolitical structure, and may also kill its geopolitical dream of becoming a world pole. This is not conducive to the multi-polarization of the world, and the containment of hegemonism and power politics. All this is not inevitable. If the lessons of the Ukrainian crisis can be correctly reflected on, and the EU can unite and view the world with a more open and inclusive attitude, the EU may also have a better future.

title_en: Four features of current Middle East politics
abstract_en: ＜In the second decade of the twenty-first century, the turmoil in the Middle East is destined to become one of the major events in international politics. The combination of political unrest, changes in the international energy structure, and adjustments in the policies of the major powers has led to changes in the basic features of Middle Eastern politics, and these changes are likely to be the beginning of a long-term trend that will ultimately change the historical face of Middle Eastern politics. Firstly, at the international political level, the Middle East has evolved from a place where the great Powers must fight to a trap against which the great Powers are on high alert. Because of its geographic location, religious centre, energy town and other reasons, the Middle East has always been a place of contention for soldiers. During the Cold War, the United States and the Soviet Union fought fiercely for supremacy in the Middle East. After the Cold War, the United States

title_en: Leaning on the Land to the Sea: Rebalancing China's Strategic Centre of Gravity
abstract_en: The coastalisation of China's economy has created the strategic danger of an imbalance in China's centre of gravity. In order to maintain the stability and development of China and Central Asia in the geopolitical game of the Eurasian continent's pivotal region, China needs to make use of the SCO platform to actively promote the development of the western part of the country, build special cities and comprehensive transport corridors in the western part of the country, and rebalance China's national strategic centre of gravity through balanced development of land and sea.

title_en: Prospects for Sino-Russian Relations - Proceedings of an International Symposium
abstract_en: Broad Prospects for Sino-Russian Relations - Summary of an International Academic Symposium ¥Abstra ct: Anacademicsympos...

title_en: Central Asia after independence: challenges and opportunities
abstract_en: Although the independence of the five middle Asian countries has opened up vast, space for developing their own national economy independently, it also poses a series of challenges on them in various aspects. The five countries have certain developing potentials: abundant natural resources and better social and economic infrastructure. At the same time, they face some difficulties: simple economic struture, lack of capital funds, relative low level of living standard and short of necessary facilities for opening to the outside world. Although the social and political situation in most of the five countries is calm at present, there still exist some unstable factors: complicated national problems, unsettled territorial disputes, increasingly active religious influence and serious problems of growing population. At present the forces of ex-communists in middle Asia are still strong, but they are facing cliallengcs from the other two political forces. One is "the Democratic Force" and the other is the Islamic Fundamentalist Force. The influence of Islamism in this region is very likely to become a bigger ideological and political factor affecting its future development. After the independence of the five nations, foreign influences have been penetrating into them by means of providing economic aid and investment. This has helped create a favourable outside environment for their development, but at the same time it has also added some complicacy to their deplomatic activities.

title_en: Analysis of the characteristics of the Trump administration's sanctions instruments
abstract_en: Trump administration has used sanctions to solve diplomatic problems. It has created many new sanctions programs and put more emphasis on human rights sanctions. It has also made more use of secondary sanctions, export controls and investment restriction. Both sanction-related criminal enforcements and fines have hit new highs. The main reason is that President Trump and his economic team are keen on "Money War". Meanwhile, sanctions can meet Trump’s requirements for easy achievements, and can also contain and suppress opponents. But the sanctions have undermined the US ally system and boosted the de-dollarization and it will be difficult to reach the goal in the future.

title_en: Increased Imbalance in Europe-U.S. Relations and Prospects for EU Strategic Autonomy
abstract_en: Trump’s victory in November 2024 once again had a strong impact on the European Union. However, unlike when Trump won the election for the first time in 2016, there have been some disturbing development trends in US–Europe relations. The imbalance in relations between the US and Europe has become even more pronounced. Whether in important fields such as the economy, finance, science and technology, or the military, the gap between the European Union and the United States is widening. Meanwhile, Europe’s dependence on the United States is also increasing. Especially since the outbreak of the Ukraine crisis, it has formed an all-round dependence on the United States in terms of security, energy, markets, as well as capital and technology. The increasing imbalance in US–Europe relations has triggered anxiety in Europe, including concerns that Europe might become a “vassal” of the United States. During Trump’s second term, Europe may be more inclined to cater to the United States and submit to its demands more often. However, under internal and external pressures, it may also accelerate the process of promoting strategic autonomy. Where the European Union will go will largely depend on the direction and intensity of policy adjustments during Trump’s second term.

title_en: Situation and internal and external policy in Ukraine
abstract_en: Ukraine's Situation and Internal and External Policy Zi Shufang This year marks the fifth anniversary of Ukraine's independence. After independence, Ukraine's development path has been very rugged, with domestic political turmoil, sharp ethnic conflicts, prominent social problems, and deteriorating economic conditions. In terms of external relations, the relationship between Ukraine and Russia was estranged, and potential conflicts between the two countries became public.In July 1994, Kuchma became president and adjusted Ukraine's internal and external policies...

title_en: The EU's strategic dilemma in the light of the changes in Afghanistan
abstract_en: The European Union has significant geopolitical and security interests in Afghanistan: preventing the resurgence of refugees, combating terrorism, improving EU’s image, exporting Western values and increasing its geopolitical weight by transforming Afghanistan. The Taliban’s renewed control of Afghanistan means a heavy blow for the EU, and brings uncertainty in security and geopolitical issues. The Afghan changes highlight the long-standing strategic predicament of the EU: too much dependence on the US that prevents the EU from realizing strategic autonomy; long-term values-oriented diplomacy that compresses its own strategic space so tha a pragmatic cooperation system in the“post-American era”is hard to take shape; the limitations of mechanism and authority that aggravate the conflict between ideal and reality, which disables the EU as a whole to exert its due international influence. After Trump’s era, the Afghan changes have again stimulated the EU strongly; a new round of discussions has been started within the EU and the sense of independence has been reinforced. But due to a number of constraints, the EU’s strategic adjustment will have its limits, and it still faces difficulties to ge out of its strategic predicament.

title_en: An Exploration of the Homogeneous Security Pattern in Northeast Asia
abstract_en: After the Cold War, the relationship between the major powers in North-East Asia has undergone a new division and combination, and the reconstruction of the relationship between China, Japan and Russia is in the same historical space and time of the radiation of the United States hegemony, which makes the international relations of the North-East Asian region extremely vulnerable to the influence of the superpowers. The geopolitical structure of Northeast Asia is characterised by one superpower and three superpowers, which provides a strategic space for the superpowers to play the role of "offshore balancing hand". In order to establish and maintain hegemony in Northeast Asia, the United States has carried out the strategic layout of combining with Japan to control China, holding back Russia and suppressing North Korea. The combination of the United States and Japan has given birth to the Sino-Russian strategic partnership, and the adjustment and improvement of the relations between the major Powers in the Northeast Asian region has thus been plunged into a structural dilemma, making the construction of a security of equilibrium a realistic option for the realisation of peace and stability in the Northeast Asian region in the early part of the twenty-first century.

title_en: Monthly Events Review
Problems in the Realignment of U.S. Foreign Strategy
abstract_en: Problems in the Adjustment of U.S. Foreign Strategy China Centre for International Studies Wan Guang In the late 1980s, the United States began to conceive of adjusting its foreign strategy. In the 1990s, the Bush administration and the Clinton administration successively put forward the U.S. foreign strategy after the end of the U.S.-Soviet Cold War. However, so far, there are also more people in the United States who believe that the United States has not yet formulated a strategy that truly adapts to the international situation and the United States' own situation...

title_en: World Outlook 2004
abstract_en: Looking back to 2003, wars, terror and crises have come one after another, seemingly shocking and pessimistic. But reason, as a unique attribute of human beings, is after all powerful. The "six-party talks", India and Pakistan to send a message of reconciliation, East Asian integration process accelerated, the great powers after the tension of the relations between the easing, etc., repeatedly illustrated this point. As we reflect on the new year, we certainly do not rule out contradictions, differences and competition, but we believe that the mainstream development trend is based on rational cooperation. In order to help you think about the future development of the world, in this issue, we invited researcher Lu Zhongwei, president of the China Institute of Modern International Relations, and 11 experts in related fields to hold an in-depth dialogue on the theme of "Prospect of the World Trend in 2004". This is the sequel to our "Outlook of World Trends in 2003", and we hope to provide you with a platform for thinking in a coherent manner.

title_en: Trends in the militarisation of international deep ocean space and its governance
abstract_en: In recent years, countries have advanced the exploration of international deep-sea space, but the militarization of international deep-sea space has also become increasingly prominent, mainly reflected in the increasing awareness of deep-sea strategies by major countries, the improvement in the level of intelligence of deepsea military equipment, and the improvement of deep-sea military equipment. The concept of combat tactics is gradually enriched. The continuous development of the militarization of international deep-sea space will not only pose a serious threat to the sustainable development of deep-sea resources, but also trigger an international arms race in deep-sea space, which will hinder the in-depth advancement of global governance of international deep-sea space.All countries in the world should work together to deal with the militarization of international deep-sea space.

title_en: America's new Central Asian strategy
abstract_en: The new US strategy for Central Asia Wan Guang, China Centre for International Studies (CCSIS) Central Asia1 Developments in Central Asia are attracting more and more attention from the world. Central Asia is rich in oil and gas resources as well as other strategic resources. It is estimated that the Caspian Sea region has about 200 billion barrels of oil reserves, second only to the Gulf. Central Asia also has some of the largest natural gas reserves in the world. Central Asia is considered likely to become the next century's new Asia-Europe...

title_en: Future trends in regional security in Europe
abstract_en: Future Trends in European Regional Security Tong Feng With the end of the Cold War and the collapse of the Soviet Union, the security environment in the European region has changed profoundly: the pattern of confrontation between the two major military blocs no longer exists, and the prospect of a major war in Europe has disappeared; the decades of post-war peace (albeit peace under a balance of nuclear terror) have ended, and Europe has become one of the most concentrated hotspots of conflict in the world, with an unabated sense of insecurity...

title_en: Review of the latest situation on the Korean peninsula
abstract_en: Since the North-South summit talks in 2000, there have been substantial breakthroughs in relations between the two sides in many fields, including political, economic and military, and an unprecedented easing of the situation on the entire peninsula. Taking this opportunity, North Korea's relations with Russia, the European Union and other major Western countries have improved and even established diplomatic relations. But after the new U.S. government came to power, North Korea-U.S. relations have stagnated or even a certain degree of regression, affected by the reconciliation process between the North and South also slowed down significantly. A few days ago, Bush formally launched his policy towards the DPRK, announcing that he would resume dialogue with the DPRK, and all parties concerned are now actively brewing a new policy towards the peninsula. How the situation on the peninsula will develop in the future is becoming one of the focuses of international attention. For this reason, this magazine specially invited several experts from the Institute of Modern International Relations (IMIR), in the form of dialogue, each from a different professional point of view to express their views, which can be said to be intertwined and complement each other.

title_en: United States non-proliferation policy after the Cold War
abstract_en: Post-Cold War U.S. Non-Proliferation Policy Wang Ling I. After the end of the Cold War, the focus of U.S. arms control policy shifted to preventing the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and missiles in the Third World. After the collapse of the Soviet Union, the United States shifted its defence focus from dealing with the global threat of the Soviet Union to dealing with regional conflicts. While continuing to focus on implementing a strategic nuclear arms reduction agreement with Russia and eliminating the U.S.-Russian nuclear confrontation posture, it prominently strengthened...

title_en: Shanghai Cooperation Organisation and regional cooperation
abstract_en: The Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) will hold its fourth summit on 17 June in the Uzbek capital, Tashkent. During the summit, not only will various relevant legal documents be signed, the SCO Regional Anti-Terrorist Structure be officially inaugurated, and issues related to deepening the organization of the structure and functioning of the organization itself, diplomatic immunity for the members of its conference bodies, the status of the host country, the status of the observer state, and the status of the partner state in the dialogue will be discussed, but also important decisions will be made on practical cooperation in the fields of diplomacy, security, economy, transport, humanities, and so forth, and discussions will be held on the establishment of a dialogue mechanism with Important decisions will be taken on practical cooperation in the areas of foreign affairs, security, economy, transport, humanities, etc., and the establishment of a dialogue mechanism with ASEAN will be discussed. What is the significance of this summit for the development of the SCO? Does it mean the expansion of the SCO's co-operation areas and functions? Does it mean the expansion of the SCO's co-operation areas and functions, the deepening of regional co-operation? What kind of regional co-operation model is favourable for the development of the member states? What issues should be taken into account in order to promote the smooth development of such regional cooperation so that the SCO can play a more distinctive and constructive role in the world? With these questions in mind, this issue invites five experts from the China Institute of Modern International Relations (CIMIR) to hold a dialogue, in the hope that the discussion of these questions will help you further deepen your research and thinking.

title_en: The new dynamics of international energy security
abstract_en: Energy security has a bearing not only on a country's economic security but also on its political and military security. Energy security is therefore a strategic issue for a country and a core element of national security. Since the beginning of the 21st century, international terrorist activities have become rampant, the global geopolitical situation is unstable, and international oil prices have continued to soar, which has once again heated up the issue of energy security. In order to ensure energy security, the United States, the European Union and Japan have successively formulated new energy strategies or policies, highlighting the need to cut back on expenditure, strengthening the source of income, strengthening international cooperation and adhering to the principle of diversification.

title_en: The Strengthening of the Security Relationship between Europe and the United States and Its Limits
abstract_en: Three trends have been distinguished in both Europe and America’s assessment of the external security environment since 2014 Ukraine crisis: the weakening of the Western order as a degradation of the international security order, taking geopolitical and strategic competition as the primary consideration, and emphasis on hybrid threats and other changes in battlefield patterns.This new perception has pushed transatlantic security relations into a phase of intensification, with a marked expansion of issues, agendas, and networks of coordinating mechanisms, as well as the initial formation of a two-front strategic structure of deterrence against Russia and China.This change has exacerbated the polarization of the international security structure and has had a multifaceted negative impact on the international security situation. However, the process of strengthening the security relations between Europe and the United States is accompanied by an unbalanced development of its internal structure, which in the medium and long term will constrain its sustainability and the direction of its evolution.

title_en: Enhanced military engagement of extraterritorial States in East Africa: dynamics and implications
abstract_en: The most fundamental challenge facing Eastern African countries is development.However,the outside powers’troops have flooded into the region and regarded it as an arena of geopolitical rivalry.The process of outside military deployment can be divided into several stages of preparation,the soft military presence,the hard military base and the military hub.So far,France,US and Japan have deployed military bases in Djibouti;the UAE has military bases in Eritrea and Somaliland;Israel has military presence in Eritrea;Iran had military presence in Eritrea and Sudan;Turkey and Qatar have stationed troops in Sudan and Somalia;Saudi Arabia will build its military base in Djibouti,and Russia will establish military base in Sudan.The outside military deployment has intensified security dilemma among Eastern African states.It may bring potential threats to China’s logistics base in Djibouti,its anti-piracy campaign in Somali Waters,the mission of convoy fleets as well as the implementation of the Belt and Road Initiative and the interconnectivity among Eastern African countries.

title_en: US strategy of denial deterrence in the Indo-Pacific
abstract_en: The denial deterrence of the United States in the “Indo–Pacific” region is an important means of advancing its “Indo–Pacific” strategy. It is characterized by emphasizing the multi-dimensional denial effect, flexible use of multiple deterrent means, and mobilizing the participation of multiactors. In the implementation of the denial deterrence strategy, the United States has intensified the strategic game between major countries at the regional level, triggered the escalation of tension in the regional security situation, and impacted the balance of power in the “Indo–Pacific” region to a certain extent. However, the United States’ denial deterrence in the “Indo–Pacific” region will continue to be constrained by factors such as the restriction of strategic resources and coordination space caused by a relative decline in the strength and status, the formation of strategic synergy caused by partner countries’ suspicion and distrust, and the uncertainty of the strategic environment caused by the improvement of the area denial ability of the “Indo–Pacific” countries, such as China. The ability development, subjective will, and firm determination of most countries in the “Indo–Pacific” region in shaping the security order at this stage will become the decisive variables of the future “Indo–Pacific” security order.

title_en: U.S. accelerates pace of building missile defence system
Current status and future directions of international cooperation and competition in space
abstract_en: In the past 60 years of international space activities, mankind has witnessed a history of three alternating cycles of competition and cooperation, and in the past 10 years, intense competition intertwined with in-depth cooperation has become a new feature of international cooperation and competition in space. Owing to the fragility of space, the high cost of space weapons, the fear of escalation of space conflicts and the advantages of space cooperation, no space conflicts have occurred so far. However, with international cooperation in space gradually falling into difficulties, the adjustment of national nuclear strategies and nuclear deterrence strategies, the development of space technology and space weapons, and the advancement of research on theories of space deterrence and transdimensional deterrence, the likelihood of the outbreak of an international space conflict will increase.

abstract_en: Summary of the Seminar on Bosnia and Herzegovina Recently, the state of affairs in Bosnia and Herzegovina has remained tense, the situation has become more complicated, and the future is confusing, which has attracted the attention of the world. 23 April, the editorial board of this magazine invited relevant scholars from the China Institute of Modern Institute of International Relations (CIMIR) to discuss the causes, current situation, intentions of the big powers and development trend of the Bosnia and Herzegovina issue. The various views are summarised as follows; I. Background Chi Degang (East Europe and Central Asia Research Office)...

title_en: Kazakhstan's Eurasian statehood and multidimensional diplomacy
abstract_en: This is a special contribution to the magazine Contemporary International Relations by Mr. K. K. Tokaev, the first deputy foreign minister of Kazakstan, on the invitation of China Institute of Contemporary International Relations. In the article, he holds that as a burgeoning state Kazakstan should define its status in international arena——a great regional power of Central asia. He emphasizes that Kazakstan is a Eurasian country with favorable location both politically and geographically. He advocates to consolidate Kazakstan’s relationship with other Central Asian countries and describes a range of foreign policies towards Russia, China, Southeast Asia, South Asia, Near east, Europe as well as the US. He also believes that Kazakstan may join in the line of rapidly developing Asian countries towards the 21st century by establishing a friendly relationship with China.

title_en: Geopolitics in the context of larger history
abstract_en: Each country should choose between the development of sea power and land power according to its own natural endowment, and those choices that can promote the long-term development of the country are good, whether they are based on the development of sea power or on the development of land power. From a broad historical perspective, the development of land power is more sustainable, whereas the maritime space has the characteristics of dispersion, uncertainty and instability, and the power of the sea has the characteristics of non-sustainability, which is quick to gather and quick to disappear. Human society has a certain degree of mobility in changing the limitations of the natural world, but it has a limit, and those who change the face of the sea to the land or the land to the sea often end up in failure. Institution-building in a country was a fundamental prerequisite for the development of both land and sea power. The concept of the right to control could not be adapted to geopolitical changes and developments, and the issues of the right to life, the right to development and the resulting influence should be raised and deepened.

title_en: China's Oil Security and Its Strategic Options
abstract_en: Oil is a non-renewable strategic resource, and its importance to economic development is self-evident. The limited nature of oil resources, regional distribution and consumption of unevenness makes oil-consuming countries in oil-rich regions to carry out a fierce geopolitical competition. With the development of China's economy, China's dependence on the international oil market is increasing. The current situation of China's oil situation requires that China must pay attention to the world's oil geopolitics and formulate corresponding oil security strategies to ensure oil security.

title_en: Summary of the seminar "Russian-Chinese Social Sciences Forum".
Reactivation of the Franco-German axis and prospects
abstract_en: As the engine of European integration, The Franco-German axis has weakened with the expansion of the European Union over the past decades. However, after Emmanuel Macron came to power, Aachen Treaty signed by France and Germany has promoted the EU’s defense and fiscal integration and committed to the EU’s common foreign and security policies. It has shown the strong return of the Franco-German axis. Changes in transatlantic relations, the crisis of European integration, and the uncertainty brought about by new changes in the international structure have accelerated the restart of the axis. Although there is constant discord between France and Germany, the two sides will take into account the overall interests of the EU in the "fight without breaking" and keep up the slow operation of the axial engine.

title_en: Ten international events in 2000
A brief analysis of Putin's version of "pre-emption"
abstract_en: ＜On 8 September this year, Russia announced its intention to carry out "pre-emptive" strikes against terrorist bases around the world. This is a major strategic move by the Russian Government in response to the recent increase in terrorist activity in its territory, the results of which are bound to have a significant impact on the political situation in Russia and on the international counter-terrorism and security situation.

title_en: EEC Accelerated development of relations with countries in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union region
abstract_en: ＜Since the 1990s, the European Community has made rapid progress in strengthening and developing its economic, political and diplomatic relations with the countries of Eastern Europe and the region of the former Soviet Union in order to ultimately achieve the goal of a "Greater Europe". The dramatic changes in Eastern Europe, the disintegration of the Soviet Union and the ensuing collapse of the Economic and Social Council have created conditions for the EC to actively develop and closely cooperate with the countries of Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union. (i) The Community signed and began to implement trade co-operation and associated countries agreements (collectively known as the Europe Agreements) with the countries of Eastern Europe.

title_en: Geo-centres of gravity and fulcrums of world politics
abstract_en: 10 years ago the concept of geopolitics was formally introduced and a relatively systematic theory developed. Traditional geopolitical theories emphasise the relationship between the growth of state power and spatial expansion, and the confrontation between sea power and land power. With the end of the Cold War and the development of globalisation, although this theory, which underpins power politics, still has an impact on the strategic choices of some countries, its limitations in explaining the realities of international politics have become increasingly apparent. The article tries to analyse the real international relations from a new geopolitical perspective: the "geo-centre of gravity theory", stressing that the geo-centre of gravity countries are the engine of regional integration and the fulcrum of world politics. At the same time, it is believed that it is possible to analyse the current international conflicts in the geopolitical structure of international relations from the perspective of the geo-centre of gravity. The article advocates coordination and co-operation among the geo-centre of gravity countries on the basis of mutual respect, so as to construct a stable world order and maintain long-term peace and prosperity of mankind.

title_en: Exploring the issue of competition for world resources
abstract_en: Three years ago, Michael Klare, an American security expert, predicted in his book Resource Wars: A New Landscape of Global Conflict that future conflicts would centre mainly on dwindling precious resources, and that competition over oil, water, precious stones and timber would be the new driving force of war. Taking into account a series of developments in recent years, such as the energy factor behind the war in Iraq, the water dilemma in the Middle East and Central Asia, the emergence of the Caspian Sea dispute, the competition for oil pipelines between China and Japan, and so on, there seems to be a real tendency to intensify the competition for resources on a global scale. What is the actual situation? How should such competition be viewed? How should we respond to it? With these questions in mind, we invited six experts from the China Institute of Modern International Relations (CIMIR) to hold a dialogue. In view of the complexity of the issue itself, it is difficult to be comprehensive and profound in a single endeavour, so this dialogue is intended to be a preliminary attempt to throw light on the issue.

title_en: An Analysis of the Challenges Facing the United States in Afghanistan
abstract_en: After the terrorist attack, Bin Laden is once again regarded by the United States as the biggest suspect, and his hiding place in Afghanistan has also become a challenge that the United States has to face. After the end of the Cold War, the United States out of their own strategic considerations, actively intervene in the Afghan civil war, but also bring their own trouble, resulting in the United States faced with the challenge of Afghanistan more serious.

title_en: Mongolia's participation in regional economic cooperation and the development of relations with major Powers
abstract_en: Mongolia has always attached importance to and actively participated in regional economic cooperation in North-East Asia, which is not only of great significance for economic cooperation in the region, but also favourable to Mongolia's own economic development. As Mongolia needs to accumulate capital by exploiting its natural resources, which requires a large amount of capital and a long-term process of exploration and development, as well as large-scale infrastructure construction, it has adopted preferential policies to attract foreign capital on the premise of guaranteeing national interests and security. Economic and trade cooperation between Mongolia and China is developing steadily on the basis of the principle of equality and mutual benefit. China is the largest direct investor in Mongolia. Cooperation between Mongolia and China in the development of Mongolia's mineral resources will become the main theme of Mongolia-China economic and trade cooperation in the 21st century. Another very important component of economic cooperation between Mongolia and China today is the protection of the natural environment. In addition to the co-operation between Mongolia and China in the development of pastoralism, China can also invest in or establish joint ventures with Mongolia and China in the processing of meat, dairy and other livestock products. Mongolia and China also have broad prospects for co-operation in the field of plantation. Mongolia's economic cooperation with the Russian Federation was further strengthened with President Putin's November 2000 visit to Mongolia. Following the establishment of diplomatic relations between Mongolia and the United States, relations between the two countries have developed rapidly and economic cooperation has been strengthened. In recent years, economic cooperation between Mongolia and Japan has been developing rapidly. Japan is the largest provider of assistance and loans to Mongolia among all aid donors.

title_en: New features and trends in the international situation
abstract_en: New features and trends in the international situation BING Jinfu Fanghua In 1997, the international situation underwent profound and striking changes, and the overall international situation continued to evolve in the direction of détente against the background of peace and development. As they face the 21st century, the world's major countries have been adjusting their internal and external policies and strategic deployments. The United States attempted to realise the trend of multi-polarity in the world pattern with the unipolar world that it had commanded...

title_en: The security situation in Asia and the Pacific and visions for a security mechanism
abstract_en: Since the end of the Cold War, drastic changes have taken place in the Asia-Pacific security situation. In the comparatively stable situation of the Asia-Pacific region, however, some unstable factors still exist. Under such circumstances, various countries in the region are in a hurry to readjust their security strategies. In adapting themselves to the changes of Asia -Pacific security situation, countries in the region are deliberating successively to put forward various conceptions of security mechanism: The US advocates to hold"multilateral consultations"over Asia-Pacific security issues on the basis of maintaining bilateral alliance; Japan proposes to establish a CSCE-patterned Asia-Pacific security institute in the future; Russia holds to have a multilateral negotiation mechanism of the Northeast Asian area as the first step towards that of the Asia-Pacific region; the ASEAN countries stand for taking enlarged ASEAN foreign ministers’ conference as the framework of security mechanism of this region. Both the US and Japan now agree the issue of setting up an Asia 鈥?Pacific security mechanism should be discussed in the coming enlarged ASEAN foreign ministers’ conference. And some other Asian nations advance their respective ideas over the issue as well. Thus, the principles, contents and forms of the Asia-Pacific security cooperation are to be seriously approached by us.

title_en: Analysis of the "thaw" in Russian-Japanese relations and its prospects
abstract_en: Russia-Japan relations have witnessed progress especially when the two leaders met in April 2013 as a sign of thawing relations. Russia-Japan strategic conflicts are relatively reduced and more cooperative proposals have been aired due to great changes in Asia-Pacific situation. However,the future Russia-Japan relations will be influenced by a series of factors including the U. S. and the U. S.-Japan alliance,historical mistrust between Russia and Japan and Russia’s concern over Japan’s ambition of becoming a military power. Therefore,Russia-Japan relations face uncertain future.

title_en: Russia-US Relations: A Mutual Tug-of-War Under the Power Imbalance
abstract_en: Ever since the financial crisis,the full- fledged competition over comprehensive national power in the strategic fields of new energy revolution,new industrial revolution,new military revolution has been going on. The U. S. leads the world’s new military revolution,and the military capability gap between the U. S. and Russia is widening,thus creating a serious imbalance of strategic power. The imbalance of power and discrepancies in strategic goals give rise to their mistrust in security and strategic matters. The two countries also have huge differences in international strategy and the view of historical development. Therefore,suffering an increasing"cool- down",the"restart"of their relations can hardly maintain. Meanwhile,from the perspective of geopolitics,the two countries have fiercely competed with each other in the Post- Soviet area and the Middle East,while their serious contradictions on Russia’s domestic politics and human rights issues are obvious. However,due to the complexity of the global agenda and the support they need from each other,no serious conflicts will erupt between the U. S. and Russia,and a particular status of "cold peace"plus "cold cooperation"can be expected.

title_en: Ethnic issues in the security landscape of the Central Asian region
Monthly Events Review
Prospects for the crisis and reform of the international financial system
abstract_en: Abstract  The Asian Financial crisis has unveiled the rigidity of the world financial system. There are two most striking problems: a) abundant international risk capital which has rigged the financial market and disturbed the financial order could not be regulated under the current system; b) currency exchange rates influenced by speculation are skyrocketing one moment and plunge the next. The foreign exchange market turns from normal floating to abnormal spasm casting a great impact on manufacture, trade and finance and constituting the  danger of economic circles of rise and fall worldwide. Under the circumstance, reform of the outmoded world financial system must be put on the agenda. One of the central points of the reform strategy is how to appropriately deal with the relationship between government and market in transnational capital movement. On the other side of the shield, developed countries take advantage of their financial capacity and focus their interest on expanding capital-flow space. The conflicts over rules and procedures incurred from vying for interest and the leading financial role among these countries have actually got the reform nowhere. What’s more, the thoughts and interests of the developing countries could not be fully represented. Therefore, it will be very hard to work out a proposal that could be accepted by both the South and the North and the readjustment of the world financial system will last for a considerably long time.

title_en: New Developments in the China-Russia-India Triangular Relationship
abstract_en: Since 2001, positive developments have taken place in the triangular relations between China, Russia and India. The three countries are now deeply aware that the strengthening of triangular relations is conducive to the development of mutual economic, trade, scientific and technological and energy cooperation, to counteracting the trend towards unipolarity, and to safeguarding their own important interests through the "convergence effect", and the meeting of the foreign ministers of the three countries in Vladivostok, Russia, on 2 June 2005 changed the situation of "a shy rose blooming quietly", marking a new level of China-Russia-India triangular relations at the official level. The meeting of the foreign ministers of the three countries in Vladivostok on 2 June 2005 has changed the situation of the "quiet blossoming of roses" and marked a new level in the triangular relations between China, Russia and India at the official level, which means the launching of the trilateral substantive co-operation.

title_en: U.S. "Recession Theory" and the Construction of the Current International Order
abstract_en: ＜A newly released report by the World Bank has added to the buzz about the international order. According to a report released by the World Bank on 29 April 2014, China's GDP will overtake that of the United States in 2014 to become the world's top economy, according to GDP data based on purchasing power parity (PPP) of various countries. The Financial Times commented that China will take away the crown that the United States has held since 1872 this year, which has led to heated debate about whether China will replace the United States as the global hegemon. The Washington Times said that within a few months China will overtake the United States as the world's strongest economy.

title_en: China's Brilliant Success and the Evolution of Western Perceptions
abstract_en: The perfect conclusion of the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games further highlighted China's development achievements since its reform and opening up, signalling that China's national strength, power and fortune have entered a new upward trajectory, and that China's relationship with the world has once again become a hot topic in the international arena. What kind of changes will China's development and rise cause in the international pattern and system? In a changing world, especially when China's development itself constitutes an important part of the international situation, and when the "China threat theory" and "China responsibility theory" are constantly on the rise in the international arena, what kind of new tasks does China face, what kind of national strategy does it need to set up, and what kind of new strategic choices does it need to make? Should it be prepared for danger in times of peace and continue to bide its time and keep its head in the sand? These questions are not only seriously considered by the elites, but are also of great concern to the general public. In view of this, the Modern International Relations magazine held a seminar on 31 August 2008 under the title of "China's Relationship with the World in the Post-Olympic Era", inviting more than 20 experts and scholars in related fields from Beijing and Tianjin to have an in-depth discussion on the above issues. The main views of the seminar are summarised below for the benefit of the readers.

title_en: Status and prospects of the energy industry in the USSR
abstract_en: ＜The Soviet Union is the only industrially developed country in the world that is self-sufficient in energy. For a long time, the energy industry has been an important pillar of the national economy of the USSR, playing an important role in strengthening the economic and military power of the USSR, developing international trade and earning foreign exchange. Therefore, the successive leaders of the Soviet Union have attached great importance to the development of the energy industry, according to the conditions and changes in the situation, in different periods of time to formulate different energy development strategies and specific policies. Generally speaking, before the mid-1970s, the development of the energy industry in the USSR was relatively smooth, harmonious and balanced. However, in the past decade, especially after the 1980s, energy production has been experiencing a difficult situation in which the original favourable conditions have been lost and various unfavourable factors have increased significantly. In order to solve the increasingly urgent energy problems, the Basic Guidelines for the Long-Term Energy Programme of the USSR were formulated in March 1984, which provided a comprehensive plan for the energy development in the next 20 years. This article provides a preliminary analysis of the current situation and prospects for the development of the energy industry in the USSR.

title_en: Ten major international events in 1998
abstract_en: First, the Asian financial crisis has ravaged the world. This year, the Asian financial crisis has spread to the former Soviet Union and even Latin America in a "globalised" manner, and to a certain extent, it has affected Europe and the United States, causing turmoil in the global financial markets and a decline in economic growth. Japan's GDP growth rate has slipped to -2.5 per cent, Southeast Asian countries per capita GDP retrogression of more than 10 years, the Russian economy from 1997 growth of 1 per cent sharp...

abstract_en: The background and impact of the resurgence of the Russian Communist Party Jiang Li The Communist Party of the Russian Federation (CPRF) won 22.31 per cent of the vote in the elections for the new parliament (the State Duma) that ended in December 1995, more than double the number of votes it had received in the 1993 parliamentary elections, and jumped from being the third-largest to the first-largest party. title_en: Characteristics of the current international energy situation and prospects for change
abstract_en: The current international energy situation is in a new stage of change and adjustment, with increased uncertainty. On the one hand, tensions in the oil market have tended to ease, consumer countries are paying more attention to demand management and the development of new energy sources, and there has been greater progress in international energy security dialogue and cooperation. On the other hand, the balance between supply and demand in the market is still fragile, energy investment and environmental constraints have come to the fore, and the countries concerned have strengthened their control over resources and pursued energy diplomacy, which has made the energy and geopolitical relationship more complex and competition more intense.

title_en: Strategic Concept for Soviet Participation in Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation
abstract_en: ＜I. The economic take-off of the Asia-Pacific region, with a population of 3.3 billion, has caused concern and reflection in the Soviet Union, and its economy has been on the upswing since the post-war period: during the 20-year period 1960-1980, the economic growth rate in Europe was 4.5 per cent, while in Asia and the Pacific, it was 8 per cent, and at the beginning of the 1980s the average annual growth rate of the world economy was only 1.4 per cent, while the average annual growth rate in Asia and the Pacific remained at 4 per cent. In the early 1980s, the world economy grew at an average annual rate of 1.4 per cent, while Asia and the Pacific maintained an average annual growth rate of 4 per cent, and in 1989, Asia and the Pacific grew at an average annual rate of 6.1 per cent after adjusting for inflation, while the European Community and the United States grew at an average annual rate of 3.5 per cent and 2.9 per cent, respectively. This shows that Asia and the Pacific is the most dynamic region in the world today in terms of economic development. The Asia-Pacific region's foreign trade development and financial activity; in 1980, the Asia-Pacific trade accounted for 32.9 per cent of the total world trade, and in the 1990s it will account for half of the total world trade. The trade volume of the United States with Asia and the Pacific increased from $120 billion in 1980 to $271 billion in 1988, far exceeding the $186 billion to Western Europe. United States companies have invested more than $33 billion in Asia and the Pacific. Japan relies on the Asia-Pacific market for 55 per cent of its exports and 58 per cent of its imports. The "Four Little Ones" of Asia, ASEAN and China have also made the Asia-Pacific region their major trading partner.
